The physiological individual, characterized by definiteness and independence of function, in distinction from the morphological individual or morphon .
all the plant and animal life of a particular region.
A two-footed animal, as man.

A tree of several species, constituting the genus Betula ; as, the white or common birch ( Betula alba ) (also called silver birch and lady birch); the dwarf birch ( Betula glandulosa ); the paper or canoe birch ( Betula papyracea ); the yellow birch ( Betula lutea ); the black or cherry birch ( Betula lenta ).
Orig., a chicken; the young of a fowl; a young eaglet; a nestling; and hence, a feathered flying animal (see 2).
A birch tree.
To revolve or cause to revolve; to spin.
a pen with small metal ball as point of transfer of ink to paper; same as ballpoint pen .
To make, or move with, a whirring noise, as of wheels in motion.
A bristle or bristles.
A fish of the turbot kind; the brill.
The act or fact of coming into life, or of being born; -- generally applied to human beings; as, the birth of a son .
Twice; -- a word showing that something is, or is to be, repeated; as a passage of music, or an item in accounts.
A cold north wind which prevails on the northern coasts of the Mediterranean and in Switzerland, etc.; -- nearly the same as the mistral .
Same as Bikh .
To busy; to employ.
Soup or broth made by boiling several sorts of flesh together.
The aurochs or European bison.
The part of a bridle, usually of iron, which is inserted in the mouth of a horse, and having appendages to which the reins are fastened.
The female of the canine kind, as of the dog, wolf, and fox.
To seize something forcibly with the teeth; to wound with the teeth; to have the habit of so doing; as, does the dog bite ?
One who, or that which, bites; that which bites often, or is inclined to bite, as a dog or fish.
A small scrubby tree ( Balanites Ægyptiaca ) growing in dry regions of tropical Africa and Asia.
See Bitts .

A frame of two strong timbers fixed perpendicularly in the fore part of a ship, on which to fasten the cables as the ship rides at anchor, or in warping. Other bitts are used for belaying ( belaying bitts ), for sustaining the windlass ( carrick bitts , winch bitts , or windlass bitts ), to hold the pawls of the windlass ( pawl bitts ) etc.
a dry cold north wind in southeastern France.
The upper faceted portion of a brilliant-cut diamond, which projects from the setting and occupies the zone between the girdle and the table. See Brilliant , n.
the chemical symbol for berkelium .
To utter or tell unnecessarily, or in a thoughtless manner; to publish (secrets or trifles) without reserve or discretion; -- sometimes used with out .

Destitute of light, or incapable of reflecting it; of the color of soot or coal; of the darkest or a very dark color, the opposite of white ; characterized by such a color; as, black cloth; black hair or eyes .
To furnish with a blade.
Consisting of blades.
An inflammatory swelling or sore; a bulla, pustule, or blister.
An expression of disapprobation fir something deemed to be wrong; imputation of fault; censure.
A white cosmetic.
Any void space; a void space on paper, or in any written instrument; an interval void of consciousness, action, result, etc; a void.
To sound loudly and somewhat harshly.
A violent gust of wind.
To cry, as a calf or sheep; to bleat; to make a senseless noise; to talk inconsiderately.
to of sheep, goats, or calves.
A fish. See Bleak , n.
A stream of gas or vapor emitting light and heat in the process of combustion; a bright flame.
The part of a tree which lies immediately under the bark; the alburnum or sapwood.
Without color; pale; pallid.
Dim or sore with water or rheum; -- said of the eyes.
To make the noise of, or one like that of, a sheep; to cry like a sheep or calf.
A large vesicle or bulla, usually containing a serous fluid; a blister; a bubble, as in water, glass, etc.
To blacken; also, to defile.
imp. & p. p. of Bleed .
Complexion; color; hue; likeness; form.
To emit blood; to lose blood; to run with blood, by whatever means; as, the arm bleeds ; the wound bled freely; to bleed at the nose .
a short high-pitched tone produced as a signal or warning.
To mix or mingle together; esp. to mingle, combine, or associate so that the separate things mixed, or the line of demarcation, can not be distinguished. Hence: To confuse; to confound.
To blink; to shine; to look.
Mingled; mixed; blended; also, polluted; stained.
To make or pronounce holy; to consecrate
A form of decay in fruit which is overripe.
imp. of Blow .
any elderly pompous reactionary.
To stop; to cease; to desist.
Destitute of the sense of seeing, either by natural defect or by deprivation; without sight.

Russian pancakes of buckwheat flour and yeast, sometimes made from white flour; they are usually served folded over, with caviar and sour cream on the inside; -- properly, it is a plural word (from the Russian plural of blin ) but in America, often used as singular; thus the common plural blinis .
To shut out of sight; to avoid, or purposely evade; to shirk; as, to blink the question .
same as blini .
a spot of light on a radar screen, showing the position of a reflecting surface, such as an airplane or ship.
A gust of wind and rain.
Orig., blithesomeness; gladness; now, the highest degree of happiness; blessedness; exalted felicity; heavenly joy.
A genus of herbs ( Blitum ) with a fleshy calyx. Blitum capitatum is the strawberry blite .

a quick move by defensive players toward the passer on the offensive team, as soon as the ball is snapped; -- it is used when the defensive teams assumes that a pass will be attempted, and risks allowing substantial gains by the offensive team if other plays are in fact planned.
Quickly; forthwith.
To make turgid, as with water or air; to cause a swelling of the surface of, from effusion of serum in the cellular tissue, producing a morbid enlargement, often accompanied with softness.
Something blunt and round; a small drop or lump of something viscid or thick; a drop; a bubble; a blister.

To obstruct so as to prevent passage or progress; to prevent passage from, through, or into, by obstructing the way; -- used both of persons and things; -- often followed by up ; as, to block up a road or harbor; to block an entrance .
Of a fair color; light-colored; as, blond hair; a blond complexion .
The fluid which circulates in the principal vascular system of animals, carrying nourishment to all parts of the body, and bringing away waste products to be excreted. See under Arterial .
A blossom; the flower of a plant; an expanded bud; flowers, collectively.
The act of blowing; a roaring wind; a blast.
To take a blot; as, this paper blots easily .
To cure, as herrings, by salting and smoking them; to bloat.
To flower; to blossom; to bloom.
Swollen; inflated; distended; puffed up, as cattle when gorged with green food which develops gas.
Windy; as, blowy weather; a blowy upland .
To swell; to puff out, as with weeping.
Having the color of the clear sky, or a hue resembling it, whether lighter or darker; as, the deep, blue sea; as blue as a sapphire; blue violets .
a type of folk song that originated among Black Americans at the beginning of the 20th century; has a melancholoy sound from repeated used of blue notes.
A bushman's blanket; -- named from its color.
Having a broad, flattened front; as, the bluff bows of a ship .
Having a thick edge or point, as an instrument; dull; not sharp.

To render obscure by making the form or outline of confused and uncertain, as by soiling; to smear; to make indistinct and confused; as, to blur manuscript by handling it while damp; to blur the impression of a woodcut by an excess of ink .
To utter suddenly and unadvisedly; to divulge inconsiderately; to ejaculate; -- commonly with out .
To suffuse with a blush; to redden; to make roseate.
an abbreviation for bowel movement ; -- used as an informal euphemism, especially in hospitals.
any automobile manufactured by the German firm BMW AG (from the German Bayerische MotorWerke ); -- sometimes referred to colloquially as a beemer .
An exclamation used to startle or frighten.
A genus of large American serpents, including the boa constrictor, the emperor boa of Mexico ( Boa imperator ), and the chevalier boa of Peru ( Boa eques ).
The uncastrated male of swine; specifically, the wild hog.
A piece of timber sawed thin, and of considerable length and breadth as compared with the thickness, -- used for building, etc.

To vaunt one's self; to brag; to say or tell things which are intended to give others a high opinion of one's self or of things belonging to one's self; as, to boast of one's exploits courage, descent, wealth .
To transport in a boat; as, to boat goods .
Anything that hangs so as to play loosely, or with a short abrupt motion, as at the end of a string; a pendant; as, the bob at the end of a kite's tail .
The Poland marmot ( Arctomys bobac ).
A nickname for a British policeman; -- from Sir Robert Peel , who remodeled the police force. See Peeler .
A cylindrical glass vessel, with a large and short neck.
The round hole in the furnace of a glass manufactory through which the fused glass is taken out.
A European fish ( Box vulgaris ), having a compressed body and bright colors; -- called also box , and bogue .
To indicate by signs, as future events; to be the omen of; to portend to presage; to foreshow.
A botch; a patch.
A small Scotch coin worth about one sixth of an English penny.
To furnish with, or as with, a body; to produce in definite shape; to embody.
A colonist or farmer in South Africa of Dutch descent.
Behoves or behooves.
meat from an adult domestic bovine.
a hearty laugh.
highly successful; superbly well done.
To sink, as into a bog; to submerge in a bog; to cause to sink and stick, as in mud and mire.
A goblin; a bugbear.
Consisting of, or containing, a bog or bogs; of the nature of a bog; swampy; as, boggy land .
A four-wheeled truck, having a certain amount of play around a vertical axis, used to support in part a locomotive on a railway track.
A goblin; a specter; a frightful phantom; a bogy; a bugbear.
To fall off from the wind; to edge away to leeward; -- said only of inferior craft.
Spurious; fictitious; sham; -- a cant term originally applied to counterfeit coin, and hence denoting anything counterfeit.
A specter; a hobgoblin; a bugbear.
Bohea tea, an inferior kind of black tea. See under Tea .
See Boyar .

To be agitated, or tumultuously moved, as a liquid by the generation and rising of bubbles of steam (or vapor), or of currents produced by heating it to the boiling point; to be in a state of ebullition; as, the water boils .
To poke; to thrust.
Of or pertaining to bole or clay; partaking of the nature and qualities of bole; clayey.

A kind of missile weapon consisting of one, two, or more balls of stone, iron, or other material, attached to the ends of a leather cord; -- used by the Gauchos of South America, and others, for hurling at and entangling an animal.
Forward to meet danger; venturesome; daring; not timorous or shrinking from risk; brave; courageous.
A fragrant evergreen shrub of Chili ( Peumus Boldus ). The bark is used in tanning, the wood for making charcoal, the leaves in medicine, and the drupes are eaten.
The trunk or stem of a tree, or that which is like it.
Same as Booly .
A meteor or brilliant shooting star, followed by a train of light or sparks; esp. one which explodes.
The pod or capsule of a plant, as of flax or cotton; a pericarp of a globular form.
To swell; to puff.
A kind of large knife resembling a machete.
An exchange for the transaction of business.
A shaft or missile intended to be shot from a crossbow or catapult, esp. a short, stout, blunt-headed arrow; a quarrel; an arrow, or that which resembles an arrow; a dart.
An edible fish of the Nile (genus Chromis ).
A rounded mass of anything, esp. a large pill.
A large American serpent, so called from the sound it makes.
To bombard.
Good; valid as security for something.
A boy's game played with large marbles.
That which binds, ties, fastens, or confines, or by which anything is fastened or bound, as a cord, chain, etc.; a band; a ligament; a shackle or a manacle.
The hard, calcified tissue of the skeleton of vertebrate animals, consisting very largely of calcium carbonate, calcium phosphate, and gelatine; as, blood and bone .
Having (such) bones; -- used in composition; as, big- boned ; strong- boned .
an embarrassing mistake.

Either of two large antelopes ( Boöcercus eurycercus of West Africa, and Boöcercus isaaci of East Africa) of a reddish or chestnut-brown color with narrow white stripes on the body. Their flesh is especially esteemed as food.
A female servant charged with the care of a young child.
Handsome; beautiful; pretty; attractively lively and graceful.
A premium given for a loan, or for a charter or other privilege granted to a company; as the bank paid a bonus for its charter .
Consisting of bone, or of bones; full of bones; pertaining to bones.
A Buddhist or Fohist priest, monk, or nun.
to show displeasure (after a performance or speech) by making a prolonged sound of “boo”.
to commit a faux pas or fault.
Having the characteristics of a booby; stupid.
Same as Buddha .
A collection of sheets of paper, or similar material, blank, written, or printed, bound together; commonly, many folded and bound sheets containing continuous printing or writing.

A company of Irish herdsmen, or a single herdsman, wandering from place to place with flocks and herds, and living on their milk, like the Tartars; also, a place in the mountain pastures inclosed for the shelter of cattle or their keepers.
A long pole or spar, run out for the purpose of extending the bottom of a particular sail; as, the jib boom , the studding-sail boom , etc.
A prayer or petition.
Daniel Boone , a noted American frontiersman, 1734-1820.
A husbandman; a peasant; a rustic; esp. a clownish or unrefined countryman.
A stall or a crib for an ox, cow, or other animal.
To lift or push from behind (one who is endeavoring to climb); to push up; hence, to assist in overcoming obstacles, or in making advancement.
Remedy; relief; amends; reparation; hence, one who brings relief.
A house or shed built of boards, boughs, or other slight materials, for temporary occupation.
A servant at a hotel or elsewhere, who cleans and blacks the boots and shoes.
That which is seized by violence or obtained by robbery, especially collective spoil taken in war; plunder; pillage.
To drink greedily or immoderately, esp. alcoholic liquor; to tipple.
A little intoxicated; fuddled; stupid with liquor; bousy.
an early form of modern jazz (originating around 1940).

A white or gray crystalline salt, with a slight alkaline taste, used as a flux, in soldering metals, making enamels, fixing colors on porcelain, and as a soap. It occurs native in certain mineral springs, and is made from the boric acid of hot springs in Tuscany. It was originally obtained from a lake in Thibet, and was sent to Europe under the name of tincal . Borax is a pyroborate or tetraborate of sodium, Na2B4O7.10H2O.
A board; a table.
To perforate or penetrate, as a solid body, by turning an auger, gimlet, drill, or other instrument; to make a round hole in or through; to pierce; as, to bore a plank .
tired of the world; bored with life.
Same as Bourrée .
See Borrel .
One that bores; an instrument for boring.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, boron.
Brought forth, as an animal; brought into life; introduced by birth.
Carried; conveyed; supported; defrayed. See Bear , v. t.

A nonmetallic element occurring abundantly in borax. It is reduced with difficulty to the free state, when it can be obtained in several different forms; viz., as a substance of a deep olive color, in a semimetallic form, and in colorless quadratic crystals similar to the diamond in hardness and other properties. It occurs in nature also in boracite, datolite, tourmaline, and some other minerals. Atomic number 5. Atomic weight 10.81. Symbol B .
a Russian soup usually containing beet juice as a foundation, and often served with sour cream. Also, as used in the U.S., a sour cabbage soup, called in Russian shchi .
Imperfectly crystallized or coarse diamonds, or fragments made in cutting good diamonds which are reduced to powder and used in lapidary work.
Pledge; borrow.
A genus of ruminant quadrupeds, including the wild and domestic cattle, distinguished by a stout body, hollow horns, and a large fold of skin hanging from the neck.
A drink, used in the East. See Boza .
A greenish-yellow variety of pear.
Figure; outline; show.
A thicket; a small wood.
Woody or bushy; covered with boscage or thickets.
The breast of a human being; the part, between the arms, to which anything is pressed when embraced by them.

A fundamental particle that obeys Bose-Einstein statistical rules, but not the Pauli exclusion principle; the spin value of a boson is always an integer. Examples of bosons are alpha particles, photons, and those nuclei which have an even mass number.
Any protuberant part; a round, swelling part or body; a knoblike process; as, a boss of wood .
Ornamented with bosses; studded.
a petty officer on a merchant ship who controls the work of other seamen; a contraction of boatswain .
A swelling on the skin; a large ulcerous affection; a boil; an eruptive disease.
Compensation; amends; satisfaction; expiation; as, man bote , a compensation or a man slain .
The one and the other; the two; the pair, without exception of either.
A wooden hut or humble cot, esp. a rude hut or barrack for unmarried farm servants; a shepherd's or hunter's hut; a booth.
The larvæ of several species of botfly, especially those larvæ which infest the stomach, throat, or intestines of the horse, and are supposed to be the cause of various ailments.
A weevil; a worm that breeds in malt, biscuit, etc.
To stave in; to bilge.
A curved handle.
Same as Buhl , Buhlwork .
Corrupted form Bolt .
Ready; prepared; destined; tending.
The external or limiting line, either real or imaginary, of any object or space; that which limits or restrains, or within which something is limited or restrained; limit; confine; extent; boundary.
A chamber or a cottage.
A mullet ( Mugil capito ) found in the rivers of Southern Europe and in Africa.
A stream or rivulet; a burn.
To drink immoderately; to carouse; to booze. See Booze .
Drunken; sotted; boozy.
Relating to that tribe of ruminant mammals of which the genus Bos is the type.
To bend; to curve.
bent over; -- used of back or head.
To take out the bowels of; to eviscerate; to disembowel.
One of the two highest cards in the pack commonly used in the game of euchre.
To swell out. See Bouge .
To roll, as a bowl or cricket ball.
See Bowl , a ball, a game.
To make ready; to prepare; to dress.
A carouse; a drinking bout; a booze.

A tree or shrub, flourishing in different parts of the world. The common box ( Buxus sempervirens ) has two varieties, one of which, the dwarf box ( Buxus suffruticosa ), is much used for borders in gardens. The wood of the tree varieties, being very hard and smooth, is extensively used in the arts, as by turners, engravers, mathematical instrument makers, etc.
enclosed in or set off by a border or box; as, boxed sections of the report; boxed announcements in the newspaper .
Made of boxwood; pertaining to, or resembling, the box ( Buxus ).
One who packs boxes.
A male child, from birth to the age of puberty; a lad; hence, a son.
A member of a Russian aristocratic order abolished by Peter the Great. Also, one of a privileged class in Roumania.
A winding or zigzag trench forming a path or communication from one siegework to another, to a magazine, etc.
A Flemish sloop with a castle at each end.
a battle in the War of the Grand Alliance in Ireland in 1690, where William III of England defeated the deposed James II and so ended Stuart Catholicism in England.
An acidulated fermented drink of the Arabs and Egyptians, made from millet seed and various astringent substances; also, an intoxicating beverage made from hemp seed, darnel meal, and water.
same as brassiere .
That which holds anything tightly or supports it firmly; a bandage or a prop.
A bitch of the hound kind.
An opening caused by the parting of any solid body; a crack or breach; a flaw.
A leaf, usually smaller than the true leaves of a plant, from the axil of which a flower stalk arises.

A thin nail, usually small, with a slight projection at the top on one side instead of a head; also, a small wire nail, with a flat circular head; sometimes, a small, tapering, square-bodied finishing nail, with a countersunk head.
A hillside; a slope; a bank; a hill.

To talk about one's self, or things pertaining to one's self, in a manner intended to excite admiration, envy, or wonder; to talk boastfully; to boast; -- often followed by of ; as, to brag of one's exploits, courage, or money, or of the great things one intends to do .
the Norse god of poetry and music; a son of Odin.
the Norse god of poetry and music; a son of Odin.
A plait, band, or narrow fabric formed by intertwining or weaving together different strands.
To haul up by the brails; -- used with up ; as, to brail up a sail .
A rough diamond.
imp. of Break .
Full of brakes; abounding with brambles, shrubs, or ferns; rough; thorny.
See Brahma .
Sharp passion; vexation.
The broken coat of the seed of wheat, rye, or other cereal grain, separated from the flour or meal by sifting or bolting; the coarse, chaffy part of ground grain.
A burning piece of wood; or a stick or piece of wood partly burnt, whether burning or after the fire is extinct.
A sort of bridle with wooden side pieces.
A species of wild goose ( Branta bernicla ) -- called also brent and brand goose . The name is also applied to other related species.
Hasty in temper; impetuous.
An alloy (usually yellow) of copper and zinc, in variable proportion, but often containing two parts of copper to one part of zinc. It sometimes contains tin, and rarely other metals.
A coarse garment or cloak; also, coarse clothing, in general.
A brave person; one who is daring.
A daring villain; a bandit; one who sets law at defiance; a professional assassin or murderer.
Well-dressed; handsome; smart; brave; -- used of persons or their clothing, etc.; as, a braw lad .
To quarrel noisily and outrageously.
A muscle; flesh.
A disease of sheep. The term is variously applied in different localities.
To pound, beat, rub, or grind small or fine.
To solder with hard solder, esp. with an alloy of copper and zinc; as, to braze the seams of a copper pipe .
An article of food made from flour or meal by moistening, kneading, and baking.
To strain apart; to sever by fracture; to divide with violence; as, to break a rope or chain; to break a seal; to break an axle; to break rocks or coal; to break a lock .
To clean, as a ship's bottom of adherent shells, seaweed, etc., by the application of fire and scraping.
imp. & p. p. of Breed .
To produce as offspring; to bring forth; to bear; to procreate; to generate; to beget; to hatch.
Fierce; sharp; severe; cruel.
Steep; high.
for Bursteth .
Same as Britzska .

A note or character of time, equivalent to two semibreves or four minims. When dotted, it is equal to three semibreves. It was formerly of a square figure (as thus: &unr_; ), but is now made oval, with a line perpendicular to the staff on each of its sides; -- formerly much used for choir service.
To boil or seethe; to cook.
Same as Brier .
A gift begged; a present.
A block or clay tempered with water, sand, etc., molded into a regular form, usually rectangular, and sun-dried, or burnt in a kiln, or in a heap or stack called a clamp.
A woman newly married, or about to be married.
same as Brie cheese .
Short in duration.
A plant with a slender woody stem bearing stout prickles; especially, species of Rosa , Rubus , and Smilax .
A two-masted, square-rigged vessel.
A breach; ruin; downfall; peril.
A fish allied to the turbot ( Rhombus levis ), much esteemed in England for food; -- called also bret , pearl , prill . See Bret .
The rim, border, or upper edge of a cup, dish, or any hollow vessel used for holding anything.
One of the radiating sticks of a fan. The outermost are larger and longer, and are called panaches .

Water saturated or strongly impregnated with salt; pickle; hence, any strong saline solution; also, the saline residue or strong mother liquor resulting from the evaporation of natural or artificial waters.
To convey to the place where the speaker is or is to be; to bear from a more distant to a nearer place; to fetch.
The edge, margin, or border of a steep place, as of a precipice; a bank or edge, as of a river or pit; a verge; a border; as, the brink of a chasm . Also Fig.
Of or pertaining to brine, or to the sea; partaking of the nature of brine; salt; as, a briny taste; the briny flood .
the Jewish rite of circumcision.
Full of liveliness and activity; characterized by quickness of motion or action; lively; spirited; quick.
The young of the common herring; also, a small species of herring; the sprat.
To be or become overripe, as wheat, barley, or hops.
the Jewish rite of circumcision.
the people of Great Britain.
the young of a herring or sprat or similar fish.
The breeze fly. See Breeze .
Wide; extend in breadth, or from side to side; -- opposed to narrow ; as, a broad street, a broad table; an inch broad .
A peculiar brad-shaped spike, to be driven alongside the end of an abutting timber to prevent its slipping.
A pointed instrument, as a joiner's awl, a brad awl, a needle, or a small sharp stick.
A tumult; a noisy quarrel; a disturbance; a brawl; contention; discord, either between individuals or in the state.
To transact business for another.
Aliment; food.
See Bromine .
an unbroken or imperfectly broken mustang.
The young birds hatched at one time; a hatch; as, a brood of chickens .
A natural stream of water smaller than a river or creek.

A plant having twigs suitable for making brooms to sweep with when bound together; esp., the Cytisus scoparius of Western Europe, which is a low shrub with long, straight, green, angular branches, minute leaves, and large yellow flowers.

Pottage made by pouring some boiling liquid on meal (esp. oatmeal), and stirring it. It is called beef brose , water brose , etc., according to the name of the liquid (beef broth, hot water, etc.) used.
Liquid in which flesh (and sometimes other substances, as barley or rice) has been boiled; thin or simple soup.
The prominent ridge over the eye, with the hair that covers it, forming an arch above the orbit.
Of a dark color, of various shades between black and red or yellow.
The rhesus monkey. See Rhesus .
A bear; -- so called in popular tales and fables.
Report; rumor; fame.
Mist; fog; vapors.
Same as Brun , a brook.
The heat, or utmost violence, of an onset; the strength or greatest fury of any contention; as, the brunt of a battle .

An instrument composed of bristles, or other like material, set in a suitable back or handle, as of wood, bone, or ivory, and used for various purposes, as in removing dust from clothes, laying on colors, etc. Brushes have different shapes and names according to their use; as, clothes brush , paint brush , tooth brush , etc.
Same as Brusque .
very dry; -- used of wine or champagne.
See Edentata .
Not having sensation; senseless; inanimate; unconscious; without intelligence or volition; as, the brute earth; the brute powers of nature .
A lantern; also, the moon.
Strong malt liquor.
A woman's breast.
An inflammation, with enlargement, of a lymphatic gland, esp. in the groin, as in syphilis.

A South African shrub ( Barosma ) with small leaves that are dotted with oil glands; also, the leaves themselves, which are used in medicine for diseases of the urinary organs, etc. Several species furnish the leaves.
Lye or suds in which cloth is soaked in the operation of bleaching, or in which clothes are washed.
A small protuberance on the stem or branches of a plant, containing the rudiments of future leaves, flowers, or stems; an undeveloped branch or flower.
To move off; to stir; to walk away.
Consisting of fur.
A sort of leather, prepared from the skin of the buffalo, dressed with oil, like chamois; also, the skins of oxen, elks, and other animals, dressed in like manner.
The comic actress in an opera.
The comic actor in an opera.
Resembling, or characterized by, buff.
A genus of Amphibia including various species of toads.
A bugbear; anything which terrifies.
Infested or abounding with bugs.
A sort of wild ox; a buffalo.
Decorative woodwork in which tortoise shell, yellow metal, white metal, etc., are inlaid, forming scrolls, cartouches, etc.
To erect or construct, as an edifice or fabric of any kind; to form by uniting materials into a regular structure; to fabricate; to make; to raise.
Shape; build; form of structure; as, the built of a ship .
An East Indian insectivorous mammal ( Gymnura Rafflesii ), somewhat like a rat in appearance, but allied to the hedgehog.

A spheroidal body growing from a plant either above or below the ground (usually below), which is strictly a bud , consisting of a cluster of partially developed leaves, and producing, as it grows, a stem above, and roots below, as in the onion, tulip, etc. It differs from a corm in not being solid.
The bilge or protuberant part of a cask.
Bulged; bulging; bending, or tending to bend, outward.
Magnitude of material substance; dimensions; mass; size; as, an ox or ship of great bulk .
Of great bulk or dimensions; of great size; large; thick; massive; as, bulky volumes .
The male of any species of cattle ( Bovidæ ); hence, the male of any large quadruped, as the elephant; also, the male of the whale.
A bleb; a vesicle, or an elevation of the cuticle, containing a transparent watery fluid.
A noisy, blustering fellow, more insolent than courageous, who threatens, intimidates, or badgers people who are smaller or weaker than he is; an insolent, tyrannical fellow.
A purse or bag in which to carry or measure diamonds, etc.
Same as Bolty .
The buttock.
To strike, as with or against anything large or solid; to thump; as, to bump the head against a wall .
any of a variety of slightly sweetened or plain raised cakes or bisquits, often having a glazing of sugar and milk on the top crust; as, a hot cross bun .
a synthetic rubber made by copolymerizing butadiene with another substance such as acrylonitrile or styrene.
a sudden unexpected piece of good fortune.
A protuberance; a hunch; a knob or lump; a hump.
see bunko .
League; confederacy; esp. the confederation of German states.
The large stopper of the orifice in the bilge of a cask.
A kind of canoe used in Central and South America; also, a kind of boat used in the Southern United States.
A wooden case or box, which serves for a seat in the daytime and for a bed at night.
A kind of swindling game or scheme, originally by means of cards or by a sham lottery, but now used for any swindling tactic.
A great collection of ore without any vein coming into it or going out from it.
the buttocks .
A fungus ( Ustilago fœtida ) which affects the ear of cereals, filling the grains with a fetid dust; -- also called pepperbrand .
A float; esp. a floating object moored to the bottom, to mark a channel or to point out the position of something beneath the water, as an anchor, shoal, rock, etc.

Any rough or prickly envelope of the seeds of plants, whether a pericarp, a persistent calyx, or an involucre, as of the chestnut and burdock; a seed vessel having hooks or prickles. Also, any weed which bears burs.
Same as Borrel .
A fortified town.
A borough or incorporated town, especially, one in Scotland. See Borough .

The cutting tool of an engraver on metal, used in line engraving. It is made of tempered steel, one end being ground off obliquely so as to produce a sharp point, and the other end inserted in a handle; a graver; also, the similarly shaped tool used by workers in marble.
To murder by suffocation, or so as to produce few marks of violence, for the purpose of obtaining a body to be sold for dissection.
To dress or finish up (cloth); to pick knots, burs, loose threads, etc., from, as in finishing cloth.

Having a large, strong, or gross body; stout; lusty; -- now used chiefly of human beings, but formerly of animals, in the sense of stately or beautiful, and of inanimate things that were huge and bulky.
To consume with fire; to reduce to ashes by the action of heat or fire; -- frequently intensified by up : as, to burn up wood .
Consumed with, or as with, fire; scorched or dried, as with fire or heat; baked or hardened in the fire or the sun.
to same as belch ; as, In China it is polite to burp at the table .
A prickly seed vessel. See Bur , 1.
Abounding in burs, or containing burs; resembling burs; as, burry wool .
Any sac or saclike cavity; especially, one of the synovial sacs, or small spaces, often lined with synovial membrane, interposed between tendons and bony prominences.
A purse; also, a vesicle; a pod; a hull.

To fly apart or in pieces; of break open; to yield to force or pressure, especially to a sudden and violent exertion of force, or to pressure from within; to explode; as, the boiler had burst ; the buds will burst in spring .
A borough; a manor; as, the Bury of St. Edmond's
An omnibus.
A military headdress or cap, used in the British army. It is of fur, with a bag, of the same color as the facings of the regiment, hanging from the top over the right shoulder.
A thicket, or place abounding in trees or shrubs; a wild forest.
Thick and spreading, like a bush.
A thin, elastic strip of metal, whalebone, wood, or other material, worn in the front of a corset.
See Bosky , and 1st Bush , n.
A kiss; a rude or playful kiss; a smack.
A piece of sculpture representing the upper part of the human figure, including the head, shoulders, and breast.
A bust; a statue.
Engaged in some business; hard at work (either habitually or only for the time being); occupied with serious affairs; not idle nor at leisure; as, a busy merchant .
Except with; unless with; without.
markedly masculine in appearance or manner; -- used of men.
a genus of East Indian trees or shrubs: dhak.
a genus of broad-winged soaring hawks.
A limit; a bound; a goal; the extreme bound; the end.
A detached low mountain, or high rising abruptly from the general level of the surrounding plain; -- applied to peculiar elevations in the Rocky Mountain region.
One who mines by contract, at so much per ton of coal or ore.
A compound radical, regarded as butane, less one atom of hydrogen.
Yielding; pliable or compliant; ready to obey; obedient; tractable; docile; meek; humble.
the type genus of the Buxaceae .
To acquire the ownership of (property) by giving an accepted price or consideration therefor, or by agreeing to do so; to acquire by the payment of a price or value; to purchase; -- opposed to sell .
One who buys; a purchaser.
To make a low, continuous, humming or sibilant sound, like that made by bees with their wings. Hence: To utter a murmuring sound; to speak with a low, humming voice.
biological warfare; the use of bacteria or viruses or toxins to destroy men and animals or food.
a boiling water reactor; a type of nuclear reactor that uses water as a coolant and moderator; -- the steam produced can drive a steam turbine and produce electrical power.
In the neighborhood of; near or next to; not far from; close to; along with; as, come and sit by me .
A piece of leather crossing the breast, used by the men who drag sledges in coal mines.
A thing not directly aimed at; something which is a secondary object of regard; an object by the way, etc.; as in on or upon the bye , i. e. , in passing; indirectly; by implication.
A cow house.
See Byssus , n. , 1.
A secluded, private, or obscure way; a path or road aside from the main one.
the chemical symbol for calcium , the fifth most abundant element in the earth's crust, having an atomic number of 20.
The small and nearly cubical stone building, toward which all Muslims must pray.
A kind of close carriage with two or four wheels, usually a public vehicle.
Tradition; occult doctrine. See Cabala .
A flat basket or frail for figs, etc.; hence, a lady's flat workbasket, reticule, or hand bag; -- often written caba .
A pole or beam, esp. one used in Gaelic games for tossing as a trial of strength.
A cottage or small house; a hut.
A large, strong rope or chain, of considerable length, used to retain a vessel at anchor, and for other purposes. It is made of hemp, of steel wire, or of iron links.
A small piece of mutton or other meat roasted on a skewer; -- so called in Turkey and Persia.

A small evergreen tree ( Theobroma Cacao ) of South America and the West Indies. Its fruit contains an edible pulp, inclosing seeds about the size of an almond, from which cocoa, chocolate, and broma are prepared.
A hole in the ground, or other hiding place, for concealing and preserving provisions which it is inconvenient to carry.
To ease the body by stool; to go to stool.
A person who stands at the door of an omnibus to open and shut it, and to receive fares; an idle hanger-on about innyards.
A small box, can, or chest to keep tea in, also called tea caddy .
Bred by hand; domesticated; petted.
See Cadre .
A caddice. See Caddice .
A circular frame on which cadgers carry hawks for sale.
Cheerful or mirthful, as after good eating or drinking; also, wanton.
An inferior magistrate or judge among the Muslims, usually the judge of a town or village.
A Scotch errand boy, porter, or messenger.
A kind of coarse serge.
The framework or skeleton upon which a regiment is to be formed; the officers of a regiment forming the staff.
See Cadie .
To confine in, or as in, a cage; to shut up or confine.
Confined in, or as in, a cage; like a cage or prison.
A kind of parrot, of a beautiful green color, found in the Philippine Islands.
One of a race inhabiting the valleys of the Pyrenees, who until 1793 were political and social outcasts (Christian Pariahs). They are supposed to be a remnant of the Visigoths.
A traveling tinker; also a tramp or sturdy beggar.
A rounded or conical heap of stones erected by early inhabitants of the British Isles, apparently as a sepulchral monument.
The capital city of Egypt . It is the largest city in Africa. Population (2000) = 7,010,000.
In Louisiana, a person reputed to be Acadian French descent. Also used attributively, as in Cajun cooking.
To form into a cake, or mass.
Wolfram, an ore of tungsten.
The young of the cow, or of the Bovine family of quadrupeds. Also, the young of some other mammals, as of the elephant, rhinoceros, hippopotamus, and whale.
The tenth avatar or incarnation of the god Vishnu.
Hot; burning; ardent.
Same as Caliph , Caliphate , etc.
An alloy of lead and tin, of which the Chinese make tea canisters.
A cup. See Calyx .
To drive tarred oakum into the seams between the planks of (a ship, boat, etc.), to prevent leaking. The calking is completed by smearing the seams with melted pitch.
To command or request to come or be present; to summon; as, to call a servant .
A genus of plants, of the order Araceæ .
A kind of head covering; a caul.
Freedom from motion, agitation, or disturbance; a cessation or absence of that which causes motion or disturbance, as of winds or waves; tranquility; stillness; quiet; serenity.
Tranquil; peaceful; calm.
the Rock of Gibraltar, a limestone promontory at the southern tip of Spain; associated with Britain.
To bring forth a calf.
The covering of a flower. See Flower .

A turning or sliding piece which, by the shape of its periphery or face, or a groove in its surface, imparts variable or intermittent motion to, or receives such motion from, a rod, lever, or block brought into sliding or rolling contact with it.
same as camass .
imp. of Come .

A large ruminant used in Asia and Africa for carrying burdens and for riding. The camel is remarkable for its ability to go a long time without drinking. Its hoofs are small, and situated at the extremities of the toes, and the weight of the animal rests on the callous. The dromedary ( Camelus dromedarius ) has one hump on the back, while the Bactrian camel ( Camelus Bactrianus ) has two. The llama, alpaca, and vicuña, of South America, belong to a related genus ( Auchenia ).
A carving in relief, esp. one on a small scale used as a jewel for personal adornment, or like.
A light, loose dress or robe.
The ground or spot on which tents, huts, etc., are erected for shelter, as for an army or for lumbermen, etc.
See Camis .
an obs. form of began , imp. & p. p. of Begin , sometimes used in old poetry. [See Gan .]
Fluor spar. See Kand .
To conserve or boil in sugar; as, to candy fruits; to candy ginger .
To beat with a cane.
Filled with white flakes; mothery; -- said vinegar when containing mother.
any doglike animal of the family canidae .
A genus of carnivorous mammals, of the family Canidæ , including the dogs and wolves.
A measure of length in Italy, varying from six to seven feet. See Cane , 4.
Artful; cunning; shrewd; wary.
A boat used by rude nations, formed of trunk of a tree, excavated, by cutting of burning, into a suitable shape. It is propelled by a paddle or paddles, or sometimes by sail, and has no rudder.
A law or rule.
A corner; angle; niche.
One of the chief divisions of a long poem; a book.
Cheerful; sprightly; lively; merry.
Of or pertaining to cane or canes; abounding with canes.
A covering for the head
A piece or point of land, extending beyond the adjacent coast into the sea or a lake; a promontory; a headland.
A horse; a nag.
To leap or jump about in a sprightly manner; to cut capers; to skip; to spring; to prance; to dance.
See Capel .
A sort of cotton so short and fine that it can not be spun, used in the East Indies to line palanquins, to make mattresses, etc.
A castrated cock, esp. when fattened; a male chicken gelded to improve his flesh for the table.
A winning of all the tricks at the game of piquet. It counts for forty points.
A genus of ruminants, including the common goat.
Wine produced on the island of Capri, commonly a light, dry, white wine.
The head; also, a knoblike protuberance or capitulum.
A small vehicle moved on wheels; usually, one having but two wheels and drawn by one horse; a cart.
See Carack .
The weight by which precious stones and pearls are weighed.
A piece of pasteboard, or thick paper, blank or prepared for various uses; as, a playing card ; a visiting card ; a card of invitation ; pl. a game played with cards.
The basal joint of the maxilla in insects.
A burdensome sense of responsibility; trouble caused by onerous duties; anxiety; concern; solicitude.
A mark [^] used by writers and proof readers to indicate that something is interlined above, or inserted in the margin, which belongs in the place marked by the caret.
A numerous and widely distributed genus of perennial herbaceous plants of the order Cypreaceæ ; the sedges.
pret. of Carve .
The lading or freight of a ship or other vessel; the goods, merchandise, or whatever is conveyed in a vessel or boat; load; freight.

A native of the Caribbee islands or the coasts of the Caribbean sea; esp., one of a tribe of Indians inhabiting a region of South America, north of the Amazon, and formerly most of the West India islands.
A noxious or corroding care; solicitude; worry.
A rude, rustic man; a churl.
An evergreen leguminous tree ( Ceratania Siliqua ) found in the countries bordering the Mediterranean; the St. John's bread; -- called also carob tree .
A round dance.
A shot in which the ball struck with the cue comes in contact with two or more balls on the table; a hitting of two or more balls with the player's ball. In England it is called cannon .
To talk; to speak; to prattle.
To convey or transport in any manner from one place to another; to bear; -- often with away or off .
Low, fertile land; a river valley.
A common name for various kinds of vehicles, as a Scythian dwelling on wheels, or a chariot.
Bill of fare.
Coma with complete insensibility; deep lethargy.
To exercise the trade of a sculptor or carver; to engrave or cut figures.
A house or mansion.
Of or pertaining to case; as, a casal ending .
To cover or protect with, or as with, a case; to inclose.
covered or protected with or as if with a case; as, knights cased in steel .
A place where money is kept, or where it is deposited and paid out; a money box.
Same as Casque .
To render useless or void; to quash; to annul; to reject; to send away.
To send or drive by force; to throw; to fling; to hurl; to impel.
One of the hereditary classes into which the Hindu are divided according to the laws of Brahmanism.
An event; an occurrence; an occasion; a combination of circumstances; a case; an act of God. See the Note under Accident .

Any animal belonging to the natural family Felidae , and in particular to the various species of the genera Felis , Panthera , and Lynx . The domestic cat is Felis domestica . The European wild cat ( Felis catus ) is much larger than the domestic cat. In the United States the name wild cat is commonly applied to the bay lynx ( Lynx rufus ). The larger felines, such as the lion, tiger, leopard, and cougar, are often referred to as cats , and sometimes as big cats . See Wild cat , and Tiger cat .

The Latin and English form of a Greek preposition, used as a prefix to signify down , downward , under , against , contrary or opposed to , wholly , completely ; as in cata clysm, cata rrh. It sometimes drops the final vowel, as in cato ptric; and is sometimes changed to cath , as in cath artic, cath olic.
To attain possession.
Property; -- often used by Chaucer in contrast with rent , or income .
A provider; a purveyor; a caterer.
Provisions; food; viands; especially, luxurious food; delicacies; dainties.
A base fellow; a rogue; a cheat.
An East Indian Weight of 1 1/3 pounds.
A chest with holes for keeping fish alive in water.
See Cawk , Calker .
A covering of network for the head, worn by women; also, a net.
See Calk , v. .
Great heat, as of the body in fever.
That which produces or effects a result; that from which anything proceeds, and without which it would not exist.
A hollow place in the earth, either natural or artificial; a subterraneous cavity; a cavern; a den.
To raise captious and frivolous objections; to find fault without good reason.
A hollow way, adapted to cover troops, and facilitate their aproach to a place.
A rodent of the genera Cavia and Dolichotis , as the guinea pig ( Cavia cobaya ). Cavies are natives of South America.
To cry like a crow, rook, or raven.
An opaque, compact variety of barite, or heavy spar.
Of or pertaining to cawk; like cawk.
A kind of wig.
See Key , a ledge.
A small island or ledge of rock in the water; a key.

same as citizens' band ; that portion of the radio frequency spectrum allocated by the FCC for the use of individual citizens for short-distance personal or business use, from either fixed or mobile stations. Also used attributively, as CB radio .
the complete blood count; a clinical test which counts the number of white and red blood cells and the number of platelets in one cubic milimeter of blood.
the chemical suymbol for cadmium , a metallic element of atomic number 48.
the chemical symbol for cerium , the most abundant element of the rare-earth group.
To come to an end; to stop; to leave off or give over; to desist; as, the noise ceased .
one of the Visayan islands of the central Philippines, important for its fine harbor.
the type genus of the Cebidae .
of, pertaining to, or like a cecum.
The caecum , the cavity in which the large intestine begins and into which the ileum opens.
The name of several evergreen trees. The wood is remarkable for its durability and fragrant odor.
To yield or surrender; to give up; to resign; as, to cede a fortress, a province, or country, to another nation, by treaty .
Of the nature of cedar.
a genus of tropical American trees with palmately compound leaves and showy bell-like flowers.
a small South American spiny tree ( Erythrina crista-galli ) with dark crimson and scarlet flowers solitary or clustered.
To overlay or cover the inner side of the roof of; to furnish with a ceiling; as, to ceil a room .
A very small and close apartment, as in a prison or in a monastery or convent; the hut of a hermit.
The part inclosed within the walls of an ancient temple, as distinguished from the open porticoes.
A contraction for Violoncello .

One of an ancient race of people, who formerly inhabited a great part of Central and Western Europe, and whose descendants at the present day occupy Ireland, Wales, the Highlands of Scotland, and the northern shores of France.
A census; -- also, a public rate or tax.
A hundred; as, ten per cent , the proportion of ten parts in a hundred .
A literary or a musical composition formed by selections from different authors disposed in a new order.
A freeman of the lowest class; one not a thane or of the servile classes; a churl.
a conditioned emotional response , an emotional response that has been acquired by conditioning.
one of the often brightly colored and branching hornlike structures on the backs of nudibranchs and other related mollusks that serve as gills.
The soft naked sheath at the base of the beak of birds of prey, parrots, and some other birds. See Beak .
The daughter of Saturn and Ops or Rhea, the goddess of corn and tillage.
Cerium oxide, CeO2 , a white infusible substance constituting about one per cent of the material of the common incandescent mantle.
A waxy substance extracted by alcohol or ether from cork; sometimes applied also to the portion of beeswax which is soluble in alcohol.

A large and valuable fish of the Mackerel family, of the genus Scomberomorus . Two species are found in the West Indies and less commonly on the Atlantic coast of the United States, -- the common cero ( Scomberomorus caballa ), called also kingfish , and spotted, or king, cero ( Scomberomorus regalis ).
A radical, C27H55 supposed to exist in several compounds obtained from Chinese wax, beeswax, etc.
A rate or tax.
A woman's girdle; a cestus.
One of the Cetacea, or collectively, the Cetacea.
Of or pertaining to a whale.
A white, waxy substance, forming the essential part of spermaceti.
A radical, C16H33 , not yet isolated, but supposed to exist in a series of compounds homologous with the ethyl compounds, and derived from spermaceti.

An abbreviation for Centimeter , Gram , Second . -- applied to a system of units much employed in physical science, based upon the centimeter as the unit of length, the gram as the unit of weight or mass, and the second as the unit of time.
An abbreviation for Confédération Générale du Travail (the French syndicalist labor union).
Tea; -- the Chinese (Mandarin) name, used generally in early works of travel, and now for a kind of rolled tea used in Central Asia.
The red-bellied woodpecker ( Melanerpes Carolinus ).
See 3d Chase , n. , 3.
To toss up the head frequently, as a horse to avoid the restraint of the bridle.
To excite heat in by friction; to rub in order to stimulate and make warm.
To use light, idle language by way of fun or ridicule; to banter.

A series of links or rings, usually of metal, connected, or fitted into one another, used for various purposes, as of support, of restraint, of ornament, of the exertion and transmission of mechanical power, etc.
To place in a chair.

The crested screamer of Brazil ( Palamedea chavaria syn. Chauna chavaria ), so called in imitation of its notes; -- called also chauna , and faithful kamichi . It is often domesticated and is useful in guarding other poultry. See Kamichi .
A soft, earthy substance, of a white, grayish, or yellowish white color, consisting of calcium carbonate, and having the same composition as common limestone.
The sovereign prince of Tartary; -- now usually written khan .
To bite with repeated action of the teeth so as to be heard.
The East Indian name for the large spiral shell of several species of sea conch much used in making bangles, esp. Turbinella pyrum . Called also chank shell .
To utter with a melodious voice; to sing.
An empty, immeasurable space; a yawning chasm.
To cause to open in slits or chinks; to split; to cause the skin of to crack or become rough.
The piece by which an object is attached to something, as the frog of a scabbard or the metal loop at the back of a buckle by which it is fastened to a strap.
The jaws, or the fleshy parts about them. See Chap .

One of the several species of fishes of the genus Salvelinus , allied to the spotted trout and salmon, inhabiting deep lakes in mountainous regions in Europe. In the United States, the brook trout ( Salvelinus fontinalis ) is sometimes called a char .
A genus of flowerless plants, having articulated stems and whorled branches. They flourish in wet places.
The tender leaves or leafstalks of the artichoke, white beet, etc., blanched for table use.
A narrow street.
Charcoal; a cinder.
A melody; a song.
See 1st Char .
A sheet of paper, pasteboard, or the like, on which information is exhibited, esp. when the information is arranged in tabular form; as, an historical chart .
Careful; wary; cautious; not rash, or reckless; as, the latest internet IPO's were shunned by investors made chary by the poor performance of the first wave of companies that went public .
To pursue for the purpose of killing or taking, as an enemy, or game; to hunt.
A deep opening made by disruption, as a breach in the earth or a rock; a yawning abyss; a cleft; a fissure.
to chasten.
To talk in a light and familiar manner; to converse without form or ceremony; to gossip.
A small South American species of tiger cat ( Felis mitis ).
To open; to yawn.
a lynxlike animal of Asia and Africa ( Lynx Lybicus ).
To grind with the teeth; to masticate, as food in eating; to chew, as the cud; to champ, as the bit.
A bargain; a purchase; cheapness.
See Cheer .
An act of deception or fraud; that which is the means of fraud or deception; a fraud; a trick; imposition; imposture.

A word of warning denoting that the king is in danger; such a menace of a player's king by an adversary's move as would, if it were any other piece, expose it to immediate capture. A king so menaced is said to be in check , and must be made safe at the next move.
The side of the face below the eye.
To chirp, as a young bird.
The face; the countenance or its expression.
A chief or head person.
The pincherlike claw of Crustacea and Arachnida.
A claw. See Chela .
a wild goose having white adult plumage.
A chinese reed instrument, with tubes, blown by the mouth.
An impure, massive, flintlike quartz or hornstone, of a dull color.
pret. of Chese .

A game played on a chessboard, by two persons, with two differently colored sets of men, sixteen in each set. Each player has a king, a queen, two bishops, two knights, two castles or rooks, and eight pawns.
A large box of wood, or other material, having, like a trunk, a lid, but no covering of skin, leather, or cloth.
To come to an issue; to turn out; to succeed; as, to cheve well in a enterprise .
See Chivy , v. t.
To bite and grind with the teeth; to masticate.
Of or pertaining to Chios, an island in the Ægean Sea.
Original and in good taste or form; stylish; in current fashion, fashionable.
A red coloring matter. extracted from the Bignonia Chica , used by some tribes of South American Indians to stain the skin.
The chick-pea.
To sprout, as seed in the ground; to vegetate.
Var. of Chica .
To rebuke; to reprove; to scold; to find fault with.
The head or leader of any body of men; a commander, as of an army; a head man, as of a tribe, clan, or family; a person in authority who directs the work of others; the principal actor or agent.
A son or a daughter; a male or female descendant, in the first degree; the immediate progeny of human parents; -- in law , legitimate offspring. Used also of animals and plants.
A kind of red pepper. See Capsicum
Moderately cold; tending to cause shivering; chilly; raw.
The edge of a cask, etc; a chine. See Chine , n. , 3.
See Chine , n. , 3.
same as chimpanzee .
The lower extremity of the face below the mouth; the point of the under jaw.
A country in Eastern Asia.
A chink or cleft; a narrow and deep ravine; as, Shanklin Chine in the Isle of Wight, a quarter of a mile long and 230 feet deep .
A small cleft, rent, or fissure, of greater length than breadth; a gap or crack; as, the chinks of a wall .
a coarse, tough, twilled cotton fabric used for uniforms or sports clothes.
To cut small pieces from; to diminish or reduce to shape, by cutting away a little at a time; to hew.
A ship's carpenter.
To shriek; to gnash; to utter harsh or shrill cries.
Noise; din; esp.; confused noise, clamor, or hum of many voices, notes of birds, or the like.
To make a shop, sharp, cheerful, as of small birds or crickets.
The embryo or the growing bud of a plant; a shoot; a sprout; as, the chits of Indian corn or of potatoes .
A filament of a stamen.
To goad, drive, hunt, throw, or pitch; to repeatedly cause annoyance or concern to.
See Choke .
chocolate; a colloquial British abbreviation; as, a box ov chocs .
To stop or fasten, as with a wedge, or block; to scotch; as, to chock a wheel or cask .
the old imp. of chide . See Chide .
A band or organized company of singers, especially in church service.
To render unable to breathe by filling, pressing upon, or squeezing the windpipe; to stifle; to suffocate; to strangle.
Tending to choke or suffocate, or having power to suffocate.
To chew loudly and greedily; to champ.
To cut by striking repeatedly with a sharp instrument; to cut into pieces; to mince; -- often with up .
The jaws; also, the fleshy parts about the mouth.
The string of a musical instrument.
A small job; in the pl. , the regular or daily light work of a household or farm, either within or without doors.
A thing; personal property.
An assessment equal to a fourth part of the revenue.
A prefecture or district of the second rank in China, or the chief city of such a district; -- often part of the name of a city, as in Foochow .

A species to fresh-water fish of the Cyprinidæ or Carp family. The common European species is Leuciscus cephalus ; the cheven. In America the name is applied to various fishes of the same family, of the genera Semotilus , Squalius , Ceratichthys , etc., and locally to several very different fishes, as the tautog , black bass , etc.
To make a noise resembling that of a hen when she calls her chickens; to cluck.
To champ; to bite.
Minced meat.
A sedgelike plant ( Cyperus esculentus ) producing edible tubers, native about the Mediterranean, now cultivated in many regions; the earth almond.
A coarse or stupid fellow.
A roommate, especially in a college or university; an old and intimate friend.
A short, thick, heavy piece of wood.
A short, thick piece of anything.
A rustic; a countryman or laborer.
A vessel in which milk or cream is stirred, beaten, or otherwise agitated (as by a plunging or revolving dasher) in order to separate the oily globules from the other parts, and obtain butter.
A vibrant or whirring noise such as that made by some insects, as the cockchafer, or by some birds, as the nightjar, the partridge, etc.
See Choose.
A framework, trough, or tube, upon or through which objects are made to slide from a higher to a lower level, or through which water passes to a wheel.

A milky fluid containing the fatty matter of the food in a state of emulsion, or fine mechanical division; formed from chyme by the action of the intestinal juices. It is absorbed by the lacteals, and conveyed into the blood by the thoracic duct.
The pulpy mass of semi-digested food in the small intestines just after its passage from the stomach. It is separated in the intestines into chyle and excrement. See Chyle .
A perennial alliaceous plant ( Allium fistulosum ), sometimes called Welsh onion . Its fistular leaves areused in cookery.
The expressed juice of apples. It is used as a beverage, for making vinegar, and for other purposes.
A small roll of tobacco, used for smoking.
The eyelashes.
See Sill ., n. a foundation.
A kind of molding. See Cyma .
See Simar .
A genus of hemipterous insects of which the bedbug is the best known example. See Bedbug .
See Cimbia .
To put a cinch upon; to girth tightly.
See Scion .
An amphitheatrical circle for sports; a circus.
Approximately; about; commonly abbreviated ca. ; -- used especially before dates and numerical measures; as, he was born circa 1650; ca. 50 feet high .

the candlewood of Mexico and couthwestern California ( Idria columnaris or Fouquieria columnaris ), having tall columnar stems and bearing honey-scented creamy yellow flowers; -- called also the boojum tree .
See Cirrus .
The Lake herring ( Coregonus Artedi ), valuable food fish of the Great Lakes of North America. The name is also applied to Coregonus Hoyi , a related species of Lake Michigan.
A citizen; an inhabitant of a city; a pert townsman; -- used contemptuously.
Summons to appear, as before a judge.
To call upon officially or authoritatively to appear, as before a court; to summon.
One who cites.
A large town.
Same as Chive .

A substance, of the consistence of butter or honey, taken from glands in the anal pouch of the civet ( Viverra civetta ). It is of clear yellowish or brownish color, of a strong, musky odor, offensive when undiluted, but agreeable when a small portion is mixed with another substance. It is used as a perfume.
Relating to, or derived from, a city or citizen; relating to man as a member of society, or to civil affairs.
Pertaining to a city or state, or to a citizen in his relations to his fellow citizens or to the state; within the city or state.
To clip with scissors.
Bulk; largeness. [Obs.] See Size .
To make a sudden, sharp noise, or a succesion of such noises, as by striking an object, or by collision of parts; to rattle; to click.
imp. & p. p. of Clothe .
See Clake .
To ask for, or seek to obtain, by virtue of authority, right, or supposed right; to challenge as a right; to demand as due.
The bernicle goose; -- now called barnacle goose and also called clack goose .

A bivalve mollusk of many kinds, especially those that are edible; as, the long clam ( Mya arenaria ), the quahog or round clam ( Venus mercenaria ), the sea clam or hen clam ( Spisula solidissima ), and other species of the United States . The name is said to have been given originally to the Tridacna gigas , a huge East Indian bivalve.
Something rigid that holds fast or binds things together; a piece of wood or metal, used to hold two or more pieces together.
A tribe or collection of families, united under a chieftain, regarded as having the same common ancestor, and bearing the same surname; as, the clan of Macdonald .
To strike together so as to produce a ringing metallic sound.

A sharp, brief, ringing sound, made by a collision of metallic or other sonorous bodies; -- usually expressing a duller or less resounding sound than clang , and a deeper and stronger sound than clink .
To strike; to slap; to strike, or strike together, with a quick motion, so, as to make a sharp noise; as, to clap one's hands; a clapping of wings .
A bird; the flicker.
Variant of Clasp
A nun of the order of St. Clare.
To daub, smear, or spread, as with mud, etc.
To make a loud or shrill noise.
To make a noise by striking against something; to dash noisily together.
To shut or fasten together with, or as with, a clasp; to shut or fasten (a clasp, or that which fastens with a clasp).
A group of individuals ranked together as possessing common characteristics; as, the different classes of society; the educated class ; the lower classes .
imp. of Cleave .
A mantelpiece.
A sharp, hooked nail, as of a beast or bird.

A soft earth, which is plastic, or may be molded with the hands, consisting of hydrous silicate of aluminium. It is the result of the wearing down and decomposition, in part, of rocks containing aluminous minerals, as granite. Lime, magnesia, oxide of iron, and other ingredients, are often present as impurities.
Free from dirt or filth; as, clean clothes .
Free from opaqueness; transparent; bright; light; luminous; unclouded.
To strengthen with a cleat.
The redshank.
A large hook or crook, as for a pot over a fire; specif., an iron-headed golf club with a straight, narrow face and a long shaft.
A character used in musical notation to determine the position and pitch of the scale as represented on the staff.
imp. & p. p. from Cleave .
A small breeze or horsefly.
To starve; to famish.
To call, or name.
A clergyman or ecclesiastic.
A ball of thread, yarn, or cord; also, The thread itself.
To make a slight, sharp noise (or a succession of such noises), as by gentle striking; to tick.
A high, steep rock; a precipice.
A cleft of crack; a narrow opening.
To ascend or mount laboriously, esp. by use of the hands and feet.
A climate; a tract or region of the earth. See Climate .
To adhere closely; to stick; to hold fast, especially by twining round or embracing; as, the tendril of a vine clings to its support ; -- usually followed by to or together .
To cause to give out a slight, sharp, tinkling, sound, as by striking metallic or other sonorous bodies together.
The Muse who presided over history.
To embrace, hence; to encompass.
Same as clitoris .
A loose outer garment, extending from the neck downwards, and commonly without sleeves. It is longer than a cape, and is worn both by men and by women.

A machine for measuring time, indicating the hour and other divisions; in ordinary mechanical clocks for domestic or office use the time is indicated on a typically circular face or dial plate containing two hands , pointing to numbers engraved on the periphery of the face, thus showing the hours and minutes. The works of a mechanical clock are moved by a weight or a spring, and it is often so constructed as to tell the hour by the stroke of a hammer on a bell. In electrical or electronic clocks, the time may be indicated, as on a mechanical clock, by hands, but may also be indicated by direct digital readout, with the hours and minutes in normal Arabic numerals. The readout using hands is often called analog to distinguish it from the digital readout. Some clocks also indicate the seconds. Clocks are not adapted, like the watch, to be carried on the person. Specialized clocks, such as atomic clocks , may be constructed on different principles, and may have a very high precision for use in scientific observations.
A lump or mass, especially of earth, turf, or clay.
Formerly an allowance of two pounds in every three hundred weight after the tare and tret are subtracted; now used only in a general sense, of small deductions from the original weight.
That which hinders or impedes motion; hence, an encumbrance, restraint, or impediment, of any kind.
imp. & p. p. of Climb (for climbed ).
See Clamp .
a group of organisms derived from a single individual by some kind of asexual reproduction; -- used mostly of microorganisms such as bacteria and yeast.
imp. of Cling .
To close with glutinous matter.
The sound made when a cork is forcibly drawn from a bottle.
One of the divisions of a cleft hoof, as in the ox; also, the whole hoof.
To stop, or fill up, as an opening; to shut; as, to close the eyes; to close a door .
A disease in the feet of cattle; laminitis.
A concretion or coagulation; esp. a soft, slimy, coagulated mass, as of blood; a coagulum.
The common burdock; the clotbur.

A fabric made of fibrous material (or sometimes of wire, as in wire cloth); commonly, a woven fabric of cotton, woolen, or linen, adapted to be made into garments; specifically, woolen fabrics, as distinguished from all others.
A collection of visible vapor, or watery particles, suspended in the upper atmosphere.
A cloth; a piece of cloth or leather; a patch; a rag.
A cleft; a gap; a ravine; -- rarely used except as part of a proper name; as, Kaaterskill Clove ; Stone Clove .
A man of coarse nature and manners; an awkward fellow; an ill-bred person; a boor.
To fill or choke up; to stop up; to clog.
A heavy staff of wood, usually tapering, and wielded with the hand; a weapon; a cudgel.
To make the noise, or utter the call, of a brooding hen.
A ball of thread; a thread or other means of guidance. Same as Clew .
Silence; hush.
An unshaped piece or mass of wood or other substance.
imp. & p. p. of Cling .
the abbreviation for centimeter .
One of the peculiar stinging cells found in Cœlenterata; a nematocyst; a lasso cell.
acronym for central nervous system the portion of the vertebrate nervous system consisting of the brain and spinal cord.
the chemical formula for cobalt , a ferromagnetic metal of atomic number 27.
an abbreviation for coenzyme A .
A large, closed, four-wheeled carriage, having doors in the sides, and generally a front and back seat inside, each for two persons, and an elevated outside seat in front for the driver.
To force; to compel; to drive.
See Coak , a kind of tenon.
See Coke , n.
A thoroughly charred, and extinguished or still ignited, fragment from wood or other combustible substance; charcoal.
Pertaining to, or resembling, coal; containing coal; of the nature of coal.
The side of a thing.
An outer garment fitting the upper part of the body; especially, such a garment worn by men.
A mammal of tropical America of the genus Nasua , allied to the raccoon, having a ringed tail but with a longer body, tail, and nose; -- called also coati mondi and coati mundi .
To persuade by gentle, insinuating courtesy, flattering, or fondling; to wheedle; to soothe.
The top or head of anything.
Headstrong; obstinate.
An oceanic fish of large size ( Elacate canada ); the crabeater; -- called also bonito , cubbyyew , coalfish , and sergeant fish .
A flat-floored fishing boat with a lug sail, and a drop rudder extending from two to four feet below the keel. It was originally used on the stormy coast of Yorkshire, England.
See Copra .
The dried leaf of a South American shrub ( Erythroxylon Coca ). In med., called Erythroxylon .
The male of birds, particularly of gallinaceous or domestic fowls.
See Cocoa .

A tall palm tree producing the cocoanut ( Cocos nucifera ) as its fruit. It grows in nearly all tropical countries, attaining a height of sixty or eighty feet. The trunk is without branches, and has a tuft of leaves at the top, each being fifteen or twenty feet in length, and at the base of these the nuts hang in clusters; the cocoanut tree. It is widely planted throughout the tropics, and in some locations as an ornamental tree.
one of the Titans.
an abbreviation of collect on delivery ; payment due by the recipient on delivery; as, a COD parcel .
A few measures added beyond the natural termination of a composition.
A body of law, sanctioned by legislation, in which the rules of law to be specifically applied by the courts are set forth in systematic form; a compilation of laws by public authority; a digest.
A book, especially an early form of book with pages stitched together, contrasting with the earlier scrolls; a manuscript; as, a DaVinci codex .
See Coddle .

a sequence of three nucleotides in a genome or a DNA or messenger RNA molecule, which specifies the incorporation of one amino acid or is a stop signal, during the biosynthesis of proteins. Codons occur within the protein-coding segments of the DNA or RNA genome of living organisms. The amino acid sequence of proteins synthesized on ribosomes is thus determined by the sequence of the nucleotides in the genome.
To deceive; to cheat; to play false; to lie; to wheedle; to cajole.
A tall, coarse grass ( Imperata arundinacea ) of the Philippine Islands and adjacent countries, used for thatching.
A small wooden vessel; a pail.
To cover or dress with, or as with, a coif.
A var. spelling of Coin , Quoin , a corner, wedge; -- chiefly used in the phrase coign of vantage , a position advantageous for action or observation.
To wind cylindrically or spirally; as, to coil a rope when not in use; the snake coiled itself before springing .
A quoin; a corner or external angle; a wedge. See Coigne , and Quoin .
A material for cordage, matting, etc., consisting of the prepared fiber of the outer husk of the cocoanut.
To throw, as a stone. [Obs.] See Quoit .

Mineral coal charred, or depriver of its bitumen, sulphur, or other volatile matter by roasting in a kiln or oven, or by distillation, as in gas works. It is lagerly used where &unr_; smokeless fire is required.
A simpleton; a gull; a dupe.
A short ridge connecting two higher elevations or mountains; the pass over such a ridge.
L. pl. of Colon .
Deprived of heat, or having a low temperature; not warm or hot; gelid; frigid.
A plant of the Brassica or Cabbage genus; esp. that form of Brassica oleracea called rape and coleseed .
An inferior church servant. [Obs.] See Acolyte .
A severe paroxysmal pain in the abdomen, due to spasm, obstruction, or distention of some one of the hollow viscera.
The American quail or bobwhite. The name is also applied to other related species. See Bobwhite .
To embrace.
The black grime or soot of coal.
That part of the large intestines which extends from the cæcum to the rectum. [See Illust. of Digestion .]
A property depending on the relations of light to the eye, by which individual and specific differences in the hues and tints of objects are apprehended in vision; as, gay colors ; sad colors , etc.
See Collop .
The young of the equine genus or horse kind of animals; -- sometimes distinctively applied to the male, filly being the female. Cf. Foal .
Any bird of the genus Colius and allied genera. They inhabit Africa.
A variety of cabbage ( Brassica oleracea ), cultivated for its seeds, which yield an oil valued for illuminating and lubricating purposes; summer rape.
A state of profound insensibility from which it is difficult or impossible to rouse a person. See Carus .
An instrument with teeth, for straightening, cleansing, and adjusting the hair, or for keeping it in place.
a small band of jazz musicians.
To move hitherward; to draw near; to approach the speaker, or some place or person indicated; -- opposed to go .
One who comes, or who has come; one who has arrived, and is present.
The answer to the theme ( dux ) in a fugue.

A member of the solar system which usually moves in an elongated orbit, approaching very near to the sun in its perihelion, and receding to a very great distance from it at its aphelion. A comet commonly consists of three parts: the nucleus, the envelope, or coma, and the tail; but one or more of these parts is frequently wanting. See Illustration in Appendix.
comfortable.
Relating to comedy, as distinct from tragedy.
A character or point [,] marking the smallest divisions of a sentence, written or printed.
Short for Composition ; -- used, esp. in England, colloq. in various trade applications;
Account; reckoning; computation.
Against the affirmative side; in opposition; on the negative side; -- The antithesis of pro , and usually in connection with it. See Pro .

A name applied to various marine univalve shells; esp. to those of the genus Strombus , which are of large size. Strombus gigas is the large pink West Indian conch. The large king, queen, and cameo conchs are of the genus Cassis . See Cameo and cameo conch .
To con, as a ship.
one of the units in a condominium.

A solid of the form described by the revolution of a right-angled triangle about one of the sides adjacent to the right angle; -- called also a right cone . More generally, any solid having a vertical point and bounded by a surface which is described by a straight line always passing through that vertical point; a solid having a circle for its base and tapering to a point or vertex.
A rabbit. See Cony .
An abbreviation of Congius .
music composed for dancing the conga.
To take leave with the customary civilities; to bow ceremoniously, or courtesy.
Same as Conine .
Having the form of, or resembling, a geometrical cone; round and tapering to a point, or gradually lessening in circumference; as, a conic or conical figure; a conical vessel .
to hit on the head; as, to conk someone on the head with a pipe .
See Con , to direct a ship.
Brave; fine; canny.
A short narrative or tale, esp. one dealing with surprising or marvelous events.
A rabbit, esp., the European rabbit ( Lepus cuniculus )
To make a low repeated cry or sound, like the characteristic note of pigeons or doves.

A peculiar cry uttered by the Australian aborigines as a call to attract attention, and also in common use among the Australian colonists. In the actual call the first syllable is much prolonged (k&oomacr_;"-) and the second ends in a shrill, staccato ē. To represent the sound itself the spelling cooee is generally used.
To make the noise of the cuckoo.
A small, flat, sweetened cake of various kinds.
Moderately cold; between warm and cold; lacking in warmth; producing or promoting coolness.
An East Indian porter or carrier; a laborer transported from the East Indies, China, or Japan, for service in some other country.
Soot; coal dust; refuse matter, as the dirty grease which comes from axle boxes, or the refuse at the mouth of an oven.
A dry measure of four bushels, or half a quarter.
A raccoon. See Raccoon .
To confine in a coop; hence, to shut up or confine in a narrow compass; to cramp; -- usually followed by up , sometimes by in .
A wading bird with lobate toes, of the genus Fulica . The common European or bald coot is Fulica atra (see under bald ); the American is Fulica Americana
The top of a thing; the head; a crest.

A resinous substance flowing spontaneously from trees of Zanzibar, Madagascar, and South America ( Trachylobium Hornemannianum , Trachylobium verrucosum , and Hymenæa Courbaril ), and dug from earth where forests have stood in Africa; -- used chiefly in making varnishes.
A covering for the head.
Clad in a cope.
See Copse .
The dried meat of the cocoanut, from which cocoanut oil is expressed.
The connecting crook of a harrow.
A wood of small growth; a thicket of brushwood. See Coppice .
Characterized by copses.
An Egyptian race thought to be descendants of the ancient Egyptians.
An abundance or plenty of anything.
A small loop or bow of ribbon used in making hats, boas, etc.
A Hebrew measure of capacity; a homer.
The Arabian gazelle ( Gazella Arabica ), found from persia to North Africa.
Plain; undyed; -- applied to Indian silk.
The hard parts or skeleton of various Anthozoa, and of a few Hydrozoa. Similar structures are also formed by some Bryozoa.
A basket used in coal mines, etc. see Corf .
A string, or small rope, composed of several strands twisted together.
trousers made of corduroy cloth; corduroys.
Of, or like, cord; having cords or cordlike parts.
A body of individuals; an assemblage.
That which cores; an instrument for coring fruit; as, an apple corer .
either of two Welsh breeds of long-bodied short-legged dogs with erect ears and a foxlike head.
The outer layer of the bark of the cork tree ( Quercus Suber ), of which stoppers for bottles and casks are made. See Cutose .
Consisting of, or like, cork; dry shriveled up.
A solid bulb-shaped root, as of the crocus. See Bulb .
A thickening of the epidermis at some point, esp. on the toes, by friction or pressure. It is usually painful and troublesome.
A horn, or anything shaped like or resembling a horn.
Strong, stiff, or hard, like a horn; resembling horn.
The human body, whether living or dead.
A living body or its bulk.
See Cozen .
a piece of leather-covered metal with a flexible handle; used for hitting people.
A Hindoo measure of distance, varying from one and a half to two English miles.
A rib; a side; a region or coast.
A rib of an animal or a human being.
A small house; a cottage or hut.
A cottage or hut.
