A surplice, in England and America usually one shorter and less full than the ordinary surplice and with short sleeves, or sometimes none.
To lie down or recline, as on a bed or other place of rest; to repose; to lie.
To expel air, or obstructing or irritating matter, from the lungs or air passages, in a noisy and violent manner.
Was, should be, or would be, able, capable, or susceptible. Used as an auxiliary, in the past tense or in the conditional present.
To tell or name one by one, or by groups, for the purpose of ascertaining the whole number of units in a collection; to number; to enumerate; to compute; to reckon.
A sudden stroke delivered with promptness and force; -- used also in various ways to convey the idea of an unexpected, clever, and successful tactic or stratagem.
Curved; rounded.
An inclosed space; a courtyard; an uncovered area shut in by the walls of a building, or by different building; also, a space opening from a street and nearly surrounded by houses; a blind alley.
Could; was able; knew or known; understood.
To arch over; to build in a hollow concave form; to make in the form of a cove.
To overspread the surface of (one thing) with another; as, to cover wood with paint or lacquer; to cover a table with a cloth .
To have or indulge inordinate desire.
A brood or hatch of birds; an old bird with her brood of young; hence, a small flock or number of birds together; -- said of game; as, a covey of partridges .
A collusive agreement between two or more persons to prejudice a third.
A chimney cap; a cowl
One who works as a mason without having served a regular apprenticeship.
frightened into submission or compliance.
To stoop by bending the knees; to crouch; to squat; hence, to quail; to sink through fear.
A monk's hood; -- usually attached to the gown. The name was also applied to the hood and garment together.
domesticated bovine animals as a group regardless of sex or age; as, wait till the cows come home .
A coxcomb; a simpleton; a gull.
The first joint of the leg of an insect or crustacean.
Quiet; still.
In a coy manner; with reserve.
a tropical American palm ( Acrocomia vinifera ) having edible nuts and yielding a useful fiber.
A South American rodent ( Myopotamus coypus ), allied to the beaver. It produces a valuable fur called nutria .
A contraction of cousin .
To cheat; to defraud; to beguile; to deceive, usually by small arts, or in a pitiful way.
A wadded covering, often decorative, for a teakettle or other vessel to keep the contents hot. Also called tea cozy
a certified public accountant; an accountant certified by the state.
the consumer price index , an index of the cost of all goods and services to a typical consumer. The increase of this value each year is one measure of monetary inflation.

The central processing unit , that part of the electronic circuitry of a computer in which the arithmetic and logical operations are performed on input data, which are thereby converted to output data; it is usually located on the mainboard, or motherboard, of a computer. The CPU and the memory form the central part of a computer to which the peripherals are attached. Most personal computers as of 1998 had only one CPU, but some computers may have more than one CPU.

In radiotelegraphy, the letters signified by the code call formerly used (cf. S O S) by ships in distress, formed by combining the code call C Q (formerly used as a general call for all stations) with D for distress.
One of the brachyuran Crustacea. They are mostly marine, and usually have a broad, short body, covered with a strong shell or carapace. The abdomen is small and curled up beneath the body.
To burst or open in chinks; to break, with or without quite separating into parts.
Strength; might; secret power.
A steep, rugged rock; a rough, broken cliff, or point of a rock, on a ledge.
See Crare .
A creel or osier basket.
To cry out harshly and loudly, like the bird called crake .

To press, force, or drive, particularly in filling, or in thrusting one thing into another; to stuff; to crowd; to fill to superfluity; as, to cram anything into a basket; to cram a room with people .
That which confines or contracts; a restraint; a shackle; a hindrance.
A measure for fresh herrings, -- as many as will fill a barrel.
A wading bird of the genus Grus , and allied genera, of various species, having a long, straight bill, and long legs and neck.
See Krang .

A bent portion of an axle, or shaft, or an arm keyed at right angles to the end of a shaft, by which motion is imparted to or received from it; also used to change circular into reciprocating motion, or reciprocating into circular motion. See Bell crank .
In the game of craps, a first throw of the dice in which the total is two, three, or twelve, in which case the caster loses. Also called craps .
A thin, crimped stuff, made of raw silk gummed and twisted on the mill. Black crape is much used for mourning garments, also for the dress of some clergymen.
A gambling game with dice. It is one of the more popular games in casinos.
Resembling crape.
A slow unwieldy trading vessel.
To break in pieces; to crack.
To break in pieces violently; to dash together with noise and violence.
Gross; thick; dense; coarse; not elaborated or refined.
A large basket or hamper of wickerwork, used for the transportation of china, crockery, and similar wares.
To ask with earnestness or importunity; to ask with submission or humility; to beg; to entreat; to beseech; to implore.
The crop of a bird.
To move slowly by drawing the body along the ground, as a worm; to move slowly on hands and knees; to creep.
the type genus of the Cracidae ; curassows.
See Crare .
To break into pieces; to crush; to grind to powder. See Crase .
Characterized by weakness or feebleness; decrepit; broken; falling to decay; shaky; unsafe.
To make a prolonged sharp grating or squeaking sound, as by the friction of hard substances; as, shoes creak .
The rich, oily, and yellowish part of milk, which, when the milk stands unagitated, rises, and collects on the surface. It is the part of milk from which butter is obtained.
An usher to a riding master.
the first decisive battle of the Hundred Years' War; in 1346 the English under Edward III defeated the French under King Philip of Valois.
The creed, as sung or read in the Roman Catholic church.
A definite summary of what is believed; esp., a summary of the articles of Christian faith; a confession of faith for public use; esp., one which is brief and comprehensive.
A small inlet or bay, narrower and extending further into the land than a cove; a recess in the shore of the sea, or of a river.
To move along the ground, or on any other surface, on the belly, as a worm or reptile; to move as a child on the hands and knees; to crawl.
An Algonquin tribe of Indians, inhabiting a large part of British America east of the Rocky Mountains and south of Hudson's Bay.
See Krems .
imp. & p. p. of Creep .
A plant of various species, chiefly cruciferous. The leaves have a moderately pungent taste, and are used as a salad and antiscorbutic.
A tuft, or other excrescence or natural ornament, growing on an animal's head; the comb of a cock; the swelling on the head of a serpent; the lengthened feathers of the crown or nape of bird, etc.
Used in English only in the expression en creux . Thus, engraving en creux is engraving in intaglio, or by sinking or hollowing out the design.
The Manx shearwater.
a genus of birds including the corncrake ( Crex crex ).
To shut up or confine in a narrow habitation; to cage; to cramp.
The ring which turns inward and condenses the flame of a lamp.
The creaking of a door, or a noise resembling it.
imp. & p. p. of Cry .
One who cries; one who makes proclamation.
Any violation of law, either divine or human; an omission of a duty commanded, or the commission of an act forbidden by law.
To fold or plait in regular undulation in such a way that the material will retain the shape intended; to give a wavy appearance to; as, to crimp the border of a cap; to crimp a ruffle . Cf. Crisp .
Curling in stiff curls or ringlets; as, crisp hair .

The unit for estimating the weight of aëriform substances; -- the weight of a liter of hydrogen at 0° centigrade, and with a tension of 76 centimeters of mercury. It is 0.0896 of a gram, or 1.38274 grains.
acronym for cathode-ray oscilloscope , an electronic device which provides visual images of varying electrical quantities. See oscilloscope .
To make a low, hoarse noise in the throat, as a frog, a raven, or a crow; hence, to make any hoarse, dismal sound.
A native or resident of Croatia.
a contraction for crocodile .
The loose black particles collected from combustion, as on pots and kettles, or in a chimney; soot; smut; also, coloring matter which rubs off from cloth.
A small, inclosed field, adjoining a house; a small farm.
See Cross , n.
An old ewe.
A bend, turn, or curve; curvature; flexure.
To make a continuous hollow moan, as cattle do when in pain.
The pouchlike enlargement of the gullet of birds, serving as a receptacle for food; the craw.
Ten millions; as, a crore of rupees (which is nearly $5,000,000) .
Not parallel; lying or falling athwart; transverse; oblique; intersecting.
See Crowd , a violin.
The hinder part or buttocks of certain quadrupeds, especially of a horse; hence, the place behind the saddle.
See Sourkrout .
To make the shrill sound characteristic of a cock, either in joy, gayety, or defiance.
To push, to press, to shove.
p. p. of Crow .
A tribe of Indians of the Dakota stock, living in Montana; -- also called Upsarokas .
See Cross , n.
A cooper's tool for making the grooves for the heads of casks, etc.; also, the groove itself.
In its natural state; not cooked or prepared by fire or heat; undressed; not altered, refined, or prepared for use by any artificial process; raw; as, crude flesh .
Coagulated.
See Crewel .
A bottle or vessel; esp., a vial or small glass bottle for holding vinegar, oil, pepper, or the like, for the table; a caster.
Curly; curled.
A small fragment or piece; especially, a small piece of bread or other food, broken or cut off.
Crooked; bent.
To cry like a crane.
The coloring matter of the blood; the clotted portion of coagulated blood, containing the coloring matter; gore.
Short; brittle; as, crup cake .
That part of the hind limb between the femur, or thigh, and the ankle, or tarsus; the shank.
A cup or dish.
To press or bruise between two hard bodies; to squeeze, so as to destroy the natural shape or integrity of the parts, or to force together into a mass; as, to crush grapes .
The hard external coat or covering of anything; the hard exterior surface or outer shell; an incrustation; as, a crust of snow .
The rough, shaggy part of oak bark.
See 4th Crowd .
Anything that is very puzzling or difficult to explain.
See 4th Crowd .
To make a loud call or cry; to call or exclaim vehemently or earnestly; to shout; to vociferate; to proclaim; to pray; to implore.
The female of the hawk; a falcon-gentil.
A vault wholly or partly under ground; especially, a vault under a church, whether used for burial purposes or for a subterranean chapel or oratory.
acronym for the Confederate States of America .
the chemical symbol for copper .
A young animal, esp. the young of the bear.
a country on the island of Cuba.
Of or pertaining to Cuba or its inhabitants.
A snug or confined or secluded place; a small room or a snug space within a room.
A regular solid body, with six equal square sides.

The small, spicy berry of a species of pepper ( Piper Cubeba ; in (Med.) , Cubeba officinalis ), native in Java and Borneo, but now cultivated in various tropical countries. The dried unripe fruit is much used in medicine as a stimulant and purgative.
Having the form or properties of a cube; contained, or capable of being contained, in a cube.
The forearm; the ulna, a bone of the arm extending from elbow to wrist.
That portion of food which is brought up into the mouth by ruminating animals from their first stomach, to be chewed a second time.
An ass; esp., one driven by a huckster or greengrocer.
The tail; the end of a thing; especially, a tail-like twist of hair worn at the back of the head; a queue.
To strike; esp., to smite with the palm or flat of the hand; to slap.
A name for a negro.
Of or pertaining to the older characters of the Arabic language.
Defensive armor for the thighs.
a contraction of cul-de-sac .

A genus of mosquitoes of the family Culicidae , to which most of the North American species belong. Some members of this genus are exceedingly annoying, as Culex sollicitans , which breeds in enormous numbers in the salt marshes of the Atlantic coast, and Culex pipiens , the common house mosquito, breeding very widely in the fresh waters of North America. (For characters distinguishing these from the malaria mosquitoes, see Anopheles , above). The yellow-fever mosquito is now placed in another genus, Stegomyia .
To separate, select, or pick out; to choose and gather or collect; as, to cull flowers .
Refuse timber, from which the best part has been culled out.
A person easily deceived, tricked, or imposed on; a mean dupe; a gull.
The stalk or stem of grain and grasses (including the bamboo), jointed and usually hollow.
Negligence or fault, as distinguishable from dolus (deceit, fraud), which implies intent, culpa being imputable to defect of intellect, dolus to defect of heart.
Blameworthiness.
Attentive care; homage; worship.
with; together with; along with; as, I work at home in an office- cum -bedroom .
See Cuming .

A dwarf umbelliferous plant, somewhat resembling fennel ( Cuminum Cyminum ), cultivated for its seeds, which have a bitterish, warm taste, with an aromatic flavor, and are used like those of anise and caraway.
To con (a ship).
To con (a ship).
The female pudenda; specifically the vagina.
a genus of canids including the Asiatic wild dog.

A small vessel, used commonly to drink from; as, a tin cup , a silver cup , a wine cup ; especially, in modern times, the pottery or porcelain vessel, commonly with a handle, used with a saucer in drinking tea, coffee, and the like.
A shallow porous cup, used in refining precious metals, commonly made of bone ashes (phosphate of lime).
The god of love, son of Venus; usually represented as a naked, winged boy with bow and arrow.
a cup of tea.
Hollow; cuplike; also, full of cups, or small depressions.
A mongrel or inferior dog.
A cuirass or breastplate.
To bend or curve.
See Courche .
The coagulated or thickened part of milk, as distinguished from the whey, or watery part. It is eaten as food, especially when made into cheese.
Like curd; full of curd; coagulated.
Care, heed, or attention.
One who cures; a healer; a physician.
One of the thirty parts into which the Roman people were divided by Romulus.
Any curiosity{3} or article of virtu; any object esteemed for its unusual nature.
To twist or form into ringlets; to crisp, as the hair.
Curling or tending to curl; having curls; full of ripples; crinkled.
To dress or prepare for use by a process of scraping, cleansing, beating, smoothing, and coloring; -- said of leather.
To call upon divine or supernatural power to send injury upon; to imprecate evil upon; to execrate.
imp. & p. p. of Curse .
Characterized by excessive brevity; short; rudely concise; as, curt limits; a curt answer .
Bent without angles; crooked; curved; as, a curve line; a curve surface .
not requiring strong efforts; easy; -- said of paid employment; as, He got a cushy job in a large company .
A large, edible, marine fish ( Brosmius brosme ), allied to the cod, common on the northern coasts of Europe and America; -- called also tusk and torsk .
To furnish with a cusp or cusps.
To separate the parts of with, or as with, a sharp instrument; to make an incision in; to gash; to sever; to divide.
See Catechu .
Clever; sharp; shrewd; ingenious; cunning.
A waxy substance containing fatty acids, soaps, and resinous material which, combined with cellulose, forms a substance nearly impervious to water and constituting the cuticle in plants.
See Dermis .
Short; as, a cutty knife; a cutty sark .
Same as curriculum vitae ; -- a commonly used initialism.
Any plant of the natural order Cycadaceæ , as the sago palm, etc.
A genus of trees, intermediate in character between the palms and the pines. The pith of the trunk of some species furnishes a valuable kind of sago.
An imaginary circle or orbit in the heavens; one of the celestial spheres.
See Cider .
A slight covering; a scarf. See Simar .
A flattish or convex flower cluster, of the centrifugal or determinate type, differing from a corymb chiefly in the order of the opening of the blossoms.
A collective term for the Welsh race; -- so called by themselves .
Having the qualities of a surly dog; snarling; captious; currish.
See Cion , and Scion .
a large tropical American tree ( Cordia alliodora ) grown for its abundant creamy white flowers and valuable wood.
A pouch or sac without opening, usually membranous and containing morbid matter, which is accidentally developed in one of the natural cavities or in the substance of an organ.
A king; a chief; the title of the emperor of Russia.
One of the Czechs; an inhabitant or native of the Czech Republic .
A skillful hand; a dabster; an expert.
A large, spine-tailed lizard ( Uromastix spinipes ), found in Egypt, Arabia, and Palestine; -- called also dhobb , and dhubb .
A small European cyprinoid fish ( Leuciscus leuciscus , formerly Squalius leuciscus or Leuciscus vulgaris ); -- called also dare .
a Russian country house, especially a cottage used in the summer.
Father; -- a word sometimes used by children.
Diminutive of Dad .
To hold up by leading strings or by the hand, as a child while he toddles.
That part of a pedestal included between the base and the cornice (or surbase); the die. See Illust. of Column .
To cast aside; to put off; to doff.
Stupid; foolish; idiotic; also, delirious; insane; as, he has gone daft .
A dagger; a poniard.
the Mesopotanian god of agriculture and earth; it is a counterpart of Phoenician and Philistine Dagon.
in Irish legend, chief god of the Tuatha De Danann; father of Angus Og and Brigit.
a relatively nontoxic South African herb ( Leonotis leonurus ) smoked like tobacco.
A nickname given to a person of Spanish (or, by extension, Portuguese or Italian) descent.
The national god of the Philistines, represented with the face and hands and upper part of a man, and the tail of a fish.
the lower house of the parliament of the Republic of Ireland; -- also called the Dail Eirann . From its members is selected the Taoiseach , or prime minister.
Happening, or belonging to, each successive day; diurnal; as, daily labor; a daily bulletin.
Something of exquisite taste; a dainty.
The place, room, or house where milk is kept, and converted into butter or cheese.
The high or principal table, at the end of a hall, at which the chief guests were seated; also, the chief seat at the high table.
A genus of low herbs ( Bellis ), belonging to the family Compositæ . The common English and classical daisy is Bellis perennis , which has a yellow disk and white or pinkish rays.
Post; mail; also, the mail or postal arrangements; -- spelt also dawk , and dauk .
The capital city of Senegal . Population (2000) = 1,729,823.
A measure of certain commodities by number, usually ten or twelve, but sometimes twenty; as, a daker of hides consisted of ten skins; a daker of gloves of ten pairs.
Split pulse, esp. of Cajanus Indicus .
A low place between hills; a vale or valley.
a genus of plants including the indigo bush.
imp. of Delve .
To waste time in effeminate or voluptuous pleasures, or in idleness; to fool away time; to delay unnecessarily; to tarry; to trifle.
a herb of the Pacific islands ( Colocasia esculenta ) grown throughout the tropics for its edible root and in temperate areas as an ornamental for its large glossy leaves.
A female parent; -- used of beasts, especially of quadrupeds; sometimes applied in contempt to a human mother.
a genus of deer including the Eurasian fallow deer, Dama dama .

A small herbivorous mammal of the genus Hyrax . The species found in Palestine and Syria is Hyrax Syriacus ; that of Northern Africa is Hyrax Brucei ; -- called also ashkoko , dassy , and rock rabbit . See Cony , and Hyrax .
See Dammar .
A mistress of a family, who is a lady; a woman in authority; especially, a lady.
To condemn; to declare guilty; to doom; to adjudge to punishment; to sentence; to censure.
Moisture; humidity; fog; fogginess; vapor.
Somewhat damp.
A title of honor equivalent to master , or sir .

To move with measured steps, or to a musical accompaniment; to go through, either alone or in company with others, with a regulated succession of movements, (commonly) to the sound of music; to trip or leap rhythmically.
Same as Dancetté .
A boatman; an oarsman.
One who affects special finery or gives undue attention to dress; a fop; a coxcomb.
A native, or a naturalized inhabitant, of Denmark.
imp. of Ding .
Damp; moist; humid; wet.
To drop the bait gently on the surface of the water.
A plasterer's float, having two handles; -- used in smoothing ceilings, etc.
To have adequate or sufficient courage for any purpose; to be bold or venturesome; not to be afraid; to venture.
One who dares or defies.
A day's work; also, a fixed amount of work, whether more or less than that of a day.
A gold coin of ancient Persia, weighing usually a little more than 128 grains, and bearing on one side the figure of an archer.

Destitute, or partially destitute, of light; not receiving, reflecting, or radiating light; wholly or partially black, or of some deep shade of color; not light-colored; as, a dark room; a dark day; dark cloth; dark paint; a dark complexion.
a negro; an African-American; -- an older term now considered offensive.
To mend as a rent or hole, with interlacing stitches of yarn or thread by means of a needle; to sew together with yarn or thread.
The Egyptian sycamore ( Ficus Sycamorus ). See Sycamore .
The European black tern.
A pointed missile weapon, intended to be thrown by the hand; a short lance; a javelin; hence, any sharp-pointed missile weapon, as an arrow.
To throw with violence or haste; to cause to strike violently or hastily; -- often used with against .
Calculated to arrest attention; ostentatiously fashionable; showy.
digital audiotape, a digitally encoded tape recording of sound; -- in contrast to the usual analog audio tape.
See Datum .
The fruit of the date palm; also, the date palm itself.
marked by features of the immediate and usually discounted past.
One who dates.
Something given or admitted; a fact or principle granted; that upon which an inference or an argument is based; -- used chiefly in the plural.
To smear with soft, adhesive matter, as pitch, slime, mud, etc.; to plaster; to bedaub; to besmear.
Smeary; viscous; glutinous; adhesive.
See Dawk , v. t. , to cut or gush.
A variant of Dan , a title of honor.
To overcome; to conquer.
The striped quagga, or Burchell's zebra, of South Africa ( Asinus Burchellii ); -- called also peechi , or peetsi .
A spar formerly used on board of ships, as a crane to hoist the flukes of the anchor to the top of the bow, without injuring the sides of the ship; -- called also the fish davit .
A European bird of the Crow family ( Corvus monedula ), often nesting in church towers and ruins; a jackdaw.
To cut or mark with an incision; to gash.
To begin to grow light in the morning; to grow light; to break, or begin to appear; as, the day dawns ; the morning dawns .
The time of light, or interval between one night and the next; the time between sunrise and sunset, or from dawn to darkness; hence, the light; sunshine; -- also called daytime .
To stupefy with excess of light; with a blow, with cold, or with fear; to confuse; to benumb.
stupefied; conscious but unable to think clearly; -- usually caused by a blow or other shock.
a database management system, a software system that facilitates the creation and maintenance and use of an electronic database.

Deprived of life; -- opposed to alive and living ; reduced to that state of a being in which the organs of motion and life have irrevocably ceased to perform their functions; as, a dead tree; a dead man.
The substances which inclose the ore on every side.
Wanting the sense of hearing, either wholly or in part; unable to perceive sounds; hard of hearing; as, a deaf man .
A part or portion; a share; hence, an indefinite quantity, degree, or extent, degree, or extent; as, a deal of time and trouble; a deal of cold.
A dignitary or presiding officer in certain ecclesiastical and lay bodies; esp., an ecclesiastical dignitary, subordinate to a bishop.
Bearing a high price; high-priced; costly; expensive.
variant of Dere , v. t. & n.
Secret; lonely; solitary; dreadful.
A dear; a darling.
The cessation of all vital phenomena without capability of resuscitation, either in animals or plants.
To stun or stupefy with noise; to deafen.
To cut off from entrance, as if by a bar or barrier; to preclude; to hinder from approach, entry, or enjoyment; to shut out or exclude; to deny or refuse; -- with from , and sometimes with of .
To conquer.
A debt; an entry on the debtor (Dr.) side of an account; -- mostly used adjectively; as, the debit side of an account .
That which is due from one person to another, whether money, goods, or services; that which one person is bound to pay to another, or to perform for his benefit; thing owed; obligation; liability.

To pass gradually from a sound, prosperous, or perfect state, to one of imperfection, adversity, or dissolution; to waste away; to decline; to fail; to become weak, corrupt, or disintegrated; to rot; to perish; as, a tree decays ; fortunes decay ; hopes decay .
An aspect or position of two planets, when they are distant from each other a tenth part of the zodiac, or 36°.
To cover; to overspread.
the layout, style, and furnishings of a livable interior.
To lead into danger by artifice; to lure into a net or snare; to entrap; to insnare; to allure; to entice; as, to decoy troops into an ambush; to decoy ducks into a net.
To cry down; to censure as faulty, mean, or worthless; to clamor against; to blame clamorously; to discredit; to disparage.
A hydrocarbon radical, C10H21. , never existing alone, but regarded as the characteristic constituent of a number of compounds of the paraffin series.
an electrode with a large interior cavity, shaped like the letter "D", used in opposed pairs to accelerate particles in a cyclotron.
That which is done or effected by a responsible agent; an act; an action; a thing done; -- a word of extensive application, including, whatever is done, good or bad, great or small.
performance of moral or religious acts; salvation is not by deeds , but by faith; to do good deeds .
Industrious; active.
To decide; to judge; to sentence; to condemn.

Extending far below the surface; of great perpendicular dimension (measured from the surface downward, and distinguished from high , which is measured upward); far to the bottom; having a certain depth; as, a deep sea .
Any animal; especially, a wild animal.
To put off; to postpone to a future time; to delay the execution of; to delay; to withhold.
To fix; to fasten; to establish.
Apt; fit; spruce; neat.
To renounce or dissolve all bonds of affiance, faith, or obligation with; to reject, refuse, or renounce.
A small South American rodent ( Octodon Cumingii ), of the family Octodontidæ .
To deprive of, or free from, gum; as, to degum ramie .
to remove ice or frost from.
To make a god of; to exalt to the rank of a deity; to enroll among the deities; to apotheosize; as, Julius Cæsar was deified .
To esteem worthy; to consider worth notice; -- opposed to disdain .
Devil; -- spelt also deel .
The doctrine or creed of a deist; the belief or system of those who acknowledge the existence of one God, but deny revelation.
One who believes in the existence of a God, but denies revealed religion; a freethinker.
The collection of attributes which make up the nature of a god; divinity; godhead; as, the deity of the Supreme Being is seen in his works .
See Deckle .
Share; portion; part.
A putting off or deferring; procrastination; lingering inactivity; stop; detention; hindrance.
Erase; remove; -- a direction to cancel something which has been put in type; usually expressed by a peculiar form of d , thus: &deletemark_;.
A mine; a quarry; a pit dug; a ditch.
Same as Delftware .
A small, retired valley; a ravine.
The duykerbok.
The drain on the land side of a sea embankment.
The fourth letter of the Greek alphabet (Δ δ), corresponding to D .
The deltoid muscles; -- a contraction used by body-building and health enthusiasts. Used similarly to abs and pecs . See deltoid muscle .
To dig; to open (the ground) as with a spade.
A territorial subdivision of Attica (also of modern Greece), corresponding to a township.
See Demy , n.
To let fall; to depress.
A spirit, or immaterial being, holding a middle place between men and deities in pagan mythology.
To linger; to stay; to tarry.
A printing and a writing paper of particular sizes. See under Paper .
A small cavern or hollow place in the side of a hill, or among rocks; esp., a cave used by a wild beast for shelter or concealment; as, a lion's den ; a den of robbers.
Denial; refusal.
A coarse cotton drilling used for overalls, etc.
Having the constituent parts massed or crowded together; close; compact; thick; containing much matter in a small space; heavy; opaque; as, a dense crowd; a dense forest; a dense fog.
A stroke; a blow.
To declare not to be true; to gainsay; to contradict; -- opposed to affirm , allow , or admit .
A place of deposit for the storing of goods; a warehouse; a storehouse.
The quality of being deep; deepness; perpendicular measurement downward from the surface, or horizontal measurement backward from the front; as, the depth of a river; the depth of a body of troops.
Disorder; merriment.
A race for three-old horses, run annually at Epsom (near London), for the Derby stakes. It was instituted by the 12th Earl of Derby, in 1780.
To hurt; to harm; to injure.
Strong; powerful; fierce.
The integument of animal; the skin.
See Dermis .
A gatepost or doorpost.
To hide; to skulk.
Dearth; scarcity.
to make infertile, especially by removing or incapacitating the sexual organs; -- used of both males and females.
A table, frame, or case, usually with sloping top, but often with flat top, for the use writers and readers. It often has a drawer or repository underneath.
To prevent by fear; hence, to hinder or prevent from action by fear of consequences, or difficulty, risk, etc.
the hospital ward or clinic in which patients are detoxified; -- often used attributively.
A present of books given to a meritorious undergraduate student as a prize.
Two; a card or a die with two spots; as, the deuce of hearts .
See Deuce , Deuced .
A god; a deity; a divine being; an idol; a king.
Bending down; sloping.
; fem . of Deva . A goddess.
The Evil One; Satan, represented as the tempter and spiritual of mankind.

One of a breed of hardy cattle originating in the country of Devon, England. Those of pure blood have a deep red color. The small, longhorned variety, called North Devons , is distinguished by the superiority of its working oxen.
To give up; to devote.
Moisture from the atmosphere condensed by cool bodies upon their surfaces, particularly at night.

A double-walled glass vessel for holding liquid air, liquid nitrogen, etc., having the space between the walls exhausted so as to prevent conduction of heat, and sometimes having the glass silvered to prevent absorption of radiant heat; -- called also, according to the particular shape, Dewar bulb , Dewar tube , etc.
Pertaining to dew; resembling, consisting of, or moist with, dew.
A servant who has charge of the dairy; a dairymaid.
The capital city of Bangladesh . Population (2000) = 3,839,000.
A fierce, wild dog ( Canis Dukhunensis ), found in the mountains of India. It is remarkable for its propensity to hunt the tiger and other wild animals in packs.
A Ceylonese boat. See Doni .
A coasting vessel of Arabia, East Africa, and the Indian Ocean. It has generally but one mast and a lateen sail.

An instrument, formerly much used for showing the time of day from the shadow of a style or gnomon on a graduated arc or surface; esp., a sundial; but there are lunar and astral dials . The style or gnomon is usually parallel to the earth's axis, but the dial plate may be either horizontal or vertical.
The daughter of Jupiter and Latona; a virgin goddess who presided over hunting, chastity, and marriage; -- identified with the Greek goddess Artemis .
A register of daily events or transactions; a daily record; a journal; a blank book dated for the record of daily memoranda; as, a diary of the weather; a physician's diary .
One of the small bones in the knee joints of sheep uniting the bones above and below the joints.
A sweet preparation or treacle of grape juice, much used in the East.
Small cubes used in gaming or in determining by chance; also, the game played with dice. See Die , n.
A player at dice; a dice player; a gamester.
See dickey .
same as dicotyledon .
See Dictum .
imp. of Do .
A kind of triangular spade.
A shrewd trick; an antic; a caper.
the 2d pers. sing. imp. of Do .
See Didymium .

To pass from an animate to a lifeless state; to cease to live; to suffer a total and irreparable loss of action of the vital functions; to become dead; to expire; to perish; -- said of animals and vegetables; often with of , by , with , from , and rarely for , before the cause or occasion of death; as, to die of disease or hardships; to die by fire or the sword; to die with horror at the thought.
Course of living or nourishment; what is eaten and drunk habitually; food; victuals; fare.
To turn up, or delve in, (earth) with a spade or a hoe; to open, loosen, or break up (the soil) with a spade, or other sharp instrument; to pierce, open, or loosen, as if with a spade.
To prepare; to put in order; hence, to dress, or put on; to array; to adorn.
One of the terminal divisions of a limb appendage; a finger or toe.
Worthy; honorable; deserving.
same as diggings .
A bank; a dike.
A kind of food, made from the almondlike seeds of the Irvingia Barteri , much used by natives of the west coast of Africa; -- called also dika bread .
A ditch; a channel for water made by digging.
A burden in popular songs.
An herb ( Peucedanum graveolens ), the seeds of which are moderately warming, pungent, and aromatic, and were formerly used as a soothing medicine for children; -- called also dillseed .
A kind of stagecoach.
Not bright or distinct; wanting luminousness or clearness; obscure in luster or sound; dusky; darkish; obscure; indistinct; overcast; tarnished.
A silver coin of the United States, of the value of ten cents; the tenth of a dollar.
To dismiss, let go, or release.
In a dim or obscure manner; not brightly or clearly; with imperfect sight.
An order of lamellibranchiate mollusks having an anterior and posterior adductor muscle, as the common clam. See Bivalve .
Loud, confused, harsh noise; a loud, continuous, rattling or clanging sound; clamor; roar.
A petty money of accounts of Persia; 100 dinars consituted a rial .
To eat the principal regular meal of the day; to take dinner.
One who dines.
To dash; to throw violently.
A wild dog found in Australia, but supposed to have introduced at a very early period. It has a wolflike face, bushy tail, and a reddish brown color.
Soiled; sullied; of a dark or dusky color; dark brown; dirty.
Trim; neat.
a Nilotic language.
small and insignificant; shabby or unimpressive; as, he drove to work in a dinky old Volkswagen; we stayed in a dinky little hotel .
A blow; a stroke.
A vase or drinking cup having two handles or ears.
To plunge or immerse; especially, to put for a moment into a liquid; to insert into a fluid and withdraw again.
Ill-boding; portentous; as, dire omens .
A piece of music of a mournful character, to accompany funeral rites; a funeral hymn.
A kind of dagger or poniard; -- formerly much used by the Scottish Highlander.
To thrill; to vibrate; to penetrate.
Any foul of filthy substance, as excrement, mud, dust, etc.; whatever, adhering to anything, renders it foul or unclean; earth; as, a wagonload of dirt .
Defiled with dirt; foul; nasty; filthy; not clean or pure; serving to defile; as, dirty hands; dirty water; a dirty white.
The god Pluto, god of the underworld; also called Dis Pater .
any orchid of the genus Disa , a genus of beautiful orchids with dark green leaves and usually hooded flowers; -- they are much prized as emblematic flowers in their native regions.
A flat round plate
A vessel, as a platter, a plate, a bowl, used for serving up food at the table.
good-looking; -- used of persons.
A discus; a quoit.
A tenth; a tenth part; a tithe.
A word; a decree.

A trench made in the earth by digging, particularly a trench for draining wet land, for guarding or fencing inclosures, or for preventing an approach to a town or fortress. In the latter sense, it is called also a moat or a fosse .
To prepare for action or use; to make ready; to dight.
See Dit , n. , 2.
The aforesaid thing; the same (as before). Often contracted to do. , or to two “turned commas” (”), or small marks. Used in bills, books of account, tables of names, etc., to save repetition.
A saying or utterance; especially, one that is short and frequently repeated; a theme.
A prima donna.
A book; esp., a collection of poems written by one author; as, the divan of Hafiz .
To plunge into water head foremost; to thrust the body under, or deeply into, water or other fluid.
To rend apart.
One who, or that which, dives.
The name popularly given to the rich man in our Lord's parable of the “Rich Man and Lazarus” ( Luke xvi. 19-31 ). Hence, a name for a rich worldling.
See Divot .
A thin, oblong turf used for covering cottages, and also for fuel.
a dividend, especially one paid by a cooperative society.
A colloquial name for the Southern portion of the United States, esp. during the Civil War.
To dress; to attire.
To make dizzy; to astonish; to puzzle.
Having in the head a sensation of whirling, with a tendency to fall; vertiginous; giddy; hence, confused; indistinct.
same as disc jockey .
The Dow Jones Industrial Average .
abbreviation for deoxyribonucleic acid ; -- more commonly used than the full name. See also RNA .
any of numerous enzymes that catalyze the breakdown of DNA into oligonucleotides or mononucleotides.
An abbreviation of Ditto .
A tongue or tract of land included between two rivers; as, the doab between the Ganges and the Jumna .
An apparatus resembling a Jacquard for weaving small figures (usually about 12 - 16 threads, seldom more than 36 - 40 threads).
A genus of plants ( Rumex ), some species of which are well-known weeds which have a long taproot and are difficult of extermination.

the United States Department of Defense, the federal department responsible for safeguarding national security; created in 1947. It includes within its jurisdiction control of the Army, Navy, Air Force, and Marines.
To cut off, as wool from sheep's tails; to lop or clip off.
To start suddenly aside, as to avoid a blow or a missile; to shift place by a sudden start.

A large, extinct bird ( Didus ineptus ), formerly inhabiting the Island of Mauritius. It had short, half-fledged wings, like those of the ostrich, and a short neck and legs; -- called also dronte . It was related to the pigeons.
A female deer or antelope; specifically, the female of the fallow deer, of which the male is called a buck . Also applied to the female of other animals, as the rabbit. See the Note under Buck .
One who does; one who performs or executes; one who is wont and ready to act; an actor; an agent.
The 3d pers. sing. pres. of Do .
To put off, as dress; to divest one's self of; hence, figuratively, to put or thrust away; to rid one's self of.
A quadruped of the genus Canis , esp. the domestic dog ( Canis familiaris ).
Of or pertaining to a doge.
The chief magistrate in the republics of Venice and Genoa.
a motherless calf in a range herd of cattle.
a motherless calf in a range herd of cattle.
That which is held as an opinion; a tenet; a doctrine.
a motherless calf in a range herd of cattle.
the syllable naming the first (tonic) note of any major diatonic scale in solmization, usually written do .
The capital city of Qatar . Population (2000) = 300,000.
A kind of woolen stuff.
Anything done; a deed; an action good or bad; hence, in the plural, conduct; behavior. See Do .
A small Dutch coin, worth about half a farthing; also, a similar small coin once used in Scotland; hence, any small piece of money.
See Lepidosiren .
Softly; sweetly; with soft, smooth, and delicate execution.
grief; sorrow; lamentation.
imp. of Delve .
a small, usually flexible figure representing a human being, especially a toy baby for a little girl; a child's puppet.
A contrivance, turning on a vertical axis by a handle or winch, and giving a circular motion to the ore to be washed; a stirrer.

a dish composed of well-seasoned rice (with nuts or currants of minced lamb) simmered or braised in stock, stuffed into tomatoes or green peppers, or wrapped in grape leaves; -- popular in the near east.
Pain; grief; distress; anguish.
A heavy, stupid fellow; a blockhead; a numskull; an ignoramus; a dunce; a dullard.
Evil intent, embracing both malice and fraud. See Culpa .
A title anciently given to the pope, and later to other church dignitaries and to some monastic orders. See Don , and Dan .
Pertaining to a house.
A building; a house; an edifice; -- used chiefly in poetry.
Furnished with a dome; shaped like a dome.
Sir; Mr; Signior; -- a title in Spain, formerly given to noblemen and gentlemen only, but now common to all classes.
the Teutonic god of thunder; counterpart of Norse Thor.
A canelike grass of southern Europe ( Arundo Donax ), used for fishing rods, etc.
p. p. from Do , and formerly the infinitive.
The person to whom a gift or donation is made.
Same as Donat . Piers Plowman .
A clumsy craft, having one mast with a long sail, used for trading purposes on the coasts of Coromandel and Ceylon.
A lady; madam; mistress; -- the title given a lady in Italy.
One who gives or bestows; one who confers anything gratuitously; a benefactor. Inverse of recipient .
Sorrow; dole.
A kind of litter suspended from men's shoulders, for carrying persons or things; a palanquin.
Judgment; judicial sentence; penal decree; condemnation.
An opening in the wall of a house or of an apartment, by which to go in and out; an entrance way.
A little copper cup in which a diamond is held while being cut.
Any thick liquid or pasty preparation, as of opium for medicinal purposes, of grease for a lubricant, etc.
stupid; as, a dopy kid .

A large European scaraboid beetle ( Geotrupes stercorarius ), which makes a droning noise while flying. The name is also applied to allied American species, as the June bug . Called also dorr , dorbeetle , or dorrbeetle , dorbug , dorrfly , and buzzard clock .
A European marine fish ( Zeus faber ), of a yellow color. See Illust. of John Doree .
Pertaining to Doris, in ancient Greece, or to the Dorians; as, the Doric dialect .
A genus of nudibranchiate mollusks having a wreath of branchiæ on the back.
a person who is stupid, socially inept, or ridiculous; -- always used disparagingly.
stupid, socially inept, unfashionable, or ridiculous; -- always used disparagingly.
a dormitory.
Up, or ahead, as many holes as remain to be played; -- said of a player or side.
A British ray; the thornback.
The dorbeetle; also, a drone or an idler. See 1st Dor .
Same as dorsal , n.
A European fish. See Doree , and John Doree .
The quantity of medicine given, or prescribed to be taken, at one time.
Same as Dorsal , n.
A place to sleep in; a bed; hence, sleep.
A marriage portion; dowry.
Pertaining to dower, or a woman's marriage portion; constituting dower, or comprised in it.
A marriage portion. [Obs.] See 1st Dot , n.
Stupid; foolish.
One who dotes; a man whose understanding is enfeebled by age; a dotard.
Composed of, or characterized by, dots.
Half-rotten; as, doty timber .
A village composed of Arab tents arranged in streets.

To waver in opinion or judgment; to be in uncertainty as to belief respecting anything; to hesitate in belief; to be undecided as to the truth of the negative or the affirmative proposition; to b e undetermined.
A monkey ( Semnopithecus nemæus ), remarkable for its varied and brilliant colors. It is a native of Cochin China.
Sweet; pleasant.
Paste of bread; a soft mass of moistened flour or meal, kneaded or unkneaded, but not yet baked; as, to knead dough .
The carrion crow.
Hard; inflexible; obstinate; sour in aspect; hardy; bold.
sorghums of dry regions of Asia and North Africa; A kind of millet. See Durra .
To plunge suddenly into water; to duck; to immerse; to dowse.
To put out.
A pigeon of the genus Columba and various related genera. The species are numerous.
A kind of vessel. See Dhow .
Showing a vulgar taste in dress; awkward and slovenly in dress; vulgar-looking.
A pin, or block, of wood or metal, fitting into holes in the abutting portions of two pieces, and being partly in one piece and partly in the other, to keep them in their proper relative position.
That with which one is gifted or endowed; endowment; gift.
Same as Dowle .
Feathery or wool-like down; filament of a feather.
Fine, soft, hairy outgrowth from the skin or surface of animals or plants, not matted and fleecy like wool
Covered with down, or with pubescence or soft hairs.
A gift; endowment.
To plunge, or duck into water; to immerse; to douse.
A loose wench; a disreputable sweetheart.
Lit., a dean; the senior member of a body or group; as, the doyen of French physicians .
See Doily .
To slumber; to sleep lightly; to be in a dull or stupefied condition, as if half asleep; to be drowsy.
A collection of twelve objects; a tale or set of twelve; with or without of before the substantive which follows.
One who dozes or drowses.
Drowsy; inclined to doze; sleepy; sluggish; as, a dozy head .
Doctor of Philosophy, a British doctorate.
abbreviation for doctor , a title accorded to a person who holds a doctorate degree from an academic institution, such as a Ph.D. degree or M.D. degree.
A low, sluttish woman.
The Dragon, a northern constellation within which is the north pole of the ecliptic.
Refuse; lees; dregs; the wash given to swine or cows; hogwash; waste matter.
The act of drawing; also, the thing drawn. Same as Draught .
A confection; a comfit; a drug.
To trail; to draggle.
To draw off by degrees; to cause to flow gradually out or off; hence, to cause the exhaustion of.
The male of the duck kind.
A weight; in Apothecaries' weight , one eighth part of an ounce, or sixty grains; in Avoirdupois weight , one sixteenth part of an ounce, or 27.34375 grains.

A composition, in prose or poetry, accommodated to action, and intended to exhibit a picture of human life, or to depict a series of grave or humorous actions of more than ordinary interest, tending toward some striking result. It is commonly designed to be spoken and represented by actors on the stage.
Wild oats, or darnel grass. See Drake a plant.
To cover or adorn with drapery or folds of cloth, or as with drapery; as, to drape a bust, a building, etc.
old imp. of Drive .
To cause to move continuously by force applied in advance of the thing moved; to pull along; to haul; to drag; to cause to follow.
To utter in a slow, lengthened tone.
See Draw , v. t. & i.
A squirrel's nest.
To fear in a great degree; to regard, or look forward to, with terrific apprehension.
The thoughts, or series of thoughts, or imaginary transactions, which occupy the mind during sleep; a sleeping vision.
Dismal; gloomy with solitude.
To endure; to suffer.

Corrupt or defiling matter contained in a liquid, or precipitated from it; refuse; feculence; lees; grounds; sediment; hence, the vilest and most worthless part of anything; as, the dregs of society .
Drenched; drowned.
To direct; to put right or straight; to regulate; to order.
A squirrel's nest. See Dray .
To do by little and little
imp. & p. p. of Dry . Also adj. ; as, dried apples .
One who, or that which, dries; that which may expel or absorb moisture; a desiccative; as, the sun and a northwesterly wind are great driers of the earth .
A driving; a violent movement.
To pierce or bore with a drill, or a with a drill; to perforate; as, to drill a hole into a rock; to drill a piece of metal.
See Dryly .
To swallow anything liquid, for quenching thirst or other purpose; to imbibe; to receive or partake of, as if in satisfaction of thirst; as, to drink from a spring .
To fall in drops; as, water drips from the eaves .

To impel or urge onward by force in a direction away from one, or along before one; to push forward; to compel to move on; to communicate motion to; as, to drive cattle; to drive a nail; smoke drives persons from a room.
A water course.
To work sluggishly or slowly; to plod.
A right; law in its aspect of the foundation of rights; also, in old law, the writ of right.
Queer, and fitted to provoke laughter; ludicrous from oddity; amusing and strange.
The crab plover ( Dromas ardeola ), a peculiar North African bird, allied to the oyster catcher.
The male of bees, esp. of the honeybee. It gathers no honey. See Honeybee .
Like a drone; sluggish; lazy.
To drivel, or drop saliva; as, the child drools .
To hang bending downward; to sink or hang down, as an animal, plant, etc., from physical inability or exhaustion, want of nourishment, or the like.
The quantity of fluid which falls in one small spherical mass; a liquid globule; a minim; hence, also, the smallest easily measured portion of a fluid; a small quantity; as, a drop of water .
imp. & p. p. of Drop , v.
The scum or refuse matter which is thrown off, or falls from, metals in smelting the ore, or in the process of melting; recrement.
A collection of cattle driven, or cattle collected for driving; a number of animals, as oxen, sheep, or swine, driven in a body.
Turbid; muddy; filthy.
To be suffocated in water or other fluid; to perish in water.
To beat with a stick; to thrash; to cudgel.
To drudge; to toil laboriously.
One of an order of priests which in ancient times existed among certain branches of the Celtic race, especially among the Gauls and Britons.

An instrument of percussion, consisting either of a hollow cylinder, over each end of which is stretched a piece of skin or vellum, to be beaten with a stick; or of a metallic hemisphere (kettledrum) with a single piece of skin to be so beaten; the common instrument for marking time in martial music; one of the pair of tympani in an orchestra, or cavalry band.
Intoxicated with, or as with, strong drink; inebriated; drunken; -- never used attributively , but always predicatively ; as, the man is drunk (not, a drunk man) .

A fruit consisting of pulpy, coriaceous, or fibrous exocarp, without valves, containing a nut or stone with a kernel. The exocarp is succulent in the plum, cherry, apricot, peach, etc.; dry and subcoriaceous in the almond; and fibrous in the cocoanut.
A cavity in a rock, having its interior surface studded with crystals and sometimes filled with water; a geode.
Covered with a large number of minute crystals.

Free from moisture; having little humidity or none; arid; not wet or moist; deficient in the natural or normal supply of moisture, as rain or fluid of any kind; -- said especially: (a) Of the weather: Free from rain or mist.
A wood nymph; a nymph whose life was bound up with that of her tree.
See Drier .
In a dry manner; not succulently; without interest; without sympathy; coldly.
A union of two; duality.
Expressing, or consisting of, the number two; belonging to two; as, the dual number of nouns, etc. , in Greek.
A division of a poem corresponding to a canto; a poem or song.
To confer knighthood upon; as, the king dubbed his son Henry a knight .
The Syrian bear. See under Bear .
Of or pertaining to a duke.
A coin, either of gold or silver, of several countries in Europe; originally, one struck in the dominions of a duke.
The territory or dominions of a duke; a dukedom.
A pet; a darling.
fine; satisfactory; excellent.
Any tube or canal by which a fluid or other substance is conducted or conveyed.
A kind of dandy; especially, one characterized by an ultrafashionable style of dress and other affectations.
Old or inferior clothes; tattered garments.
Owed, as a debt; that ought to be paid or done to or for another; payable; owing and demandable.
A combat between two persons, fought with deadly weapons, by agreement. It usually arises from an injury done or an affront given by one to the other.
A duel; also, the rules of dueling.
A composition for two performers, whether vocal or instrumental.
Dough or paste.
A teat, pap, or nipple; -- formerly that of a human mother, now that of a cow or other beast.
A leader; a chief; a prince.
To make sweet; to soothe.
An inferior kind of veneration or worship, given to the angels and saints as the servants of God.
Slow of understanding; wanting readiness of apprehension; stupid; doltish; blockish.
In a dull manner; stupidly; slowly; sluggishly; without life or spirit.
A seaweed of a reddish brown color, which is sometimes eaten, as in Scotland. The true dulse is Sarcophyllis edulis ; the common is Rhodymenia . [Written also dillisk. ]
In a due, fit, or becoming manner; as it (anything) ought to be; properly; regularly.
Pertaining to, or set with, briers or bushes; brambly.
Destitute of the power of speech; unable; to utter articulate sounds; as, the dumb brutes .
Silent; mute; noiseless; as a dummy engine.
A thick, ill-shapen piece; a clumsy leaden counter used by boys in playing chuck farthing.
a gloomy mental state; same as 2nd dump{1} ; -- used mostly in the phrase “in the dumps ”.
Short and thick; of low stature and disproportionately stout.
A mound or small hill.
One backward in book learning; a child or other person dull or weak in intellect; a dullard; a dolt.
A low hill of drifting sand usually formed on the coats, but often carried far inland by the prevailing winds.
The excrement of an animal.
Full of dung; filthy; vile; low.
A slang shortening of I don't know or don't know ; as, dunno where I lost my keys; Where'd he go? I dunno. .
Deaf; stupid.
A composition for two performers; a duet.
A cathedral. See Dome , 2.
To open; as, to dup the door .
One who has been deceived or who is easily deceived; a gull; as, the dupe of a schemer .
One who dupes another.
Major; in the major mode; as, C dur , that is, C major .
Short form for Dura mater .
Pertaining to the dura, or dura mater.
Hard; harsh; severe; rough; toilsome.
Same as Doorga .
A fruit tree ( Durio zibethinus , the only species known) of the Indian Archipelago. It bears the durian .
A kind of millet, cultivated throughout Asia, and introduced into the south of Europe; a variety of Sorghum vulgare ; -- called also Indian millet , and Guinea corn .
of Dare . See Dare , v. i.
A demon or spirit. See Deuce .
Tending to darkness or blackness; moderately dark or black; dusky.
Partially dark or obscure; not luminous; dusk; as, a dusky valley .
Fine, dry particles of earth or other matter, so comminuted that they may be raised and wafted by the wind; that which is crumbled to minute portions; fine powder; as, clouds of dust ; bone dust .
Filled, covered, or sprinkled with dust; clouded with dust; as, a dusty table; a dusty attic ; also, reducing to dust.
Pertaining to Holland, or to its inhabitants.
That which is due; payment.
The scholastic name for the theme or subject of a fugue, the answer being called the comes , or companion.
The deadly nightshade ( Atropa Belladonna ), having stupefying qualities.
A piece of wood set between two studs, posts, etc., to stiffen and support them.
An animal or plant which is much below the ordinary size of its species or kind.
To be delirious.
To delay; to linger.
To waste away; to pine; to languish.
the chemical symbol for dysprosium, a rare earth element of atomic number 66.
Two units treated as one; a couple; a pair.
The aboriginal and most numerous inhabitants of Borneo. They are partially civilized, but retain many barbarous practices.
A name applied in Germany to the Permian formation, there consisting of two principal groups.
the Hindu god of the sky.
To stain; to color; to give a new and permanent color to, as by the application of dyestuffs.
colored or impregnated with dye.
One whose occupation is to dye cloth and the like.
In the act of dying; destined to death; mortal; perishable; as, dying bodies .
See Dike . The spelling dyke is restricted by some to the geological meaning.
A unit of measure for dynamical effect or work; a foot pound. See Foot pound .
The unit of force, in the C. G. S. (Centimeter Gram Second) system of physical units; that is, the force which, acting on a gram for a second, generates a velocity of a centimeter per second.
the Akkadian god of wisdom; son of Apsu and father of Marduk; counterpart of the Sumerian Enki.
Every one of the two or more individuals composing a number of objects, considered separately from the rest. It is used either with or without a following noun; as, each of you or each one of you .
Sharp; sour; acid.

Any large, rapacious bird of the Falcon family, esp. of the genera Aquila and Haliæetus . The eagle is remarkable for strength, size, graceful figure, keenness of vision, and extraordinary flight. The most noted species are the golden eagle ( Aquila chrysaëtus ); the imperial eagle of Europe ( Aquila mogilnik or Aquila imperialis ); the American bald eagle ( Haliæetus leucocephalus ); the European sea eagle ( Haliæetus albicilla ); and the great harpy eagle ( Thrasaetus harpyia ). The figure of the eagle, as the king of birds, is commonly used as an heraldic emblem, and also for standards and emblematic devices. See Bald eagle , Harpy , and Golden eagle .
A wave, or two or three successive waves, of great height and violence, at flood tide moving up an estuary or river; -- commonly called the bore or tidal bore . See Bore .
To bring forth, as young; to yean.
The organ of hearing; the external ear.
Receiving by the ear.
Having (such or so many) ears; -- used in composition; as, long- eared-eared ; sharp- eared ; full- eared ; ten- eared .

A nobleman of England ranking below a marquis, and above a viscount. The rank of an earl corresponds to that of a count ( comte ) in France, and graf in Germany. Hence the wife of an earl is still called countess. See Count .
Soon; in good season; seasonably; betimes; as, come early .
See Ern , n.
See Arrish .
The globe or planet which we inhabit; the world, in distinction from the sun, moon, or stars. Also, this world as the dwelling place of mortals, in distinction from the dwelling place of spirits.
Satisfaction; pleasure; hence, accommodation; entertainment.
made less severe or intense; mitigated.
A frame (commonly) of wood serving to hold a canvas upright, or nearly upright, for the painter's convenience or for exhibition.

The point in the heavens where the sun is seen to rise at the equinox, or the corresponding point on the earth; that one of the four cardinal points of the compass which is in a direction at right angles to that of north and south, and which is toward the right hand of one who faces the north; the point directly opposite to the west.
At ease; free from pain, trouble, or constraint
To chew and swallow as food; to devour; -- said especially of food not liquid; as, to eat bread .
ingested through the mouth. Contrasted with uneaten .
One who, or that which, eats.
Easy or easily.
The edges or lower borders of the roof of a building, which overhang the walls, and cast off the water that falls on the roof.
The European bunting.
The prince of the evil spirits; Satan.
Consisting of ebony.
A hard, heavy, and durable wood, which admits of a fine polish or gloss. The usual color is black, but it also occurs red or green.
The European green woodpecker; -- also called ecall , eaquall , yaffle .
A sound reflected from an opposing surface and repeated to the ear of a listener; repercussion of sound; repetition of a sound.
Brilliancy of success or effort; splendor; brilliant show; striking effect; glory; renown.
Toward the outside or surface; -- opposed to entad .
Pertaining to, or situated near, the surface; outer; -- opposed to ental .

A mild Dutch pressed cheese of yellow color and fine flavor, made in balls weighing three or four pounds, and usually colored crimson outside; -- so called from the village of Edam, near Amsterdam. Also, cheese of the same type, wherever made.
The religious or mythological book of the old Scandinavian tribes of German origin, containing two collections of Sagas (legends, myths) of the old northern gods and heroes.
An adder or serpent.
A current of air or water running back, or in a direction contrary to the main current.
Same as œdema .
The garden where Adam and Eve first dwelt; hence, a delightful region or residence.
The thin cutting side of the blade of an instrument; as, the edge of an ax, knife, sword, or scythe .
having a specified kind of border or edge; as, a black- edged card; dried sweat left salt- edged patches .
Easily irritated; sharp; as, an edgy temper .
The name of the Anglo-Saxon letter ð, capital form Ð. It is sounded as “English th in a similar word: ōðer, other, dôð, doth.”

A public command or ordinance by the sovereign power; the proclamation of a law made by an absolute authority, as if by the very act of announcement; a decree; as, the edicts of the Roman emperors; the edicts of the French monarch.
To build; to construct.
See ædile .
To superintend the publication of; to revise and prepare for publication; to select, correct, arrange, etc., the matter of, for publication; as, to edit a newspaper .
To bring or draw out; to cause to appear; to produce against counter agency or influence; to extract; to evolve; as, to educe a form from matter .
That which is educed, as by analysis.

An elongated fish of many genera and species. The common eels of Europe and America belong to the genus Anguilla . The electrical eel is a species of Gymnotus . The so called vinegar eel is a minute nematode worm. See Conger eel , Electric eel , and Gymnotus .
The old plural of Eye .
Serving to inspire fear, esp. a dread of seeing ghosts; wild; weird; as, eerie stories .
imp. of Eat .
The common newt; -- called also asker , eft , evat , and ewt .
A European lizard of the genus Seps .
An exclamation expressing exultation or surprise, etc.
Equal; impartial.
See Ægean .
Sharp; bitter; acid; sour.
To cast or throw out; to void, as excrement; to excrete, as the indigestible matter of the food; in an extended sense, to excrete by the lungs, skin, or kidneys.
The oval or roundish body laid by domestic poultry and other birds, tortoises, etc. It consists of a yolk, usually surrounded by the “white” or albumen, and inclosed in a shell or strong membrane.
Any bombycid moth of the genera Eriogaster and Lasiocampa ; as, the oak eggar ( L. roboris ) of Europe.
One who gathers eggs; an eggler.

The conscious and permanent subject of all psychical experiences, whether held to be directly known or the product of reflective thought; the subject consciously considered as “I” by a person; -- opposed to non-ego .
See Eager , and Eagre .

The name of several species of herons which bear plumes on the back. They are generally white. Among the best known species are the American egret ( Ardea egretta syn. Herodias egretta ); the great egret ( Ardea alba ); the little egret ( Ardea garzetta ), of Europe; and the American snowy egret ( Ardea candidissima ).
a country at the northeastern corner of Africa. At one time it was joined with Syria to form the United Arab Republic .
An expression of inquiry or slight surprise.

Any species of sea duck of the genus Somateria , esp. Somateria mollissima , which breeds in the northern parts of Europe and America, and lines its nest with fine down (taken from its own body) which is an article of commerce; -- called also eider duck . The American eider ( S. Dresseri ), the king eider ( S. spectabilis ), and the spectacled eider ( Arctonetta Fischeri ) are related species.
An exclamation expressing delight.
An island in a river; an ait.
Eldest; firstborn.
An image or effigy; -- used rather in an abstract sense, and rarely for a work of art.
the Irish name for Ireland; the name used in 1937 to 1949 for the Republic of Ireland.
See Aerie , and Eyrie .
Vinegar; verjuice.
To expel; to dismiss; to cast forth; to thrust or drive out; to discharge; as, to eject a person from a room; to eject a traitor from the country; to eject words from the language.
Gomuti fiber. See Gomuti .

To increase; to add to; to augment; -- now commonly used with out , the notion conveyed being to add to, or piece out by a laborious, inferior, or scanty addition; as, to eke out a scanty supply of one kind with some other .
A lengthening or filling piece to make good a deficiency in length.
A species of large South African antelope ( Oreas canna ). It is valued both for its hide and flesh, and is rapidly disappearing in the settled districts; -- called also Cape elk .
A genus of venomous snakes found both in America and the Old World. Many species are known. See Coral snake , under Coral .
To raise; to exalt.
Olefiant gas or ethylene; -- so called by Berzelius from its forming an oil combining with chlorine. [Written also elayle .] See Ethylene .
The joint or bend of the arm; the outer curve in the middle of the arm when bent.
Age; esp., old age.
Older; more aged, or existing longer.
Chosen; taken by preference from among two or more.
A mournful or plaintive poem; a funereal song; a poem of lamentation.

A fragrant gum resin obtained chiefly from tropical trees of the genera Amyris and Canarium . Amyris elemifera yields Mexican elemi; Canarium commune , the Manila elemi. It is used in the manufacture of varnishes, also in ointments and plasters.

An imaginary supernatural being, commonly a little sprite, much like a fairy; a mythological diminutive spirit, supposed to haunt hills and wild places, and generally represented as delighting in mischievous tricks.
Relating to elves.
To break or dash in pieces; to demolish; as, to elide the force of an argument .
To extract.

A large deer, of several species. The European elk Alces alces (formerly Alces machlis or Cervus alces ) is closely allied to the American moose. The American elk, or wapiti ( Cervus Canadensis ) the largest member of the deer family, has large, spreading antlers and is closely related to the European stag. See Moose , and Wapiti .
A measure for cloth; -- now rarely used. It is of different lengths in different countries; the English ell being 45 inches, the Dutch or Flemish ell 27, the Scotch about 37.

A tree of the genus Ulmus , of several species, much used as a shade tree, particularly in America. The English elm is Ulmus campestris ; the common American or white elm is U. Americana ; the slippery or red elm, U. fulva .
Belonging to elms.
Abounding with elms.
See Eloign .
To lengthen out; to prolong.

To run away, or escape privately, from the place or station to which one is bound by duty; -- said especially of a woman or a man, either married or unmarried, who runs away with a paramour or a sweetheart.
A genus of fishes. See Saury .
Other; one or something beside; as, Who else is coming? What else shall I give? Do you expect anything else ?
A shoemaker's awl.

To avoid slyly, by artifice, stratagem, or dexterity; to escape from in a covert manner; to mock by an unexpected escape; to baffle; as, to elude an officer; to elude detection, inquiry, search, comprehension; to elude the force of an argument or a blow.
The sixth month of the Jewish year, by the sacred reckoning, or the twelfth, by the civil reckoning, corresponding nearly to the month of September.
To wash out.
Pertaining to elves; elvish.
An old form of Elf.
A young eel; a young conger or sea eel; -- called also elvene .
The portion of a line formerly occupied by the letter m , then a square type, used as a unit by which to measure the amount of printed matter on a page; the square of the body of a type.
To bar or shut in; to inclose securely, as with bars.
To bathe; to soothe or lull as by bathing.
To lay as in a bed; to lay in surrounding matter; to bed; as, to embed a thing in clay, mortar, or sand .
A lighted coal, smoldering amid ashes; -- used chiefly in the plural, to signify mingled coals and ashes; the smoldering remains of a fire.
To bend like a bow; to curve.
To inclose, as in a box; to imbox.
Same as Emir .
To purge of faults; to make better; to correct; esp., to make corrections in (a literary work); to alter for the better by textual criticism, generally verbal.
Corundum in the form of grains or powder, used in the arts for grinding and polishing hard substances. Native emery is mixed with more or less magnetic iron. See the Note under Corundum .
An abbreviation for electro-motive force .

An Arabian military commander, independent chieftain, or ruler of a province; also, an honorary title given to the descendants of Mohammed, in the line of his daughter Fatima; among the Turks, likewise, a title of dignity, given to certain high officials.
To send forth; to throw or give out; to cause to issue; to give vent to; to eject; to discharge; as, fire emits heat and smoke; boiling water emits steam; the sun emits light.
a hard red wheat ( Triticum dicoccum ) grown especially in Russia and Germany; also grown in the U. S. as stock feed.
To mew or coop up.

Containing nothing; not holding or having anything within; void of contents or appropriate contents; not filled; -- said of an inclosure, or a container, as a box, room, house, etc.; as, an empty chest, room, purse, or pitcher; an empty stomach; empty shackles.
A large Australian bird, of two species ( Dromaius Novæ-Hollandiæ and D. irroratus ), related to the cassowary and the ostrich. The emu runs swiftly, but is unable to fly.
To emulate.
A fresh-water tortoise of the family Emydidæ .
Half an em, that is, half of the unit of space in measuring printed matter. See Em .
To decree; to establish by legal and authoritative act; to make into a law; especially, to perform the legislative act with reference to (a bill) which gives it the validity of law.
Growing out.

The extreme or last point or part of any material thing considered lengthwise (the extremity of breadth being side ); hence, extremity, in general; the concluding part; termination; close; limit; as, the end of a field, line, pole, road; the end of a year, of a discourse; put an end to pain ; -- opposed to beginning , when used of anything having a first part.
One who, or that which, makes an end of something; as, the ender of my life .

To furnish with money or its equivalent, as a permanent fund for support; to make pecuniary provision for; to settle an income upon; especially, to furnish with dower; as, to endow a wife; to endow a public institution.
An older spelling of Endow .
Same as Æneid .
An injection, or clyster, thrown into the rectum as a medicine, or to impart nourishment.
One hostile to another; one who hates, and desires or attempts the injury of, another; a foe; an adversary; as, an enemy of or to a person; an enemy to truth, or to falsehood.
A favorite; a paramour; an ingle.
Variant of Engine .
To take pleasure or satisfaction in the possession or experience of; to feel or perceive with pleasure; to be delighted with; as, to enjoy the dainties of a feast; to enjoy conversation.
See Inlay .
See Emmew .
To make new.
A feeling of weariness and disgust; dullness and languor of spirits, arising from satiety or want of interest; tedium.
To clear of knots; to make clear.
A form of Enough .
Entity, being, or existence; an actually existing being; also, God, as the Being of Beings.
a genus of bivalve mollusks consisting of razor clams.
To place in the sky or in heaven.
To follow; to pursue; to follow and overtake.
Toward the inside or central part; away from the surface; -- opposed to ectad .
Pertaining to, or situated near, central or deep parts; inner; -- opposed to ectal .

To come or go into; to pass into the interior of; to pass within the outer cover or shell of; to penetrate; to pierce; as, to enter a house, a closet, a country, a door, etc.; the river enters the sea.

The act of entering or passing into or upon; entrance; ingress; hence, beginnings or first attempts; as, the entry of a person into a house or city; the entry of a river into the sea; the entry of air into the blood; an entry upon an undertaking.
See Inure .
To vie; to emulate; to strive.

One dispatched upon an errand or mission; a messenger; esp., a person deputed by a sovereign or a government to negotiate a treaty, or transact other business, with a foreign sovereign or government; a minister accredited to a foreign government. An envoy's rank is below that of an ambassador.
Malice; ill will; spite.
See æolic .
A genus of nudibranch mollusks having clusters of branchial papillæ along the back. See Ceratobranchia .
An immeasurable or infinite space of time; eternity; a long space of time; an age.
Aurora, the goddess of morn.

A yellow or brownish red dyestuff obtained by the action of bromine on fluoresceïn, and named from the fine rose-red which it imparts to silk. It is also used for making a fine red ink. Its solution is fluorescent.
The moon's age at the beginning of the calendar year, or the number of days by which the last new moon has preceded the beginning of the year.
See Epencephalon .
A Hebrew dry measure, supposed to be equal to two pecks and five quarts. Ten ephahs make one homer.

A part of the sacerdotal habit among Jews, being a covering for the back and breast, held together on the shoulders by two clasps or brooches of onyx stones set in gold, and fastened by a girdle of the same stuff as the ephod. The ephod for the priests was of plain linen; that for the high priest was richly embroidered in colors. The breastplate of the high priest was worn upon the ephod in front.
A magistrate; one of a body of five magistrates chosen by the people of ancient Sparta. They exercised control even over the king.

Narrated in a grand style; pertaining to or designating a kind of narrative poem, usually called an heroic poem, in which real or fictitious events, usually the achievements of some hero, are narrated in an elevated style.

A fixed point of time, established in history by the occurrence of some grand or remarkable event; a point of time marked by an event of great subsequent influence; as, the epoch of the creation; the birth of Christ was the epoch which gave rise to the Christian era.
The after song; the part of a lyric ode which follows the strophe and antistrophe, -- the ancient ode being divided into strophe, antistrophe, and epode .
One instructed in the mysteries of a secret system.

Agreeing in quantity, size, quality, degree, value, etc.; having the same magnitude, the same value, the same degree, etc.; -- applied to number, degree, quantity, and intensity, and to any subject which admits of them; neither inferior nor superior, greater nor less, better nor worse; corresponding; alike; as, equal quantities of land, water, etc. ; houses of equal size; persons of equal stature or talents; commodities of equal value.

To furnish for service, or against a need or exigency; to fit out; to supply with whatever is necessary to efficient action in any way; to provide with arms or an armament, stores, munitions, rigging, etc.; -- said esp. of ships and of troops.
A genus of mammals, including the horse, ass, etc.
the chemical symbol for erbium , a rare earth element. It has atomic number 68 and an atomic weight of 167.26.
A fixed point of time, usually an epoch, from which a series of years is reckoned.
To rub or scrape out, as letters or characters written, engraved, or painted; to efface; to expunge; to cross out; as, to erase a word or a name .
The Muse who presided over lyric and amatory poetry.
Before; sooner than.
Upright, or having a vertical position; not inverted; not leaning or bent; not prone; as, to stand erect .
A garden plot, usually about half an acre.

The unit of work or energy in the C. G. S. system, being the amount of work done by a dyne working through a distance of one centimeter; the amount of energy expended in moving a body one centimeter against a force of one dyne (981 dynes exert the same force as a one gram mass in the earth's gravitational field). One foot pound is equal to 13,560,000 ergs. The absolute Joule is equivalent to 10 7 ergs, which are equivalent to 0.2389 gram-calories at 15° C. See also mechanical equivalent of heat under equivalent .
Potential energy; negative value of the force function.
To deduce logically, as conclusions.
Therefore; consequently; -- often used in a jocular way.
Work, measured in terms of the quantity of heat to which it is equivalent.
A diseased condition of rye and other cereals, in which the grains become black, and often spur-shaped. It is caused by a parasitic fungus, Claviceps purpurea .
A genus of shrubby plants, including the heaths, many of them producing beautiful flowers.
An early, and now a poetic, name of Ireland.
To grieve; to feel sad.
An Armenian.
A sea eagle, esp. the European white-tailed sea eagle ( Haliæetus albicilla ).
To eat into or away; to corrode; as, canker erodes the flesh .
Love; the god of love; -- by earlier writers represented as one of the first and creative gods, by later writers as the son of Aphrodite, equivalent to the Latin god Cupid.
Irregular or uneven as if eaten or worn away.
To wander; to roam; to stray.
A wandering; a roving or irregular course.
The bitter vetch ( Ervum Ervilia ).
A name sometimes given to that dialect of the Celtic which is spoken in the Highlands of Scotland; -- called, by the Highlanders, Gaelic .
See Arrish .
An insect in the larval state; a caterpillar; a larva.
To eject, as wind, from the stomach; to belch.
To cause to burst forth; to eject; as, to erupt lava .

the chemical symbol for einsteinium , a transuranic element with atomic number 99. The atomic weight of the longest-lived isotope, with a half-life of 276 days, is 254. The first isotope discovered, having atomic weight 253 and a half-life of 20 days, was recognized in 1952 in the debris from a hydrogen bomb test. As much as 3 micrograms of einsteinium were produced by a complex process involving long irradiation of plutonium isotopes in nuclear reactors. Its chemical properties are those of a trivalent actinide element.
See Scot , a tax.
Ease; pleasure.
See Eschar .
A genus of fresh-water fishes, including pike and pickerel.

To catch sight of; to perceive with the eyes; to discover, as a distant object partly concealed, or not obvious to notice; to see at a glance; to discern unexpectedly; to spy; as, to espy land; to espy a man in a crowd.
An effort made, or exertion of body or mind, for the performance of anything; a trial; attempt; as, to make an essay to benefit a friend .

An ethereal salt, or compound ether, consisting of an organic radical united with the residue of any oxygen acid, organic or inorganic; thus the natural fats are esters of glycerin and the fatty acids, oleic, etc.
To impede or bar by estoppel.
The inward part of a building; the interior.
The blue buck.
A variant of Eddish .
A white waxy solid, C16H33.OH ; -- called also cetyl alcohol and cetylic alcohol . See Cetylic alcohol , under Cetylic .
