A medium of great elasticity and extreme tenuity, once supposed to pervade all space, the interior of solid bodies not excepted, and to be the medium of transmission of light and heat; hence often called luminiferous ether . It is no longer believed that such a medium is required for the transmission of electromagnetic waves; the modern use of the term is mostly a figurative term for empty space , or for literary effect, and not intended to imply the actual existence of a physical medium. However. modern cosmological theories based on quantum field theory do not rule out the possibility that the inherent energy of the vacuum is greater than zero, in which case the concept of an ether pervading the vacuum may have more than metaphoric meaning.
Of, or belonging to, morals; treating of the moral feelings or duties; containing percepts of morality; moral; as, ethic discourses or epistles; an ethical system; ethical philosophy.

The character, sentiment, or disposition of a community or people, considered as a natural endowment; the spirit which actuates manners and customs; also, the characteristic tone or genius of an institution or social organization.
A monatomic, hydrocarbon radical, C2H5 of the paraffin series, forming the essential radical of ethane, and of common alcohol and ether.
A kind of small, portable, cooking apparatus for which heat is furnished by a spirit lamp.
To earn. [Obs.] See Addle , to earn.
See Étui .
See Etymon .
the chemical symbol for Europium, an element with atomic number 63 and atomic weight 151.96.
The east wind.

To get away from by artifice; to avoid by dexterity, subterfuge, address, or ingenuity; to elude; to escape from cleverly; as, to evade a blow, a pursuer, a punishment; to evade the force of an argument .
Relating to time or duration.
Evening. See Eve , n. 1.
That which comes, arrives, or happens; that which falls out; any incident, good or bad.
At any time; at any period or point of time.
To overthrow; to subvert.
All the parts which compose a whole collection or aggregate number, considered in their individuality, all taken separately one by one, out of an indefinite number.
The common newt or eft. In America often applied to several species of aquatic salamanders.
To dispossess by a judicial process; to dispossess by paramount right or claim of such right; to eject; to oust.

Having qualities tending to injury and mischief; having a nature or properties which tend to badness; mischievous; not good; worthless or deleterious; poor; as, an evil beast; and evil plant; an evil crop.
To call out; to summon forth.
The female of the sheep, and of sheeplike animals.
A kind of wide-mouthed pitcher or jug; esp., one used to hold water for the toilet.
An office or place of household service where the ewers were formerly kept.
An ex-wife or ex-husband; a former spouse; -- used usually with a possessive; as, she invited her ex to her second wedding; her ex ; his ex ; John's ex .

Precisely agreeing with a standard, a fact, or the truth; perfectly conforming; neither exceeding nor falling short in any respect; true; correct; precise; as, the clock keeps exact time; he paid the exact debt; an exact copy of a letter; exact accounts.
To raise high; to elevate; to lift up.
To go beyond or surpass in good qualities or laudable deeds; to outdo or outgo, in a good sense.
To run out or forth; to extend.
A license for absence from a college or a religious house.
To cut off or out. [Obs.] See Exsect .
To thrust forth; to emit; to push out.
Forced separation from one's native country; expulsion from one's home by the civil authority; banishment; sometimes, voluntary separation from one's native country.
To be as a fact and not as a mode; to have an actual or real being, whether material or spiritual.
He (or she ) goes out, or retires from view; as, exit Macbeth .
Departure; exodus; esp., the exodus of the Israelites from Egypt.
Exodus; withdrawal.
A native or inhabitant of Exeter, in England.
To drive or force out from that within which anything is contained, inclosed, or situated; to eject; as, to expel air from a bellows .
To place on high; to lift up; to elevate.
Beyond what is due, usual, expected, or necessary; additional; supernumerary; also, extraordinarily good; superior; as, extra work; extra pay.
To discharge through pores or incisions, as moisture or other liquid matter; to give out.
To be in high spirits; figuratively, to leap for joy; to rejoice in triumph or exceedingly; to triumph; as, an exulting heart .
An interj. of wonder or inquiry.
A nesting or unfledged bird; in falconry, a young hawk from the nest, not able to prey for itself.
A brood; as, an eye of pheasants .
Heaving (such or so many) eyes; -- used in composition; as, sharp- eyed ; blue- eyed ; dull- eyed ; sad- eyed ; ox- eyed Juno; myriad- eyed .
One who eyes another.
An island. See Eyot .
An island. See Eyot .
Plural of eye ; -- now obsolete, or used only in poetry.
A little island in a river or lake. See Ait .
A wild cat ( Felis eyra ) ranging from southern Brazil to Texas. It is reddish yellow and about the size of the domestic cat, but with a more slender body and shorter legs.
A journey in circuit of certain judges called justices in eyre (or in itinere ).
See Ey , an egg.
The nest of a bird of prey or other large bird that builds in a lofty place; aerie.
A syllable applied to the fourth tone of the diatonic scale in solmization.
extremely pleasing.
A Feigned story or tale, intended to instruct or amuse; a fictitious narration intended to enforce some useful truth or precept; an apologue. See the Note under Apologue .
A large ornamental letter used, esp. by the early printers, at the commencement of the chapters and other divisions of a book.

The exterior form or appearance of anything; that part which presents itself to the view; especially, the front or upper part or surface; that which particularly offers itself to the view of a spectator.
Having (such) a face, or (so many) faces; as, smooth- faced , two- faced .
One who faces; one who puts on a false show; a bold-faced person.
A little face; a small, plane surface; as, the facets of a diamond .
See Fascia .
A doing, making, or preparing.
In fact; by the act or fact.
A hobby ; freak; whim.
Weak; insipid; tasteless; commonplace.
That has lost freshness, color, or brightness; grown dim.
To fit; to suit; to agree.
A knot or coarse part in cloth; a flaw.
A bundle of sticks, twigs, or small branches of trees, used for fuel, for raising batteries, filling ditches, or other purposes in fortification; a fascine.
The leaves of an orchid ( Angraecum fragrans ), of the islands of Bourbon and Mauritius, used (in France) as a substitute for Chinese tea.
an abbreviation of Fahrenheit ; -- used in designating temperatures; as, 72° Fahr. Used as an alternative to celsius .

To be wanting; to fall short; to be or become deficient in any measure or degree up to total absence; to cease to be furnished in the usual or expected manner, or to be altogether cut off from supply; to be lacking; as, streams fail ; crops fail .
Well-pleased; glad; apt; wont; fond; inclined.
Lacking strength; weak; languid; inclined to swoon; as, faint with fatigue, hunger, or thirst .
Free from spots, specks, dirt, or imperfection; unblemished; clean; pure.
Enchantment; illusion.
Belief; the assent of the mind to the truth of what is declared by another, resting solely and implicitly on his authority and veracity; reliance on testimony.
One of the circles or windings of a cable or hawser, as it lies in a coil; a single turn or coil.
One who fakes something;
an Oriental Muslim or Hindu religious ascetic or begging monk who is regarded as a holy man or a wonder worker.
The razorbill.
To Descend, either suddenly or gradually; particularly, to descend by the force of gravity; to drop; to sink; as, the apple falls ; the tide falls ; the mercury falls in the barometer.
Uttering falsehood; unveracious; given to deceit; dishnest; as, a false witness .
A curved fold or process of the dura mater or the peritoneum; esp., one of the partitionlike folds of the dura mater which extend into the great fissures of the brain.
Public report or rumor.
An instrument used for producing artificial currents of air, by the wafting or revolving motion of a broad surface
A lighthouse, or the apparatus placed in it for giving light.

The faculty by which the mind forms an image or a representation of anything perceived before; the power of combining and modifying such objects into new pictures or images; the power of readily and happily creating and recalling such objects for the purpose of amusement, wit, or embellishment; imagination.
imp. of Find .
A temple; a place consecrated to religion; a church.
To catch; to seize, as with the teeth; to lay hold of; to gripe; to clutch.
A term applied to various articles,

A list of questions and answers concerning a specific topic, such as how to use a particular computer program. Many such lists contain answers to the most commonly asked questions about that topic, however the questions need not derive from actual queries. Such lists are often maintained in electronic form and made available on the World Wide Web.
A young pig, or a litter of pigs.

The standard unit of electrical capacity; the capacity of a condenser whose charge, having an electro-motive force of one volt, is equal to the amount of electricity which, with the same electromotive force, passes through one ohm in one second; the capacity, which, charged with one coulomb, gives an electro-motive force of one volt.
To stuff with forcemeat; hence, to fill with mingled ingredients; to fill full; to stuff.

A contagious disease of horses, associated with painful ulcerating enlargements, esp. upon the head and limbs. It is of the same nature as glanders, and is often fatal. Called also farcin , and farcimen .
Paint used on the face.
To go; to pass; to journey; to travel.
p. p. of Fare , v. i.
Same as Furl .
The rent of land, -- originally paid by reservation of part of its products.
A gambling game at cards, in which all the other players play against the dealer or banker, staking their money upon the order in which the cards will lie and be dealt from the pack.
An addition to, or a paraphrase of, some part of the Latin service in the vernacular; -- common in English before the Reformation.
The language spoken in modern Iran; modern Persian. It is written in the Arabic alphabet.
To vex; to tease; to trouble.
To abstain from food; to omit to take nourishment in whole or in part; to go hungry.
The Roman calendar, which gave the days for festivals, courts, etc., corresponding to a modern almanac.
A large tub, cistern, or vessel; a vat.
Proceeding from, or appointed by, fate or destiny; necessary; inevitable.
A fixed decree by which the order of things is prescribed; the immutable law of the universe; inevitable necessity; the force by which all existence is determined and conditioned.
Decreed by fate; destined; doomed; as, he was fated to rule a factious people .
Grossly; greasily.
a rotund, obese individual.
Containing fat, or having the qualities of fat; greasy; gross; as, a fatty substance .
Same as fetwah .
An exclamation of contempt, disgust, or abhorrence.
The arch over the dam of a blast furnace; the tymp arch.
A fall or falling band.
Defect; want; lack; default.
A god of fields and shepherds, differing little from the satyr. The fauns are usually represented as half goat and half man.
The animals of any given area or epoch; as, the fauna of America; fossil fauna ; recent fauna .

A tragedy by Goethe, commenced in 1772, and published as “Faust, ein Fragment” in 1790. Part 1, complete, was published as "Faust, eine Tragödie" in 1808; part 2, finished in 1831, was published in 1833. It has been translated into English by Bayard Taylor, Blackie, Anster, Hayward, Martin, and others (nearly 40 in all). Goethe accomplished the transformation of Faust from a common necromancer and conjurer into a personification of humanity, tempted and disquieted, but at length groping its way to the light. See Goethe .
See Fauces .
See Favus , n. , 2.
Yellow; fallow; dun.
Kind regard; propitious aspect; countenance; friendly disposition; kindness; good will.
A disease of the scalp, produced by a vegetable parasite.
Fain; glad; delighted.
A young deer; a buck or doe of the first year. See Buck .

A document which is a facsimile of another document, converted into electrical symbols by a facsimile machine at one telephone terminal, transmitted via telephone and printed on some form of paper at a facsimile machine at a second telephone terminal. A document transmitted using a computer at one or both ends may also be called a fax if the transmission protocol is similar to that used by telefax devices, i.e. if the originating or receiving device could be a telefax device.
A fairy; an elf.
To cause to become disconcerted or disturbed. A variant form of Feeze .
Faithful; loyal.
A variant of Fere , a mate, a companion.
A festival; a holiday; a solemn, or more commonly, a joyous, anniversary.
An act; a deed; an exploit.
To untwist; to unravel, as the end of a rope.
Relating to, or containing, dregs, feces, or ordure; fæcal.
Dregs; sediment; excrement. See faeces .
A corruption of the word faith .
imp. & p. p. of Feed .
property; possession; tenure.
To give food to; to supply with nourishment; to satisfy the physical huger of.

To perceive by the touch; to take cognizance of by means of the nerves of sensation distributed all over the body, especially by those of the skin; to have sensation excited by contact of (a thing) with the body or limbs.
A consort, husband or wife; a companion; a fere.
The short run before a leap.
Fact; performance.
To turn, as a screw.
Same as Vehm , Vehmgericht .
To give a mental existence to, as to something not real or actual; to imagine; to invent; hence, to pretend; to form and relate as if true.
Feigned; counterfeit.
See Feeze , v. t.
any of various lithe-bodied round-headed fissiped mammals, many with retractile claws; a member of the Felidae .

A genus of mostly small carnivorous mammals, including the domestic cat, puma, ocelot, and margay, which share the inability to roar due to bone structure in the larynx. The lion, tiger, and other large roaring cats were once included in Felis but are now assigned to the genus Panthera . The lynx ( Felis lynx ) is also called Lynx lynx .
imp. of Fall .
In a fell or cruel manner; fiercely; barbarously; savagely.
A person who has committed a felony.
imp. & p. p. or a. from Feel .
A woman. See Feme , n.
The thigh bone; -- it is the longest and thickest bone of the human skeleton, which extends from the pelvis to the knee.
Low land overflowed, or covered wholly or partially with water, but producing sedge, coarse grasses, or other aquatic plants; boggy land; moor; marsh.
That which fends off attack or danger; a defense; a protection; a cover; security; shield.
To keep off; to prevent from entering or hitting; to ward off; to shut out; -- often with off ; as, to fend off blows .
The refuse whale blubber, used as a manure, and in the manufacture of Prussian blue.
Pertaining to, or inhabiting, a fen; abounding in fens; swampy; boggy.
A feud. See 2d Feud .
To invest with a fee or feud; to give or grant a corporeal hereditament to; to enfeoff.
Wild; untamed; ferine; not domesticated; -- said of beasts, birds, and plants.
imp. of Fare .
A mate or companion; -- often used of a wife.
A week day, esp. a day which is neither a festival nor a fast.
Singular; wonderful; extraordinary.
Rent for a farm; a farm; also, an abode; a place of residence; as, he let his land to ferm .
Ancient; old. [Obs.] “Pilgrimages to . . . ferne halwes.” [saints].
Abounding in ferns.
compar. of Fer .
To carry or transport over a river, strait, or other narrow water, in a boat.
A band drawn horizontally across the center of an escutcheon, and containing in breadth the third part of it; one of the nine honorable ordinaries.
Pertaining to, or connected with, a fetus; as, fetal circulation ; fetal membranes.
To bear toward the person speaking, or the person or thing from whose point of view the action is contemplated; to go and bring; to get.
Having an offensive smell; stinking.
Neat; pretty; well made; graceful.
A strong, offensive smell; stench; fetidness.

The young or embryo of a vertebrate animal in the womb, or in the egg; often restricted to the later stages in the development of viviparous and oviparous animals. showing the main recognizable features of the mature animal, embryo being applied to the earlier stages.
A free and gratuitous right to lands made to one for service to be performed by him; a tenure where the vassal, in place of military services, makes a return in grain or in money.
One who holds a feu.
A combination of kindred to avenge injuries or affronts, done or offered to any of their blood, on the offender and all his race.

A diseased state of the system, marked by increased heat, acceleration of the pulse, and a general derangement of the functions, including usually, thirst and loss of appetite. Many diseases, of which fever is the most prominent symptom, are denominated fevers ; as, typhoid fever ; yellow fever .
Not many; small, limited, or confined in number; -- indicating a small portion of units or individuals constituting a whole; often, by ellipsis of a noun, a few people.
Fated; doomed.
A fair or market.
A felt or cloth cap, usually red and having a tassel, -- a variety of the tarboosh. See Tarboosh .
a corporation authorized by Congress to provide a secondary market for residential mortgages. It is called Freddie Mac in the jargon of the finance industry.
One in whom the property of an estate is vested, subject to the estate of a life renter.
An authoritative command or order to do something; an effectual decree.
A falsehood; a lie; -- used euphemistically.
One of the delicate, threadlike portions of which the tissues of plants and animals are in part constituted; as, the fiber of flax or of muscle .
Same as fiber .
A small dog; -- written also fise , fyce , fiste , etc.
A light cape, usually of lace, worn by women, to cover the neck and throat, and extending to the shoulders.
A fig; an insignificant trifle, no more than the snap of one's thumb; a sign of contempt made by the fingers, expressing. A fig for you .
A genus of trees or shrubs, one species of which ( F. Carica ) produces the figs of commerce; the fig tree.
A square bar of wood or iron, used to support the topmast, being passed through a hole or mortise at its heel, and resting on the trestle trees.
Faith personified as a goddess; the goddess of faith.
See Fidget .
A genus of small beetles, of which one species (the grapevine Fidia, F. longipes ) is very injurious to vines in America.
An exclamation denoting contempt or dislike. See Fy .
An estate held of a superior on condition of military service; a fee; a feud. See under Benefice , n. , 2.
Cleared land; land suitable for tillage or pasture; cultivated ground; the open country.
An implacable or malicious foe; one who is diabolically wicked or cruel; an infernal being; -- applied specifically to the devil or a demon.
Consisting of, containing, or resembling, fire; as, the fiery gulf of Etna; a fiery appearance.
A small shrill pipe, resembling the piccolo flute, used chiefly to accompany the drum in military music.
One who plays on a fife.

an accounting method in which goods in inventory are valued at the price of the most recent acquisition of each type of goods, and those used up from inventory are valued at the cost of those first acquired.
Next in order after the fourth; -- the ordinal of five.
Five times ten; as, fifty men .
A small fruit tree ( Ficus Carica ) with large leaves, known from the remotest antiquity. It was probably native from Syria westward to the Canary Islands.
To strive or contened for victory, with armies or in single combat; to attempt to defeat, subdue, or destroy an enemy, either by blows or weapons; to contend in arms; -- followed by with or against .
imp. of Fall , v. i. Fell.
Of or pertaining to a thread or line; characterized by threads stretched across the field of view; as, a filar microscope; a filar micrometer.
To steal or take privily (commonly, that which is of little value); to pilfer.
An orderly succession; a line; a row
One who works with a file.
One of the thills or shafts of a carriage.
a young unmarried woman.
A female foal or colt; a young mare. Cf. Colt , Foal .
A thin skin; a pellicle; a membranous covering, causing opacity.
Composed of film or films.
Son; -- sometimes used after a French proper name to distinguish a son from his father, as, Alexandre Dumas, fils .
Foul matter; anything that soils or defiles; dirt; nastiness.
To carve or cut up, as a chub.
Pertaining to the end or conclusion; last; terminating; ultimate; as, the final day of a school term .
A small singing bird of many genera and species, belonging to the family Fringillidæ .
To meet with, or light upon, accidentally; to gain the first sight or knowledge of, as of something new, or unknown; hence, to fall in with, as a person.
Full; heavy; firm; solid; substantial.
Finished; brought to perfection; refined; hence, free from impurity; excellent; superior; elegant; worthy of admiration; accomplished; beautiful.
subjected to punishment by a fine.
One who fines or purifies.
An end; conclusion. It is often placed at the end of a book.
A native of Finland; one of the Finn&unr_; in the ethnological sense. See Finns .
Natives of Finland; Finlanders.
Having, or abounding in, fins, as fishes; pertaining to fishes.
Second best wool from Merino sheep.
3d pers. sing. pr. of Find , for findeth .
A narrow inlet of the sea, penetrating between high banks or rocks, as on the coasts of Norway and Alaska.

A genus ( Abies ) of coniferous trees, often of large size and elegant shape, some of them valued for their timber and others for their resin. The species are distinguished as the balsam fir , the silver fir , the red fir , etc. The Scotch fir is a Pinus .
The evolution of light and heat in the combustion of bodies; combustion; state of ignition.
One who fires or sets fire to anything; an incendiary.
To beat; to strike; to chastise.
Fixed; hence, closely compressed; compact; substantial; hard; solid; -- applied to the matter of bodies; as, firm flesh; firm muscles, firm wood.
The principal rafters of a roof, especially a pair of rafters taken together.
Made of fir; abounding in firs.
Preceding all others of a series or kind; the ordinal of one; earliest; as, the first day of a month; the first year of a reign.
An arm of the sea; a frith.
A public or state treasury.
A counter, used in various games.
Consisting of fish; fishlike; having the qualities or taste of fish; abounding in fish.
To run about; to frisk; to whisk.
The hand with the fingers doubled into the palm; the closed hand, especially as clinched tightly for the purpose of striking a blow.
imp. & p. p. of Fight .
The European polecat; also, its fur.
In a fit manner; suitably; properly; conveniently; as, a maxim fitly applied .
See 2d Fit .

A son; -- used in compound names, to indicate paternity, esp. of the illegitimate sons of kings and princes of the blood; as, Fitz roy, the son of the king; Fitz clarence, the son of the duke of Clarence.
Four and one added; one more than four.
A kind of play with a ball against a wall, resembling tennis; -- so named because three fives , or fifteen , are counted to the game.
Fixed; solidified.
Securely placed or fastened; settled; established; firm; imovable; unalterable.
To make a hissing sound, such as that of a burning fuse or a bubbling carbonated beverage.
See Fiord .
Loose or flaccid body fat.
To hang loose without stiffness; to bend down, as flexible bodies; to be loose, yielding, limp.

An instrument for threshing or beating grain from the ear by hand, consisting of a wooden staff or handle, at the end of which a stouter and shorter pole or club, called a swipe, is so hung as to swing freely.
p. p. of Flay .
Smell; odor.
A paling; a hurdle.
Consisting of flakes or of small, loose masses; lying, or cleaving off, in flakes or layers; flakelike.
A freak or whim; also, a falsehood; a lie; an illusory pretext; deception; delusion.
A stream of burning vapor or gas, emitting light and heat; darting or streaming fire; a blaze; a fire.
Flaming; blazing; flamelike; flame-colored; composed of flame.
A miner's two-pointed pick.
The fleshy or muscular part of the side of an animal, between the ribs and the hip. See Illust. of Beef .
Anything broad and limber that hangs loose, or that is attached by one side or end and is easily moved; as, the flap of a garment .
To burn with an unsteady or waving flame; as, the candle flares .
To burst or break forth with a sudden and transient flood of flame and light; as, the lighting flashes vividly; the powder flashed .
A small bottle-shaped vessel for holding fluids; as, a flask of oil or wine .
Having an even and horizontal surface, or nearly so, without prominences or depressions; level without inclination; plane.
A crack or breach; a gap or fissure; a defect of continuity or cohesion; as, a flaw in a knife or a vase .
A sort of flat custard or pie.
Full of flaws or cracks; broken; defective; faulty.

A plant of the genus Linum , esp. the L. usitatissimum , which has a single, slender stalk, about a foot and a half high, with blue flowers. The fiber of the bark is used for making thread and cloth, called linen , cambric , lawn , lace , etc. Linseed oil is expressed from the seed.
Like flax; flaxen.
To skin; to strip off the skin or surface of; as, to flay an ox; to flay the green earth.

An insect belonging to the genus Pulex , of the order Aphaniptera . Fleas are destitute of wings, but have the power of leaping energetically. The bite is poisonous to most persons. The human flea ( Pulex irritans ), abundant in Europe, is rare in America, where the dog flea ( Ctenocephalides canis , formerly Pulex canis ) and the smaller cat flea ( Ctenocephalides felis ) take its place. See Aphaniptera , and Dog flea . See Illustration in Appendix.
A flake; a thread or twist.
A sharp instrument used for opening veins, lancing gums, etc.; a kind of lancet.
See Fleer .
A flake; also, a lock, as of wool.
imp. & p. p. of Flee .
To run away, as from danger or evil; to avoid in an alarmed or cowardly manner; to hasten off; -- usually with from . This is sometimes omitted, making the verb transitive.
Obs. pl. of Flea .
One who flees.
To sail; to float.
To banish; to drive out; to expel.
The aggregate of the muscles, fat, and other tissues which cover the framework of bones in man and other animals; especially, the muscles.
To float; to swim.
imp. of Fly .
The pendulous or overhanging lateral parts of the upper lip of dogs, especially prominent in hounds; -- called also chaps . See Illust. of Bloodhound .
To bend; as, to flex the arm .
To whip lightly or with a quick jerk; to flap; as, to flick a horse; to flick the dirt from boots.
One who flies or flees; a runaway; a fugitive.
To cast, send, to throw from the hand; to hurl; to dart; to emit with violence as if thrown from the hand; as, to fing a stone into the pond .
A massive, somewhat impure variety of quartz, in color usually of a gray to brown or nearly black, breaking with a conchoidal fracture and sharp edge. It is very hard, and strikes fire with steel.
A mixture of beer, spirit, etc., stirred and heated by a hot iron.
To turn inside out, or with the leg part back over the foot, as a stocking in pulling off or for putting on.
To throw with a jerk or quick effort; to fling suddenly; as, they flirt water in each other's faces; he flirted a glove, or a handkerchief.
To frisk; to skip; to caper.
To move with celerity through the air; to fly away with a rapid motion; to dart along; to fleet; as, a bird flits away; a cloud flits along.
To scold; to quarrel.
The flux; dysentery.
Anything which floats or rests on the surface of a fluid, as to sustain weight, or to indicate the height of the liquid surface, or mark the place of, something.
A company or collection of living creatures; -- especially applied to sheep and birds, rarely to persons or (except in the plural) to cattle and other large animals; as, a flock of ravenous fowl .
A low, flat mass of floating ice.
To beat or strike with a rod or whip; to whip; to lash; to chastise with repeated blows.
imp. & p. p. of Fling .

A great flow of water; a body of moving water; the flowing stream, as of a river; especially, a body of water, rising, swelling, and overflowing land not usually thus covered; a deluge; a freshet; an inundation.
A fluke of an anchor.
The bottom or lower part of any room; the part upon which we stand and upon which the movables in the room are supported.
To clap or strike, as a bird its wings, a fish its tail, etc.; to flap.
The goddess of flowers and spring.
A hopper-shaped box or &unr_;nortar in which ore is placed for the action of the stamps.
The slender styles of the pistillate flowers of maize; also called silk .
A fleet; especially, a &unr_;eet of Spanish ships which formerly sailed every year from Cadiz to Vera Cruz, in Mexico, to transport to Spain the production of Spanish America.
To fleet; to skim.

The finely ground meal of wheat, or of any other grain; especially, the finer part of meal separated by bolting; hence, the fine and soft powder of any substance; as, flour of emery; flour of mustard.
To mock or insult; to treat with contempt.
imp. sing. of Fly , v. i.
See 1st Fluke .
p. p. of Fly ; -- often used with the auxiliary verb to be ; as, the birds are flown .
An inclosed passage way for establishing and directing a current of air, gases, etc.; an air passage
Downy; fluffy.
Nap or down; flue[2]; soft, downy feathers.
Having particles which easily move and change their relative position without a separation of the mass, and which easily yield to pressure; capable of flowing; liquid or gaseous.
The European flounder. See Flounder .
Formed like, or having, a fluke.

A stream; especially, a passage channel, or conduit for the water that drives a mill wheel; or an artifical channel of water for hydraulic or placer mining; also, a chute for conveying logs or lumber down a declivity.
imp. & p. p. of Fling .
To fail, as on a lesson; to back out, as from an undertaking, through fear.
A fluid state.
To flow and spread suddenly; to rush; as, blood flushes into the face .

A musical wind instrument, consisting of a hollow cylinder or pipe, with holes along its length, stopped by the fingers or by keys which are opened by the fingers. The modern flute is closed at the upper end, and blown with the mouth at a lateral hole.
Soft and clear in tone, like a flute.
The act of flowing; a continuous moving on or passing by, as of a flowing stream; constant succession; change.
To move in or pass through the air with wings, as a bird.
One that uses wings.
the symbol for the element Fermium .
To breathe heavily; to snort.
The Federal National Mortgage Association a federally chartered corporation that purchases and resells mortgages.
The Chinese name of Buddha.
The young of any animal of the Horse family (Equidæ) ; a colt; a filly.

The white substance, consisting of an aggregation of bubbles, which is formed on the surface of liquids, or in the mouth of an animal, by violent agitation or fermentation; froth; spume; scum; as, the foam of the sea .
Covered with foam; frothy; spumy.
A little pocket for a watch; -- callled also a watch pocket .
Belonging to,or concerning, a focus; as, a focal point.
A point in which the rays of light meet, after being reflected or refracted, and at which the image is formed; as, the focus of a lens or mirror.
To treat as an enemy.

A warm dry wind that often blows in the northern valleys of the Alps, due to the indraught of a storm center passing over Central Europe. The wind, heated by compression in its descent from the mountains, reaches the base, particularly in winter, dry and warm.
A second growth of grass; aftergrass.
The Cornish name for a forge used for smelting tin.
Filled or abounding with fog, or watery exhalations; misty; as, a foggy atmosphere; a foggy morning.
A dull old fellow; a person behind the times, over-conservative, or slow; -- usually preceded by old ; an old fogy .
An exclamation of abhorrence or contempt; poh; fie.
To tread under foot; to trample.
The beech marten ( Mustela foina ). See Marten .
A light and fast-sailing ship.
To lap or lay in plaits or folds; to lay one part over another part of; to double; as, to fold cloth; to fold a letter.
A leaf of a book or manuscript.
In Anglo-Saxon times, the people of a group of townships or villages; a community; a tribe.
The state of being foolish; want of good sense; levity, weakness, or derangement of mind.
Any substance supposed to be capable of absorbing, retaining, and transporting contagious or infectious germs; as, woolen clothes are said to be active fomites .
(Irish) one of a group of sea demons sometimes associated with the hostile power of nature.
A fool; an idiot.
imp. of Find . Found.
To endeavor; to strive; to try.
Blended; gradually changing or passing into each other by subtle gradations; -- said of colors or of the surface or material on which the colors are laid.
pl. of Foe .
To take; to receive.
Foolishly; fondly.

A complete assortment of printing type of one size, including a due proportion of all the letters in the alphabet, large and small, points, accents, and whatever else is necessary for printing with that variety of types; a fount.

What is fed upon; that which goes to support life by being received within, and assimilated by, the organism of an animal or a plant; nutriment; aliment; especially, what is eaten by animals for nourishment.
Eatable; fruitful.
A compound of gooseberries scalded and crushed, with cream; -- commonly called gooseberry fool .
The terminal part of the leg of man or an animal; esp., the part below the ankle or wrist; that part of an animal upon which it rests when standing, or moves. See Manus , and Pes .
The settlings of oil, molasses, etc., at the bottom of a barrel or hogshead.
Having foots , or settlings; as, footy oil, molasses, etc.
One whose ambition it is to gain admiration by showy dress; a coxcomb; an inferior dandy.
In the most general sense, indicating that in consideration of, in view of, or with reference to, which anything is done or takes place.
A sudden or irregular incursion in border warfare; hence, any irregular incursion for war or spoils; a raid.
Near; hard by; along; past.
To stuff; to lard; to farce.
A place in a river, or other water, where it may be passed by man or beast on foot, by wading.
To destroy; to undo; to ruin.
Journey; way; method of proceeding.
A kind of parchment for book covers. See Forrill .
A place or establishment where iron or other metals are wrought by heating and hammering; especially, a furnace, or a shop with its furnace, etc., where iron is heated and wrought; a smithy.
To pass by; to leave. See 1st Forego .

An instrument consisting of a handle with a shank terminating in two or more prongs or tines, which are usually of metal, parallel and slightly curved; -- used for piercing, holding, taking up, or pitching anything.
Opening into two or more parts or shoots; forked; furcated.

The shape and structure of anything, as distinguished from the material of which it is composed; particular disposition or arrangement of matter, giving it individuality or distinctive character; configuration; figure; external appearance.

A strong or fortified place; usually, a small fortified place, occupied only by troops, surrounded with a ditch, rampart, and parapet, or with palisades, stockades, or other means of defense; a fortification.
The strong point; that in which one excels.
Forward; onward in time, place, or order; in advance from a given point; on to end; as, from that day forth ; one, two, three, and so forth .
Four times ten; thirty-nine and one more.
A market place or public place in Rome, where causes were judicially tried, and orations delivered to the people.
A pit, groove, cavity, or depression, of greater or less depth; as, the temporal fossa on the side of the skull; the nasal fossæ containing the nostrils in most birds.
A ditch or moat.

Covered with, or containing, extraneous matter which is injurious, noxious, offensive, or obstructive; filthy; dirty; not clean; polluted; nasty; defiled; as, a foul cloth; foul hands; a foul chimney; foul air; a ship's bottom is foul when overgrown with barnacles; a gun becomes foul from repeated firing; a well is foul with polluted water.
imp. & p. p. of Find .
A fountain.
One more than three; twice two.
A tricky fellow; a cheat.
Despicable.
A slight depression or pit; a fossa.
Any bird; esp., any large edible bird.

A carnivorous animal of the genus Vulpes , family Canidæ , of many species. The European fox ( V. vulgaris or V. vulpes ), the American red fox ( V. fulvus ), the American gray fox ( V. Virginianus ), and the arctic, white, or blue, fox ( V. lagopus ) are well-known species.
Discolored or stained; -- said of timber, and also of the paper of books or engravings.
See Fox , n. , 7.
Like or pertaining to the fox; foxlike in disposition or looks; wily; cunning.
Faith; allegiance; fealty.
A lobby in a theater; a greenroom.
Spongy; soft; fat and puffy.
Brother; -- a title of a monk or friar; as, Fra Angelo .
To scold; to nag.
To break; to violate.
To assault, especially to kill or wound, with a fragmentation grenade.
A basket made of rushes, used chiefly for containing figs and raisins.

To construct by fitting and uniting the several parts of the skeleton of any structure; specifically, in woodwork, to put together by cutting parts of one member to fit parts of another. See Dovetail , Halve , v. t. , Miter , Tenon , Tooth , Tusk , Scarf , and Splice .

A silver coin of France, and since 1795 the unit of the French monetary system. It has been adopted by Belgium and Swizerland. In 1913 it was equivalent to about nineteen cents American, or ten pence British, and is divided into 100 centimes.
To shut up in a frank or sty; to pen up; hence, to cram; to fatten.
To draw together; to bind with a view to secure and strengthen, as a vessel by passing cables around it; to tighten; as a tackle by drawing the lines together.
A crowd, a rabble.
a social club for male college undergraduates; a shortened form of fraternity .
In Germany, a woman; a married woman; a wife; -- as a title, equivalent to Mrs. , Madam .
Deception deliberately practiced with a view to gaining an unlawful or unfair advantage; artifice by which the right or interest of another is injured; injurious stratagem; deceit; trick.
An angry quarrel; an affray; contest; combat; broil.
To variegate; to checker; to streak.
To checker; to diversify.
Peace; -- a word used in composition, especially in proper names; as, Al fred ; Fred eric.

Exempt from subjection to the will of others; not under restraint, control, or compulsion; able to follow one's own impulses, desires, or inclinations; determining one's own course of action; not dependent; at liberty.
One who frees, or sets free.
Strange; foreign.
A stranger.
Possessed of original life and vigor; new and strong; unimpaired; sound.
to eat copiously and without restraint; to snack frequently.
See 1st Frith .
The worn side of the bank of a river. See 4th Fret , n. , 4.
Sigmund Freud , the founder of the practise of psychoanalysis. Born 1856, died 1939.

The god of earth's fertility and peace and prosperity, presiding over rain, sunshine, and all the fruits of the earth, dispensing wealth among men; son of Njorth (Njord) and brother of Freya; originally of the Vanir; later with the Aesir. He was especially worshipped in the temple at Upsala in Sweden
The daughter of Njörd, and goddess of love and beauty; the Scandinavian Venus; -- in Teutonic myths confounded with Frigga, but in Scandinavian, distinct.

A brother or member of any religious order, but especially of one of the four mendicant orders, viz: (a) Minors, Gray Friars, or Franciscans. (b) Augustines . (c) Dominicans or Black Friars. (d) White Friars or Carmelites. See these names in the Vocabulary.
imp. & p. p. of Fry .
One who fries.
The wife of Odin and mother of the gods; the supreme goddess; the Juno of the Valhalla. Cf. Freya .
To shake or shiver as with cold; as, the hawk frills .
Flourishing; thriving; fresh; in good condition; vigorous.
Lively; brisk; frolicsome; frisky.
To sell upon credit, as goods.
The material of which glass is made, after having been calcined or partly fused in a furnace, but before vitrification. It is a composition of silex and alkali, occasionally with other ingredients.
A forest; a woody place.
To curl or form into small curls, as hair, with a crisping pin; to crisp.
See 1st Frieze .
See Friz , v. t. & n.
From; away; back or backward; -- now used only in opposition to the word to , in the phrase to and fro , that is, to and from . See To and fro under To .

A loose outer garment; especially, a gown forming a part of European modern costume for women and children; also, a coarse shirtlike garment worn by some workmen over their other clothes; a smock frock; as, a marketman's frock .
A dirty woman; a slattern; a frow.
An amphibious animal of the genus Rana and related genera, of many species. Frogs swim rapidly, and take long leaps on land. Many of the species utter loud notes in the springtime.

Out of the neighborhood of; lessening or losing proximity to; leaving behind; by reason of; out of; by aid of; -- used whenever departure, setting out, commencement of action, being, state, occurrence, etc., or procedure, emanation, absence, separation, etc., are to be expressed. It is construed with, and indicates, the point of space or time at which the action, state, etc., are regarded as setting out or beginning; also, less frequently, the source, the cause, the occasion, out of which anything proceeds; -- the antithesis and correlative of to ; as, it, is one hundred miles from Boston to Springfield; he took his sword from his side; light proceeds from the sun; separate the coarse wool from the fine; men have all sprung from Adam, and often go from good to bad, and from bad to worse; the merit of an action depends on the principle from which it proceeds; men judge of facts from personal knowledge, or from testimony.

The organ formed by the combination or union into one body of stem and leaf, and often bearing the fructification; as, the frond of a fern or of a lichen or seaweed ; also, the peculiar leaf of a palm tree.
The forehead; the part of the cranium between the orbits and the vertex.
The forehead or brow, the part of the face above the eyes; sometimes, also, the whole face.
Frozen; stiff with cold.
a student during his first year in a high school, college, or university; a freshman .
The act of freezing; -- applied chiefly to the congelation of water; congelation of fluids.
To rub or wear by rubbing; to chafe.
To cause to foam.
A woman; especially, a Dutch or German woman.
To contract the brow in displeasure, severity, or sternness; to scowl; to put on a stern, grim, or surly look.
Musty; rancid; as, frowy butter .
imp. of Freeze .
Whatever is produced for the nourishment or enjoyment of man or animals by the processes of vegetable growth, as corn, grass, cotton, flax, etc.; -- commonly used in the plural.
To insult; to flout; to mock; to snub.
To batter; to break in pieces.
To cook in a pan or on a griddle (esp. with the use of fat, butter, or olive oil) by heating over a fire; to cook in boiling lard or fat; as, to fry fish; to fry doughnuts.
Something or someone that fries.

An acronym for file transfer protocol , a standardized protocol used to allow transmission of files between computers; as, send me the file by ftp . It consists of a set of coded signals which are transmitted between computers, and which inform the receiving computer of the nature of a packet of information to be transmitted, and inform the transmitting computer when a packet has been successfully received.
A department in China comprising several hsein ; also, the chief city of a department; -- often forming the last part of a name; as, Paoting- fu .
Same as Fumage .
Same as Feuar .
A plump young person or child.
Plump; chubby; short and stuffy; as a fubsy sofa.
A student of the first year.
A slang term for sexual intercourse.
A paint; a dye; also, false show.
The tail of a hare, coney, etc.
A made-up story; stuff; nonsense; humbug; -- often an exclamation of contempt.
Any matter used to produce heat by burning; that which feeds fire; combustible matter used for fires, as wood, coal, peat, etc.
A code; a charter; a grant of privileges.
Light; puffy.
An exclamation of disgust; foh; faugh.
To maneuver; to move hither and thither.

A polyphonic composition, developed from a given theme or themes, according to strict contrapuntal rules. The theme is first given out by one voice or part, and then, while that pursues its way, it is repeated by another at the interval of a fifth or fourth, and so on, until all the parts have answered one by one, continuing their several melodies and interweaving them in one complex progressive whole, in which the theme is often lost and reappears.
Same as Fulahs .

Filled up, having within its limits all that it can contain; supplied; not empty or vacant; -- said primarily of hollow vessels, and hence of anything else; as, a cup full of water; a house full of people.
In a full manner or degree; completely; entirely; without lack or defect; adequately; satisfactorily; as, to be fully persuaded of the truth of a proposition .
To play upon a fiddle.
Exhalation; volatile matter (esp. noxious vapor or smoke) ascending in a dense body; smoke; vapor; reek; as, the fumes of tobacco .
One that fumes.
The dung of deer.
Smoky; vaporous.
Producing fumes; fumous.
Sport; merriment; frolicsome amusement.
An aggregation or deposit of resources from which supplies are or may be drawn for carrying on any work, or for maintaining existence.
A blockhead; a dolt; a fool.

A group of thallophytic plant-like organisms of low organization, destitute of chlorophyll, in which reproduction is mainly accomplished by means of asexual spores, which are produced in a great variety of ways, though sexual reproduction is known to occur in certain Phycomycetes , or so-called algal fungi. They include the molds, mildews, rusts, smuts, mushrooms, toadstools, puff balls, and the allies of each. In the two-kingdom classification system they were classed with the plants, but in the modern five-kingdom classification, they are not classed as plants, but are classed in their own separate kingdom fungi , which includes the phyla Zygomycota (including simple fungi such as bread molds), Ascomycota (including the yeasts), Basidiomycota (including the mushrooms, smuts, and rusts), and Deuteromycota (the fungi imperfecti ). Some of the forms, such as the yeasts, appear as single-celled microorganisms, but all of the fungi are are eukaryotic, thus distinguishing them from the prokaryotic microorganisms of the kingdon Monera .
A cord; specifically, the umbilical cord or navel string.
An offensive smell; a stench.
A genus of robust East Asian clump-forming perennial herbs having racemose flowers: plantain lilies; sometimes placed in the family Hostaceae .
Pertaining to, or characterized by, great fear, or funking; having great fear.
Droll; comical; amusing; laughable; inciting laughter.
Of or pertaining to furs; bearing or made of fur; as, a fur cap; the fur trade.
To draw up or gather into close compass; to wrap or roll, as a sail, close to the yard, stay, or mast, or, as a flag, close to or around its staff, securing it there by a gasket or line.
an interest followed with exaggerated zeal; a fad.
Covered with fur; dressed in fur.
Violent or extreme excitement; overmastering agitation or enthusiasm.
A thorny evergreen shrub ( Ulex Europæus ), with beautiful yellow flowers, very common upon the plains and hills of Great Britain; -- called also gorse , and whin . The dwarf furze is Ulex nanus .
Abounding in, or overgrown with, furze; characterized by furze.
To liquefy by heat; to render fluid; to dissolve; to melt.
joined together into a whole.
A flintlock gun. See 2d Fusil .

A hot, acrid, oily liquid, accompanying many alcoholic liquors (as potato whisky, corn whisky, etc.), as an undesirable ingredient, and consisting of several of the higher alcohols and compound ethers, but mostly of amyl alcohol;
Capable of being melted or rendered fluid by heat; fusible.
A tumult; a bustle; unnecessary or annoying ado about trifles.
Making a fuss; disposed to make an unnecessary ado about trifles; overnice; fidgety.
The shaft of a column, or trunk of a pilaster.
Moldy; musty; ill-smelling; rank.
To fool around; to act without plan or purpose; -- usually used with around ; as, don't futz around with a device without understanding its operation .
A tube, filled with combustible matter, for exploding a shell, etc. See Fuse , n.
a friction match with a large head that will stay alight in the wind.
To make drunk.
Not firmly woven; that ravels.
A word which expresses blame, dislike, disapprobation, abhorrence, or contempt. See Fie .
A long bag net distended by hoops, into which fish can pass easily, without being able to return; -- called also fyke net .
The military force of the whole nation, consisting of all men able to bear arms.
See Fit a song.
The hook on the end of an eccentric rod opposite the strap. See. Illust. of Eccentric .
A rent, service, tribute, custom, tax, impost, or duty; an excise.

The vertical triangular portion of the end of a building, from the level of the cornice or eaves to the ridge of the roof. Also, a similar end when not triangular in shape, as of a gambrel roof and the like.
A simpleton; a dunce; a lout.
The point of a spear, or an arrowhead.
A small British fish ( Motella argenteola ) of the Cod family.
Pertaining to, or derived from, the cod ( Gadus ); -- applied to an acid obtained from cod-liver oil, viz., gadic acid.
The goddess of the earth, considered as a personification of the earth. According to Hesiod she was the first-born of Chaos, and mother of Uranus, Pontus, Cronus and the Titans in ancient mythology.
A Celt or the Celts of the Scotch Highlands or of Ireland; now esp., a Scotch Highlander of Celtic origin.
A barbed spear or a hook with a handle, used by fishermen in securing heavy fish.
A socially awkward or tactless act.
To stop the mouth of, by thrusting sometimes in, so as to hinder speaking; hence, to silence by authority or by violence; not to allow freedom of speech to.
mentally or physically infirm with age.
A pledge or pawn; something laid down or given as a security for the performance of some act by the person depositing it, and forfeited by nonperformance; security.
A measurer. See Gauger .
Goddess of the earth; same as Gaea .
Merrily; showily. See gaily .
A square or beveled notch cut out of a girder, binding joist, or other timber which supports a floor beam, so as to receive the end of the floor beam.
A going; a walk; a march; a way.
Pomp, show, or festivity.
The general outward form of any solid object, as of a column or a vase.
A strong current of air; a wind between a stiff breeze and a hurricane. The most violent gales are called tempests .
The upper lip or helmet-shaped part of a labiate flower.
That division of elasmobranch fishes which includes the sharks.
The bitter, alkaline, viscid fluid found in the gall bladder, beneath the liver. It consists of the secretion of the liver, or bile, mixed with that of the mucous membrane of the gall bladder.
To frighten; to worry.
A kind of lively dance, in 2-4 time; also, the music to the dance.
To gape,; to yawn.
Same as Gault .
A herd, or school, of whales.
A viola da gamba.
Crooked; lame; as, a game leg .
suggestive of sexual impropriety; as, he skips asterisks and gives you the gamey details .
Pertaining to, or resulting from, sexual connection; formed by the union of the male and female elements.
A neglected and untrained city boy; a young street Arab.
The third letter (Γ, γ = Eng. G ) of the Greek alphabet.
A large umbrella; -- said to allude to Mrs. Gamp's umbrella, in Dickens's “Martin Chuzzlewit.”
Having the flavor of game, esp. of game kept uncooked till near the condition of tainting; high-flavored.
Began; commenced.
To drop from a high place upon sharp stakes or hooks, as the Turks dropped malefactors, by way of punishment.
To yawn; to gape.
To go; to walk.
To protect (the part of a line next a fishhook, or the hook itself) by winding it with wire.
A kind of brittle limestone.
The dried hemp plant, used in India for smoking. It is extremely narcotic and intoxicating.
Same as Ganza .
A kind of wild goose, by a flock of which a virtuoso was fabled to be carried to the lunar world.
A place of confinement, especially for minor offenses or provisional imprisonment; a jail.

An opening in anything made by breaking or parting; as, a gap in a fence ; an opening for a passage or entrance; an opening which implies a breach or defect; a vacant space or time; a hiatus; a mountain pass.
To open the mouth wide
One who gapes.
See as the gapes , under gape , n. .
Any slender marine fish of the genera Belone and Tylosurus . See Garfish .
Clothing in general.
See Guard .
Coarse wool on the legs of sheep.
A close; a yard; a croft; a garden; as, a cloister garth .
A sauce made of small fish. It was prized by the ancients.

An aëriform fluid; -- a term used at first by chemists as synonymous with air , but since restricted to fluids supposed to be permanently elastic, as oxygen, hydrogen, etc., in distinction from vapors, as steam, which become liquid on a reduction of temperature. In present usage, since all of the supposed permanent gases have been liquified by cold and pressure, the term has resumed nearly its original signification, and is applied to any substance in the elastic or aëriform state.
To make a gash, or long, deep incision in; -- applied chiefly to incisions in flesh.
To open the mouth wide in catching the breath, or in laborious respiration; to labor for breath; to respire convulsively; to pant violently.
Full of gas; like gas.
To make aghast; to frighten; to terrify. See Aghast .
imp. of Get .
Plaster as used in Persian architecture and decorative art.
A large door or passageway in the wall of a city, of an inclosed field or place, or of a grand edifice, etc.; also, the movable structure of timber, metal, etc., by which the passage can be closed.
Having gates.
a United Nations agency created by a multinational treaty to promote trade by the reduction of tariffs and import quotas.
Trick; jest; sport.
Ostentatiously fine; showy; gay, but tawdry or meretricious.
A measure; a standard of measure; an instrument to determine dimensions, distance, or capacity; a standard.
The Anglicized form of Gallia , which in the time of the Romans included France and Upper Italy (Transalpine and Cisalpine Gaul).
A series of beds of clay and marl in the South of England, between the upper and lower greensand of the Cretaceous period.
Attenuated, as with fasting or suffering; lean; meager; pinched and grim.
An East Indian species of wild cattle ( Bibos gauris ), of large size and an untamable disposition.
To gaze; to stare.

The C.G.S. unit of density of magnetic field, equal to a field of one line of force per square centimeter, being thus adopted as an international unit at Paris in 1900; sometimes used as a unit of intensity of magnetic field. It was previously suggested as a unit of magnetomotive force.
A very thin, slight, transparent stuff, generally of silk; also, any fabric resembling silk gauze; as, wire gauze ; cotton gauze .
Pertaining to, or resembling, gauze; thin and slight as gauze.
imp. of Give .
A small heap of grain, not tied up into a bundle.
A kind of difficult, old formal French dance in quadruple time.
A baby; a dunce.
To act like a gawky.
Foolish and awkward; clumsy; clownish; as, gawky behavior . -- n. A fellow who is awkward from being overgrown, or from stupidity, a gawk.
A small tub or lading vessel.
An ornament
A Southern Asiatic species of wild cattle ( Bibos frontalis ).
With mirth and frolic; merrily; blithely; gleefully.
To fix the eyes in a steady and earnest look; to look with eagerness or curiosity, as in admiration, astonishment, or with studious attention.
The black currant; also, the wild plum.
One who gazes.
A Venetian coin, worth about three English farthings, or one and a half cents.
One of the pieces of sod used to line or cover parapets and the faces of earthworks.
The chemical symbol for germanium, a metalloid element of atomic number 32. See germanium .
To congeal.
A species of cherry tree common in Europe ( Prunus avium ); also, the fruit, which is usually small and dark in color.
Clothing; garments; ornaments.
The channel or spout through which molten metal runs into a mold in casting.
The god of the earth; father of Osiris and Isis.
Scorn, derision, or contempt.

Any lizard of the family Geckonidæ . The geckoes are small, carnivorous, mostly nocturnal animals with large eyes and vertical, elliptical pupils. Their toes are generally expanded, and furnished with adhesive disks, by which they can run over walls and ceilings. They are numerous in warm countries, and a few species are found in Europe and the United States. See Wall gecko , Fanfoot .
The European pike.
To agree; to harmonize.
A performer in a carnival, often presented as a wild man, who performs grotesquely disgusting acts, such as biting the head off a live chicken or snake.
See Gear , Gearing .
pl. of Goose .
Alluvial matter on the surface of land, not of recent origin.
The original native name for the ancient Ethiopic language or people. See Ethiopic .
Pertaining to, or derived from, earthy or vegetable mold.
See Humin .
Money; tribute; compensation; ransom.
Cold; very cold; frozen.
Trubute, tax.
To put forth in the form of buds.
Coupled; paired.
A leaf bud, as distinguished from a flower bud.
The chamois.
A small South American deer ( Furcifer Chilensis ), with simple forked horns.
The cheek; the feathered side of the under mandible of a bird.
One of several species of small Carnivora of the genus Genetta , allied to the civets, but having the scent glands less developed, and without a pouch.
Same as Genius {1}.
A man of a particular turn of mind.
Any tree or shrub of the genus Genipa .
Kind; genus; class; form; style, esp. in literature.
A clan or family connection, embracing several families of the same stock, who had a common name and certain common religious rites; a subdivision of the Roman curia or tribe.
Neat; trim.
See Gonys .
A nodule of stone, containing a cavity, lined with crystals or mineral matter.
A small coin and weight; 1-20th of a shekel.
A kind of ornamental firework.
A small genus of hairy herbs with yellow flowers.
That which is to develop a new individual; as, the germ of a fetus, of a plant or flower, and the like ; the earliest form under which an organism appears.
To grin or yawn.
Changeable; fickle.

Plaster of Paris, or gypsum, esp. as prepared for use in painting, or in making bas-reliefs and the like; by extension, a plasterlike or pasty material spread upon a surface to fit it for painting or gilding, or a surface so prepared.
To tell stories or gests.
Jet, the mineral.
A type of Japanese footwear usually with wooden soles, held to the foot by a thong that passes between the first two toes.
p. p. of Get .
the original third pers. sing. pres. of Go .
General composition or structure; manner in which the parts of a thing are combined; arrangement; format; make-up; style of dress, etc.
A genus of plants of the rose family comprising the avens.

A country in Western Africa, bordering the North Atlantic Ocean, between Cote d'Ivoire and Togo, with Burkina Faso bordering on the north, with a population of 17,698,271 (July 1996 est), and a total area of 238,540 sq km. The government is a constitutional democracy, and the capital city is Accra.
To strike aghast; to affright.
Among Muslims, a warrior champion or veteran, esp. in the destruction of infidels.
Butter clarified by boiling, and thus converted into a kind of oil.
See Guess .
See Ghoul .
To die; to expire.
An imaginary evil being among Eastern nations, which was supposed to feed upon human bodies.
A ravine. See Gill a woody glen.
Like a giant; extraordinary in size, strength, or power; as, giant brothers; a giant son.
A male cat; a tomcat.
To cast reproaches and sneering expressions; to rail; to utter taunting, sarcastic words; to flout; to fleer; to scoff.
A kind of carp ( Cyprinus gibelio ); -- called also Prussian carp .
One who utters gibes.
A disease of sheep, characterized by vertigo; the staggers. It is caused by the presence of the C&unr_;nurus, a larval tapeworm, in the brain. See C&unr_;nurus .
To reel; to whirl.
To guide. See Gye .

The Graphics Interchange Format, one of the most popular standardized formats for storing graphic data in binary computer files. The standard has been revised several times, and includes provisions for interlacing and animating images. Its disadvantage is that it can store only 256 colors. Compare JPEG .
See Jiffy .
Anything given; anything voluntarily transferred by one person to another without compensation; a present; an offering.
To engender.
The leather strap by which the shield of a knight was slung across the shoulder, or across the neck and shoulder.
A leg of mutton.
A piece of lively dance music, in two strains which are repeated; also, the dance.
To overlay with a thin covering of gold; to cover with a golden color; to cause to look like gold.
An organ for aquatic respiration; a branchia.
See Grilse .
A female pig, when young.
Neat; spruce.
the 3rd letter of the Hebrew alphabet.
Smart; spruce; trim; nice.
Against; near by; towards; as, gin night .
A tropical American tree ( Melicocca bijuga ) bearing a small edible fruit with green leathery skin and sweet juicy translucent pulp.
Same as Gang , n. , 2.
To take out the entrails of (herrings).
See Gypsy .
To gibe; to sneer; to break a scornful jest; to utter severe sarcasms.
The Babylonian god of fire; often invoked in incantations against sorcery.
imp. & p. p. of Gird .
A band or strap which encircles the body; especially, one by which a saddle is fastened upon the back of a horse.
To feed or pasture.
A resting place.
The corn cockle; also anciently applied to the Nigella , or fennel flower.
Same as Joust .
To bestow without receiving a return; to confer without compensation; to impart, as a possession; to grant, as authority or permission; to yield up or allow.
p. p. & a. from Give , v.
One who gives; a donor; a bestower; a grantor; one who imparts or distributes.
To make glad; to cheer; to gladden; to exhilarate.
To smear with the white of an egg.
A copious gummy secretion of the humor of the eyelids, in consequence of some disorder; blearedness; lippitude.
To shoot out, or emit, as a dazzling light.
Of a dazzling luster; glaring; bright; shining; smooth.
To reflect, as in a mirror; to mirror; -- used reflexively.
To grope with the hands, as in the dark.
See Glaive .
To become glazed of glassy.
Having a glazed appearance; -- said of the fractured surface of some kinds of pin iron.
A live coal. See Gleed .
To disgorge filth, as a hawk.
To gather stalks or ears of grain left by reapers.
The chambered sporogenous tissue forming the central mass of the sporophore in puff balls, stinkhorns, etc.
A lump; a clod.
The common European kite ( Milvus ictinus ). This name is also sometimes applied to the buzzard.
A live or glowing coal; a glede.
To make sport; to gibe; to sneer; to spend time idly.
To glisten; to gleam.
A transparent mucous discharge from the membrane of the urethra, commonly an effect of gonorrhea.
Quick of perception; alert; sharp.
A secluded and narrow valley; a dale; a depression between hills.
See Glint .
To squint; to look obliquely; to overlook things.
To make glib.
The glede or kite.
A transient glance; an unexpected view of something that startles one; a sudden fear.
A sneer; a flout.
Brightness; splendor.
A glimpse, glance, or gleam.
The type genus of the Gliridae .
Glimmer; mica.
The twilight; gloaming.
To squint; to stare.
To look steadfastly; to gaze earnestly; to gaze with passionate desire, lust, or avarice.
a compact mass, especially of a semiliquid or viscous substance; as, a glob of glue fell on my shoe .
A round or spherical body, solid or hollow; a body whose surface is in every part equidistant from the center; a ball; a sphere.
Resembling, or pertaining to, a globe; round; orbicular.
imp. of Glide .
One of the two prominences at the posterior extremity of the frog of the horse's foot.
To shine or appear obscurely or imperfectly; to glimmer.
To glare; to glower.
Praise, honor, admiration, or distinction, accorded by common consent to a person or thing; high reputation; honorable fame; renown.
See Gloze .
Brightness or luster of a body proceeding from a smooth surface; polish; as, the gloss of silk; cloth is calendered to give it a gloss .
The lead glaze used for pottery.
To pout; to look sullen.
To cover with, or as with, a glove.
To make hot; to flush.
To smooth over; to palliate.

A hard brittle brownish gelatin, obtained by boiling to a jelly the skins, hoofs, etc., of animals. When gently heated with water, it becomes viscid and tenaceous, and is used as a cement for uniting substances. The name is also given to other adhesive or viscous substances.
affixed with glue or paste.
One who cements with glue.
Viscous; glutinous; of the nature of, or like, glue.
Sullenness.
The bracteal covering of the flowers or seeds of grain and grasses; esp., an outer husk or bract of a spikelet.
To manifest sullenness; to sulk.
To swallow, or to swallow greedlly; to gorge.
A glen. See Glen . [ Obs. singly, but occurring often in locative names in Ireland, as Glen does in Scotland.]
A sunken channel or groove, usually vertical. See Triglyph .
A knot or gnarl in wood; hence, a tough, thickset man; -- written also gnarr .
To growl; to snarl.
To strike together, as in anger or pain; as, to gnash the teeth .

A blood-sucking dipterous fly, of the genus Culex , undergoing a metamorphosis in water. The females have a proboscis armed with needlelike organs for penetrating the skin of animals. These are wanting in the males. In America they are generally called mosquitoes . See Mosquito .

To bite, as something hard or tough, which is not readily separated or crushed; to bite off little by little, with effort; to wear or eat away by scraping or continuous biting with the teeth; to nibble at.
imp. of Gnaw .
To rub; to bruise; to break in pieces.
Churl; curmudgeon.
An imaginary being, supposed by the Rosicrucians to inhabit the inner parts of the earth, and to be the guardian of mines, quarries, etc.
One of two species of large South African antelopes of the genus Catoblephas , having a mane and bushy tail, and curved horns in both sexes.

To pass from one place to another; to be in motion; to be in a state not motionless or at rest; to proceed; to advance; to make progress; -- used, in various applications, of the movement of both animate and inanimate beings, by whatever means, and also of the movements of the mind; also figuratively applied.
A species of antelope ( Procapra picticauda ), inhabiting Thibet.
A pointed instrument used to urge on a beast; hence, any necessity that urges or stimulates.
That part of a mine from which the mineral has been partially or wholly removed; the waste left in old workings; -- called also gob .
Same as 1st Gore .
A hollow-horned ruminant of the genus Capra , of several species and varieties, esp. the domestic goat ( Capra hircus ), which is raised for its milk, flesh, and skin.
Same as Goaf .
See Gobbet .
A genus of fish comprising the true gudgeons.
One of several species of small marine fishes of the genus Gobius and allied genera.
A being conceived of as possessing supernatural power, and to be propitiated by sacrifice, worship, etc.; a divinity; a deity; an object of worship; an idol.
Pious; reverencing God, and his character and laws; obedient to the commands of God from love for, and reverence of, his character; conformed to God's law; devout; righteous; as, a godly life .
p. p. of Go.
One who, or that which, goes; a runner or walker
Invocation of evil spirits; witchcraft.
A silly clown.
Haste; ardent desire to go.
The act of moving in any manner; traveling; as, the going is bad .
An old English name of some yellow flower, -- the marigold ( Calendula ), according to Dr. Prior , but in Chaucer perhaps the turnsole.
The gullet.

A game played with a small ball and a bat or club crooked at the lower end. He who drives the ball into each of a series of small holes in the ground and brings it into the last hole with the fewest strokes is the winner.
A hand, paw, or claw.
A husband; a master of a family.
See Gumbo .
The black grease on the axle of a cart or wagon wheel; -- called also gorm . See Gorm .
A Hebrew measure. See Homer .
imp. & p. p. of Go .
One of the masses of generative tissue primitively alike in both sexes, but giving rise to either an ovary or a testis; a generative gland; a germ gland.
p. p. of Go .
A privy or jakes.
Going to; as, who's gonna get the milk? .
The keel or lower outline of a bird's bill, so far as the mandibular rami are united.
That which possesses desirable qualities, promotes success, welfare, or happiness, is serviceable, fit, excellent, kind, benevolent, etc.; -- opposed to evil .
See Good , n. , 3.
A bonbon, cake, or the like; -- usually in the pl.
a stupid fool.
foolish and silly, or appearing silly; as, he wore a goofy hat .
Ghost; spirit.
The Republican Party, the younger of the two major political parties in the U. S.
An Indian goat antelope ( Nemorhedus goral ), resembling the chamois.
A pool of water to keep fish in; a wear.
An instrument of gaming; a sort of dice.
A wedgeshaped or triangular piece of cloth, canvas, etc., sewed into a garment, sail, etc., to give greater width at a particular part.
The throat; the gullet; the canal by which food passes to the stomach.
An industrial city in the European part of Soviet Russia.
Axle grease. See Gome .
The European cormorant.
Furze. See Furze .
imp. & p. p. of Get . See Get .
A channel for water.
One of an ancient Teutonic race, who dwelt between the Elbe and the Vistula in the early part of the Christian era, and who overran and took an important part in subverting the Roman empire.
Got to; have to; must; as, I gotta leave now .
A fire worshiper; a Gheber or Gueber.

One of several species of large, crested ground pigeons of the genus Goura , inhabiting New Guinea and adjacent islands. The Queen Victoria pigeon ( Goura Victoria ) and the crowned pigeon ( G. coronata ) are among the best known species.

A fleshy, three-celled, many-seeded fruit, as the melon, pumpkin, cucumber, etc., of the order Cucurbitaceæ ; and especially the bottle gourd ( Lagenaria vulgaris ) which occurs in a great variety of forms, and, when the interior part is removed, serves for bottles, dippers, cups, and other dishes.
Diseased with, or subject to, the gout; as, a gouty person; a gouty joint.
A mow; a rick for hay.
The daisy, or mountain daisy.
Gold; wealth.
To make a, booby of one); to stupefy.
A loose, flowing upper garment
See Grail , a dish.
A vessel used on the Malabar coast, having two or three masts.
The exercise of love, kindness, mercy, favor; disposition to benefit or serve another; favor bestowed or privilege conferred.
A step or degree in any series, rank, quality, order; relative position or standing; as, grades of military rank; crimes of every grade ; grades of flour.
A German title of nobility, equivalent to earl in English, or count in French. See Earl .
A steward; an overseer.
A small shoot or scion of a tree inserted in another tree, the stock of which is to support and nourish it. The two unite and become one tree, but the graft determines the kind of fruit.
A book of offices in the Roman Catholic Church; a gradual.
To paint in imitation of the grain of wood, marble, etc.
A dungfork.
The East Indian name of the chick-pea ( Cicer arietinum ) and its seeds; also, other similar seeds there used for food.
Anger; wrath; scorn.
Of large size or extent; great; extensive; hence, relatively great; greatest; chief; principal; as, a grand mountain; a grand army; a grand mistake.
See Groan .
To give over; to make conveyance of; to give the possession or title of; to convey; -- usually in answer to petition.

A well-known edible berry growing in pendent clusters or bunches on the grapevine. The berries are smooth-skinned, have a juicy pulp, and are cultivated in great quantities for table use and for making wine and raisins.
A curve or surface, the locus of a point whose coordinates are the variables in the equation of the locus; as, a graph of the exponential function .
Composed of, or resembling, grapes.
To seize and hold by clasping or embracing with the fingers or arms; to catch to take possession of.
Popularly: Herbage; the plants which constitute the food of cattle and other beasts; pasture.
Serving to gratify; agreeable.
To clean, as a vessel's bottom, of barnacles, grass, etc., and pay it over with pitch; -- so called because graves or greaves was formerly used for this purpose.
The juice or other liquid matter that drips from flesh in cooking, made into a dressing for the food when served up.

any color of neutral hue between white and black; white mixed with black, as the color of pepper and salt, or of ashes, or of hair whitened by age; sometimes, a dark mixed color; as, the soft gray eye of a dove .
To feed or supply (cattle, sheep, etc.) with grass; to furnish pasture for.
See Gree , a step.
Large in space; of much size; big; immense; enormous; expanded; -- opposed to small and little ; as, a great house, ship, farm, plain, distance, length .

One of several swimming birds or divers, of the genus Colymbus (formerly Podiceps ), and allied genera, found in the northern parts of America, Europe, and Asia. They have strong, sharp bills, and lobate toes.
Good will; favor; pleasure; satisfaction; -- used esp. in such phrases as: to take in gree ; to accept in gree ; that is, to take favorably.
An eager desire or longing; greediness; as, a greed of gain .
Of or pertaining to Greece or the Greeks; Grecian.
Having the color of grass when fresh and growing; resembling that color of the solar spectrum which is between the yellow and the blue; verdant; emerald.
To weep; to cry; to lament.
To make heavy; to increase.
See Greet , to weep.
imp. of Grow .
See Gray (the correct orthography).
The genus of trees including the anchovy pear tree Grias cauliflora , whose fruit is somewhat like the mango.
A little pig.
A grating of thin parallel bars, similar to a gridiron.
To cut with a grating sound; to cut; to penetrate or pierce harshly; as, the griding sword .
Pain of mind on account of something in the past; mental suffering arising from any cause, as misfortune, loss of friends, misconduct of one's self or others, etc.; sorrow; sadness.
Grasp; reach.
A cricket or grasshopper.
Harsh; hard; severe; stern; rough.
A gridiron.
Of forbidding or fear-inspiring aspect; fierce; stern; surly; cruel; frightful; horrible.
Foul matter; dirt, rubbed in; sullying blackness, deeply ingrained.
Full of grime; begrimed; dirty; foul.
A snare; a gin.
To reduce to powder by friction, as in a mill, or with the teeth; to crush into small fragments; to produce as by the action of millstones.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Grind , contr. from grindeth .
The griffin.
A vulture; the griffin.
A costly kind of fur.
See Grice , a pig.
Sand or gravel; rough, hard particles.
Peace; security; agreement.
Same as 2d Grise .
To give forth a low, moaning sound in breathing; to utter a groan, as in pain, in sorrow, or in derision; to moan.
An old English silver coin, equal to four pence.
A mixture of spirit and water not sweetened; hence, any intoxicating liquor.
The snout of a swine.
obs. imp. of Grind .
A boy or young man; a waiter; a servant; especially, a man or boy who has charge of horses, or the stable.
To feel with or use the hands; to handle.
A heavy silk with a dull finish; as, gros de Naples; gros de Tours.
Great; large; bulky; fat; of huge size; excessively large.
a Polish monetary unit, equal to 1/100 of a zloty.
A cluster, crowd, or throng; an assemblage, either of persons or things, collected without any regular form or arrangement; as, a group of men or of trees; a group of isles .
Coarse meal; ground malt;
A smaller group of trees than a forest, and without underwood, planted, or growing naturally as if arranged by art; a wood of small extent.
Pertaining to, or resembling, a grove; situated in, or frequenting, groves.
To increase in size by a natural and organic process; to increase in bulk by the gradual assimilation of new matter into the living organism; -- said of animals and vegetables and their organs.
To utter a deep guttural sound, as an angry dog; to give forth an angry, grumbling sound.
p. p. of Grow .
To dig in or under the ground, generally for an object that is difficult to reach or extricate; to be occupied in digging.
A light, liquid food, made by boiling meal of maize, oatmeal, or flour in water or milk; thin porridge.
Forwards; with one's face to the ground.
Of a rough or stern manner, voice, or countenance; sour; surly; severe; harsh.
Morose; severe of countenance; sour; surly; glum; grim.
A thick, viscid fluid; a clot, as of blood.
To make a deep, short noise, as a hog; to utter a short groan or a deep guttural sound.
A constellation in the southern celestial hemisphere between Indus and Piscis Austrinus.
A measure equal to one tenth of a line.
To gride. See Gride .
A vulture; the griffin.

A suit worn by aviators and astronauts, designed to counteract the effects of high accelerations experienced in aerial maneuvers, in particular to avoid unconsciousness; called also anti-g suit . It exerts force on the abdomen and legs to prevent blackouts by counteracting the tendency of blood to accumulate below the heart, thus reducing the supply to the brain, when the forces due to acceleration are directed from head to toe.
A plant ( Aristolochia anguicida ) of Carthagena, used as an antidote to serpent bites.
A tropical tree of Central America and the West Indies and Puerto Rico ( Inga laurina ) having spikes of white flowers; it is used as shade for coffee plantations.
Any one of many species of large gallinaceous birds of Central and South America, belonging to Penelope , Pipile , Ortalis , and allied genera. Several of the species are often domesticated.
See Iguana .

A substance found in great abundance on some coasts or islands frequented by sea fowls, and composed chiefly of their excrement. It is rich in phosphates and ammonia, and is used as a powerful fertilizer.
The scarlet ibis. See Ibis .

To protect from danger; to secure against surprise, attack, or injury; to keep in safety; to defend; to shelter; to shield from surprise or attack; to protect by attendance; to accompany for protection; to care for.

A tropical tree, or its fruit, of the genus Psidium . Two varieties are well known, the P. pyriferum , or white guava , and P. pomiferum , or red guava . The fruit or berry is shaped like a pomegranate, but is much smaller. It is somewhat astringent, but makes a delicious jelly.
any thick messy substance.
A sharper; a rogue.
To form an opinion concerning, without knowledge or means of knowledge; to judge of at random; to conjecture.
