A visitor; a person received and entertained in one's house or at one's table; a visitor entertained without pay.
One of several very small species and varieties of African antelopes, of the genus Cephalophus , as the Cape guevi or kleeneboc ( Cephalophus pygmæa ); -- called also pygmy antelope .
A ludicrously false statment.
A loose, earthy deposit from water, found in the cavities or clefts of rocks, mostly white, but sometimes red or yellow, from a mixture of clay or ocher.
Same as Guaiac .
A West African antelope ( Tragelaphus scriptus ), curiously marked with white stripes and spots on a reddish fawn ground, and hence called harnessed antelope ; -- called also guiba.
A person who leads or directs another in his way or course, as in a strange land; one who exhibits points of interest to strangers; a conductor; also, that which guides; a guidebook.

An association of men belonging to the same class, or engaged in kindred pursuits, formed for mutual aid and protection; a business fraternity or corporation; as, the Stationers' Guild ; the Ironmongers' Guild . They were originally licensed by the government, and endowed with special privileges and authority.
Craft; deceitful cunning; artifice; duplicity; wile; deceit; treachery.

The criminality and consequent exposure to punishment resulting from willful disobedience of law, or from morally wrong action; the state of one who has broken a moral or political law; crime; criminality; offense against right.

Customary way of speaking or acting; custom; fashion; manner; behavior; mien; mode; practice; -- often used formerly in such phrases as: at his own guise ; that is, in his own fashion, to suit himself .
The upper front of the neck, next to the chin; the upper throat.
Pertaining to the gula or throat; as, gular plates . See Illust. of Bird , and Bowfin .
Act of gulching or gulping.
A flower. See Gold .
To give the color of gules to.
The tincture red, indicated in seals and engraved figures of escutcheons by parallel vertical lines. Hence, used poetically for a red color or that which is red.
A hollow place in the earth; an abyss; a deep chasm or basin,
Full of whirlpools or gulfs.
To deceive; to cheat; to mislead; to trick; to defraud.
A large knife.
To swallow eagerly, or in large draughts; to swallow up; to take down at one swallow.
Guilt. See Guilt .
Of or pertaining to gules; red.
The dense tissues which invest the teeth, and cover the adjacent parts of the jaws.
A soup thickened with the mucilaginous pods of the okra; okra soup.
A kind of soft tumor, usually of syphilitic origin.
Consisting of gum; viscous; adhesive; producing or containing gum; covered with gum or a substance resembling gum.
A dolt; a dunce.

A weapon which throws or propels a missile to a distance; any firearm or instrument for throwing projectiles, consisting of a tube or barrel closed at one end, in which the projectile is placed, with an explosive charge (such as guncotton or gunpowder) behind, which is ignited by various means. Pistols, rifles, carbines, muskets, and fowling pieces are smaller guns, for hand use, and are called small arms . Larger guns are called cannon , ordnance , fieldpieces , carronades , howitzers , etc. See these terms in the Vocabulary.
In Sanskrit grammar, a lengthening of the simple vowels a , i , e , by prefixing an a element. The term is sometimes used to denote the same vowel change in other languages.
any thick gooey and messy substance.

A strong, coarse kind of sacking, made from the fibers (called jute ) of two plants of the genus Corchorus ( C. olitorius and C. capsularis ), of India. The fiber is also used in the manufacture of cordage.
A small freshwater fish of South America and West Indies ( Lebistes reticulatus or Poecilia reticulata , originaly called Gerardinus guppyi ), often kept in aquariums; also called rainbow fish .
A whirlpool.
A young person of either sex. See Girl .
A level; a working.
An alvine evacuation; also, refuse matter.
A gutter or channel for water, hewn out of the bottom of a working drift.
Same as gooroo .

A sudden and violent issue of a fluid from an inclosed plase; an emission of a liquid in a large quantity, and with force; the fluid thus emitted; a rapid outpouring of anything; as, a gush of song from a bird .
extravagantly demonstrative; gushing{2}; as, to write unrestrained and gushy poetry .
A sudden squall; a violent blast of wind; a sudden and brief rushing or driving of the wind.
Nice or keen appreciation or enjoyment; relish; taste; fancy; as, he ate it with gusto .
Subject to, or characterized by, gusts or squalls; windy; stormy; tempestuous.
To take out the bowels from; to eviscerate.
marked by courage and determination in the face of difficulties or danger.
Charged or sprinkled with drops.

A rope, chain, or rod attached to anything to steady it; as: a rope to steady or guide an object which is being hoisted or lowered; a rope which holds in place the end of a boom, spar, or yard in a ship; a chain or wire rope connecting a suspension bridge with the land on either side to prevent lateral swaying; a rod or rope attached to the top of a structure, as of a derrick, and extending obliquely to the ground, where it is fastened.
A roundlet of tincture sanguine , which is blazoned without mention of the tincture.
See Gayal .
To shift from one side of a vessel to the other; -- said of the boom of a fore-and-aft sail when the vessel is steered off the wind until the sail fills on the opposite side.
To guide; to govern.
Fermented wort used for making vinegar.
To begin. See Gin .
To begin. See Gin .
A college servant; -- so called in Cambridge, England; at Oxford called a scout .
See Gypsum .

One of a vagabond race, whose tribes, coming originally from India, entered Europe in the 14th or 15th century, and are now scattered over Turkey, Russia, Hungary, Spain, England, etc., living by theft, fortune telling, horsejockeying, tinkering, etc. Cf. Bohemian , Romany .
Moving in a circular path or way; whirling; gyratory.
A circular motion, or a circle described by a moving body; a turn or revolution; a circuit.
See Gyrus .

A subordinary of triangular form having one of its angles at the fess point and the opposite side at the edge of the escutcheon. When there is only one gyron on the shield it is bounded by two lines drawn from the fess point, one horizontally to the dexter side, and one to the dexter chief corner.
A convoluted ridge between grooves; a convolution; as, the gyri of the brain; the gyri of brain coral . See Brain .
Delirious; senselessly extravagant; as, the man is clean gyte .
A shackle; especially, one to confine the legs; a fetter.

An exclamation denoting surprise, joy, or grief. Both as uttered and as written, it expresses a great variety of emotions, determined by the tone or the context. When repeated, ha, ha , it is an expression of laughter, satisfaction, or triumph, sometimes of derisive laughter; or sometimes it is equivalent to “Well, it is so.”
The deep-sea fishing for cod, ling, and tusk, off the Shetland Isles.
A sea fish. See Hake .
A fog; esp., a fog or mist with a chill wind.

The usual condition or state of a person or thing, either natural or acquired, regarded as something had, possessed, and firmly retained; as, a religious habit ; his habit is morose; elms have a spreading habit ; esp., physical temperament or constitution; as, a full habit of body .
See Habile .
A frame or grating of various kinds; as, a frame for drying bricks, fish, or cheese; a rack for feeding cattle; a grating in a mill race, etc.
The descent of a hill.
The nether world (according to classical mythology, the abode of the shades, ruled over by Hades or Pluto); the invisible world; the grave.

The pilgrimage to Mecca, performed by Muslims. It is the duty of Moslems to make a journey to Mecca at least once ina lifetime, or if that is not possible, three journeys to one of the alternate sacred sites.
A Muslim who has made a pilgrimage to Mecca; -- used among Orientals as a respectful salutation or a title of honor.
A handle; that part of an instrument or vessel taken into the hand, and by which it is held and used; -- said chiefly of a knife, sword, or dagger; the hilt.
A witch, sorceress, or enchantress; also, a wizard.
Same as Ha .
A large piece of woolen or cotton cloth worn by Arabs as an outer garment.
Small roundish masses of ice precipitated from the clouds, where they are formed by the congelation of vapor. The separate masses or grains are called hailstones .
To inclose for mowing; to set aside for grass.
The collection or mass of filaments growing from the skin of an animal, and forming a covering for a part of the head or for any part or the whole of the body.
Bearing or covered with hair; made of or resembling hair; rough with hair; hirsute.
a country on the island of Hispaniola.
A pilgrimage to Mecca; every Muslim must make this journey at least once.

The Egyptian asp or cobra ( Naja haje .) It is related to the cobra of India, and like the latter has the power of inflating its neck into a hood. Its bite is very venomous. It is supposed to be the snake by means of whose bite Cleopatra committed suicide, and hence is sometimes called Cleopatra's snake or asp . See Asp .
One who has made a journey to Mecca; Same as hadji .
A drying shed, as for unburned tile.
A wise man; a physician, esp. a Muslim.
Harold; -- a nickname.
Sound; entire; healthy; robust; not impaired; as, a hale body .
Consisting of a moiety, or half; as, a half bushel; a half hour; a half dollar; a half view.
A nook; a corner.
A building or room of considerable size and stateliness, used for public purposes; as, Westminster Hall , in London .
Same as Haulm .
The long jump, with weights in the hands, -- the most important of the exercises of the Pentathlon.

A luminous circle, usually prismatically colored, round the sun or moon, and supposed to be caused by the refraction of light through crystals of ice in the atmosphere. Connected with halos there are often white bands, crosses, or arches, resulting from the same atmospheric conditions.
The neck or throat.
To embrace about the neck; to salute; to greet.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Hold , contraction for holdeth .
To divide into two equal parts; as, to halve an apple ; to be or form half of.
a person who performs in a showy or exaggerated style; -- used especially of actors. Also used attributively, as, a ham actor .
In Turkey and other Oriental countries, a porter or burden bearer; specif., in Western India, a palanquin bearer.

One of the two curved pieces of wood or metal, in the harness of a draught horse, to which the traces are fastened. They are fitted upon the collar, or have pads fitting the horse's neck attached to them.
Same as Hamble .
To have; have.
A rich goblet, esp. one used on state occasions.
To raise; to elevate.
That part of the fore limb below the forearm or wrist in man and monkeys, and the corresponding part in many other animals; manus; paw. See Manus .
a person's power or discretionary action; as, my fate is in your hands .
Performed by the hand.
To suspend; to fasten to some elevated point without support from below; -- often used with up or out ; as, to hang a coat on a hook; to hang up a sign; to hang out a banner.
A parcel consisting of two or more skeins of yarn or thread tied together.
Same as handkerchief .
See 2d Hanse .
That part of an elliptical or many-centered arch which has the shorter radius and immediately adjoins the impost.
A leafless East Indian vine ( Sarcostemma acidum ); its sour milky juice was formerly used to make an intoxicating drink.
To clothe; to wrap.
By hap, chance, luck, or accident; perhaps; it may be.
Favored by hap, luck, or fortune; lucky; fortunate; successful; prosperous; satisfying desire; as, a happy expedient; a happy effort; a happy venture; a happy omen.
Not easily penetrated, cut, or separated into parts; not yielding to pressure; firm; solid; compact; -- applied to material bodies, and opposed to soft ; as, hard wood; hard flesh; a hard apple.
The refuse or coarse part of flax; tow.
Bold; brave; stout; daring; resolute; intrepid.
To excite; to tease, harass, or worry; to harry.
The apartments or portion of the house allotted to females in Muslim families.
To listen; to hearken.
A filamentous substance; especially, the filaments of flax or hemp.
The red-breasted merganser.
Injury; hurt; damage; detriment; misfortune.
The brains.
A musical instrument consisting of a triangular frame furnished with strings and sometimes with pedals, held upright, and played with the fingers.
A genus of marine univalve shells; the harp shells; -- so called from the form of the shells, and their ornamental ribs.
A fabulous winged monster, ravenous and filthy, having the face of a woman and the body of a vulture, with long claws, and the face pale with hunger. Some writers mention two, others three.
To make a predatory incursion; to plunder or lay waste.
Rough; disagreeable; grating
A stag; the male of the red deer. See the Note under Buck .
To draw; to drag; to carry off by violence.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Have .
See Haze , v. t.
That which is hashed or chopped up; meat and vegetables, especially such as have been already cooked, chopped into small pieces and mixed.
A basket made of rushes or flags, as for carrying fish.
To shut or fasten with a hasp.
2d pers. sing. pres. of Have , contr. of havest .
Celerity of motion; speed; swiftness; dispatch; expedition; -- applied only to voluntary beings, as men and other animals.
Involving haste; done, made, etc., in haste; as, a hasty retreat; a hasty sketch .
sing. pres. of Hote to be called. Cf.
To cross with lines in a peculiar manner in drawing and engraving. See Hatching .
Strong aversion coupled with desire that evil should befall the person toward whom the feeling is directed; as exercised toward things, intense dislike; hatred; detestation; -- opposed to love .
Hateful; detestable.
One who hates.
pres. & imp. sing. & pl. of Hote , to be called. See Hote .
A low-lying meadow by the side of a river.
To pull or draw with force; to drag.
The denuded stems or stalks of such crops as buckwheat and the cereal grains, beans, etc.; straw.
Lofty; haughty.
See Haulm , stalk.
To frequent; to resort to frequently; to visit pertinaciously or intrusively; to intrude upon.
To hold in possession or control; to own; as, he has a farm .
A bay, recess, or inlet of the sea, or the mouth of a river, which affords anchorage and shelter for shipping; a harbor; a port.
A possessor; a holder.
Wide and general destruction; devastation; waste.
The third eyelid, or nictitating membrane. See Nictitating membrane , under Nictitate .

One of numerous species and genera of rapacious birds of the family Falconidae . They differ from the true falcons in lacking the prominent tooth and notch of the bill, and in having shorter and less pointed wings. Many are of large size and grade into the eagles. Some, as the goshawk, were formerly trained like falcons. In a more general sense the word is not infrequently applied, also, to true falcons, as the sparrow hawk , pigeon hawk , duck hawk , and prairie hawk .
See Haulm , straw.
A hawse hole.
To lay snares for rabbits.
Light vapor or smoke in the air which more or less impedes vision, with little or no dampness; a lack of transparency in the air; hence, figuratively, obscurity; dimness.

A shrub or small tree of the genus Corylus , as the Corylus avellana , bearing a nut containing a kernel of a mild, farinaceous taste; the filbert. The American species are Corylus Americana , which produces the common hazelnut, and Corylus rostrata . See Filbert .
To make dry; to dry.
Thick with haze; somewhat obscured with haze; not clear or transparent.

High density lipoprotein, a lipoprotein that transports cholesterol in the blood; high levels are thought to be associated with decreased risk of coronary heart disease and atherosclerosis; sometimes called good cholesterol . Contrasted with LDL .

The man or male being (or object personified to which the masculine gender is assigned), previously designated; a pronoun of the masculine gender, usually referring to a specified subject already indicated.
The anterior or superior part of an animal, containing the brain, or chief ganglia of the nervous system, the mouth, and in the higher animals, the chief sensory organs; poll; cephalon.
Willful; rash; precipitate; hurried on by will or passion; ungovernable.
To cover, as a roof, with tiles, slate, lead, or the like.
The afterbirth or secundines of a beast.
A crowd; a throng; a multitude or great number of persons.
a large quantity. See heap , senses 2 and 3; as, he made heaps of money in the stock market .
Lying in heaps.
To perceive by the ear; to apprehend or take cognizance of by the ear; as, to hear sounds; to hear a voice; to hear one call.
imp. & p. p. of Hear .
A hollow, muscular organ, which, by contracting rhythmically, keeps up the circulation of the blood.

A force in nature which is recognized in various effects, but especially in the phenomena of fusion and evaporation, and which, as manifested in fire, the sun's rays, mechanical action, chemical combination, etc., becomes directly known to us through the sense of feeling. In its nature heat is a mode of motion, being in general a form of molecular disturbance or vibration. It was formerly supposed to be a subtile, imponderable fluid, to which was given the name caloric .

A low shrub ( Erica vulgaris or Calluna vulgaris ), with minute evergreen leaves, and handsome clusters of pink flowers. It is used in Great Britain for brooms, thatch, beds for the poor, and for heating ovens. It is also called heather , and ling .
To cause to move upward or onward by a lifting effort; to lift; to raise; to hoist; -- often with up ; as, the wave heaved the boat on land .
Having the heaves.
The bolt or latch of a door.

A thicket of bushes, usually thorn bushes; especially, such a thicket planted as a fence between any two portions of land; and also any sort of shrubbery, as evergreens, planted in a line or as a fence; particularly, such a thicket planted round a field to fence it, or in rows to separate the parts of a garden.
To mind; to regard with care; to take notice of; to attend to; to observe.
To lean or tip to one side, as a ship; as, the ship heels aport; the boat heeled over when the squall struck it.
The hip of the dog-rose.
A yarn measure of six hundred yards or 1/24 of a spindle. See Spindle .
Same as Haft , n.
Moderately heavy.
Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel , a German writer (1770-1831).
One who inherits, or is entitled to succeed to the possession of, any property after the death of its owner; one on whom the law bestows the title or property of another at the death of the latter.
imp. & p. p. of Hold .
Health; welfare.

A nonplane curve whose tangents are all equally inclined to a given plane. The common helix is the curve formed by the thread of the ordinary screw. It is distinguished from the spiral , all the convolutions of which are in the plane.
To overwhelm.

An exclamation used as a greeting, to call attention, as an exclamation of surprise, or to encourage one. This variant of Halloo and Holloo has become the dominant form. In the United States, it is the most common greeting used in answering a telephone.
See Haulm , straw.
A slave in ancient Sparta; a Spartan serf; hence, a slave or serf.

To furnish with strength or means for the successful performance of any action or the attainment of any object; to aid; to assist; as, to help a man in his work; to help one to remember ; -- the following infinitive is commonly used without to ; as, “ Help me scale yon balcony.”
The handle of an ax, hatchet, or adze.
An onomatopoetic word used as an expression of hesitation, doubt, etc. It is often a sort of voluntary half cough, loud or subdued, and would perhaps be better expressed by hm .
Relating to the blood or blood vessels; pertaining to, situated in the region of, or on the side with, the heart and great blood vessels; -- opposed to neural .

A substance, in the form of reddish brown, microscopic, prismatic crystals, formed from dried blood by the action of strong acetic acid and common salt; -- called also Teichmann's crystals. Chemically, it is a hydrochloride of hematin.
A plant of the genus Cannabis ( Cannabis sativa ), the fibrous skin or bark of which is used for making cloth and cordage. The name is also applied to various other plants yielding fiber.
The female of the domestic fowl; also, the female of grouse, pheasants, or any kind of birds; as, the heath hen ; the gray hen .
From this place; away.
Skillful; dexterous; clever.
See Hende .
The unit of electric induction; the induction in a circuit when the electro-motive force induced in this circuit is one volt, while the inducing current varies at the rate of one ampère a second.
To seize; to lay hold on; to catch; to get.
See Hip , the fruit of the dog-rose.

Liver of sulphur; a substance of a liver-brown color, sometimes used in medicine. It is formed by fusing sulphur with carbonates of the alkalies (esp. potassium), and consists essentially of alkaline sulphides. Called also hepar sulphuris (&unr_;) .
A combining form from Gr. "epta` , seven.
The form of the objective and the possessive case of the personal pronoun she ; as, I saw her with her purse out .
A plant whose stem does not become woody and permanent, but dies, at least down to the ground, after flowering.
Having the nature of, pertaining to, or covered with, herbs or herbage.
One who herds or assembles domestic animals; a herdsman; -- much used in composition; as, a shep herd ; a goat herd , and the like.
See Her , their.
Made of hair.
To praise; to worship.
Same as Harl , 2.
See Hermes , 2.
A heron; esp., the common European heron.
An illustrious man, supposed to be exalted, after death, to a place among the gods; a demigod, as Hercules.

Any wading bird of the genus Ardea and allied genera, of the family Ardeidae . The herons have a long, sharp bill, and long legs and toes, with the claw of the middle toe toothed. The common European heron ( Ardea cinerea ) is remarkable for its directly ascending flight, and was formerly hunted with the larger falcons.
A title of respect given to gentlemen in Germany, equivalent to the English Mister .
See the Note under Her , pron.
A kind of gate or portcullis, having iron bars, like a harrow, studded with iron spikes. It is hung above gateways so that it may be quickly lowered, to impede the advance of an enemy.

a unit of frequency equal to one cycle per second; it is abbreviated Hz . It is commonly used to specify the frequency of radio waves, and also the clock frequencies in digital computers. For these applications, kilohertz and megahertz are the most commonly used units, derived from hertz .
To worship; to glorify; to praise.
A measure of two hanks of linen thread.
Command; precept; injunction.
Variant of Hote .
A crag; a cliff; a glen with overhanging sides.
Variant of Huke .
A small genus of South American trees yielding latex. It includes the rubber tree , Hevea brasiliensis , originally found in South America, but now used for production of rubber world-wide.
To cut with an ax; to fell with a sharp instrument; -- often with down , or off .
A domestic servant; a retainer.
One who hews.
Felled, cut, or shaped as with an ax; roughly squared; as, a house built of hewn logs .

An atom whose valence is six, and which can be theoretically combined with, substituted for, or replaced by, six monad atoms or radicals; as, sulphur is a hexad in sulphuric acid . Also used as an adjective.
A univalent organic radical, C6H13- , regarded as the essential residue of hexane , and a related series of compounds.
An exclamation of joy, surprise, or encouragement.
A wretch; a rascal.
A person who is not very intelligent or interested in culture; a hayseed.
imp. & p. p. of Hide . See Hidden .
To conceal, or withdraw from sight; to put out of view; to secrete.
One who hides or conceals.
To hasten; to go in haste; -- also often with the reciprocal pronoun.

An electronic device that plays phonograph records, reproducing the original sound with a high degree of fidelity. It superseded the older phonographs, and itself is being displaced in popularity by CD players.

Elevated above any starting point of measurement, as a line, or surface; having altitude; lifted up; raised or extended in the direction of the zenith; lofty; tall; as, a high mountain, tower, tree; the sun is high .
A variant of Height .
See Eagre .
To move with a swing, toss, throw, jerk, or the like.
Of or pertaining to a hilum.
Belonging to the hilum.
To hide. See Hele .
A natural elevation of land, or a mass of earth rising above the common level of the surrounding land; an eminence less than a mountain.
Abounding with hills; uneven in surface; as, a hilly country .
A handle; especially, the handle of a sword, dagger, or the like.
The eye of a bean or other seed; the mark or scar at the point of attachment of an ovule or seed to its base or support; -- called also hile .
Same as Hilum , 2.
Them. See Hem .
A Hebrew measure of liquids, containing three quarts, one pint, one gill, English measure.
The female of the red deer, of which the male is the stag.
The name given by Europeans to that form of the Hindustani language which is chiefly spoken by native Hindus. In employs the Devanagari character, in which Sanskrit is written.
Same as Hindoo . This is now the more commonly used spelling.
A servant; a farm laborer; a peasant; a hind.
To attach by, or furnish with, hinges.
A reaping hook.
A hybrid between a stallion and an ass; -- correlative of the mule .
To bring to mind by a slight mention or remote allusion; to suggest in an indirect manner; as, to hint a suspicion .
To dislocate or sprain the hip of, to fracture or injure the hip bone of (a quadruped) in such a manner as to produce a permanent depression of that side.
A throw in which the wrestler lifts his opponent from the ground, swings him to one side, knocks up his nearer thigh from the back with the knee, and throws him on his back.
A genus of marine decapod crustaceans, which burrow rapidly in the sand by pushing themselves backward; -- called also bait bug . See Illust. under Anomura .
Same as hippopotamus .
See Here , pron.
See Here , pron.
performing work for pay; as, hired hands .
One who hires.
Hers; theirs. See Here , pron.
Belonging or pertaining to him ; -- used as a pronominal adjective or adjective pronoun; as, tell John his papers are ready ; formerly used also for its , but this use is now obsolete.

To make with the mouth a prolonged sound like that of the letter s , by driving the breath between the tongue and the teeth; to make with the mouth a sound like that made by a goose or a snake when angered; esp., to make such a sound as an expression of hatred, passion, or disapproval.
Hush; be silent; -- a signal for silence.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Hide , contracted from hideth .
To become entangled or caught; to be linked or yoked; to unite; to cling.
A port or small haven; -- used in composition; as, Lambhithe , now Lambeth .
To make sexual advances toward; -- usually of men making advances to women.
A box, basket, or other structure, for the reception and habitation of a swarm of honeybees.
One who collects bees into a hive.
A health maintenance organization; a form of group health insurance that entitles members to services of participating hospitals and clinics and physicians.
A prefix used in the names of British warships, meaning His Majesty's Ship or Her Majesty's Ship ; as, H. M. S. Pinafore .
a colorless explosive liquid that is volatile, poisonous, and foul-smelling.
The chemical formula for water .
White, or grayish white; as, hoar frost; hoar cliffs .
See Hoarding , 2.
White or whitish.
A deception for mockery or mischief; a deceptive trick or story; a practical joke.
A fairy; a sprite; an elf.
A small, strong-winged European falcon ( Falco subbuteo ), formerly trained for hawking.
A small mortar on a gun carriage, in use before the howitzer.
A professional tramp; one who spends his life traveling from place to place, esp. by stealing rides on trains, and begging for a living.
A hautboy or oboe.
The crested curassow; -- called also royal pheasant . See Curassow .
A Rhenish wine, of a light yellow color, either sparkling or still. The name is also given indiscriminately to all Rhenish wines.
To deceive or cheat.

A kind of wooden tray with a handle, having V-shaped trough, made of wood or metal, attached to a long handle and usually carried over the shoulder; it is a tool used by construction workers for carrying bricks or mortar.
See Dun crow , under Dun , a.
A blind god; misled by Loki he kills Balder by throwing a bough of mistletoe.

A tool chiefly for digging up weeds, and arranging the earth about plants in fields and gardens. It is made of a flat blade of iron or steel having an eye or tang by which it is attached to a wooden handle at an acute angle.
Careful; wary.

A quadruped of the genus Sus , and allied genera of Suidæ ; esp., the domesticated varieties of Sus scrofa , kept for their fat and meat, called, respectively, lard and pork ; swine; porker; specifically, a castrated boar; a barrow.
An earth-covered Navajo lodge; it is traditionally built with the entrance facing east.
A hill; a cliff.
High flavor; strong scent.
To raise; to lift; to elevate; esp., to raise or lift to a desired elevation, by means of tackle, as a sail, a flag, a heavy package or weight.
To leap; to caper; to romp noisily.
Scorn; derision; abusive talk.
The whole interior portion of a vessel below the lower deck, in which the cargo is stowed.
A hollow place or cavity; an excavation; a pit; an opening in or through a solid body, a fabric, etc.; a perforation; a rent; a fissure.
having pores or holes.
See Hollo , v. i.
Ho there; stop; attend; hence, a loud cry or a call to attract attention; a halloo.

A tree or shrub of the genus Ilex . The European species ( Ilex Aquifolium ) is best known, having glossy green leaves, with a spiny, waved edge, and bearing berries that turn red or yellow about Michaelmas.
A common evergreen oak, of Europe ( Quercus Ilex ); -- called also ilex , and holly .
imp. & p. p. of Help .
3d pers. sing. pres. of Hold , contr. from holdeth .
Set apart to the service or worship of God; hallowed; sacred; reserved from profane or common use; holy vessels; a holy priesthood.
See Homelyn .
A carrier pigeon remarkable for its ability to return home from a distance; also called a homing pigeon .
having a feeling of home; cozy and comfortable; as, the homey everyday atmosphere; a restaurant with a homey atmosphere .
To grumble; pine; lament; long.
A sweet viscid fluid, esp. that collected by bees from flowers of plants, and deposited in the cells of the honeycomb.
A mercantile establishment or factory for foreign trade in China, as formerly at Canton; a succession of offices connected by a common passage and used for business or storage.
The cry of a wild goose.
A white (caucasian) person; -- a term used by some African-Americans, intended to be disparaging and often taken as offensive.
Esteem due or paid to worth; high estimation; respect; consideration; reverence; veneration; manifestation of respect or reverence.
See under Hunt .
an illicitly distilled (and usually inferior) alcoholic liquor.
State; condition.
The hooded crow; also, in Scotland, the hooded gull.
The horny substance or case that covers or terminates the feet of certain animals, as horses, oxen, etc.

A piece of metal, or other hard material, formed or bent into a curve or at an angle, for catching, holding, or sustaining anything; as, a hook for catching fish; a hook for fastening a gate; a boat hook , etc.
Full of hooks; pertaining to hooks.
A pliant strip of wood or metal bent in a circular form, and united at the ends, for holding together the staves of casks, tubs, etc.
The game of basketball.
To cry out or shout in contempt.
A disease in cattle consisting in inflammation of the stomach by gas, ordinarily caused by eating too much green food; tympany; bloating.
To move by successive leaps, as toads do; to spring or jump on one foot; to skip, as birds do.
A sloping plain between mountain ridges.
One who hopes.
A collector of customs, as at Canton; an overseer of commerce.
Of or pertaining to an hour, or to hours.
A wandering troop or gang; especially, a clan or tribe of a nomadic people migrating from place to place for the sake of pasturage, plunder, etc.; a predatory multitude.

A hard, projecting, and usually pointed organ, growing upon the heads of certain animals, esp. of the ruminants, as cattle, goats, and the like. The hollow horns of the Ox family consist externally of true horn, and are never shed.
Having horns or hornlike projections.

A hoofed quadruped of the genus Equus ; especially, the domestic horse ( Equus caballus ), which was domesticated in Egypt and Asia at a very early period. It has six broad molars, on each side of each jaw, with six incisors, and two canine teeth, both above and below. The mares usually have the canine teeth rudimentary or wanting. The horse differs from the true asses, in having a long, flowing mane, and the tail bushy to the base. Unlike the asses it has callosities, or chestnuts, on all its legs. The horse excels in strength, speed, docility, courage, and nobleness of character, and is used for drawing, carrying, bearing a rider, and like purposes.
Pertaining to, or suggestive of, a horse, or of horse racing; as, horsy manners; garments of fantastically horsy fashions.
Close-fitting trousers or breeches, as formerly worn, reaching to the knee.
The consecrated wafer, believed to be the body of Christ, which in the Mass is offered as a sacrifice; also, the bread before consecration.
A genus of robust East Asian clump-forming perennial herbs having racemose flowers: plantain lilies; sometimes placed in the family Hostaceae .
imp. & p. p. of Hote .
To command; to enjoin.
A house for entertaining strangers or travelers; an inn or public house, of the better class.
p. p. of Hote .
In a hot or fiery manner; ardently; vehemently; violently; hastily; as, a hotly pursued .
Same as Hock , a joint.
A piece of woodland; a small wood. [Obs.] See Holt .

A variety of the domestic dog, usually having large, drooping ears, esp. one which hunts game by scent, as the foxhound, bloodhound, deerhound, but also used for various breeds of fleet hunting dogs, as the greyhound, boarhound, etc.
See Hoopoe .
The twenty-fourth part of a day; sixty minutes.
A nymph of paradise; -- so called by the Muslims.
Goddess of the seasons, or of the hours of the day.
A structure intended or used as a habitation or shelter for animals of any kind; but especially, a building or edifice for the habitation of man; a dwelling place, a mansion.
A saddlecloth; a housing.
A head covering of various kinds; a hood; a coif; a cap.
imp. & p. p. of Heave .
An open shed for sheltering cattle, or protecting produce, etc., from the weather.
p. p. of Heave .
A cover; a shelter; a protection.
In what manner or way; by what means or process.
A tool used by coopers for smoothing and chamfering rheir work, especially the inside of casks.
To utter a loud, protracted, mournful sound or cry, as dogs and wolves often do.
To cry out; to whoop.
A hood. See Houve .
To hock; to hamstring. See Hock .
A small coaster vessel, usually sloop-rigged, used in conveying passengers and goods from place to place, or as a tender to larger vessels in port.
any plant of the genus Hoya having fleshy leaves and usually nectariferous flowers.
Headquarters, the place from which a commander performs the functions of command.
An abbreviation for hour , the period of time equal to 1/24th of a day.
Herpes simplex 1, a herpes virus that causes oral herpes; also called type I Herpes .
An administrative subdivision of a fu , or department, or of an independent chow; also, the seat of government of such a district.
The central part, usually cylindrical, of a wheel; the nave. See Illust. of Axle box .
Full of hubs or protuberances; as, a road that has been frozen while muddy is hubby .
A large salmon ( Salmo hucho or Salvelinus hucho ) inhabiting the Danube; -- called also huso , and bull trout .
To higgle in trading.
A huck or hull, as of a nut.
An iron bucket for hoisting coal or ore.
Color or shade of color; tint; dye.
Having color; -- usually in composition; as, bright- hued ; many- hued .
One who cries out or gives an alarm; specifically, a balker; a conder. See Balker .
To swell; to enlarge; to puff up; as, huffed up with air .
Puffed up; as, huffy bread .
To cower; to crouch; to curl up.
Very large; enormous; immense; excessive; -- used esp. of material bulk, but often of qualities, extent, etc.; as, a huge ox; a huge space; a huge difference.
An outer garment worn in Europe in the Middle Ages.
See Uhlan .
The body of a ship or decked vessel of any kind; esp., the body of an old vessel laid by as unfit for service.
The outer covering of anything, particularly of a nut or of grain; the outer skin of a kernel; the husk.
See Hollo .
Having or containing hulls.
To make a low, prolonged sound, like that of a bee in flight; to drone; to murmur; to buzz; as, a top hums .
Belonging to man or mankind; having the qualities or attributes of a man; of or pertaining to man or to the race of man; as, a human voice; human shape; human nature; human sacrifices.
Pertaining to, or derived from, vegetable mold; as, humic acid . See Humin .
Containing sensible moisture; damp; moist; as, a humid air or atmosphere ; somewhat wet or watery; as, humid earth ; consisting of water or vapor.

A bitter, brownish yellow, amorphous substance, extracted from vegetable mold, and also produced by the action of acids on certain sugars and carbohydrates; -- called also humic acid , ulmin , gein , ulmic or geic acid , etc.
Moisture, especially, the moisture or fluid of animal bodies, as the chyle, lymph, etc.; as, the humors of the eye, etc.
A protuberance; especially, the protuberance formed by a crooked back.
An exclamation denoting surprise, or contempt, doubt, etc.
Full of humps or bunches; covered with protuberances; humped.
That portion of the soil formed by the decomposition of animal or vegetable matter. It is a valuable constituent of soils.
One of a warlike nomadic people of Northern Asia who, in the 5th century, under Atilla, invaded and conquered a great part of Europe.
A hump; a protuberance.
imp. & p. p. of Hang .
A large lump or piece; a hunch; as, a hunk of bread .
A covetous, sordid man; a miser; a niggard.
All right; in a good condition; also, even; square.
To search for or follow after, as game or wild animals; to chase; to pursue for the purpose of catching or killing; to follow with dogs or guns for sport or exercise; as, to hunt a deer .
The coarse part of flax or hemp; hards.
To send whirling or whizzing through the air; to throw with violence; to drive with great force; as, to hurl a stone or lance .
Noise; confusion; uproar.
To make a rolling or burring sound.
To hasten; to impel to greater speed; to urge on.
A wood or grove; -- a word used in the composition of many names, as in Hazle hurst .
A band on a trip-hammer helve, bearing the trunnions.
To still; to silence; to calm; to make quiet; to repress the noise or clamor of.
The external covering or envelope of certain fruits or seeds; glume; hull; rind; in the United States, especially applied to the covering of the ears of maize.
Abounding with husks; consisting of husks.

A large European sturgeon ( Huso huso or Acipenser huso ), inhabiting the region of the Black and Caspian Seas. It sometimes attains a length of more than twelve feet, and a weight of two thousand pounds. Called also hausen and beluga . It is the source of the finest and most esteemed caviar.
A housewife or housekeeper.
A small house, hivel, or cabin; a mean lodge or dwelling; a slightly built or temporary structure.
To place in huts; to live in huts; as, to hut troops in winter quarters .
To buzz; to murmur.
A word used as a shout of joy, exultation, approbation, or encouragement.

A serpent or monster in the lake or marsh of Lerna, in the Peloponnesus, represented as having many heads, one of which, when cut off, was immediately succeeded by two others, unless the wound was cauterized. It was slain by Hercules. Hence, a terrible monster.
A hydro-aëroplane.

Any carnivorous mammal of the family Hyænidæ , doglike nocturnal mammals of Africa and southern Asia, of which three living species are known. They are large and strong, but cowardly. They feed chiefly on carrion, and are nocturnal in their habits.
See Haik , and Huke .
Of or pertaining to matter; material; corporeal; as, hylic influences .
The wild ass of Persia.
A fold of muscous membrane often found at the orifice of the vagina in virgins; the vaginal membrane. It is usually torn by sexual intercourse.
An ode or song of praise or adoration; especially, a religious ode, a sacred lyric; a song of praise or thanksgiving intended to be used in religious service; as, the Homeric hymns ; Watts' hymns .
A servant. See Hine .
Having the form of an arch, or of the Greek letter upsilon [Υ].
An abbreviation of hypochonaria ; -- usually in plural.
any of the threadlike filaments forming the mycelium of a fungus. See hyphae .
Hypochondria.

Any animal of the genus Hyrax , of which about four species are known. They constitute the order Hyracoidea . The best known species are the daman ( Hyrax Syriacus ) of Palestine, and the klipdas ( Hyrax capensis ) of South Africa. Other species are Hyrax arboreus and Hyrax Sylvestris , the former from Southern, and the latter from Western, Africa. See Daman .
A wood. See Hurst .
A fragrant kind of green tea.
A small haven. See Hithe .
Indoleacetic acid, a plant hormone promoting elongation of stems and roots.
An iambus or iambic.
One of several species of wild goats having very large, recurved horns, transversely ridged in front; -- called also steinbok .

Any bird of the genus Ibis and several allied genera, of the family Ibidæ , inhabiting both the Old World and the New. Numerous species are known. They are large, wading birds, having a long, curved beak, and feed largely on reptiles.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development , a United Nations agency created to assist developing nations by loans guaranteed by member governments.
Henrik Ibsen (1828-1906), Norwegian poet and dramatist.
A small tropical American tree ( Chrysobalanus icaco ) bearing edible plumlike fruit.
An intercontinental ballistic missile, a long-range ballistic missile that is capable of traveling from one continent to another. Contrasted with IRBM .

Water or other fluid frozen or reduced to the solid state by cold; frozen water. It is a white or transparent colorless substance, crystalline, brittle, and viscoidal. Its specific gravity (0.92, that of water at 4° C. being 1.0) being less than that of water, ice floats.
Covered with ice.
An ethereal fluid that supplied the place of blood in the veins of the gods.
In an icy manner; coldly.
A coating or covering resembling ice, as of sugar and milk or white of egg; frosting.
very bad; repulsive; unpleasant; distasteful.
An image or representation; a portrait or pretended portrait.
Pertaining to, or caused by, a blow; sudden; abrupt.
The stress of voice laid upon accented syllable of a word. Cf. Arsis .
Pertaining to, resembling, or abounding in, ice; cold; frosty.
any document testifying to the identity of the bearer, especially a card or badge.
Same as first Id , the fish.
The transcript, image, or picture of a visible object, that is formed by the mind; also, a similar image of any object whatever, whether sensible or spiritual.
Existing in idea or thought; conceptional; intellectual; mental; as, ideal knowledge .
The actual existence supposed to correspond with an idea; the correlate in real existence to the idea as a thought or existence.
The same; the same as above; -- often abbreviated id.
The fifteenth day of March, May, July, and October, and the thirteenth day of the other months.
The syntactical or structural form peculiar to any language; the genius or cast of a language.
A man in private station, as distinguished from one holding a public office.
Of no account; useless; vain; trifling; unprofitable; thoughtless; silly; barren.
One who idles; one who spends his time in inaction; a lazy person; a sluggard.
In a idle manner; ineffectually; vainly; lazily; carelessly; ( Obs. ) foolishly.

An artificial international language, selected by the “Delegation for the Adoption of an Auxillary International Language” (founded at Paris in 1901), made public in 1907, and subsequently greatly revised and extended by a permanent committee or “Academy.” It is a revised and simplified form of Esperanto . It combines systematically the advantages of previous schemes with a thoroughly logical word formation, and has neither accented constants nor arbitrarily coined pronominal words. For each idea that root is selected which is already most international, on the principle of the “greatest facility for the greatest number of people.” The word “Ido” means in the language itself “offspring.” The official name is: “Linguo Internaciona di la Delegitaro (Sistema Ido).”
An image or representation of anything.

A short poem; properly, a short pastoral poem; as, the idyls of Theocritus ; also, any poem, especially a narrative or descriptive poem, written in an eleveted and highly finished style; also, by extension, any artless and easily flowing description, either in poetry or prose, of simple, rustic life, of pastoral scenes, and the like.
Abbreviation of Latin id est , that is.
In case that; granting, allowing, or supposing that; -- introducing a condition or supposition.
An Eskimo snow house.
The peculiar dress worn by pilgrims to Mecca.

A transliteration of the four constants forming the Hebrew tetragrammaton or “incommunicable name” of the Supreme Being, which in latter Jewish tradition is not pronounced save with the vowels of adonai or elohim , so that the true pronunciation is lost.
A tropical American tree ( Annona diversifolia ) grown in the southern U. S. having a whitish pink-tinged fruit.
Ear of corn.
Pertaining to the ileum.
The last, and usually the longest, division of the small intestine; the part between the jejunum and large intestine.

A morbid condition due to intestinal obstruction. It is characterized by complete constipation, with griping pains in the abdomen, which is greatly distended, and in the later stages by vomiting of fecal matter. Called also ileac passion or iliac passion .
The holm oak ( Quercus Ilex ).
Pertaining to ancient Ilium, or Troy.
A celebrated Greek epic poem, in twenty-four books, on the destruction of Ilium, the ancient Troy. The Iliad is ascribed to Homer.
Pertaining to the ilium; iliac.
Ilium, or Troy, the ancient city in Asia Minor that was the site of the Trojan War; -- a variant spelling of Ilium .
The dorsal one of the three principal bones comprising either lateral half of the pelvis; the dorsal or upper part of the hip bone. See Innominate bone , under Innominate .
Same; each; every.
Each one; every one.
Contrary to good, in a physical sense; contrary or opposed to advantage, happiness, etc.; bad; evil; unfortunate; disagreeable; unfavorable.

An imitation, representation, or similitude of any person, thing, or act, sculptured, drawn, painted, or otherwise made perceptible to the sight; a visible presentation; a copy; a likeness; an effigy; a picture; a semblance.
Among the Muslims, a minister or priest who performs the regular service of the mosque.
To put under a ban.
To bar in; to secure.
See Embay .
To sink or lay, as in a bed; to deposit in a partly inclosing mass, as of clay or mortar; to cover, as with earth, sand, etc.
To make like a bow; to curve; to arch; to vault; to embow.
To inclose in a box.
To tinge deeply; to dye; to cause to absorb; as, clothes thoroughly imbued with black .

A compound with, or derivative of, the imido group; specif., a compound of one or more acid radicals with the imido group, or with a monamine; hence, also, a derivative of ammonia, in which two atoms of hydrogen have been replaced by divalent basic or acid radicals; -- frequently used as a combining form; as, succin imide .
Pertaining to, containing, or combined with, the radical NH, which is called the imido group .
See Emmew .
To send in; to inject; to infuse; -- the correlative of emit .
To mix; to mingle.
A shoot; a scion; a bud; a slip; a graft.
To drive or urge forward or on; to press on; to incite to action or motion in any way.
To shut up or inclose, as in a pen.
A body of Kaffir warriors; a body of native armed men.
To infold or involve; to wrap up.

The specific signification of in is situation or place with respect to surrounding, environment, encompassment, etc. It is used with verbs signifying being, resting, or moving within limits, or within circumstances or conditions of any kind conceived of as limiting, confining, or investing, either wholly or in part. In its different applications, it approaches some of the meanings of, and sometimes is interchangeable with, within , into , on , at , of , and among .
Without contents; empty; void of sense or intelligence; purposeless; pointless; characterless; useless.
Unapt; not apt; unsuitable; inept.
A Japanese measure of length equal to about two and one twelfth yards.
An emperor or monarch of Peru before, or at the time of, the Spanish conquest; any member of this royal dynasty, reputed to have been descendants of the sun.
Of or pertaining to the Incas.
An island; -- often used in the names of small islands off the coast of Scotland, as in Inch colm, Inch keith, etc.
Same as Inkle .
To pass; to enter.
Azure-colored; of a bright blue color.
To provide with an index or table of references; to put into an index; as, to index a book, or its contents .
A country in Southern Asia; the two peninsulas of Hither and Farther India; in a restricted sense, Hither India, or Hindostan.
A dark red crystalline substance, isomeric with and resembling indigo blue, and obtained from isatide and dioxindol.
See Endow .
Same as Inermis .
To ingraft, as a tree or plant, by the insertion of a bud or eye; to inoculate.
To set; to fasten or fix by piercing or thrusting in; as, to infix a sting, spear, or dart .
Below; beneath; under; after; -- often used as a prefix.
A pasture or meadow; generally one lying low, near a river.
Flame; blaze; a fire; a fireplace.
A South American freshwater dolphin ( Inia Boliviensis ). It is ten or twelve feet long, and has a hairy snout.
Pertaining to the inion.
The external occipital protuberance of the skull.
The step, or socket, in which the lower end of a millstone spindle runs.
One who, or that which, inks; especially, in printing, the pad or roller which inks the type.
A kind of tape or braid.
Consisting of, or resembling, ink; soiled with ink; black.
To clear of outlawry or attainder; to place under the protection of the law.

To lay within; hence, to insert, as pieces of pearl, ivory, mother-of-pearl, choice woods, or the like, in a groundwork of some other material; to form an ornamental surface; to diversify or adorn with insertions.
A passage by which an inclosed place may be entered; a place of ingress; entrance;
Internal; interior; secret.
To inclose, as in a mew or cage.
A place of shelter; hence, dwelling; habitation; residence; abode.
Further in; interior; internal; not outward; as, an inner chamber .
Lit., in or against a (or the) thing;

A small closed receptacle or set of receptacles of hard material, as lacquered wood, iron, bronze, or ivory, used by the Japanese to hold medicines, perfumes, and the like, and carried in the girdle. It is usually secured by a silk cord by which the wearer may grasp it, which cord passes through an ornamental button or knob called a netsuke.
That which is inserted or set in; an insertion.
in or of the present month; same as instant {3}, a. or instant {2}, n. ; as, your letter of the 10th inst. .
See Ensue , v. i.
To deposit and cover in the earth; to bury; to inhume; as, to inter a dead body .
To the inside of; within. It is used in a variety of applications.
To apply in use; to train; to discipline; to use or accustom till use gives little or no pain or inconvenience; to harden; to habituate; to practice habitually.
To put in an urn, as the ashes of the dead; hence, to bury; to intomb.
Inward sense; mind; understanding; conscience.
An exclamation of joy or triumph; -- often interjectional.
An oily liquid, CI3.CHO , analogous to chloral and bromal.
Pertaining to, or containing, iodine; specif., denoting those compounds in which it has a relatively high valence; as, iodic acid .
A crystallized substance of the composition C4I4NH , technically tetra-iodo-pyrrol, used like iodoform.

an atom or goup of atoms (radical) carrying an electrical charge. It is contrasted with neutral atoms or molecules, and free radicals. Certain compounds, such as sodium chloride, are composed of complementary ions in the solid (crystalline) as well as in solution. Others, notably acids such as hydrogen chloride, may occur as neutral molecules in the pure liquid or gas forms, and ionize almost completely in dilute aqueous solutions. In solutions (as in water) ions are frequently bound non-covalently with the molecules of solvent, and in that case are said to be solvated. According to the electrolytic dissociation theory, the molecules of electrolytes are divided into ions by water and other solvents. An ion consists of one or more atoms and carries one unit charges of electricity, 3.4 x 10 -10 electrostatic units, or a multiple of this. Those which are positively electrified (hydrogen and the metals) are called cations ; negative ions (hydroxyl and acidic atoms or groups) are called anions .
A region of Western Asia Minor colonized by the Ancient Greeks.

A foot consisting of four syllables: either two long and two short, -- that is, a spondee and a pyrrhic, in which case it is called the greater Ionic ; or two short and two long, -- that is, a pyrrhic and a spondee, in which case it is called the smaller Ionic .

A paper having on it these letters, with a sum named, and duly signed; -- in use in England as an acknowledgment of a debt, and taken as evidence thereof, but not amounting to a promissory note; a due bill.
A tribe of Indians which formerly occupied the region now included in the State of Iowa.
a battle between the successors of Alexander the Great (301 BC); Lysimachus and Seleucus defeated Antigonus and Demetrius .
a measure of a person's intelligence as indicated by an intelligence test; the ratio of a person's mental age to their chronological age (multiplied by 100).
The chemical symbol for iridium, a metallic element of the platinum group. It has atomic number 77 and an atomic weight of 192.22.
individual retirement account; -- a special type of savings account allowed by law to provide deferred taxation of the interest paid.
A decree of the Sultan.
same as Iraqi.
The native name of Persia, the name adopted by the modern nation of Iran.
a native or inhabitant of Iran.
of or relating to Iraq or its people or culture; as, Iraqi oil; Iraqi terrorists .
Angry; incensed; enraged.
Anger; wrath.
Of or pertaining to the iris.
The goddess of the rainbow, and swift-footed messenger of the gods.
Of or pertaining to Ireland or to its inhabitants; produced in Ireland.
To weary; to give pain; to annoy.

A fragrant liquid substance, a mixture of several isomers of the formula C14H22O , forming the essence of the violet fragrance, commonly isolated from orris oil or from the rhizomes of Iris. The main ingredient in violets is α-irone , which occurs as both cis and trans stereoisomers. Called also 6-methylionone .
Irascible; passionate.
A fantastic grimace or contortion of the body.
The third person singular of the substantive verb be , in the indicative mood, present tense; as, he is ; he is a man . See Be .
Pertaining to the goddess Isis; as, Isiac mysteries .
See Aisle .
A little island.
A doctrine or theory; especially, a wild or visionary theory.
To send out; to put into circulation; as, to issue notes from a bank .
A battle (333 BC) in which Alexander the Great defeated the Persians under Darius III.
Same as Ixtle .
The neuter pronoun of the third person, corresponding to the masculine pronoun he and the feminine she , and having the same plural ( they , their or theirs , them ).
An early Latin version of the Scriptures (the Old Testament was translated from the Septuagint, and was also called the Italic version ).
An eruption of small, isolated, acuminated vesicles, produced by the entrance of a parasitic mite (the Sarcoptes scabei ), and attended with itching. It is transmissible by contact.
Infected with the itch.
Also; as an additional article.
A passage; esp., the passage between the third and fourth ventricles in the brain; the aqueduct of Sylvius.
Possessive form of the pronoun it . See It .
An intrauterine device , a contraceptive device consisting of a small, usually plastic object placed within the uterus to prevent conception.

A genus of chilognathous myriapods. The body is long and round, consisting of numerous smooth, equal segments, each of which bears two pairs of short legs. It includes the galleyworms. See Chilognatha .
Overgrown with ivy.
A battle (1590) in which the Huguenots under Henry IV. of France defeated the Catholics under the duke of Mayenne.

A plant of the genus Hedera ( Hedera helix ), common in Europe. Its leaves are evergreen, dark, smooth, shining, and mostly five-pointed; the flowers yellowish and small; the berries black or yellow. The stem clings to walls and trees by rootlike fibers.
Indeed; truly. See Ywis .
a bloody and prolonged military operation in which American marines landed and defeated Japanese defenders (February and March 1945).
Industrial Workers of the World (the name of two American labor organizations, one of which advocates syndicalism)
The Roman numerals signifying nine ; denoting a quantity consisting of one more than eight and one less than ten.
A South African bulbous plant of the Iris family, remarkable for the brilliancy of its flowers.
A Mexican name for a variety of Agave rigida , which furnishes a strong coarse fiber; also, the fiber itself, which is called also pita , and Tampico fiber .
The eighth month of the civil year in the Jewish calendar; the second month of the ecclesiastical year (in April and May).
A variety of the chamois found in the Pyrenees.
One of an Oriental religious sect which worships Satan or the Devil.
To thrust; to stab; to punch. See Job , v. t.
Originally, a kind of ruffle worn by men on the bosom of the shirt.

In Mexico and the southwestern United States, a kind of plastered house or hut, usually made by planting poles or timber in the ground, filling in between them with screen work or wickerwork, and daubing one or both sides with mud or adobe mortar; also, this method of construction.

A large tree, the Artocarpus integrifolia , common in the East Indies, closely allied to the breadfruit, from which it differs in having its leaves entire. The fruit is of great size, weighing from thirty to forty pounds, and through its soft fibrous matter are scattered the seeds, which are roasted and eaten. The wood is of a yellow color, fine grain, and rather heavy, and is much used in cabinetwork. It is also used for dyeing a brilliant yellow.
Dim. or pet from Jack
A Hebrew patriarch (son of Isaac, and ancestor of the Jews), who in a vision saw a ladder reaching up to heaven ( Gen. xxviii. 12 ); -- also called Israel .

A stone, commonly of a pale to dark green color but sometimes whitish. It is very hard and compact, capable of fine polish, and is used for ornamental purposes and for implements, esp. in Eastern countries and among many early peoples.
dulled by surfeit; as, the amoral, jaded , bored upper classes .
To cut into notches or teeth like those of a saw; to notch.
A sharpshooter. See Yager .
Having jags; set with teeth; notched; uneven; as, jaggy teeth .
A kind of prison; a building for the confinement of persons held in lawful custody, especially for minor offenses or with reference to some future judicial proceeding.
One of a numerous sect in British India, holding the tenets of Jainism.
see 1st Jack .
A South American striped frog ( Pseudis paradoxa ), remarkable for having a tadpole larger than the adult, and hence called also paradoxical frog .
An African parrot ( Psittacus erithacus ), very commonly kept as a cage bird; -- called also gray parrot .

The tubers of the Mexican plant Ipomœa purga (or Exogonium purga ) of the family Convolvulaceae , a climber much like the morning-glory. The abstract, extract, and powder, prepared from the tubers, are well known purgative (cathartic) medicines, and are also called jalap . Other species of Ipomœa yield several inferior kinds of jalap, as the Ipomœa Orizabensis , and Ipomœa tuberosa .
A kind of frock for children.
See Jam , v. t. & i.
William James , an American psychologist and philosopher (1842-1910). He was the brother of Henry James .
One of an intermediate order between angels and men.
A coin of Genoa; any small coin.
See Jaunt .
A machine of great antiquity, used in Bengal for raising water to irrigate land.
See Jaunty .

A Latin deity represented with two faces looking in opposite directions. Numa is said to have dedicated to Janus the covered passage at Rome, near the Forum, which is usually called the Temple of Janus. This passage was open in war and closed in peace.
Work varnished and figured in the Japanese manner; also, the varnish or lacquer used in japanning.
To jest; to play tricks; to jeer.
A jester; a buffoon.
A deep, broad-mouthed vessel of earthenware or glass, for holding fruit, preserves, etc., or for ornamental purposes; as, a jar of honey; a rose jar .
A callous tumor on the leg of a horse, below the hock.
A chief; an earl; in English history, one of the leaders in the Danish and Norse invasions.
A wig; -- so called, perhaps, from being made of, or resembling, Jersey yarn.
the husband of Medea and leader of the Argonauts who sailed in quest of the Golden Fleece.
To jolt; to jounce.
One of the islands of the Malay Archipelago belonging to the Netherlands.
A vagabond.
To scold; to clamor.
Having jaws; -- chiefly in composition; as, lantern- jawed .
Relating to the jaws.

Any one of the numerous species of birds belonging to Garrulus , Cyanocitta , and allied genera of the family Corvidae . They are allied to the crows, but are smaller, more graceful in form, often handsomely colored, and usually have a crest.
A gem of an azure color.

A type of music that originated in New Orleans around 1900 and developed through increasingly complex styles, but generally featuring intricate rhythms, improvisation, prominent solo segments, and great freedom in harmonic idiom played frequently in a polyphonic style, on various instruments including horn, saxophone, piano and percussion, but rarely stringed instruments.
resembling jazz{1} especially in its rhythm.
Job Control Language.
juvenile delinquent.
Jewish Defense League.
A twilled cotton cloth.
See 1st Jeer (b) .
A morass; a shallow lake.
A gear; a tackle.
See 1st Jeer (b) .
See Jig , 6.
Same as jihad .
A coachman; a driver; especially, one who drives furiously.
To become jelly; to come to the state or consistency of jelly.
A short crowbar. See Jimmy .
A machine for spinning a number of threads at once, -- used in factories. Also called spinning jenny .
Same as Jereed .
To cut into long slices or strips and dry in the sun; as, to jerk beef . See Charqui .
Moving by jerks and starts; characterized by abrupt transitions; as, a jerky vehicle; a jerky style.
Flimsy; jerry-built.
A short strap of leather or silk secured round the leg of a hawk, to which the leash or line, wrapped round the falconer's hand, was attached when used. See Illust. of Falcon .
Any representation or suggestion of the genealogy of Christ, in decorative art
The Savior ; the name of the Son of God as announced by the angel to his parents; the personal name of Our Lord, in distinction from Christ, his official appellation.
Same as 2d Get .
Made of jet, or like jet in color.
Originally, one belonging to the tribe or kingdom of Judah; after the return from the Babylonish captivity, any member of the new state; a Hebrew; an Israelite.
To dress, adorn, deck, or supply with jewels, as a dress, a sword hilt, or a watch; to bespangle, as with jewels; to bejewel.
Judea; also, a district inhabited by Jews; a Jews' quarter.
To move restively backward or sidewise, -- said of a horse; to balk.
To shift, as the boom of a fore-and-aft sail, from one side of a vessel to the other when the wind is aft or on the quarter. See Gybe .
A moment; an instant; as, I will be ready in a jiffy .
To dance a jig; to skip about.
A religious war against infidels or Muslim heretics; also, any bitter war or crusade for a principle or belief.
A young woman; a sweetheart. See Gill .
A woman who capriciously deceives her lover; a coquette; a flirt.
A short crowbar used by burglars in breaking open doors.
Neat; handsome; elegant. See Gimp .
See Jinnee .
To move quickly, esp. with a sudden turn; hence, to dodge; to escape by a quick turn; -- obs. or dial., except as a hunting term in pig-sticking.
noisy and mischievous merrymaking.
A person, object, influence, or supernatural being which is supposed to bring bad luck or to cause things to go wrong.
A waistcoat or kind of stays for women.
A Cuban timber tree ( Malpighia obovata ) with hard wood very resistant to moisture.
Any of several North African gerbils.
a style of jazz played by big bands popular in the 1930s; flowing rhythms but less complex than later styles of jazz.
Abbreviation for Junior , used after a name by a son who has the same first and last name as his father; -- less commonly used than Jr.
A sweetheart; a darling.
To do chance work for hire; to work by the piece; to do petty work.
a person trained to compete in sports; an athlete.
See Johannes .
Any young animal, especially a young kangaroo.
To move by jogs or small shocks, like those of a slow trot; to move slowly, leisurely, or monotonously; -- usually with on , sometimes with over .
A proper name of a man.
To be contiguous, close, or in contact; to come together; to unite; to mingle; to form a union; as, the bones of the skull join ; two rivers join .
To fit as if by joints; to coalesce as joints do; as, the stones joint , neatly .

A piece of timber laid horizontally, or nearly so, to which the planks of the floor, or the laths or furring strips of a ceiling, are nailed; -- called, according to its position or use, binding joist , bridging joist , ceiling joist , trimming joist , etc. See Illust. of Double-framed floor , under Double , a.
To make merry with; to make jokes upon; to rally; to banter; as, to joke a comrade .
One who makes jokes or jests.
Same as Jowl .
Joyful; merry; pleasant; jolly.
To cause to be jolly; to make good-natured; to encourage to feel pleasant or cheerful; -- often implying an insincere or bantering spirit; hence, to poke fun at.
To shake with short, abrupt risings and fallings, as a carriage moving on rough ground; as, the coach jolts .
That jolts; as, a jolty coach .
The Hebrew prophet, who was cast overboard as one who endangered the ship; hence, any person whose presence is unpropitious.
See Jorum .
A large drinking vessel; also, its contents.
A small gudgeon.
A Chinese household divinity; a Chinese idol.
A command to a horse, probably meaning “stand still.”
An iota; a point; a tittle; the smallest particle. Cf. Bit , n.
An iron collar fastened to a wall or post, formerly used in Scotland as a kind of pillory. [Written also juggs .] See Juke .

A unit of work which is equal to 10 7 ergs (the unit of work in the C. G. S. system of units), and is equivalent to one watt-second, the energy expended in one second by an electric current of one ampere in a resistance of one ohm; also called the absolute joule . It is abbreviated J or j . The international joule is slightly larger, being 1.000167 times the absolute joule. The absolute joule is approximately equal to 0.737562 foot pounds, 0.239006 gram-calories (small calories), and 3.72506 x 10 -7 horsepower-hours, and 0.000948451 B.t.u.
To engage in mock combat on horseback, as two knights in the lists; to tilt.
The cheek; the jaw.
To rejoice; to be glad; to delight; to exult.

A standardized format for storing graphic data in binary computer files, allowing over 16 million different colors. It allows for lossy compression, i. e. the compression of data into a form which re-expands into an image close, but not identical to the original image. Files stored in this format usually carry the extension jpg or jpeg . Compare GIF .
A vessel for holding ale or wine; a jug.
The mane of an animal.
The disciple who betrayed Christ.
To hear and determine by authority, as a case before a court, or a controversy between two parties.
a sport adapted from jujitsu, originally a method of self-defense without weapons, and similar to wrestling; it was developed in Japan.
To utter a sound resembling this word, as certain birds do, especially the nightingale.
A Roman measure of land, measuring 28,800 square feet, or 240 feet in length by 120 in breadth.
See Jougs .
One of the ridges commonly found on the fruit of umbelliferous plants.
The characteristic fluid of any vegetable or animal substance; the sap or part which can be expressed from fruit, etc.; the fluid part which separates from meat in cooking.
A bounding with juice; succulent.
Judgment; justice; sentence.
the magical power associated with a juju{2}.
To bend the neck; to bow or duck the head.
A catkin or ament. See Ament .
The seventh month of the year, containing thirty-one days.
Very large.
A kind of loose jacket for men.
Jumping, or inducing to jump; characterized by jumps;
Any bird of the genus Junco , which includes several species of North American finches; -- called also snowbird , or blue snowbird .
The sixth month of the year, containing thirty days.
Carl Gustav Jung , a noted Swiss psychiatrist and Psychologist(1875-1961).
A fragment of any solid substance; a thick piece. See Chunk .
A council; a convention; a tribunal; an assembly; esp., the grand council of state in Spain.
A secret council to deliberate on affairs of government or politics; a number of men combined for party intrigue; a faction; a cabal; as, a junto of ministers; a junto of politicians.
Same as Jupon .
1. A range of mountains between France and Switzerland.

A yellow carangoid fish of the Atlantic and Gulf coasts ( Caranx chrysos ), most abundant southward, where it is valued as a food fish; -- called also hardtail , horse crevallé , jack , buffalo jack , skipjack , yellow mackerel , and sometimes, improperly, horse mackerel . Other species of Caranx (as Caranx fallax ) are also sometimes called jurel .
For temporary use; -- applied to a temporary contrivance.
A delicate fiber, produced in the Philippine Islands from an unidentified plant, of which dresses, etc., are made.
Precisely; exactly; -- in place, time, or degree; neither more nor less than is stated.
That which projects or juts; a projection.

The coarse, strong fiber of the East Indian Corchorus olitorius , and Corchorus capsularis ; also, the plant itself. The fiber is much used for making mats, gunny cloth, cordage, hangings, paper, etc.
Jutlanders; one of the Low German tribes, a portion of which settled in Kent, England, in the 5th century.
A projection in a building; also, a pier or mole; a jetty.
A Brazilian name for the lofty myrtaceous tree ( Bertholetia excelsa ) which produces the large seeds known as Brazil nuts .
An unknown god; an epithet of Prajapati and Brahma.

The small and nearly cubical stone building, in the court of the Great Mosque at Mecca, toward which all Muslims must pray. It contains a sacred black stone, believed by Muslims to be one of the precious stones of paradise, and to have been brought to Abraham when he was contructing the Kaaba, by the Angel Gabriel. The Kaaba itself predates Mohammed, having been a pantheon which contained Arab idols, which were destroyed by Mohammed.
The hartbeest.
See Cabob , n. & v. t.
A Turkish judge. See Cadi .
The Arabian name of two trees of the genus Balsamodendron , which yield a gum resin and a red aromatic wood.
Same as Kaffir .
Franz Kafka , a writer, b. 1883, d. 1924.
A chantry chapel inclosed with lattice or screen work.

A singular, crested, grallatorial bird (Rhinochetos jubatus) , native of New Caledonia. It is gray above, paler beneath, and the feathers of the wings and tail are handsomely barred with brown, black, and gray. It is allied to the sun bittern.

A long-nosed monkey ( Nasalis larvatus , formerly Semnopithecus nasalis ), native of Borneo. The general color of the body is bright chestnut, with the under parts, shoulders, and sides of the head, golden yellow, and the top of the head and upper part of the back brown. Called also proboscis monkey . It is now an endangered species.
A kind of headless cabbage. Same as Kale , 1.
Poultry, etc., required by the lease to be paid in kind by a tenant to his landlord.
A New Zealand parrot of the genus Nestor , especially the brown parrot ( Nestor meridionalis ).
The sea otter.
The last and worst of the four ages of the world; -- considered to have begun B. C. 3102, and to last 432,000 years.
See Caliph .
The name of Vishnu in his tenth and last avatar.
One of the Brahmanic eons, a period of 4,320,000,000 years. At the end of each Kalpa the world is annihilated.
Crooked; awry.
The Hindu Cupid. He is represented as a beautiful youth, with a bow of sugar cane or flowers.
A low ridge.
A mountain in India and Tibet, 25,447 feet high.

A title given to the celestial gods of the first mythical dynasty of Japan and extended to the demigods of the second dynasty, and then to the long line of spiritual princes still represented by the mikado.
To know; to ken.
Fluor spar; -- so called by Cornish miners.
Immanuel Kant , a German philosopher (1724-1804).
The fossil resin of the kauri tree of New Zealand.
A silky wool derived from the seeds of Ceiba pentandra (syn. Eriodendron anfractuosum ), a bombaceous tree of the East and West Indies.
the unit of measurement for the proportion of gold in an alloy; 18-karat gold is 75 2.122e-314old; 24-karat gold is pure gold.
A language spoken in the Thai-Burmese borderlands.
One's acts considered as fixing one's lot in the future existence.
A pile of rocks; sometimes, the solid rock. See Cairn .
The twenty-fourth part of a grain; -- a weight used by goldsmiths.
An Arabian shrub ( Catha edulis ) the leaves of which are used as tea by the Arabs.
The brambling finch.
A tall coniferous tree of New Zealand Agathis australis , or Dammara australis ), having white straight-grained wood furnishing valuable timber and also yielding one kind of dammar resin .
Same as kauri .

A species of Macropiper ( Macropiper methysticum ), the long pepper, from the root of which an intoxicating beverage is made by the Polynesians, by a process of mastication; also, the beverage itself.

A light canoe, made of skins stretched over a frame, and usually capable of carrying but one person, who sits amidships and uses a double-bladed paddle. It is peculiar to the Eskimos and other Arctic tribes.
The dog salmon.
A kind of toy or rude musical instrument, as a tube inside of which is a stretched string or membrane made to vibrate by singing or humming into the tube.
A large New Zealand parrot ( Nestor notabilis ), notorious for having acquired the habit of killing sheep; -- called also mountain parrot .
See kabab and kabob .
To heave or to retch, as in an effort to vomit.
Resembling a kecksy.
To move (a vessel) by carrying out a kedge in a boat, dropping it overboard, and hauling the vessel up to it.
See Kie , Ky , and Kine .
A mass or lump of fat rolled up by the butcher.
To cool; to skim or stir.
Ninepins. See Kayles .
Sharp; having a fine edge or point; as, a keen razor, or a razor with a keen edge .
To care; to desire.
A vat or tub in which the mash is made; a mash tub.
An effervescent liquor like kumiss, made from fermented milk, used as a food and as a medicine in the northern Caucasus.
A small cask or barrel.
Having a kell or covering; webbed.
A sort of pottage; kale. See Kale , 2.
The calcined ashes of seaweed, -- formerly much used in the manufacture of glass, now used in the manufacture of iodine.
See Kilt , n.
Coarse, rough hair in wool or fur, injuring its quality.
Rough; shaggy.
The long flower stems of the ribwort plantain ( Plantago Lanceolata ).
p. p. of Kemb ; combed.
A house; esp., one which is a resort for thieves.
A gambling game, a variety of the game of lotto, played with balls or knobs, numbered, and cards also numbered.
A country in East Africa, formerly a British colony.

A military cap having a close-fitting band, a round flat top sloping toward the front, and a visor. As originally worn by the French in Algeria about 1830 it was tall and stiff with a straight visor. It is now lower, has a curved visor, and is frequently soft.
imp. & p. p. of Keep .
A notch, channel, or slit made in any material by cutting or sawing.
A light-armed foot soldier of the ancient militia of Ireland and Scotland; -- distinguished from gallowglass , and often used as a term of contempt.
See Kaiser .
Carrion; any filth.
A small salmon ( Oncorhynchus keta ) of inferior value, which in the autumn runs up all the larger rivers between San Francisco and Kamchatka.
An almost obsolete form of sailing vessel, with a mainmast and a mizzenmast, -- usually from one hundred to two hundred and fifty tons burden.
One of a series of series of complex nitrogenous substances, represented by methyl ketol and related to indol.
A strong cleat to which large ropes are belayed.
An instrument by means of which the bolt of a lock is shot or drawn; usually, a removable metal instrument fitted to the mechanism of a particular lock and operated by turning in its place.
Furnished with keys; as, a keyed instrument ; also, set to a key, as a tune.
Of a dull brownish yellow, or drab color; -- applied to cloth, originally to a stout brownish cotton cloth, used in making uniforms in the Anglo-Indian army.
A king; a prince; a chief; a governor; -- so called among the Tartars, Turks, and Persians, and in countries now or formerly governed by them.
A lofty West African tree ( Khaya Senegalensis ), related to the mahogany, which it resembles in the quality of the wood. The bark is used as a febrifuge.
A Dravidian of a group of tribes of Orissa, India, a section of whom were formerly noted for their cruel human sacrifices to the earth goddess, murder of female infants, and marriage by capture.
The Sumerian goddess personifying earth; the counterpart of Akkadian Aruru .
a deciduous South African tree ( Pterocarpus angolensis ) having large odd-pinnate leaves and profuse fragrant orange-yellow flowers; it yields a red juice and heavy strong durable wood.
The dziggetai .
A chap or crack in the flesh occasioned by cold; an ulcerated chilblain.
Chapped; cracked with cold; affected with chilblains; as, kibed heels .
Affected with kibes.
To strike, thrust, or hit violently with the foot; as, a horse kicks a groom; a man kicks a dog.
A young goat.
imp. of Kythe .
To deceive; to outwit; to hoax.
Kine; cows.
A large tub or vat in which goods are subjected to the action of hot lye or bleaching liquor; -- also called keeve .
See Keeve , n.
To gaze; to stare.
