An Australian boomerang, having one side flat and the other convex.

A channel or arm of the sea; a river; a stream; as, the channel between Staten Island and Bergen Neck is the Kill van Kull, or the Kills ; -- used also in composition; as, Schuyl kill , Cats kill , etc.

A large stove or oven; a furnace of brick or stone, or a heated chamber, for the purpose of hardening, burning, or drying anything; as, a kiln for baking or hardening earthen vessels; a kiln for drying grain, meal, lumber, etc.; a kiln for calcining limestone.
An abbreviation of Kilogram .
p. p. from Kill .
Crooked; arched; bent.
See Cymry .
A primitive Chinese instrument of the cittern kind, with from five to twenty-five silken strings.
Characteristic of the species; belonging to one's nature; natural; native.
A Chinese musical instrument, consisting of resonant stones or metal plates, arranged according to their tones in a frame of wood, and struck with a hammer.
See Quinic .
A unit of force equal to the force which, acting for one second, will give a pound a velocity of one foot per second; -- proposed by J. D. Everett , an English physicist.
To wind into a kink; to knot or twist spontaneously upon itself, as a rope or thread.
Full of kinks; liable to kink or curl; as, kinky hair .
The dark red dried juice of certain plants, used variously in tanning, in dyeing, and as an astringent in medicine.
A Turkish open summer house or pavilion, supported by pillars.
The hide of a young or small beef creature, or leather made from it; kipskin.
An osier basket used for catching fish.
A church or the church, in the various senses of the word; esp., the Church of Scotland as distinguished from other reformed churches, or from the Roman Catholic Church.
A workman's name for the graphite which forms incidentally in iron smelting.
To salute with the lips, as a mark of affection, reverence, submission, forgiveness, etc.
A chest; hence, a coffin.
A small violin.
To raise money by “kites;” as, kiting transactions. See Kite , 6 .
Acquaintance; kindred.
See Kythe .
imp. of Kit to cut.
A kitten; also, a pet name or calling name for the cat.

A large chamber built under, or in, the houses of a Pueblo village, used as an assembly room in religious rites or as a men's dormitory. It is commonly lighted and entered from an opening in the roof.
A mash vat. See Keeve .
See Click .
A glen; a ravine closed at its upper end.
To seize with the teeth; to gnaw.
To crack; to make a sharp, abrupt noise to chink.
A knot in wood; a protuberance.
A protuberance; a swelling; a knob; a button; hence, rising ground; a summit. See Knob , and Knop .
A knot in wood. See Gnarl .
A boy; especially, a boy servant.
To work and press into a mass, usually with the hands; esp., to work, as by repeated pressure with the knuckles, into a well mixed mass, as the materials of bread, cake, etc.; as, to knead dough .
The twisting of a rope or cable, as it is running out.
In man, the joint in the middle part of the leg.
Having knees;- used chiefly in composition; as, in- kneed ; out- kneed ; weak- kneed .
To bend the knee; to fall or rest on the knees; -- sometimes with down .
The stroke of a bell tolled at a funeral or at the death of a person; a death signal; a passing bell;
imp. & p. p. of Kneel .
imp. of Know .

An instrument consisting of a thin blade, usually of steel and having a sharp edge for cutting, fastened to a handle, but of many different forms and names for different uses; as, table knife , drawing knife , putty knife , pallet knife , pocket knife , pen knife , chopping knife , etc. .
A fried, or sometimes baked, turnover made from a round or square sheet of dough containing a filling, usually of meat or potatoes.
To form into a knot, or into knots; to tie together, as cord; to fasten by tying.
Small particles of ore.
A hard protuberance; a hard swelling or rising; a bunch; a lump; as, a knob in the flesh, or on a bone .
To drive or be driven against something; to strike against something; to clash; as, one heavy body knocks against another .
A little round hill; a mound; a small elevation of earth; the top or crown of a hill.
A knob; a bud; a bunch; a button.
Same as Knop , 2.
A fastening together of the parts or ends of one or more threads, cords, ropes, etc., by any one of various ways of tying or entangling.
A kind of whip for flogging criminals, formerly much used in Russia. The lash is a tapering bundle of leather thongs twisted with wire and hardened, so that it mangles the flesh.
To perceive or apprehend clearly and certainly; to understand; to have full information of; as, to know one's duty .
Waste silk formed in winding off the threads from a cocoon.
A lout; a clown.
A contorted knot in wood; a crossgrained protuberance; a nodule; a boss or projection.
a knockout; a blow that renders the opponent unconscious; -- used especially in boxing.

A tailless furry marsupial ( Phascolarctos cinereus ), found in Australia. The female carries her young on the back of her neck. Called also Australian bear , koala bear , native bear , and native sloth . The koala lives almost all of its life in trees, moves sluggishly like a sloth, and eats eucalyptus leaves almost exclusively.
Any one of several species of African antelopes of the genus Kobus , esp. the species Kobus sing-sing .

A kind of portable photographic camera, esp. adapted for snapshot work, in which a succession of negatives is made upon a continuous roll of sensitized film; -- originally a trademark name of the Eastman Kodak Company, but from early 1900's through the 1930's it was popularly applied to almost any hand camera.
Any one of several species of cuckoos of the genus Eudynamys , found in India, the East Indies, and Australia. They deposit their eggs in the nests of other birds.
A two-masted Dutch vessel.
The genus comprising the pygmy sperm whales.
A mixture of soot and other ingredients, used by Egyptian and other Eastern women to darken the edges of the eyelids.
Same as Cola , Cola nut .
To know. See Can , and Con .
A large African antelope ( Alcelaphus Lichtensteini ), allied to the hartbeest, but having shorter and flatter horns, and lacking a black patch on the face.
Hill; mountain.
A hillock; a small kop, especially a small hill rising up from the African veld.
A Hebrew unit of capacity.
The Scriptures of the Muslims, containing the professed revelations to Mohammed; -- called also Alcoran .
An Asian peninsula off Manchuria.
The gazelle.
an Indian unit of length having different values in different localities.
Same as kowtow , the more common spellings.
The chemical symbol for the element krypton , one of the six noble gases.
A long-tailed ape ( Macacus cynomolgus ) of India and Sumatra. It is reddish olive, spotted with black, and has a black tail.
A collection of huts within a stockade; a village; sometimes, a single hut.
A very venomous snake of India ( Bungarus coeruleus ), allied to the cobra. Its upper parts are bluish or brownish black, often with narrow white streaks; the belly is whitish.
The carcass of a whale after the blubber has been removed.
See Creel .
A variety of white lead. See Krems lead , under Lead , n.
See Krang .
A Malay dagger. See Creese .
A coin of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, of the value of about twenty-eight cents (in 1913). See Crown , n. , 9.
The East Indian tapir. See Tapir .
Glory; fame; renown; praise.
See Koodoo .
See Cufic .
See Koulan .

A member of a people who inhabit a mountainous region of Western Asia, sometimes referred to as Kurdistan, spread over an area including adjoining parts of Turkey, Iran, Iraq, Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Syria. The people of this region speak Kurdish and are mostly Moslem.
The packet of vellum leaves in which the gold is first beaten into thin sheets.
A thin, sour beer, made by pouring warm water on rye or barley meal and letting it ferment, -- much used by the Russians.

A trailing grass ( Cynodon dactylon ) native to Europe, now cosmopolitan in warm regions; used for lawns and pastures especially in the Southern U. S. and India. Called also Bahama grass and Bermuda grass .
A kind of danceable music popular among black South Africans; it includes a whistle among its instruments.
A pack sack to be swung on either side of a packsaddle.
Cocoanut fiber, or the cordage made from it. See Coir .
p. p. of Kythe .
imp. of Kythe , to show.
To look steadfastly; to gaze.
an Australian boomerang, having one side flat and the other convex.
See Cymry .
See Kyrie eleison .
To make known; to manifest; to show; to declare.
A syllable applied to the sixth tone of the scale in music in solmization.
A lace. See Lace .
To prate; to gossip; to babble; to blab.
To affix a label to; to mark with a name, etc.; as, to label a bottle or a package .
See Labium .

Physical toil or bodily exertion, especially when fatiguing, irksome, or unavoidable, in distinction from sportive exercise; hard, muscular effort directed to some useful end, as agriculture, manufactures, and like; servile toil; exertion; work.
One hundred thousand; also, a vaguely great number; as, a lac of rupees .

That which binds or holds, especially by being interwoven; a string, cord, or band, usually one passing through eyelet or other holes, and used in drawing and holding together parts of a garment, of a shoe, of a machine belt, etc.
Fastened with a lace or laces; decorated with narrow strips or braid. See Lace , v. t.
Blame; cause of blame; fault; crime; offense.
p. p. of Lead , to guide.
imp. of Lead , to guide.
To load; to put a burden or freight on or in; -- generally followed by that which receives the load, as the direct object.
Loaded; freighted; burdened; as, a laden vessel; a laden heart.
A Romansch dialect spoken in some parts of Switzerland and the Tyrol.
A cuplike spoon, often of large size, with a long handle, used in lading or dipping.
Belonging or becoming to a lady; ladylike.
p. p. of Leave .
imp. of Leave .
Coming tardily after or behind; slow; tardy.
See Ligan .
Lager beer.
Of or pertaining to a layman or the laity.
p. p. of Lie , v. i.
A lord; a landholder, esp. one who holds land directly of the crown.
See Lamaism .
The people, as distinguished from the clergy; the body of the people not in orders.
A pigment formed by combining some coloring matter, usually by precipitation, with a metallic oxide or earth, esp. with aluminium hydrate; as, madder lake ; Florentine lake ; yellow lake , etc.
One that is connected with a lake or lakes, as in habitation, toil, etc.:
Same as Lac , one hundred thousand.
See Ladykin .
Pertaining to a lake.
The powdered leaves of the baobab tree, used by the Africans to mix in their soup, as the southern negroes use powdered sassafras. Cf. Couscous .
To beat soundly; to thrash.
See Llama .
The young of the sheep.
Moving with pain or difficulty on account of injury, defect, or temporary obstruction of a function; as, a lame leg, arm, or muscle .
See Lamella .
Small steel plates combined together so as to slide one upon the other and form a piece of armor.
A monster capable of assuming a woman's form, who was said to devour human beings or suck their blood; a vampire; a sorceress; a witch.
A thin plate or lamina.

A local area network ; a network{3} connecting computers and word processors and other electronic office equipment within a small area, to create an inter-office system, typically within one building or one site of a corporation. Contrasted to WAN , a wide-area network.
an island in the Hawaiian chain.

A weapon of war, consisting of a long shaft or handle and a steel blade or head; a spear carried by horsemen, and often decorated with a small flag; also, a spear or harpoon used by whalers and fishermen.
To throw, as a lance; to let fly; to launch.
Urine. See Lant .

A passageway between fences or hedges which is not traveled as a highroad; an alley between buildings; a narrow way among trees, rocks, and other natural obstructions; hence, in a general sense, a narrow passageway; as, a lane between lines of men, or through a field of ice .
Slender and thin; not well filled out; not plump; shrunken; lean.
Somewhat lank; tall, thin, bony and ungraceful.
Same as lanseh .

Any one of several species of small, slender, marine fishes of the genus Ammedytes . The common European species ( Ammedytes tobianus ) and the American species ( Ammedytes Americanus ) live on sandy shores, buried in the sand, and are caught in large quantities for bait. Called also launce , and sand eel .
a country in Southeast Asia.
The loose part of a coat; the lower part of a garment that plays loosely; a skirt; an apron.
That part of a garment which is turned back; specifically, the lap, or fold, of the front of a coat in continuation of collar.
Same as Laplander . Cf. Lapps .
A branch of the Mongolian race, now living in the northern parts of Norway, Sweden, and the adjacent parts of Russia.
A gliding, slipping, or gradual falling; an unobserved or imperceptible progress or passing away,; -- restricted usually to immaterial things, or to figurative uses.
To take up (drink or food) with the tongue; to drink by licking up.
A tutelary deity; a deceased ancestor regarded as a protector of the family. The domestic Lares were the tutelar deities of a house; household gods.
A genus of coniferous trees, having deciduous leaves, in fascicles (see Illust. of Fascicle ).
Bacon; the flesh of swine.
Containing, or resembling, lard; of the character or consistency of lard.
Lore; learning.
See 1st Lar .

Exceeding most other things of like kind in bulk, capacity, quantity, superficial dimensions, or number of constituent units; big; great; capacious; extensive; -- opposed to small ; as, a large horse; a large house or room; a large lake or pool; a large jug or spoon; a large vineyard; a large army; a large city.
Slow or slowly; -- more so than adagio ; next in slowness to grave , which is also weighty and solemn.
A suborder of birds including the gulls; terns; jaegers; and skimmers.
The genus of trees comrising the larches.
A frolic; a jolly time.
Same as Lorry , or Lorrie .
See Alarum , and Alarm .

Any young insect from the time that it hatches from the egg until it becomes a pupa, or chrysalis. During this time it usually molts several times, and may change its form or color each time. The larvæ of many insects are much like the adults in form and habits, but have no trace of wings, the rudimentary wings appearing only in the pupa stage. In other groups of insects the larvæ are totally unlike the parents in structure and habits, and are called caterpillars , grubs , maggots , etc.
A guillemot; -- called also lavy .
A lace. See Lace .
To give off a beam of coherent light; -- of a laser.

A device which produces an intense, usually narrow, monochromatic beam of coherent light; called also optical maser . It has various forms, and is used in various applications in science and technology. The beam is produced by boosting the majority of the electrons in specific radiation-absorbing atoms in a medium into a higher energy level, from which they are stimulated by their own emitted radiation to drop back synchronously to their lower energy level, and emit light which is in phase (coherent).
The thong or braided cord of a whip, with which the blow is given.
A diarrhea or flux.
A young woman; a girl; a sweetheart.
A rope or long thong of leather with a running noose, used for catching horses, cattle, etc.
of Last , to endure, contracted from lasteth .
imp. of Last , to endure.
To let; to allow.

A convulsive tic or hysteric neurosis prevalent among Malays, similar to or identical with miryachit and jumping disease, the person affected performing various involuntary actions and making rapid inarticulate ejaculations in imitation of the actions and words of another person.
To smear; to anoint.
Coming after the time when due, or after the usual or proper time; not early; slow; tardy; long delayed; as, a late spring .
Belated; too late.
A brick or tile.

A genus of large percoid fishes, of which one species ( Lates Niloticus ) inhabits the Nile, and another ( Lates calcarifer ) is found in the Ganges and other Indian rivers. They are valued as food fishes.

A milky or colored juice in certain plants in cavities (called latex cells or latex tubes ). It contains the peculiar principles of the plants, whether aromatic, bitter, or acid, and in many instances yields caoutchouc upon coagulation. The lattex of the India rubber plant produces the rubber of commerce on coagulation.

A thin, narrow strip of wood, nailed to the rafters, studs, or floor beams of a building, for the purpose of supporting the tiles, plastering, etc. A corrugated metallic strip or plate is sometimes used.
Formerly, a part or division of a county among the Anglo-Saxons. At present it consists of four or five hundreds, and is confined to the county of Kent.
Like a lath; long and slender.
Of or pertaining to Latium, or to the Latins, a people of Latium; Roman; as, the Latin language .
Same as cafe latte ; a type of espresso coffee served with foamy steamed milk, and usually served in a tall glass or mug.
To praise in words alone, or with words and singing; to celebrate; to extol.

To show mirth, satisfaction, or derision, by peculiar movement of the muscles of the face, particularly of the mouth, causing a lighting up of the face and eyes, and usually accompanied by the emission of explosive or chuckling sounds from the chest and throat; to indulge in laughter.
A plain sprinkled with trees or underbrush; a glade.
A number of hermitages or cells in the same neighborhood occupied by anchorites who were under the same superior.
Same as lavatory {5}; -- a shortened form of the word.

The melted rock ejected by a volcano from its top or fissured sides. It flows out in streams sometimes miles in length. It also issues from fissures in the earth's surface, and forms beds covering many square miles, as in the Northwestern United States.
To wash; to bathe; as, to lave a bruise .
A vessel for washing; a large basin.
See Lavatic .
In general, a rule of being or of conduct, established by an authority able to enforce its will; a controlling regulation; the mode or order according to which an agent or a power acts.
To cut off the claws and balls of, as of a dog's fore feet.
An open space between woods.
See Laund .
Having a lawn; characterized by a lawn or by lawns; like a lawn.
the first five books of the Old Testament, also called The Law and Torah .
Not tense, firm, or rigid; loose; slack; as, a lax bandage; lax fiber.
In a lax manner.
of Lie , to recline.
A paved area beside a main road where cars can stop temporarily.
One who, or that which, lays.
A genus of Western U. S. annuals with showy yellow or white flowers.
A person infected with a filthy or pestilential disease; a leper.
To be lazy or idle.
Disinclined to action or exertion; averse to labor; idle; shirking work.
Abbreviation for the least common multiple, the smallest multiple that is exactly divisible by every member of a set of numbers; as, the least common multiple of 12 and 18 is 36 .
The abbreviation for limited , term appended to the name of a company that is organized to give its owners limited liability; also abbreviated Ltd. It corresponds to Inc. in the United States.

Low-density lipoprotein , a lipoprotein that transports cholesterol in the blood; high levels are thought to be associated with increased risk of coronary heart disease and atherosclerosis; sometimes called informally bad cholesterol .
A measure of yarn; for linen, 300 yards; for cotton, 120 yards; a lay.
See 3d Leech .

One of the elements, a heavy, pliable, inelastic metal, having a bright, bluish color, but easily tarnished. It is both malleable and ductile, though with little tenacity, and is used for tubes, sheets, bullets, etc. Its specific gravity is 11.37. It is easily fusible (melting point 327.5° C), forms alloys with other metals, and is an ingredient of solder and type metal. Atomic number 82. Atomic weight, 207.2. Symbol Pb (L. Plumbum ). It is chiefly obtained from the mineral galena, lead sulphide.
Resembling lead.

A colored, usually green, expansion growing from the side of a stem or rootstock, in which the sap for the use of the plant is elaborated under the influence of light; one of the parts of a plant which collectively constitute its foliage.
Full of leaves; abounding in leaves; as, the leafy forest .
A crack, crevice, fissure, or hole which admits water or other fluid, or lets it escape; as, a leak in a roof; a leak in a boat; a leak in a gas pipe.
Permitting water or other fluid to leak in or out; as, a leaky roof or cask; a leaky faucet .
Faithful; loyal; true.
A cord or strap for leading a dog.
To conceal.
To spring clear of the ground, with the feet; to jump; to vault; as, a man leaps over a fence, or leaps upon a horse .
To learn. See Lere , to learn.

To gain knowledge or information of; to ascertain by inquiry, study, or investigation; to receive instruction concerning; to fix in the mind; to acquire understanding of, or skill; as, to learn the way; to learn a lesson; to learn dancing; to learn to skate; to learn the violin; to learn the truth about something.
To gather what harvesters have left behind; to glean.

A thong of leather, or a long cord, by which a person may hold or restrain an animal, such as a falconer holding his hawk, or a courser his dog. For dogs and cats, the leash is commonly attached to a collar around the neck of the animal.
Smallest, either in size or degree; shortest; lowest; most unimportant; as, the least insect; the least mercy; the least space.
Flimsy; vague; deceptive.
An artificial water trench, esp. one to or from a mill.
To send out leaves; to leaf; -- often with out .
Coagulated sour milk diluted with water; -- a common beverage among the Arabs. Also, a fermented liquor made of the same.
Same as letch .
See water buck , under 3d Buck .
Language; speech; voice; cry.
A shelf on which articles may be laid; also, that which resembles such a shelf in form or use, as a projecting ridge or part, or a molding or edge in joinery.
Abounding in ledges; consisting of a ledge or reef; as, a ledgy island .
A genus of evergreen shrubs of the north temperate regions.
To lie; to speak falsely.
See 2d Leach .
A caldron; a copper kettle.
A plant of the genus Allium ( Allium Porrum ), having broadly linear succulent leaves rising from a loose oblong cylindrical bulb. The flavor is stronger than that of the common onion.
Empty; destitute; wanting
Tape or braid; an ornament.
Dregs. See 2d Lee .
of Let , to allow.

Of or pertaining to that side of the body in man on which the muscular action of the limbs is usually weaker than on the other side; -- opposed to right , when used in reference to a part of the body; as, the left hand, or arm; the left ear . Also said of the corresponding side of the lower animals.
a person who uses the left hand with greater skill than the right; a left-handed person.
See Leveful .
A limb or member of an animal used for supporting the body, and in running, climbing, and swimming; esp., that part of the limb between the knee and foot.

Created by, permitted by, in conformity with, or relating to, law; as, a legal obligation; a legal standard or test; a legal procedure; a legal claim; a legal trade; anything is legal which the laws do not forbid .
To allege; to assert.
Anything that lies in a place; that which, or one who, remains in a place.
To lighten; to allay.
having tall spindly stems; -- of plants.
A lunar excursion module , a spacecraft designed to transport people from a command module in orbit around the moon to the surface of the moon and back again.
A sweetheart, of either sex; a gallant, or a mistress; -- usually in a bad sense.
A ray or glimmer of light; a gleam.
A preliminary or auxiliary proposition demonstrated or accepted for immediate use in the demonstration of some other proposition, as in mathematics or logic.
A genus of minute acquatic herbs floating on or below the water surface of still water consisting of a leaflike frond or plant body and single root.

One of a family ( Lemuridæ ) of nocturnal mammals allied to the monkeys, but of small size, and having a sharp and foxlike muzzle, and large eyes. They feed upon birds, insects, and fruit, and are mostly natives of Madagascar and the neighboring islands, one genus ( Galago ) occurring in Africa. The slow lemur or kukang of the East Indies is Nycticebus tardigradus . See Galago , Indris , and Colugo .
A procuress.
To allow the custody and use of, on condition of the return of the same; to grant the temporary use of; as, to lend a book ; -- opposed to borrow .
To lend; to grant; to permit.
A light open cotton fabric used for window curtains.

A piece of glass, or other transparent substance, ground with two opposite regular surfaces, either both curved, or one curved and the other plane, and commonly used, either singly or combined, in optical instruments, for changing the direction of rays of light, and thus magnifying objects, or otherwise modifying vision. In practice, the curved surfaces are usually spherical, though rarely cylindrical, or of some other figure.
imp. & p. p. of Lend .
Slow; in slow time; slowly; -- rarely written lente .
The Lion, the fifth sign of the zodiac, marked thus [&leo_;] in almanacs.
People; a nation; a man.
A sterile transformed stamen.
Any one of various species of Lepas , a genus of pedunculated barnacles found attached to floating timber, bottoms of ships, Gulf weed, etc.; -- called also goose barnacle . See Barnacle .
A person affected with leprosy.
Pleasant; jocose.
A motherless calf in a range herd of cattle.
The type genus of the Leporidae , comprising the hares.
the sea personified; father of Manannan; corresponds to the Welsh Llyr.
Learning; lesson; lore.
A small rodent ( Eliomys nitela ) of Europe and Northern Africa, allied to the dormouse.
Smaller; not so large or great; not so much; shorter; inferior; as, a less quantity or number; a horse of less size or value; in less time than before.
Lust; desire; pleasure.
To retard; to hinder; to impede; to oppose.
See Leach .
To let; to leave.
p. p. of Lete .
A river of Hades whose waters when drunk caused forgetfulness of the past.
To let; to hinder. See Let , to hinder.
An Indo-European people, allied to the Lithuanians and Old Prussians, and inhabiting a part of the Baltic provinces of Russia.
See Luke , etc.
Dear. See Lief .
The act of rising.

A line or surface to which, at every point, a vertical or plumb line is perpendicular; a line or surface which is everywhere parallel to the surface of still water; -- this is the true level , and is a curve or surface in which all points are equally distant from the center of the earth, or rather would be so if the earth were an exact sphere.
More agreeable; more pleasing.
A trumpet call for rousing soldiers; a reveille.
A husband's brother; -- used in reference to levirate marriages.
A name formerly given in Pennsylvania, Maryland, and Virginia to the Spanish real of one eighth of a dollar (or 12 1/2 cents), valued at eleven pence when the dollar was rated at 7s. 6d.
Lukewarm; tepid.
Not clerical; laic; laical; hence, unlearned; simple.
An iron dovetailed tenon, made in sections, which can be fitted into a dovetail mortise; -- used in hoisting large stones, etc.

Law; as, lex talionis , the law of retaliation; lex terræ , the law of the land; lex fori , the law of the forum or court; lex loci , the law of the place; lex mercatoria , the law or custom of merchants.
To lay; to wager.

The name of an island in the Pacific Ocean and of a battle in World War II, at which the American forces experienced the first use of Kamikaze aircraft by the Japanese. The return of U. S. troops to the Philippines after their expulsion by the Japanese began with landings on Leyte Island in October 1944.
Low frequency, a term used to refer to radio waves of a frequency from 30 to 300 kilohertz. Contrasted to HF , high frequency.
An abbreviation for luteinizing hormone , a gonadotropic hormone that is secreted by the pituitary and stimulates ovulation in female mammals, and stimulates androgen release in male mammals.
The capital city of Tibet; it is the sacred city of Lamaism.
A Chinese measure of distance, being a little more than one third of a mile.
Union by league; alliance.
A luxuriant woody plant, climbing high trees and having ropelike stems. The grapevine often has the habit of a liane. Lianes are abundant in the forests of the Amazon region.
A person who knowingly utters falsehood; one who lies.
A French copper coin of one fourth the value of a sou.
The lowest of the three divisions of the Jurassic period; a name given in England and Europe to a series of marine limestones underlying the Oölite. See the Chart of Geology .
To castrate.
To defame, or expose to public hatred, contempt, or ridicule, by a writing, picture, sign, etc.; to lampoon.

The inner bark of plants, lying next to the wood. It usually contains a large proportion of woody, fibrous cells, and is, therefore, the part from which the fiber of the plant is obtained, as that of hemp, etc.
The Balance; the seventh sign in the zodiac, which the sun enters at the autumnal equinox in September, marked thus &libra_; in almanacs, etc.

A country in Northern Africa, between Egypt and Tunisia, bordering the Mediterranean Sea. It also borders on Algeria, Chad, Niger, and Sudan. It is an Arabic-speaking country with over 97% of the population Sunni Moslem. The population in 1995 was about 5,248,000. The capital is Tripoli.
pl. of Louse .
A dead body; a corpse.
See Litchi .
To draw or pass the tongue over; as, a dog licks his master's hand .
Same as Ledge .
A recreational facility, especially one including a swimming pool for water sports.
A falsehood uttered or acted for the purpose of deception; an intentional violation of truth; an untruth spoken with the intention to deceive.
A lay; a German song. It differs from the French chanson , and the Italian canzone , all three being national.
Same as Lif .
Sovereign; independent; having authority or right to allegiance; as, a liege lord .
p. p. of Lie . See lain .
One who lies down; one who rests or remains, as in concealment.
Place; room; stead; -- used only in the phrase in lieu of , that is, instead of .
Same as Lief .
The fiber by which the petioles of the date palm are bound together, from which various kinds of cordage are made.

The state of being which begins with generation, birth, or germination, and ends with death; also, the time during which this state continues; that state of an animal or plant in which all or any of its organs are capable of performing all or any of their functions; -- used of all animal and vegetable organisms.
To enliven.
The sky; the atmosphere; the firmament.
To recline; to lie still.
Goods sunk in the sea, with a buoy attached in order that they may be found again. See Jetsam and Flotsam .
To lie; to tell lies.
To lie or recline.
That agent, force, or action in nature by the operation of which upon the organs of sight, objects are rendered visible or luminous.

Having the same, or nearly the same, appearance, qualities, or characteristics; resembling; similar to; similar; alike; -- often with in and the particulars of the resemblance; as, they are like each other in features, complexion, and many traits of character .
To allege, or think, to be like; to represent as like; to compare; as, to liken life to a pilgrimage .
A Chinese provincial tax levied at many inland stations upon imports or articles in transit.

A shrub of the genus Syringa . There are six species, natives of Europe and Asia. Syringa vulgaris , the common lilac, and Syringa Persica , the Persian lilac, are frequently cultivated for the fragrance and beauty of their purplish or white flowers. In the British colonies various other shrubs have this name.
To do anything with animation and quickness, as to skip, fly, or hop.
A plant and flower of the genus Lilium , endogenous bulbous plants, having a regular perianth of six colored pieces, six stamens, and a superior three-celled ovary.
The capital city of Peru, in South America.
The deposit of slime at the mouth of a river; slime.

A genus of airbreathing mollusks, including the common garden slugs. They have a small rudimentary shell. The breathing pore is on the right side of the neck. Several species are troublesome in gardens. See Slug .
A part of a tree which extends from the trunk and separates into branches and twigs; a large branch.
An spiritual region where certain classes of souls were supposed to await the last judgment.
A thong by which a dog is led; a leash.
a threshhold, especially the point where a psychological or physiological effect begins to occur.
A limehound; a limmer.

That which terminates, circumscribes, restrains, or confines; the bound, border, or edge; the utmost extent; as, the limit of a walk, of a town, of a country; the limits of human knowledge or endeavor.
To draw or paint; especially, to represent in an artistic way with pencil or brush.
Limousine; -- a shortened form.
To halt; to walk lamely. Also used figuratively.
a type of rye bread, made using molasses or brown sugar.
The Hawaiian name for seaweeds. Over sixty kinds are used as food, and have species names, as Limu Lipoa , Limu palawai , etc.
Smeared with, or consisting of, lime; viscous.
To yield; to stop; to cease.
A ledge; a right-angled projection.
The linden. See Linden .
an energetic American dance that was popular in the 1930s (probably named for the aviator Charles Lindbergh ).
Flax; linen.
furnished with items in a line or as if in a line.
Made of linen; as, linen cloth; a linen stocking.
One who lines, as, a liner of shoes or clothing .
A large, marine, gadoid fish ( Molva vulgaris ) of Northern Europe and Greenland. It is valued as a food fish and is largely salted and dried. Called also drizzle .
The phallic symbol under which Siva is principally worshiped in his character of the creative and reproductive power.
Language; speech; dialect.
A torch made of tow and pitch, or the like.
A tract of ground laid out for the game of golf; a golfing green.
Flax. See Linen .
A genus of herbaceous plants including the flax ( Linum usitatissimum ).

A large carnivorous feline mammal ( Panthera leo , formerly Felis leo ), found in Southern Asia and in most parts of Africa, distinct varieties occurring in the different countries. The adult male, in most varieties, has a thick mane of long shaggy hair that adds to his apparent size, which is less than that of the largest tigers. The length, however, is sometimes eleven feet to the base of the tail. The color is a tawny yellow or yellowish brown; the mane is darker, and the terminal tuft of the tail is black. In one variety, called the maneless lion , the male has only a slight mane.

One of the two fleshy folds which surround the orifice of the mouth in man and many other animals. In man the lips are organs of speech essential to certain articulations. Hence, by a figure they denote the mouth, or all the organs of speech, and sometimes speech itself.
Pertaining to, or derived from, fat. The word was formerly used specifically to designate a supposed acid obtained by the oxidation of oleic acid, tallow, wax, etc.

Any of a variety of oily or greasy organic compounds found as major structural components of living cells; they are insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents such as alcohol and ether, and include the common fats , cholesterol and other steroids, phospholipids , sphingolipids , waxes , and fatty acids ; some of the lipids, together with proteins and carbohydrates, form an essential structural component of living cells, as in the cell walls and membranes. The term lipid refers to its solubility in nonpolar solvents, and has no significance with regard to chemical structure.
A hypothetical radical of glycerin.
An Italian coin equivalent in value to the French franc.
A city of France celebrated for certain manufactures.
A cavity or hollow.
To pronounce the sibilant letter s imperfectly; to give s and z the sound of th ; -- a defect common among children.
Release; remission; ease; relief.
A line inclosing or forming the extremity of a piece of ground, or field of combat; hence, in the plural ( lists ), the ground or field inclosed for a race or combat.
a form of the imp. & p. p. of Light .
A measure of capacity in the metric system, being a cubic decimeter, equal to 61.022 cubic inches, or 2.113 American pints, or 1.76 English pints.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Lie , to recline, for lieth .
To listen or listen to; to hearken to.
A combining form from Gr. li`qos , stone .
Easily bent; pliable.
Same as Liter .

To be alive; to have life; to have, as an animal or a plant, the capacity of assimilating matter as food, and to be dependent on such assimilation for a continuance of existence; as, animals and plants that live to a great age are long in reaching maturity .
Having life; -- used only in composition; as, long- lived ; short- lived .
to make lively; -- sometimes used with up ; as, to liven up the party with some music .
One who, or that which, lives.
pl. of Life .
Black and blue; grayish blue; of a lead color; discolored, as flesh may be from a contusion.
A French money of account, afterward a silver coin equal to 20 sous. It is not now in use, having been superseded by the franc.
2d pers. sing. pres. of Lige , to lie, to tell lies, -- contracted for ligest .
The American white mullet ( Mugil curema ).

A South American ruminant ( Auchenia llama ), allied to the camels, but much smaller and without a hump. It is supposed to be a domesticated variety of the guanaco. It was formerly much used as a beast of burden in the Andes, and is also kept on some ranches in the United States.
An extensive plain with or without vegetation.
the sea personified, father of Manawydan ; corresponds to the Irish Ler .
Look; see; behold; observe.

Any one of several small, fresh-water, cyprinoid fishes of the genera Cobitis , Nemachilus , and allied genera, having six or more barbules around the mouth. They are found in Europe and Asia. The common European species ( Nemachilus barbatulus ) is used as a food fish.
A burden; that which is laid on or put in anything for conveyance; that which is borne or sustained; a weight; as, a heavy load .
A large quantity; a lot; as, loads of fun .
Any thick lump, mass, or cake; especially, a large regularly shaped or molded mass, as of bread, sugar, or cake.
A kind of soil; an earthy mixture of clay and sand, with organic matter to which its fertility is chiefly due.
Consisting of loam; partaking of the nature of loam; resembling loam.
The act of lending; a lending; permission to use; as, the loan of a book, money, services .
any of various perennial South American plants of the genus Loasa having stinging hairs and showy white or yellow or reddish-orange flowers.
Hateful; odious; disliked.
A dull, heavy person.
Of or pertaining to a lobe; characterized by, or like, a lobe or lobes.

A passage or hall of communication, especially when large enough to serve also as a waiting room. It differs from an antechamber in that a lobby communicates between several rooms, an antechamber to one only; but this distinction is not carefully preserved.
Any projection or division, especially one of a somewhat rounded form
Having lobes; lobate.
Of or pertaining to a particular place, or to a definite region or portion of space; restricted to one place or region; as, a local custom .
A lake; a bay or arm of the sea.
See Loach .
A tuft of hair; a flock or small quantity of wool, hay, or other like substance; a tress or ringlet of hair.
Having locks or tufts.
A direction in written or printed music to return to the proper pitch after having played an octave higher.
A place; a locality.
The capelin.
A water course or way; a reach of water.
A shelter in which one may rest;
A quaternary deposit, usually consisting of a fine yellowish earth, on the banks of the Rhine and other large rivers.
That which is lifted up; an elevation.
Lifted high up; having great height; towering; high.
A Hebrew measure of liquids, containing 2.37 gills.
A rocking or balanced stone.
A lodge; a habitation.
See Lodge .

The science or art of exact reasoning, or of pure and formal thought, or of the laws according to which the processes of pure thinking should be conducted; the science of the formation and application of general notions; the science of generalization, judgment, classification, reasoning, and systematic arrangement; the science of correct reasoning.
To establish communication with a host computer from a terminal or remote computer.
A word; reason; speech.
Heavy or dull in respect to motion or thought; as, a logy horse; feeling logy .

That part of a human being or quadruped, which extends on either side of the spinal column between the hip bone and the false ribs. In human beings the loins are also called the reins. See Illust. of Beef .
A large European dormouse ( Myoxus glis ).
a French river which flows into the North Atlantic.
The evil deity, the author of all calamities and mischief, answering to the Ahriman of the Persians.
A green vegetable dye imported from China.
A private path or road; also, the wicket or hatch of a door.
To act lazily or indolently; to recline; to lean; to throw one's self down; to lie at ease; as, to loll around the house on a lazy summer day .
A lobe; a membranous fringe or flap.
A lane. See Loanin .
Drawn out in a line, or in the direction of length; protracted; extended; as, a long line; -- opposed to short , and distinguished from broad or wide .
Same as 4th Lunge .

An old game played with five, or three, cards dealt to each player from a full pack. When five cards are used the highest card is the knave of clubs or (if so agreed upon) the knave of trumps; -- formerly called lanterloo .
The clay or slimes washed from tin ore in dressing.
An awkward, clumsy fellow; a lubber.
See 2d Loch .
The spongelike fibers of the fruit of a cucurbitaceous plant ( Luffa Aegyptiaca ); called also vegetable sponge .

To direct the eyes for the purpose of seeing something; to direct the eyes toward an object; to observe with the eyes while keeping them directed; -- with various prepositions, often in a special or figurative sense. See Phrases below.
A vessel used to receive the washings of ores of metals.
See Loon , the bird.
A sorry fellow; a worthless person; a rogue.
Crazy; insane; lunatic; mentally unsound.
A mass of iron in a pasty condition gathered into a ball for the tilt hammer or rolls.
A dull, stupid fellow; a drone.
Praise; fame; reputation.
Unbound; untied; unsewed; not attached, fastened, fixed, or confined; as, the loose sheets of a book .
The act of plundering.
To cut off as the top or extreme part of anything; to shorten by cutting off the extremities; to cut off, or remove, as superfluous parts; as, to lop a tree or its branches .
To leap; to dance.
One who, or that which, lopes; esp., a horse that lopes.
Somewhat lop; inclined to lop.
Of or pertaining to the lores.

A system of electronic navigation in which a vessel or aircraft determines its latitude and longitude by measuring the time differences between low frequency radio transmissions from two stationary transmitters (slaves) and a stationary master transmitter. Contrary to the name, Loran is a medium range system, usually effective for no more than a few hundred miles from shore. The first commercial system was called Loran A; the latest (and final) development is Loran C.
A hump-backed person; -- so called sportively.
The space between the eye and bill, in birds, and the corresponding region in reptiles and fishes.
A good for nothing fellow; a vagabond.
strong p. p. of Lose .
Same as Lory .

Any one of several species of small lemurs of the genus Stenops . They have long, slender limbs and large eyes, and are arboreal in their habits. The slender loris ( Stenops gracilis ), of Ceylon, in one of the best known species.
Lost; undone; ruined.

Any one of many species of small parrots of the family Trichoglossidæ , generally having the tongue papillose at the tip, and the mandibles straighter and less toothed than in common parrots. They are found in the East Indies, Australia, New Guinea, and the adjacent islands. They feed mostly on soft fruits and on the honey of flowers.
Praise. See Loos .
To suffer loss, disadvantage, or defeat; to be worse off, esp. as the result of any kind of contest.
One who loses by sloth or neglect; a worthless person; a lorel.
One who loses; as, the loser pays for a round of beer .
The act of losing; failure; destruction; privation; as, the loss of property; loss of money by gaming; loss of health or reputation.
Parted with unwillingly or unintentionally; not to be found; missing; as, a lost book or sheep .
To allot; to sort; to portion.
A large tree ( Celtis australis ), found in the south of Europe. It has a hard wood, and bears a cherrylike fruit. Called also nettle tree .
See Loath , Loathly , etc.
See Lotto .
See Lotus .

A game of chance, played with cards or tickets, on which are inscribed numbers, and any contrivance (as a wheel containing numbered balls) for determining a set of numbers by chance. The player holding a card having on it the set of numbers drawn from the wheel takes the stakes after a certain percentage of them has been deducted for the dealer. In some systems, lesser prizes are awarded for having some but not all of the numbers selected, such as four or five numbers in a six-number drawing. A variety of lotto is called keno . In another variety, the player chooses the numbers for the card or ticket s/he holds. There may be from three to seven different numbers on a card or ticket. In a modern computerized lotto system conducted by state authorities, the player chooses numbers, or allows the computer to choose numbers at random, which are then printed on a ticket that the player holds until the winning number is selected.

A name of several kinds of water lilies; as Nelumbium speciosum , used in religious ceremonies, anciently in Egypt, and to this day in Asia; Nelumbium luteum , the American lotus; and Nymphæa Lotus and Nymphæa cærulea , the respectively white-flowered and blue-flowered lotus of modern Egypt, which, with Nelumbium speciosum , are figured on its ancient monuments.
Having, making, or being a strong or great sound; noisy; striking the ear with great force; as, a loud cry; loud thunder.
A loch or lake; -- so spelt in Ireland.
An accomplice; a “pal.”
See 1st Loop .

Any of a variety of small magnifying glasses, having a magnifying power from 2X to 20X, commonly of 10X, which may be held in the hand, or in some cases held within the eyesocket without the use of a hand. It is commonly used by jewelers and watchmakers.
The Pawnees, a tribe of North American Indians whose principal totem was the wolf.
An Asiatic sardine ( Clupea Neohowii ), valued for its oil.

Any one of numerous species of small, wingless, suctorial, parasitic insects belonging to a tribe ( Pediculina ), now usually regarded as degraded Hemiptera. To this group belong of the lice of man and other mammals; as, the head louse of man ( Pediculus capitis ), the body louse ( Pediculus vestimenti ), and the crab louse ( Phthirius pubis ), and many others . See Crab louse , Dog louse , Cattle louse , etc., under Crab , Dog , etc.
Infested with lice.
To bend; to box; to stoop.
A feeling of strong attachment induced by that which delights or commands admiration; preëminent kindness or devotion to another; affection; tenderness; as, the love of brothers and sisters .
p. p. of love , v. t. . Opposite of unloved .
One who is loved.
One who loves; one who is in love; -- usually limited, in the singular, to a person of the male sex.
strong imp. of Laugh .
The Australian moundbird ( Leipoa ocellata ); it incubates eggs naturally in sandy mounds.
Compar. of Low , a.
strong imp. of Laugh .
Not high; not elevated in place; low.
A low fellow.
An open box car used on railroads. Compare Lorry .
A long, narrow spade for stony lands.
The chemical symbol for lawrencium , a transuranic element of atomic number 103.
lysergic acid diethylamide, a powerful hallucinogenic drug.
A term attached to the name of a company that is organized to give its owners limited liability; it corresponds to Inc. in the United States.
long-term memory, the term for the set of neurons and neural processes responsible for the general store of information remembered for more than a day.
The chemical symbol for lutetium .
A pike when full grown.
Shining; bright; resplendent; as, the lucid orbs of heaven .

That which happens to a person; an event, good or ill, affecting one's interests or happiness, and which is deemed casual; a course or series of such events regarded as occurring by chance; chance; hap; fate; fortune; often, one's habitual or characteristic fortune; as, good, bad, ill, or hard luck . Luck is often used by itself to mean good luck ; as, luck is better than skill; a stroke of luck .
Favored by luck; fortunate; meeting with good success or good fortune; -- said of persons; as, a lucky adventurer .
Gain in money or goods; profit; riches; -- often in an ill sense.
Disease, especially of a contagious kind.
The side of a ship toward the wind.
The ear, or its lobe.
a racing sled for one or two people; it is raced down a chute of packed snow or ice, and the occupant(s) lie down on it with feet in the direction of motion.
someone who races the luge.
Moderately warm; not hot; tepid; lukewarm.
To cause to rest by soothing influences; to compose; to calm; to soothe; to quiet.
A unit of illumination, being the amount of illumination of a unit area of spherical surface, due to a light of unit intensity placed at the center of the sphere.
A small mass of matter of irregular shape; an irregular or shapeless mass; as, a lump of coal; a lump of iron ore.
Full of lumps, or small compact masses; as, a lumpy bed; a lumpy batch of dough .
Of or pertaining to the moon; as, lunar observations .
A luncheon; specifically, a light repast between breakfast and dinner, most commonly about noontime.
A genus of birds including some of the puffins.
Anything in the shape of a half moon.
A little moon or satellite.
An organ for aërial respiration; -- commonly in the plural.
A sudden thrust or pass, as with a sword.
The match cord formerly used in firing cannon.
Crazy; insane; mentally unsound.

originally, a cutaneous disease with the appearance of the skin having been gnawed, and occurring under two distinct forms. Now used as a generic term for over ten distinguishable diseases having visible cutaneous symptoms.
To swallow or eat greedily; to devour; hence, to swallow up.
A contrivance somewhat resembling a bird, and often baited with raw meat; -- used by falconers in recalling hawks.
A large marine annelid ( Nephthys cæca ), inhabiting the sandy shores of Europe and America. It is whitish, with a pearly luster, and grows to the length of eight or ten inches.
Pale yellow; ghastly pale; wan; gloomy; dismal.
To lie hidden; to lie in wait.
A confused heap; a throng, as of persons; a jumble, as of sounds.
Full of juice or succulence.
Lazy; slothful.
To list; to like.
To close or seal with lute; as, to lute on the cover of a crucible; to lute a joint.
One who plays on a lute.
The leatherback.
A genus which in some classifications considered a genus of the subfamily Lutrinae .
To put out of joint; to luxate.
A bone of the human body which was supposed by certain Rabbinical writers to be indestructible. Its location was a matter of dispute.
the Roman numeral representation of sixty ; six times ten; -- a determinate quantifier.
the Roman numeral representation of seventy ; seven times ten; -- a determinate quantifier.
the Roman numeral representation of eighty ; eight times ten; -- a determinate quantifier.
A French lyceum, or secondary school for students intermediate between elementary school and college, supported by the French government, for preparing students for the university.
See Leden .
A strong caustic alkaline solution of potassium salts, obtained by leaching wood ashes. It is much used in making soap, etc.
A genus of plant-sucking bugs.
of Lie , to tell a falsehood.
To please; -- chiefly used impersonally.
A dog held in a leam; a bloodhound; a limehound.
A spring of water; hence, water, or a pure, transparent liquid like water.
A waterfall. See Lin .
To inflict punishment upon, especially death, without the forms of law, as when a mob captures and hangs a suspected person. See Lynch law .
See Linden .
Any one of several species of feline animals of the genus Felis , and subgenus Lynx . They have a short tail, and usually a pencil of hair on the tip of the ears.
A northern constellation, the Harp, containing a white star of the first magnitude, called Alpha Lyræ , or Vega .
A stringed instrument of music; a kind of harp much used by the ancients, as an accompaniment to poetry.
Of or pertaining to a lyre or harp.

One of the group of shooting stars which come into the air in certain years on or about the 19th of April; -- so called because the apparent path among the stars if traced backwards crosses the constellation Lyra .

A European fish ( Peristethus cataphractum ), having the body covered with bony plates, and having three spines projecting in front of the nose; -- called also noble , pluck , pogge , sea poacher , and armed bullhead .
The resolution or favorable termination of a disease, coming on gradually and not marked by abrupt change.
Hydrophobia.
The European pollack; -- called also laith , and leet .
A fibrous and muscular band lying within the longitudinal axis of the tongue in many mammals, as the dog.
A child's word for mother .
The common European gull ( Larus canus ); -- called also mar . See New , a gull.
Dejected; sorrowful; downcast.
A spirituous liquor or drink distilled from potatoes; -- used in the Barbadoes.
Shortened form of Macintosh , a brand name for a personal computer; as, the latest Mac has great new features .
A territory in South China, on the Zhu Jiang river on the South China sea, formerly a territory of Portugal. Also, the capital city of this territory.
Same as Macao , the territory.

Any parrot of the genus Ara , Sittace , or Macrocercus . About eighteen species are known, all of them found in Central and South America. They are large and have a very long tail, a strong hooked bill, and a naked space around the eyes. The voice is harsh, and the colors are brilliant and strongly contrasted; they are among the largest and showiest of parrots. Different species names have been given to the same macaw, as for example the Hyacinthine macaw , which has been variously classified as Anodorhyncus hyacynthinus , Anodorhyncus maximiliani , and Macrocercus hyacynthinus .
A gambling game in vogue in the eighteenth century.
A money of account in China equal to one tenth of a tael; also, a weight of 57.98 grains.
A mace bearer; an officer of a court.
The striped mullet of California ( Mugil cephalus , syn. Mugil Mexicanus ).
A mackintosh ; -- a shortened form.
Chiastolite; -- so called from the tessellated appearance of a cross section. See Chiastolite .
A fine Burgundy wine usually white and dry, produced in the area around Macon, a city in France.
a single computer instruction which symbolizes, and is converted at the time of program execution or by a compiler into, a series of instructions in the same computer language.
p. p. of Made .

A gentlewoman; -- an appellation or courteous form of address given to a lady, especially an elderly or a married lady; -- much used in the address, at the beginning of a letter, to a woman. The corresponding word in addressing a man is Sir ; often abbreviated ma'am when used as a term of address.
See Mad , n.
The barn owl.
A genus of composite plants, of which one species ( Madia sativa ) is cultivated for the oil yielded from its seeds by pressure. This oil is sometimes used instead of olive oil for the table.
Wet; moist; as, a madid eye .
In a mad manner; without reason or understanding; wildly.
A Chadic language spoken south of Lake Chad; called also Matakam .
see maffia , maffioso .
Shortened form of magazine , the periodic paperback publication.
A magician.
The eleventh month of the Hindu calendar.
A caste of priests, philosophers, and magicians, among the ancient Persians; hence, any holy men or sages of the East.

A comprehensive name for all of the pretended arts which claim to produce effects by the assistance of supernatural beings, or departed spirits, or by a mastery of secret forces in nature attained by a study of occult science, including enchantment, conjuration, witchcraft, sorcery, necromancy, incantation, etc.
Any crude mixture of mineral or organic matters in the state of a thin paste.
The Barbary ape.
a magician or sorcerer of ancient times.
A kind of baboon; the wanderoo.
Among Muslims, the last imam or leader of the faithful. The Sunni, the largest sect of the Muslims, believe that he is yet to appear.
A name given to several malvaceous trees (species of Hibiscus , Ochroma , etc.), and to their strong fibrous inner bark, which is used for strings and cordage.
A genus of spider crabs, including the common European species ( Maia squinado ).
Any spider crab of the genus Maia, or family Maiadae .
An unmarried woman; usually, a young unmarried woman; esp., a girl; a virgin; a maiden.
A small piece of money; especially, an English silver half-penny of the time of Henry V.
To deprive of the use of a limb, so as to render a person in fighting less able either to defend himself or to annoy his adversary.
A hand or match at dice.
One of the New England States.
The farm attached to a mansion house; a manse.

A large species of American grass of the genus Zea ( Zea Mays ), widely cultivated as a forage and food plant; Indian corn, commonly called corn . Also, its seed, growing on cobs, and used as food for men and animals.
Greater in number, quantity, or extent; as, the major part of the assembly; the major part of the revenue; the major part of the territory.
A companion; a mate; often, a husband or a wife.
One who makes, forms, or molds; a manufacturer; specifically, the Creator.
A lemur. See Lemur .
Same as mako shark .
Evils; wrongs; offenses against right and law.
Of or pertaining to the region of the cheek bone, or to the malar bone; jugal.
To soften by kneading or stirring with some thinner substance.
One of a race of a brown or copper complexion in the Malay Peninsula and the western islands of the Indian Archipelago.
Evil; wicked; bad.
A bird of Celebes ( megacephalon maleo ), allied to the brush turkey. It makes mounds in which to lay its eggs.
A little bag or budget.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, apples; as, malic acid .
A large heavy wooden beetle; a mallet for driving anything with force; a maul.
A kind of brick of a light brown or yellowish color, made of sand, clay, and chalk.
A spotted trout ( Salvelinus malma ), inhabiting Northern America, west of the Rocky Mountains; -- called also Dolly Varden trout , bull trout , red-spotted trout , and golet .
Barley or other grain, steeped in water and dried in a kiln, thus forcing germination until the saccharine principle has been evolved. It is used in brewing and in the distillation of whisky.
A country on the island of Malta.
Containing, or like, malt.
An evil. See Mala .
A genus of herbs and subshrubs including the mallows.
See Mamma .
Mother; -- word of tenderness and familiarity.
A child's name for mamma , mother.
A human being; -- opposed to beast .
See Mancus .
The long and heavy hair growing on the upper side of, or about, the neck of some quadrupedal animals, as the horse, the lion, etc. See Illust. of Horse .
Having a mane.
A Hebrew weight for gold or silver, being one hundred shekels of gold and sixty shekels of silver.
The benevolent spirits of the dead, especially of dead ancestors, regarded as family deities and protectors.
The scab or itch in cattle, dogs, and other beasts.

The fruit of the mango tree. It is rather larger than an apple, and of an ovoid shape. Some varieties are fleshy and luscious, and others tough and tasting of turpentine. The green fruit is pickled for market.
Infected with the mange; scabby.
Violent derangement of mind; madness; insanity. Cf. Delirium .
Of or pert. to, or characterized by, mania, or excitement; frenzied; as, with manic energy .
Any species of the genus Manis , or family Manidae .
Mania; insanity.

A genus of edentates, covered with large, hard, triangular scales, with sharp edges that overlap each other like tiles on a roof. They inhabit the warmest parts of Asia and Africa, and feed on ants. Called also Scaly anteater . See Pangolin .
Of or pertaining to the language or people of the Isle of Man.
Having qualities becoming to a man; not childish or womanish; manlike, esp. brave, courageous, resolute, noble.
The food supplied to the Israelites in their journey through the wilderness of Arabia; hence, divinely supplied food.
The muller, or crushing and grinding stone, used in grinding corn on a metate.
The land belonging to a lord or nobleman, or so much land as a lord or great personage kept in his own hands, for the use and subsistence of his family.
A dwelling house, generally with land attached.
The manta ray . See also Cephaloptera and Sea devil .
See Manteau .
One of a series of progenitors of human beings, and authors of human wisdom.
A wild cat ( Felis manul ), having long, soft, light-colored fur. It is found in the mountains of Central Asia, and dwells among rocks.
The distal segment of the fore limb, including the carpus and fore foot or hand.
Of or pertaining to the Isle of Man, or its inhabitants; as, the Manx language .
A retinue of servants; a household.
See Mao Tsetung .
One of the aboriginal inhabitants of New Zealand; also, the original language of New Zealand.

A representation of the surface of the earth, or of some portion of it, showing the relative position of the parts represented; -- usually on a flat surface. Also, such a representation of the celestial sphere, or of some part of it.

A tree of the genus Acer , including about fifty species. Acer saccharinum is the rock maple , or sugar maple , from the sap of which sugar is made, in the United States, in great quantities, by evaporation; the red maple or swamp maple is Acer rubrum ; the silver maple , Acer dasycarpum , having fruit wooly when young; the striped maple , Acer Pennsylvanium , called also moosewood . The common maple of Europe is Acer campestre , the sycamore maple is Acer Pseudo-platanus , and the Norway maple is Acer platanoides .
A Chilian shrub ( Aristotelia Maqui ). Its bark furnishes strings for musical instruments, and a medicinal wine is made from its berries.
A small lake. See Mere .
The principal or ruling evil spirit.
A sacred inclosure or temple; -- so called by the islanders of the Pacific Ocean.
The refuse matter which remains after the pressure of fruit, particularly of grapes.
The third month of the year, containing thirty-one days.
The female of the horse and other equine quadrupeds.
Border; margin; edge; verge.
Plural form of mare , a dark region of considerable extent on the surface of the moon.
A license of reprisals. See Marque .
To cover, as part of a rope, with marline, marking a pecular hitch at each turn to prevent unwinding.
Consisting or partaking of marl; resembling marl; abounding with marl.
Morocco, a country in Northwestern Africa.
To unite in wedlock or matrimony; to perform the ceremony of joining, as a man and a woman, for life; to constitute (a man and a woman) husband and wife according to the laws or customs of the place.
The god of war and husbandry.
A tract of soft wet land, commonly covered partially or wholly with water; a fen; a swamp; a morass.
To buy or sell in, or as in, a mart.
See Marry .
A Nilotic language.
To emit coherent microwave radiation, as in a maser{2}.
Same as Mazer .

An abbreviation for Mobile Army Surgical Hospital , consisting of the equipment and personnel required to perform emergency operations on injured soldiers, located in tents near the front lines of combat; as, he worked in the 25th MASH .
Produced by crushing or bruising; resembling, or consisting of, a mash.
A cover, or partial cover, for the face, used for disguise or protection; as, a dancer's mask ; a fencer's mask ; a ball player's mask .
To build stonework or brickwork about, under, in, over, etc.; to construct by masons; -- with a prepositional suffix; as, to mason up a well or terrace; to mason in a kettle or boiler.
To celebrate Mass.
Compacted into, or consisting of, a mass; having bulk and weight or substance; ponderous; bulky and heavy; weighty; heavy; as, a massy shield; a massy rock.
The fruit of the oak and beech, or other forest trees; nuts; acorns.
Full of mast; abounding in acorns, etc.
A name given by coppersmiths to an alloy of copper, tin, iron, etc., usually called white metal .

Anything used for catching and retaining or communicating fire, made of some substance which takes fire readily, or remains burning some time; esp., a small strip or splint of wood or cardboard dipped at one end in a substance which can be easily ignited by friction, as a preparation of phosphorus or chlorate of potassium.
The Paraguay tea, being the dried leaf of the Brazilian holly ( Ilex Paraguensis ). The infusion has a pleasant odor, with an agreeable bitter taste, and is much used for tea in South America.
Brought together for sexual activity; bred; -- of animals.
See Alma mater , Dura mater , and Pia mater .
having the relationship of friends or pals.
A mowing, or that which is gathered by mowing; -- chiefly used in composition; as, an after math .
A fat herring with undeveloped roe.
Of or pertaining to the morning, or to matins; used in the morning; matutinal.
See Matte .

A partly reduced copper sulphide, obtained by alternately roasting and melting copper ore in separating the metal from associated iron ores, and called coarse metal , fine metal , etc., according to the grade of fineness. On the exterior it is dark brown or black, but on a fresh surface is yellow or bronzy in color.
A native house servant in India.
A cake of unleavened bread eaten by the Jews at the feast of the Passover.
A gray plaid; -- used by shepherds in Scotland.
A heavy wooden hammer or beetle.
The common mallow.
A hand basket.
A color of a delicate purple, violet, or lilac.
The European throstle or song thrush ( Turdus musicus ).
A stomach; the receptacle into which food is taken by swallowing; in birds, the craw; -- now used only of the lower animals, exept humorously or in contempt.
A slattern; a mawk.
An auxiliary verb qualifying the meaning of another verb,
The name (in Vedantic philosphy) for the doctrine of the unreality of matter, called, in English, idealism ; hence, nothingness; vanity; illusion.

Designating, or pertaining to, an American Indian linguistic stock occupying the Mexican States of Veracruz, Chiapas, Tabasco, Campeche, and Yucatan, together with a part of Guatemala and a part of El Salvador. See 2nd Maya .
Perhaps; possibly; peradventure.

The chief magistrate of a city or borough; the chief administrative officer of a municipal corporation. In some American cities there is a city court of which the major is chief judge. The post is usually elective, its holder chosen by the electorate of the entire city.
A wild fancy; a confused notion.
A large drinking bowl; -- originally made of maple.
Perplexed with turns and windings; winding; intricate; confusing; perplexing; embarrassing; as, mazy error .

Methylenedioxymethamphetamine, a drug designed to have the effects of amphetamines but originally synthesized to avoid the drug laws; it is now a controlled substance. It is informally called ecstasy . It is used by some abusively and illegally without a prescription.
One. See Men , pron.
To skulk; to cower. See Mich .
A fermented drink made of water and honey with malt, yeast, etc.; metheglin; hydromel.
A hook with a long handle.
A part; a fragment; a portion.
Having the qualities of meal; resembling meal; soft, dry, and friable; easily reduced to a condition resembling meal; as, a mealy potato .
To have in the mind, as a purpose, intention, etc.; to intend; to purpose; to design; as, what do you mean to do?
imp. & p. p. of Mean .
A boundary. See Mere .
Five hundred; as, a mease of herrings .
Food, in general; anything eaten for nourishment, either by man or beast. Hence, the edible part of anything; as, the meat of a lobster, a nut, or an egg .
A sweet liquor; mead.
Abounding in meat.
The sea mew.
See Mewl , and Miaul .
A piece of metal in the form of a coin, struck with a device, and intended to preserve the remembrance of a notable event or an illustrious person, or to serve as a reward.
A native or inhabitant of Media in Asia.

The latinic plural form of medium , sometimes used as a singular noun with the same meaning as medium ; as, (Computers) place your installation media into the device which will read it; (Microbiology) the tuberculosis bacterium will only grow in a special media .
A leguminous plant of the genus Medicago . The black medic is the Medicago lupulina ; the purple medic, or lucern, is Medicago sativa .
To mix; to mingle; to meddle.
See Medle .
That which is bestowed or rendered in consideration of merit; reward; recompense.
Mild of temper; not easily provoked or orritated; patient under injuries; not vain, or haughty, or resentful; forbearing; submissive.
Simple; unmixed. See Mere , a.

To join, or come in contact with; esp., to come in contact with by approach from an opposite direction; to come upon or against, front to front, as distinguished from contact by following and overtaking.
Mead. See Meathe .
A very dull article, speech, or book, which causes the reader or listener to rapidly lose interest; -- often used of involved discussions of a technical nature, especially in newspapers.
See Menge .
A white or buff-colored granular powder, C6H9N11 , obtained by heating ammonium sulphocyanate.
In the game of pinochle, to declare or announce for a score; as, to meld a sequence .
Of or pertaining to song; lyric; tuneful.
To mix; to meddle.
A genus of beetles without wings, but having short oval elytra; the oil beetles. These beetles are sometimes used instead of cantharides for raising blisters. See Oil beetle , under Oil .
See 2d Milt .
the 13th letter of the Hebrew alphabet.
pl. of Man .
To grow better; to advance to a better state; to become improved; to recover; to heal.
See Amends .
Manliness; dignity; comeliness; civility.
p. p. of Menge .
The details of a banquet; a list of the dishes served at a meal, whether or not one has a choice.
See 6th and 7th Mew .
To subject to fine or amercement; to mulct; to amerce.
Forbearance to inflict harm under circumstances of provocation, when one has the power to inflict it; compassionate treatment of an offender or adversary; clemency.
Ordure; dung.
A pool or lake.
To cause to be swallowed up; to immerse; to sink; to absorb.
The quality or state of deserving well or ill; desert.
An old Scotch silver coin; a mark or marc.
The European blackbird. See Blackbird .

Any of several large groupers of warm seas, esp. the guasa ( Epinephelus guaza ), the red grouper ( Epinephelus morio ), the black grouper ( Epinephelus nigritas ), distinguished as Me"ro de lo al"to (&unr_;) , and a species called also rock hind , distinguished as Me"ro cabrol"la (&unr_;) .
The plain surface between the channels of a triglyph.
Laughingly gay; overflowing with good humor and good spirits; jovial; inclined to laughter or play; sportive.
See Meros .
A high tableland; a plateau on a hill.
Same as mesiad .
Same as Mesial .
The opening or space inclosed by the threads of a net between knot and knot, or the threads inclosing such a space; network; a net.
Formed with meshes; netted.

Middle; intervening; as, a mesne lord, that is, a lord who holds land of a superior, but grants a part of it to another person, in which case he is a tenant to the superior, but lord or superior to the second grantee, and hence is called the mesne lord .

The mesial plane dividing the body of an animal into similar right and left halves. The line in which it meets the dorsal surface has been called the dorsimeson , and the corresponding ventral edge the ventrimeson .
Mass; church service.
imp. & p. p. of Meet .

An elementary substance, as sodium, calcium, or copper, whose oxide or hydroxide has basic rather than acid properties, as contrasted with the nonmetals, or metalloids. No sharp line can be drawn between the metals and nonmetals, and certain elements partake of both acid and basic qualities, as chromium, manganese, bismuth, etc.
To dream; also impersonally; as, me mette , I dreamed .
One who, or that which, metes or measures. See Coal-meter .
See Meathe .
A sojourner; an immigrant; an alien resident in a Grecian city, but not a citizen.
A whitish soluble powder used as a developer in photography. Chemically, it is the sulphate of methyl- p -amino- m -cresol .
See Meter .
imp. of Mete , to dream.

Lit., mine; that which is mine; -- used in the phrase meum et tuum , or meum and tuum ; as, to confound meum and tuum , to fail to distinguish one's own property from that of others ; to be dishonest.
A European river, flowing into the North Sea.
A cage for hawks; a mew. See 4th Mew , 1.
A gull, esp. the common British species ( Larus canus ); called also sea mew , maa , mar , mow , and cobb .
To cry, as a young child; to squall.
An alley where there are stables; a narrow passage; a confined place.
See Mescal .
Same as Meine .
Mean; not extreme.
A unit of conductivity, being the reciprocal of the ohm.
A syllable applied to the third tone of the scale of C, i. e. , to E, in European solmization, but to the third tone of any scale in the American system.
The orang-outang.
To cry as a cat; to mew; to caterwaul.

The name of a group of minerals characterized by highly perfect cleavage, so that they readily separate into very thin leaves, more or less elastic. They differ widely in composition, and vary in color from pale brown or yellow to green or black. The transparent forms are used in lanterns, the doors of stoves, etc., being popularly called isinglass . Formerly called also cat-silver , and glimmer .
pl. of Mouse .
To lie hid; to skulk; to act, or carry one's self, sneakingly.
a person of Irish descent; -- an ethnic slur, offensive and disparaging.
A small South American monkey ( Mico melanurus ), allied to the marmoset. The name was originally applied to an albino variety.
The larva of the bean fly.
A genus of longeared South American monkeys, including numerous species of marmosets. See Marmoset .
A colloquial abbreviation of midshipman .
In the midst of; amidst.
Aspect; air; manner; demeanor; carriage; bearing.
A petty falling out; a tiff; a quarrel; offense.
imp. of May .
A microphone , the device for converting sound waves into electrical energy.
an obsolete monetary unit of Cyprus equal in value to 1/1000 of a pound.

Gentle; pleasant; kind; soft; bland; clement; hence, moderate in degree or quality; -- the opposite of harsh , severe , irritating , violent , disagreeable , etc.; -- applied to persons and things; as, a mild disposition; a mild eye; a mild air; a mild medicine; a mild insanity.
A certain measure of distance, being equivalent in England and the United States to 320 poles or rods, or 5,280 feet.
To draw or to yield milk.
Consisting of, or containing, milk.
A money of account of the United States, having the value of the tenth of a cent, or the thousandth of a dollar.
The spleen.
A kind of drama in which real persons and events were generally represented in a ridiculous manner; an ancient Greek or Roman form of farce.
A mimeograph.
A person who performs in a mime.
One who imitates or mimics, especially one who does so for sport; a copyist; a buffoon.
A giant who guarded the well of wisdom.
The type genus of the family Mimidae , comprising certain of the mockingbirds.
An abbreviation for minute , a unit of time equal to 60 seconds or 1/60th of an hour.
An ancient weight or denomination of money, of varying value. The Attic mina was valued at a hundred drachmas.
To walk with short steps; to walk in a prim, affected manner.
To fix the mind or thoughts on; to regard with attention; to treat as of consequence; to consider; to heed; to mark; to note.

Belonging to me; my. Used as a pronominal to me; my. Used as a pronominal adjective in the predicate; as, “Vengeance is mine ; I will repay.” Rom. xii. 19 . Also, in the old style, used attributively, instead of my , before a noun beginning with a vowel.
extracted from a source of supply as of minerals from the earth.
To mingle; to mix.

A carnivorous mammal of the genus Mustela (foremrly Putorius ), allied to the weasel. The European mink is Mustela lutreola . The common American mink ( Mustela vison ) varies from yellowish brown to black. Its fur is highly valued. Called also minx , nurik , and vison .
A person of either sex who has not attained the age at which full civil rights are accorded; an infant; in England and the United States, one under twenty-one years of age.
A king and lawgiver of Crete, fabled to be the son of Jupiter and Europa . After death he was made a judge in the Lower Regions.
See Minnow .
The name of several aromatic labiate plants, mostly of the genus Mentha , yielding odoriferous essential oils by distillation. See Mentha .
Less; requiring to be subtracted; negative; as, a minus quantity .
A pert or a wanton girl.
Abounding with mines; like a mine.
A Russian village community.
A remarkable variable star in the constellation Cetus ( ο Ceti ).
Deep mud; wet, spongy earth.
Dark; gloomy; murky.
Dark; gloomy. See Murky .
Abounding with deep mud; full of mire; muddy; as, a miry road .
The common title of honor in Persia, prefixed to the surname of an individual. When appended to the surname, it signifies Prince .
Wrong; amiss.
To do wrong; to commit a fault.
To go astray.
To rain in very fine drops, like a thick mist; to mizzle; to drizzle.
Raining in very small drops; drizzling.
A title of courtesy prefixed to the name of a girl or a woman who has not been married. See Mistress , 5.
The service or sacrifice of the Mass.
An affectionate, or contemptuous, form of miss ; a young girl; a miss.
Visible watery vapor suspended in the atmosphere, at or near the surface of the earth; fog.
Accompanied with mist; characterized by the presence of mist; obscured by, or overspread with, mist; as, a misty morning; misty weather; misty mountains; a misty atmosphere.
An impure yellow sulphate of iron; yellow copperas or copiapite.
A minute arachnid, of the order Acarina , of which there are many species; as, the dust mite , cheese mite , sugar mite , harvest mite , three-toed spider mite , etc. See Acarina .
A covering for the head, worn on solemn occasions by bishops and other church dignitaries. It has been made in many forms, the present form being a lofty cap with two points or peaks.
See Miter .
A mitten; also, a covering for the wrist and hand and not for the fingers, usually worn by women.
The stormy petrel.
A South American curassow of the genus Mitua .
Having, or abounding with, mites.

To cause a promiscuous interpenetration of the parts of, as of two or more substances with each other, or of one substance with others; to unite or blend into one mass or compound, as by stirring together; to mingle; to blend; as, to mix flour and salt; to mix wines.
Formed by mixing; united; mingled; blended. See Mix , v. t. & i.
A compost heap; a dunghill.
One who, or that which, mixes.
