To confuse the identities of (two or more objects); to mistake (one object for another); as, at the family gathering he mixed up his two nieces, to their great amusement .
A bog or quagmire.
milliliter; -- the IS standard abbreviation.
millimeter; -- the IS standard abbreviation.
The chemical symbol for manganese .
A genus of mosses similar to those of genus Bryum but larger.
More; -- usually, more in number.

Any one of several very large extinct species of wingless birds belonging to Dinornis , and other related genera, of the suborder Dinornithes , found in New Zealand . They are allied to the apteryx and the ostrich. They were probably exterminated by the natives before New Zealand was discovered by Europeans. Some species were much larger than the ostrich.
To make a low prolonged sound of grief or pain, whether articulate or not; to groan softly and continuously.
A deep trench around the rampart of a castle or other fortified place, sometimes filled with water; a ditch.
To void the excrement, as a bird; to mute.
To wrap up in, or cover with, a cowl.
To wrap the head of in a hood.
A seaport town of Yemen, on the Red Sea, also spelled Mukha .
A bale of raw silk.
To imitate; to mimic; esp., to mimic in sport, contempt, or derision; to deride by mimicry.
A South American rodent ( Cavia rupestris ), allied to the Guinea pig, but larger; -- called also rock cavy .
Of or pertaining to a mode or mood; consisting in mode or form only; relating to form; having the form without the essence or reality.
Manner of doing or being; method; form; fashion; custom; way; style; as, the mode of speaking; the mode of dressing.
A miniature representation of a thing, with the several parts in due proportion; sometimes, a facsimile of the same size; as, a 1/100 scale model of the B-52 bomber .

An electronic device that converts electronic signals into sound waves, and sound waves into electronic signals, used to transmit information between computers by the use of ordinary telephone lines; also called modulator-demodulator ; as, the latest modems can transmit data at 56,000 baud over a clear telephone line . The speed of transmission of information by a modem is usually measured in units of baud , equivalent to bits per second.
To moderate.
The arrangement of, or mode of expressing, the terms of a contract or conveyance.
Fashionable.
A wry face or mouth; a mow.
A thin silk stuff made in Caucasia.
To move away; to go off.
A person of the Mongolian race.
A kind of millet ( Setaria Italica ); German millet.
A gallinule ( Notornis Mantelli ) formerly inhabiting New Zealand, but now supposed to be extinct. It was incapable of flight. See Notornis .
A West African gazelle ( Gazella mohr ), having horns on which are eleven or twelve very prominent rings. It is one of the species which produce bezoar.
A British Indian gold coin, of the value of fifteen silver rupees, or $7.21 (in 1913).
To daub; to make dirty; to soil; to defile.
A kind of high shoe anciently worn.
The deity who assigns to every man his lot.
Originally, a fine textile fabric made of the hair of an Asiatic goat; afterwards, any textile fabric to which a watered appearance is given in the process of calendering.
Moderately wet; damp; humid; not dry; as, a moist atmosphere or air .
A stupid person; a dolt.
Misty; dark; murky; muggy.

A quantity of a substance equal to the molecular weight of a substance expressed in grams; a gram molecule; the basic unit of amount of substance adopted under the System International d'Unites; as, he added two mols of dextrose to the medium .
See Sunfish , 1.
Being at a concentration with the designated number of moles (of solute) per 1000 grams of solvent; as, an 0.5 molal solution of glycerol in water . Compare molar .
Of or pertaining to a mass of matter; -- said of the properties or motions of masses, as distinguished from those of molecules or atoms.
A spot; a blemish; a mole.
Overgrown with, or containing, mold; smelling of mold; as, moldy cheese or bread .
A spot; a stain; a mark which discolors or disfigures.
Minor; in the minor mode; as, A moll , that is, A minor .
Lower by a semitone; flat; as, E molle , that is, E flat .
Same as Mollemoke .
imp. of Melt .
Much; very; as, molto adagio, very slow .
A fabulous herb of occult power, having a black root and white blossoms, said by Homer to have been given by Hermes to Ulysses to counteract the spells of Circe .
A dull, silent person; a blockhead.
The god of blame and mockery; Momus.
See Motmot .
The god of mockery and censure.

The badge of a family, esp. of a family of the ancient feudal nobility. The most frequent form of the mon is circular, and it commonly consists of conventionalized forms from nature, flowers, birds, insects, the lightnings, the waves of the sea, or of geometrical symbolic figures; color is only a secondary character. It appears on lacquer and pottery, and embroidered on, or woven in, fabrics. The imperial chrysanthemum, the mon of the reigning family, is used as a national emblem. Formerly the mon of the shoguns of the Tokugawa family was so used.
A small, handsome, long-tailed West American monkey ( Cercopithecus mona ). The body is dark olive, with a spot of white on the haunches.
An ultimate atom, or simple, unextended point; something ultimate and indivisible.
Any Asiatic pheasant of the genus Lophophorus , as the Impeyan pheasant.
A genus of minute flagellate Infusoria of which there are many species, both free and attached. See Illust. under Monad .
The world; a globe as an ensign of royalty.
One of the Monera.

A piece of metal, as gold, silver, copper, etc., coined, or stamped, and issued by the sovereign authority as a medium of exchange in financial transactions between citizens and with government; also, any number of such pieces; coin.

A man who retires from the ordinary temporal concerns of the world, and devotes himself to religion; one of a religious community of men inhabiting a monastery, and bound by vows to a life of chastity, obedience, and poverty.
The black howler ( Mycetes villosus ), a monkey of Central America.
A favorite gambling game among Spaniards, played with dice or cards.

One of the twelve portions into which the year is divided; the twelfth part of a year, corresponding nearly to the length of a synodic revolution of the moon, -- whence the name. In popular use, a period of four weeks is often called a month .
To make the noise of a cow; to low; -- a child's word.
to ask for and get free; to borrow without intending to repay; to sponge; -- usually with objects of small value; as, he mooched a few cigarettes from me .
Manner; style; mode; logical form; musical style; manner of action or being. See Mode which is the preferable form).
Subject to varying moods, especially to states of mind which are unamiable or depressed.

The celestial orb which revolves round the earth; the satellite of the earth; a secondary planet, whose light, borrowed from the sun, is reflected to the earth, and serves to dispel the darkness of night. The diameter of the moon is 2,160 miles, its mean distance from the earth is 240,000 miles, and its mass is one eightieth that of the earth. See Lunar month , under Month .
Same as Mung .
Of or pertaining to the moon.
One of a mixed race inhabiting Morocco, Algeria, Tunis, and Tripoli, chiefly along the coast and in towns.
Of or pertaining to moors; marshy; fenny; boggy; moorish.

A large cervine mammal ( Alces alces syn. Alces machlis , syn Alces Americanus ), native of the Northern United States and Canada. The adult male is about as large as a horse, and has very large, palmate antlers. It closely resembles the European elk, and by many Zoologists is considered the same species. See Elk .
See 1st Mot .
A made-up face; a grimace.
To be dull and spiritless; to spend time doing little; as, to mope around the house .
A mope; a drone.
A game of guessing the number of fingers extended in a quick movement of the hand, -- much played by Italians of the lower classes.

Relating to duty or obligation; pertaining to those intentions and actions of which right and wrong, virtue and vice, are predicated, or to the rules by which such intentions and actions ought to be directed; relating to the practice, manners, or conduct of men as social beings in relation to each other, as respects right and wrong, so far as they are properly subject to rules.
Greater; superior; increased;
An edible fungus ( Morchella esculenta ), the upper part of which is covered with a reticulated and pitted hymenium. It is used as food, and for flavoring sauces.
Customs; habits; esp., moral customs conformity to which is more or less obligatory; customary law.
Idiocy; imbecility; fatuity; foolishness.
Pertaining to, or derived from, fustic (see Morin ); as, moric acid .
An edible fungus. Same as 1st Morel .

A yellow crystalline substance ( C15H10O7 ) of acid properties extracted from fustic ( Chlorophora tinctoria syn. Maclura tinctoria , formerly called Morus tinctoria ); -- called also moric acid and natural yellow 8 . It is used as a dye for wool, giving a color from lemon yellow through olive to olive brown, depending on the metal with which it is mordanted.
A bugbear; false terror.
The first part of the day; the morning; -- used chiefly in poetry.
Of or pertaining to the morn; morning.
A small abscess or tumor having a resemblance to a mulberry.

A mentally retarded person whose intellectual development proceeds normally up to about the eighth year of age and is then arrested so that there is little or no further development; an adult having the mental development of an 8-to-12-year old. A moron is considered capable of doing routine work under supervision.
The Muslim tribes of the southern Philippine Islands, said to have formerly migrated from Borneo. Some of them are warlike and addicted to piracy.

A sequence of phonemes, often a word fragment, which constitutes the minimum unit of meaning or syntax within a given word. A morph may be one of several variants of a morpheme, depending for its individal form on the context in which it occurs. Thus the morphs -s and -es are variants of the morpheme by which the plural form of an English noun is expressed.
A round hill or point of land; hence, Morro castle , a castle on a hill.
The walrus. See Walrus .
A great quantity or number.
A genus of trees, some species of which produce edible fruit; the mulberry. See Mulberry .
See Morrow .
sing. of Mores .
See Muzzle .
A large flatboat, used in the West Indies for taking freight from shore to ship.
To go, or move (in a certain manner); -- usually with out , off , along , etc.
See Mosque .

A cryptogamous plant of a cellular structure, with distinct stem and simple leaves. The fruit is a small capsule usually opening by an apical lid, and so discharging the spores. There are many species, collectively termed Musci , growing on the earth, on rocks, and trunks of trees, etc., and a few in running water.
Overgrown with moss; abounding with or edged with moss; as, mossy trees; mossy streams.
Consisting of the greatest number or quantity; greater in number or quantity than all the rest; nearly all.
imp. of Mote .
May; must; might.
See 1st Mot .
Filled with motes, or fine floating dust; as, the air .
A composition adapted to sacred words in the elaborate polyphonic church style; an anthem.
Any nocturnal lepidopterous insect, or any not included among the butterflies; as, the luna moth ; Io moth ; hawk moth .
Infested with moths; moth-eaten.

Movement; manner of movement; particularly, movement with increased rapidity; -- used especially in the phrase con moto , directing to a somewhat quicker movement; as, andante con moto , a little more rapidly than andante , etc.
A small plate covering the armpit in armor of the 14th century and later.
One who, or that which, imparts motion; a source of mechanical power.
A clump of trees in a prairie.
A sentence, phrase, or word, forming part of an heraldic achievment.
Full of, or consisting of, motes.
See Mold , Molder , Moldy , etc.
To contract mold; to grow moldy; to mold.
pl. of Mow , may.
A ball or globe forming part of the regalia of an emperor or other sovereign. It is encircled with bands, enriched with precious stones, and surmounted with a cross; -- called also globe .

A mass of earth, or earth and rock, rising considerably above the common surface of the surrounding land; a mountain; a high hill; -- used always instead of mountain , when put before a proper name; as, Mount Washington ; otherwise, chiefly in poetry.
To express or to feel grief or sorrow; to grieve; to be sorrowful; to lament; to be in a state of grief or sadness.

Any one of numerous species of small rodents belonging to the genus Mus and various related genera of the family Muridae . The common house mouse ( Mus musculus ) is found in nearly all countries. The American white-footed mouse , or deer mouse ( Peromyscus leucopus , formerly Hesperomys leucopus ) sometimes lives in houses. See Dormouse , Meadow mouse , under Meadow , and Harvest mouse , under Harvest .
Infested with mice; smelling of mice.

The opening through which an animal receives food; the aperture between the jaws or between the lips; also, the cavity, containing the tongue and teeth , between the lips and the pharynx; the buccal cavity.

To cause to change place or posture in any manner; to set in motion; to carry, convey, draw, or push from one place to another; to impel; to stir; as, the wind moves a vessel; the horse moves a carriage.
affected emotionally. Opposite of unmoved .
A person or thing that moves, stirs, or changes place.
A motion picture.
A wry face.
See 4th Mow .
One who, or that which, mows; a mowing machine; as, a lawn mower .
Cut down by mowing, as grass; deprived of grass by mowing; as, a mown field .

A soft woolly mass prepared from the young leaves of Artemisia Chinensis , and used as a cautery by burning it on the skin; hence, any substance used in a like manner, as cotton impregnated with niter, amadou.
energy; pep.
Mud poured out from volcanoes during eruptions; -- so called in South America.
See Moil , and Moile .
The customary abbreviation of Mister in writing and printing. See Master , 4.
The customary abbreviation of Mistress or Missess when used as a title of courtesy, in writing and printing; as, Mrs. Clinton is commonly called by her full name, Hillary Rodham Clinton .
Amall shrubby African tree ( Brachystegia speciformis ) having compound leaves and racemes of small fragrant green flowers.
See mutual savings bank .
See monosodium glutamate .
Mountain Standard Time, the time of the 105th meridian, used in the mountain states of the U.S.
A metric ton , a unit of weight equivalent to 1000 kilograms.
The 12th letter of the Greek alphabet (μ, Μ).
See Muse , and Muset .
Great in quantity; long in duration; as, much rain has fallen; much time.

Pertaining to, or derived from, gums and micilaginous substances; specif., denoting an acid obtained by the oxidation of gums, dulcite, etc., as a white crystalline substance isomeric with saccharic acid.
Musty; moldy; slimy; mucous.
See Mucedin .
Abbreviation of Amuck .
Filthy with muck; miry; as, a mucky road .
A genus of minute fungi. The plants consist of slender threads with terminal globular sporangia; mold.
A minute abrupt point, as of a leaf; any small, sharp point or process, terminating a larger part or organ.

A viscid fluid secreted by mucous membranes, which it serves to moisten and protect. It covers the lining membranes of all the cavities which open externally, such as those of the mouth, nose, lungs, intestinal canal, urinary passages, etc.
Earth and water mixed so as to be soft and adhesive.
Either one of two asclepiadaceous shrubs ( Calotropis gigantea , and Calotropis procera ), which furnish a strong and valuable fiber. The acrid milky juice is used medicinally.
Abounding in mud; besmeared or dashed with mud; as, a muddy road or path; muddy boots.
Same as Moodir .
To mew; to molt.
A soft cover of cylindrical form, usually of fur, worn by women to shield the hands from cold.
An official expounder of Muslim law.
A kind of ceramic or metal drinking cup, with a handle, -- usually cylindrical and without a lip.
Moist; damp; moldy; as, muggy straw .
A genus of fishes including the gray mullets. See Mullet .
A Russian peasant (especially prior to 1917).

Half-rotten straw, or any similar light, porous, organic substance strewn on the ground, as over the roots of plants, to protect from heat, drought, etc., and to hinder weed growth and preserve moisture.
A fine or penalty, esp. a pecuniary punishment or penalty.

A hybrid animal; specifically, one generated between an ass and a mare. Sometimes the term is applied to the offspring of a horse and a she-ass, but that hybrid is more properly termed a hinny . See Hinny .
A stiff, long saw, guided at the ends but not stretched in a gate.
A thin, soft kind of muslin.
Same as Mollah .
Wine boiled and mingled with honey.
Silent; not speaking; as, to keep mum .
To sport or make diversion in a mask or disguise; to mask.
A dead body embalmed and dried after the manner of the ancient Egyptians; also, a body preserved, by any means, in a dry state, from the process of putrefaction.
To move the lips with the mouth closed; to mumble, as in sulkiness.
Sullenness; silent displeasure; the sulks.
To chew with a grinding, crunching sound, as a beast chews provender; to chew deliberately or in large mouthfuls.

Green gram, a kind of legume (pulse) ( Vigna radiata syn. Phaseolus aureus , syn. Phaseolus Mungo ), grown for food in British India; called also gram , mung bean , Chinese mung bean , and green-seeded mung bean . It is an erect, bushy annual producing edible green or yellow seeds, and edible pods and young sprouts.
See Bonnet monkey , under Bonnet .

A material of short fiber and inferior quality obtained by deviling woolen rags or the remnants of woolen goods, specif. those of felted, milled, or hard-spun woolen cloth, as distinguished from shoddy , or the deviled product of loose-textured woolen goods or worsted, -- a distinction often disregarded.
A tough Asiatic grass ( Saccharum bengalense syn. Saccharum munja ) whose culms are used for ropes and baskets.
Of or pertaining to a wall; being on, or in, a wall; growing on, or against, a wall; as, a mural quadrant .
To inclose in walls; to wall; to immure; to shut up.
A genus of marine gastropods, having rough, and frequently spinose, shells, which are often highly colored inside; the rock shells. They abound in tropical seas.
Dark; murky.
Dark; gloomy.
Any one of several species of sea birds of the genus Uria , or Catarractes ; a guillemot.
See Muraena .
Plenty; abundance.
One of the hereditary nobility among the Tatars, esp. one of the second class.
A genus of small rodents, including the common mouse and rat.

A genus of perennial, herbaceous, endogenous plants of great size, including the banana ( Musa sapientum ), the plantain ( Musa paradisiaca of Linnaeus, but probably not a distinct species), the Abyssinian ( Musa Ensete ), the Philippine Island ( Musa textilis , which yields Manila hemp), and about eighteen other species. See Illust. of Banana and Plantain .
Of or pertaining to the Muses, or to Poetry.
An itinerant player on the musette, an instrument formerly common in Europe.
A genus of dipterous insects, including the common house fly, and numerous allied species.
An order or subclass of cryptogamous plants; the mosses. See Moss , and Cryptogamia .
A gap or hole in a hedge, hence, wall, or the like, through which a wild animal is accustomed to pass; a muset.
One who muses.
A small hole or gap through which a wild animal passes; a muse.
Meal (esp. Indian meal) boiled in water; hasty pudding; supawn.
Soft like mush; figuratively, good-naturedly weak and effusive; weakly sentimental.

The science and the art of tones, or musical sounds, i. e. , sounds of higher or lower pitch, begotten of uniform and synchronous vibrations, as of a string at various degrees of tension; the science of harmonical tones which treats of the principles of harmony, or the properties, dependences, and relations of tones to each other; the art of combining tones in a manner to please the ear.
See Muset .

A substance of a reddish brown color, and when fresh of the consistency of honey, obtained from a bag being behind the navel of the male musk deer. It has a slightly bitter taste, but is specially remarkable for its powerful and enduring odor. It is used in medicine as a stimulant antispasmodic. The term is also applied to secretions of various other animals, having a similar odor.
Having an odor of musk, or somewhat the like.
A scramble, as when small objects are thrown down, to be taken by those who can seize them; a confused struggle.
Disarranged; rumpled.
To be obliged; to be necessitated; -- expressing either physical or moral necessity; as, a man must eat for nourishment; we must submit to the laws.
Having the rank, pungent, offensive odor and taste which substances of organic origin acquire during warm, moist weather; foul or sour and fetid; moldy; as, musty corn; musty books.
The close linen or muslin cap of an old woman.
To cast off; to molt.
same as quiet ; as, the muted atmosphere of a church . Opposite of noisy .
Without a point or pointed process; blunt.
An dog that is of inferior quality or of mixed breed.
Dirt; filth; muck.
Soft; sticky, and dirty.
Absent-minded; dazed; muddled; stupid.
most valuable player; the player judged to be the most important to the sport, also the name of the award given to that player.
The symbol for the maxwell , a cgs unit of magnetic flux.
Of or belonging to me; -- used always attributively; as, my body; my book ; -- mine is used in the predicate; as, the book is mine . See Mine .
A genus of bivalve mollusks, including the common long, or soft-shelled, clam.

Any one of numerous species of Asiatic starlings of the genera Acridotheres , Sturnopastor , Sturnia , Gracula , and allied genera. In habits they resemble the European starlings, and like them are often caged and taught to talk. See Hill myna , under Hill , and Mino bird .
Composed of, or resembling, muscular fiber.
A tumor consisting of muscular tissue.
A person having myopia; a myops.
See Myope .

A gum resin, usually of a yellowish brown or amber color, of an aromatic odor, and a bitter, slightly pungent taste. It is valued for its odor and for its medicinal properties. It exudes from the bark of a shrub of Abyssinia and Arabia, the Commiphora Myrrha (syn. Balsamodendron Myrrha ) of the family Burseraceae , or from the Commiphora abyssinica . The myrrh of the Bible is supposed to have been partly the gum above named, and partly the exudation of species of Cistus , or rockrose.

A genus of small schizopod shrimps found both in fresh and salt water; the opossum shrimps. One species inhabits the Great Lakes of North America, and is largely eaten by the whitefish. The marine species form part of the food of right whales.

A story of great but unknown age which originally embodied a belief regarding some fact or phenomenon of experience, and in which often the forces of nature and of the soul are personified; an ancient legend of a god, a hero, the origin of a race, etc.; a wonder story of prehistoric origin; a popular fable which is, or has been, received as historical.
The distal end of the mandibles of a bird.
No, not. See No .
The summit of an eminence.
Pulverized sugar candy.
The edible berries of the Zizyphys Lotus , a tree of Northern Africa, and Southwestern Europe.
A deputy or viceroy in India; a governor of a province of the ancient Mogul empire.
A tortilla chip topped with cheese and often chili-pepper or beans and then broiled; -- eaten as a snack or light meal.
A pearly substance which lines the interior of many shells, and is most perfect in the mother-of-pearl.
That point of the heavens, or lower hemisphere, directly opposite the zenith; the inferior pole of the horizon; the point of the celestial sphere directly under the place where we stand.
A small horse; a pony; hence, any horse, especially one that is of inferior breeding or useless.
Irritable; touchy.
A West African gazelle ( Gazella redunca ).
A water nymph; one of the lower female divinities, fabled to preside over some body of fresh water, as a lake, river, brook, or fountain.
Any one of numerous species of small, fresh-water, chaetopod annelids of the tribe Naidina . They belong to the Oligochaeta .
A chief; a leader; a Sepoy corporal.
the horny scale of plate of epidermis at the end of the fingers and toes of man and many apes.
See Naiad .
Having native or unaffected simplicity; ingenuous; artless; frank; as, naïve manners; a naïve person; naïve and unsophisticated remarks.
A genus of cobras.
The sole genus of the family Naiadaceae .
To make naked.
Same as Nacre .
The gavial.
Ale; also, an alehouse.
imp. of Nim .
The title by which any person or thing is known or designated; a distinctive specific appellation, whether of an individual or a class.
given or having a specified name; as, an actor named Harold Lloyd; a building in Cardiff named the Temple of Peace . Contrasted to unnamed .
One who names, or calls by name.
The Sumerian goddess personifying the primeval sea; mother of the gods and of heaven and earth.
Grandmother.
The wife of Balder.
A diminutive of Ann or Anne , the proper name.
A term used by modern archaeologists instead of cella . See Cella .
To have a short sleep; to be drowsy; to doze.
A plant ( Brassica rapa pekinensis ) with an elongated celerylike head of broadstalked leaves used as a vegetable in east Asia; called also Chinese cabbage .
The back part of the neck.

Sheet; surface; all that portion of a surface that is continuous in such a way that it is possible to pass from any one point of the portion to any other point of the portion without leaving the surface. Thus, some hyperboloids have one nappe , and some have two.
Inclined to sleep; sleepy; as, to feel nappy .
A very small chevrotain ( Tragulus Javanicus ), native of Java. It is about the size of a hare, and is noted for its agility in leaping. Called also Java musk deer , pygmy musk deer , and deerlet .
A kind of turnip. See Navew .
An East Indian plant ( Nardostachys Jatamansi ) of the Valerian family, used from remote ages in Oriental perfumery.
The nostrils or nasal openings, -- the anterior nares being the external or proper nostrils, and the posterior nares , the openings of the nasal cavities into the mouth or pharynx.
A law enforcement agent specializing in narcotics law violations.
Of or pertaining to the nose.
Firm; stiff; hard; also, chilly.
Any species of marine gastropods, of the genera Nassa , Tritia , and other allied genera of the family Nassidae ; a dog whelk. See Illust. under Gastropoda .
Offensively filthy; very dirty, foul, or defiled; disgusting; nauseous.
Not at; nor at.
Of or pertaining to one's birth; accompying or dating from one's birth; native.
The rump of beef; esp., the lower and back part of the rump.
The buttocks.
A species of shrike.
Neatly dressed; smart; trim; tidy; spruce.
an intricate traditional dance in India performed by professional dancing girls.
Having to do with shipping; of or pertaining to ships or a navy; consisting of ships; as, naval forces, successes, stores, etc.
The block in the center of a wheel, from which the spokes radiate, and through which the axle passes; -- called also hub or hob .
A mark or depression in the middle of the abdomen; the umbilicus; called also belly button in humans. See Umbilicus .
A kind of small turnip, a variety of Brassica campestris . See Brassica .
Originally, a laborer on canals for internal navigation; hence, a laborer on other public works, as in building railroads, embankments, etc.
A fleet of ships; an assemblage of merchantmen, or so many as sail in company.
A deputy ruler or viceroy in India; also, a title given by courtesy to other persons of high rank in the East.
No; -- a negative answer to a question asked, or a request made, now superseded by no . Opposed to aye or yea . See also Yes .
To refuse; to deny.
A promontory or headland.
coming next after the twenty-first in a series
Not; never.
See 2d Neif .
To be tempered by heat.
The tongue or pole of a cart or other vehicle drawn by two animals.
At a little distance, in place, time, manner, or degree; not remote; nigh.
Cattle of the genus Bos , as distinguished from horses, sheep, and goats; an animal of the genus Bos ; as, a neat's tongue; a neat's foot.
The nose; the snout; the mouth; the beak of a bird; a nib, as of a pen.
The Babylonian god of wisdom and agriculture and patron of scribes and schools.
The part of an animal which connects the head and the trunk, and which, in man and many other animals, is more slender than the trunk.
A pet name for a donkey.
Born; -- a term sometimes used in introducing the name of the family to which a married woman belongs by birth (i.e. her maiden name); as, Madame de Stael, née Necker .
A state that requires supply or relief; pressing occasion for something; necessity; urgent want.
Of necessity; necessarily; indispensably; -- often with must , and equivalent to of need .
Distressed by want of the means of living; very poor; indigent; necessitous.
The nave of a church.
A desert in Southern Israel.

A black man; especially, one of a race of black or very dark persons who inhabit the greater part of tropical Africa, and are distinguished by crisped or curly hair, flat noses, and thick protruding lips; also, any black person of unmixed African blood, wherever found.
A beverage made of wine, water, sugar, nutmeg, and lemon juice; -- so called, it is said, from its first maker, Colonel Negus .
A woman born in the state of villeinage; a female serf.
To utter the cry of the horse; to whinny.
Called; named.
The ichneumon.
A funeral song; an elegy.
A genus of aquatic hemipterous insects. The species feed upon other insects and are noted for their voracity; -- called also scorpion bug and water scorpion .

The most important salmon of Alaska ( Oncorhinchus nerka ), ascending in spring most rivers and lakes from Alaska to Oregon, Washington, and Idaho; -- called also red salmon , redfish , blueback , and sawqui .
A Roman emperor notorious for debauchery and barbarous cruelty; hence, any profligate and cruel ruler or merciless tyrant.
One of the whitish and elastic bundles of fibers, with the accompanying tissues, which transmit nervous impulses between nerve centers and various parts of the animal body.
Strong; sinewy.
Soft; tender; delicate.
A promontory; a cape; a headland.
The bed or receptacle prepared by a fowl for holding her eggs and for hatching and rearing her young.
A fabric of twine, thread, or the like, wrought or woven into meshes, and used for catching fish, birds, butterflies, etc.
remaining after all deductions; same as net a. , 3. Contrasted to gross .
Like a net, or network; netted.
To name; to mention; to utter.
Not ever; not at any time; at no time, whether past, present, or future.

Having existed, or having been made, but a short time; having originated or occured lately; having recently come into existence, or into one's possession; not early or long in being; of late origin; recent; fresh; modern; -- opposed to old , as, a new coat; a new house; a new book; a new fashion.
A novelty; a new thing.
Lately; recently.
A report of recent occurrences; information of something that has lately taken place, or of something before unknown; fresh tidings; recent intelligence.
Full of news; abounding in information as to current events.

Any one of several species of small aquatic salamanders. The common British species are the crested newt ( Triton cristatus ) and the smooth newt ( Lophinus punctatus ). In America, Diemictylus viridescens is one of the most abundant species.
Nearest in place; having no similar object intervening.
Connection; tie.
The gorilla.
A young hawk; an eyas; hence, an unsophisticated person.
A small and pointed thing or part; a point; a prong.
See his nibs under nib , n.
Foolish; silly; simple; ignorant; also, weak; effeminate.
A cavity, hollow, or recess, generally within the thickness of a wall, for a statue, bust, or other erect ornament. Hence, any similar position, literal or figurative.
An evil spirit of the waters.
A nestful; a brood; as, a nide of pheasants .
Scent or savor of meat or food, cooked or cooking.
A nest: a repository for the eggs of birds, insects, etc.; a breeding place; esp., the place or substance where parasites or the germs of a disease effect lodgment or are developed.
A relative, in general; especially, a descendant, whether male or female; a granddaughter or a grandson.
See Neif , the fist.
An unpleasant smell.
Malodorous, unpleasant-smelling. Opposite of fragrant .
Very good; excellent; -- an informal term meaning about the same as groovy , sense 1.
Not distant or remote in place or time; near.

That part of the natural day when the sun is beneath the horizon, or the time from sunset to sunrise; esp., the time between dusk and dawn, when there is no light of the sun, but only moonlight, starlight, or artificial light.
The chigoe.
The Greek winged goddess of victory; identified with Roman Victoria.
Nothing; of no account; worthless; -- a term often used for canceling, in accounts or bookkeeping.
The great river of Egypt.
Not to will; to refuse; to reject.
To take; to steal; to filch.
A goddess of the watery deep and daughter of Ea .
Eight and one more; one less than ten; as, nine miles .
A solar deity, first-born of Bel and consort was Gula ; god of war and the chase and agriculture; sometimes identifed with Biblical Nimrod.
A fool; a simpleton.

A sturdy cloth material of chiffon or voile, used for the manufacture of dresses and other women's garments, and for curtains, and drapery. The material may be constructed by either a plain or a novelty weaving technique.
Following the eight and preceding the tenth; coming after eight others.
The magpie.
The daughter of Tantalus , and wife of Amphion , king of Thebes . Her pride in her children provoked Apollo and Diana , who slew them all. Niobe herself was changed by the gods into stone.
A kind of snuff prepared by the natives of Venezuela from the roasted seeds of a leguminous tree ( Piptadenia peregrina ), thence called niopo tree .
A sip or small draught; esp., a draught of intoxicating liquor; a dram.
A monotypic genus of palms of Australasia.
Pleasantly cold and invigorating; -- of weather conditions.
The first month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year, formerly answering nearly to the month of April, now to March, of the Christian calendar. See Abib .
A simpleton.
Unless; if not; -- used mostly in law.
Wist not; knew not.
A striving; an effort; a conatus.
The egg of a louse or other small insect.
A white crystalline semitransparent salt; potassium nitrate; saltpeter. See Saltpeter .
Bright; lustrous; shining.
See Niter .
Nitroglycerin.
Full of nits.
Abounding with snow; snowy.
One of a class of water spirits, commonly described as of a mischievous disposition.
The title of the native sovereigns of Hyderabad, in India, since 1719.
Chief of the Vanir; god of the sea and winds and prosperity; father of Frey and Freya ; sometimes subsumes Teutonic Nerthus.
north northeast; the compass point that is midway between north and northeast.
north northwest; the compass point that is midway between north and northwest.
Not any; not one; none; as, yes, we have no bananas ; -- often used as a quantifier.
A patriarch of Biblical history, in the time of the Deluge.
A person in a superior position in life; a nobleman.
Stylish; modish; elegant; showy; aristocratic; fashionable.
Possessing eminence, elevation, dignity, etc.; above whatever is low, mean, degrading, or dishonorable; magnanimous; as, a noble nature or action; a noble heart.
Of noble extraction; as, nobly born or descended .
To notch; to fit to the string, as an arrow; to string, as a bow.
To bend or incline the upper part, with a quick motion; as, nodding plumes .
Of the nature of, or relating to, a node; as, a nodal point .
A simpleton; a fool.
A knot, a knob; a protuberance; a swelling.
Same as Nowel .
Not of; nor of.
A wooden block, of the size of a brick, built into a wall, as a hold for the nails of woodwork.
To annoy. See Noy .
An annoyer.
A short or waste piece or knot of wool separated from the longer staple by combing; also, a similar piece or shred of waste silk.
Waste and knots of wool removed by the comb; combings.
Sound of any kind.
Making a noise, esp. a loud sound; clamorous; vociferous; turbulent; boisterous; as, the noisy crowd .
The head; the noodle.
Neat cattle.
See Canker , n. , 1.
One of a race or tribe that has no fixed location, but wanders from place to place in search of pasture or game.
A province or political division, as of modern Greece or ancient Egypt; a nomarchy.
Customary; ordinary; -- applied to the usual English spelling, in distinction from strictly phonetic methods.
No; not. See No , a.
The Fate who spins the thread of life; counterpart of Greek Clotho.
The one or single occasion; the present call or purpose; -- chiefly used in the phrase for the nonce , i. e. for the present time .
The edible plumlike fruit of the Australian tree, Parinarium Nonda .
A coarse umbelliferous plant ( Ligusticum actaeifolium ) with a large aromatic root. It is found chiefly in the Alleghany region. Also called Angelico .
Same as Nones , 2.
A composition for nine instruments, rarely for nine voices.
A silly fellow; a ninny.
The hydrocarbon radical, C9H19- , derived from nonane and forming many compounds. Used also adjectively; as, nonyl alcohol .
A narrow place formed by an angle in bodies or between bodies; a corner; a recess; a secluded retreat.
No. See the Note under No .
A running knot, or loop, which binds the closer the more it is drawn.
See 1st Not .
A cactaceous plant ( Nopalea cochinellifera ), originally Mexican, on which the cochineal insect feeds, and from which it is collected. The name is sometimes given to other species of Cactaceae .
A bullfinch.

A negative connective or particle, introducing the second member or clause of a negative proposition, following neither , or not , in the first member or clause (as or in affirmative propositions follows either ). Nor is also used sometimes in the first member for neither , and sometimes the neither is omitted and implied by the use of nor .
A type of dried seaweed, pressed into sheets and used as a seasoning or as a wrapper for sushi.

A large water wheel, turned by the action of a stream against its floats, and carrying at its circumference buckets, by which water is raised and discharged into a trough; used in Arabia, China, and elsewhere for irrigating land; a Persian wheel.
The cormorant.
A norm; a principle or rule; a model; a standard.
Any one of the three Fates, Past, Present, and Future. Their names were Urd, Verdandi, and Skuld. They are identified with the Anglo-Saxon Wyrd, and are similar to the Greek Moirae and Roman Parcae.
Of or pertaining to ancient Scandinavia, or to the language spoken by its inhabitants.
Lying toward the north; situated at the north, or in a northern direction from the point of observation or reckoning; proceeding toward the north, or coming from the north.
To smell; to scent; hence, to track, or trace out.
Having a nose, or such a nose; -- chiefly used in composition; as, pug- nosed .
To nurse; to lead or teach; to foster; to nuzzle.
Offensively or intrusively curious; prying; nosy; as, a nosy neighbor .
Wottest not; knowest not.
Offensively or intrusively curious; prying; nosey; as, he flipped through my letters in his nosy way .
Wot not; know not; knows not.
Of or pertaining to the back; dorsal.
To cut or make notches in; to indent; also, to score by notches; as, to notch a stick .
To butt; to push with the horns.
Well known by reputation or report; eminent; famous; prominent; celebrated; as, a noted author, or traveler .
One who takes notice.
The south wind.
An ouch; a jewel.
The top of the head; the head or noll.
A word used as the designation or appellation of a creature or thing, existing in fact or in thought; a substantive.
Intellect; understanding; talent; -- used humorously.

A star which suddenly increases in brightness thousands of times, then fades back to near its original intensity. It may appear as a “new” star if its original brightness was too low for routine observation. A star which suddenly increases in brightness to many millions of times its original intensity is a supernova , and the postulated mechanisms for the increases of brightness of novae and supernovae are different.
Of recent origin or introduction; not ancient; new; hence, out of the ordinary course; unusual; strange; surprising.
A game at dice, properly called novem quinque (L., nine five), the two principal throws being nine and five.
Existing at the present time; present.
In no manner or degree; not at all; nowise.
See Nouch .
The European gray gurnard ( Trigla gurnardus ).
Knotted; tied in a knot, as a serpent.
The core, or the inner part, of a mold for casting a large hollow object.
The marriage knot.
Neat cattle.
To annoy; to vex.
A cordial of brandy, etc., flavored with the kernel of the bitter almond, or of the peach stone, etc.
An annoyer.
See Noils .
The chemical symbol for Neptunium, a transuranic element having atomic number 93.
Last or greatest in an indefinitely large series; as, to the nth degree .
The 13th letter of the Greek alphabet (ν).
To push; to nudge; also, to beckon.
A light fabric of wool, worn on the head by women; a cloud.
The back or upper part of the neck; the nape.
See Juglone .
Bare; naked; unclothed; undraped; as, a nude statue .
To touch gently, as with the elbow, in order to call attention or convey intimation.
Trifles; jests.
No; not any; as, nul disseizin; nul tort.
Of no legal or binding force or validity; of no efficacy; invalid; void; nugatory; useless.
To make numb; to deprive of the power of sensation or motion; to render senseless or inert; to deaden; to benumb; to stupefy.
A dolt; a blockhead.
The 14th letter of the Hebrew alphabet, corresponding in pronunciation to n .
Same as Nupson .
A hard knot in wood; also, a hard knob of wood used by boys in playing hockey.
To cut with reeding or fluting on the edge of, as coins, the heads of screws, etc.; to knurl.

One who nourishes; a person who supplies food, tends, or brings up; as: (a) A woman who has the care of young children; especially, one who suckles an infant not her own. (b) A person, especially a woman, who has the care of the sick or infirm.
The god of fire and light; corresponds to the Babylonian Girru .
To gather nuts.
Crazy; loony; insane; batty; -- used in a predicate position, ususually in phrases such as to go nuts , went nuts , are you nuts ?
Abounding in nuts.
Not I; nor I.
A spiral-horned South African antelope ( Tragelaphus angasi ) with a fringe of white hairs along back and neck.
A brood or flock of pheasants.
Any of several thermoplastic polyamide plastics, comprising a family of high-strength resilient synthetic materials, used mostly in fibers.
Is not. See Nis .
A species of ichneumon ( Herpestes nyula ). Its fur is beautifully variegated by closely set zigzag markings.
Originally, an elf's child; a changeling left by fairies or goblins; hence, a deformed or foolish child; a simpleton; an idiot.
Made or consisting of oaks or of the wood of oaks.
See Ocher .
The material obtained by untwisting and picking into loose fiber old hemp ropes; -- used for calking the seams of ships, stopping leaks, etc.
Resembling oak; strong.
Furnished with oars; -- chiefly used in composition; as, a four- oared boat .
Having the form or the use of an oar; as, the swan's oary feet .
The Organization of American States an international association of countries in the Western hemisphere. It was created in 1948 to promote military and economic and social and cultural cooperation.
A fertile or green spot in a waste or desert, esp. in a sandy desert, where the water table approaches the surface.
A kiln to dry hops or malt; a cockle.
A well-known cereal grass ( Avena sativa ), and its edible grain, used as food and fodder; -- commonly used in the plural and in a collective sense.
Consisting of an oat straw or stem; as, an oaten pipe .
A solemn affirmation or declaration, made with a reverent appeal to God for the truth of what is affirmed.
Same as Obi .
Excessively corpulent; fat; fleshy.
To give ear to; to execute the commands of; to yield submission to; to comply with the orders of.
A species of sorcery, probably of African origin, practiced among the negroes of the West Indies.
Death; decease; the date of one's death.

One of the higher wind instruments in the modern orchestra, yet of great antiquity, having a penetrating pastoral quality of tone, somewhat like the clarinet in form, but more slender, and sounded by means of a double reed; a hautboy.
A weight of twelve grains; or, according to some, of ten grains, or half a scruple.
A copper coin, used in the Ionian Islands, about one cent in value.
A Peruvian name for certain species of Oxalis ( Oxalis crenata , and Oxalis tuberosa ) which bear edible tubers.
To meet; to clash.
The whole body of salt water which covers more than three fifths of the surface of the globe; -- called also the sea , or great sea .
A impure earthy ore of iron or a ferruginous clay, usually red (hematite) or yellow (limonite), -- used as a pigment in making paints, etc. The name is also applied to clays of other colors.
See Ocher .
See Ochery .
See Ochrea .
An atom or radical which has a valence of eight, or is octavalent.
A composition for eight parts, usually for eight solo instruments or voices.
Of the eighth degree or order.
A hypothetical hydrocarbon radical regarded as an essential residue of octane, and as entering into its derivatives; as, octyl alcohol .

An alleged force or natural power, supposed, by Reichenbach and others, to produce the phenomena of mesmerism, and to be developed by various agencies, as by magnets, heat, light, chemical or vital action, etc.; -- called also odyle or the odylic force .

Among the early and medieval Teutonic peoples, esp. Scandinavians, the heritable land held by the various odalmen constituting a family or kindred of freeborn tribesmen; also, the ownership of such land. The odal was subject only to certain rights of the family or kindred in restricting the freedom of transfer or sale and giving certain rights of redemption in case of change of ownership by inheritance, etc., and perhaps to other rights of the kindred or the tribe. Survivals of the early odal estates and tenure exist in Orkney and Shetland, where it is usually called by the variant form udal .
Not paired with another, or remaining over after a pairing; without a mate; unmatched; single; as, an odd shoe; an odd glove.
In an odd manner; unevenly.

Difference in favor of one and against another; excess of one of two things or numbers over the other; inequality; advantage; superiority; hence, excess of chances; probability. The odds are often expressed by a ratio; as, the odds are three to one that he will win, i. e. he will win three times out of four
A short poetical composition proper to be set to music or sung; a lyric poem; esp., now, a poem characterized by sustained noble sentiment and appropriate dignity of style.

A kind of theater in ancient Greece, smaller than the dramatic theater and roofed over, in which poets and musicians submitted their works to the approval of the public, and contended for prizes; -- hence, in modern usage, the name of a hall for musical or dramatic performances.
See Odeon .
Of or pertaining to od. See Od .
The supreme deity of the Scandinavians; -- the same as Woden , of the German tribes.
A writer of an ode or odes.
Intense hatred or dislike; loathing; abhorrence.
To charge with od. See Od .
A volatile liquid obtained by boiling sulphur with linseed oil. It has an unpleasant garlic odor.
Any smell, whether fragrant or offensive; scent; perfume.
A corruption of God's ; -- formerly used in oaths and ejaculatory phrases.
See Od . [Archaic] .
An eye, bud, or shoot, as of a plant; an oilet.
In a general sense, from, or out from; proceeding from; belonging to; relating to; concerning; -- used in a variety of applications; as:
In a general sense, denoting from or away from; as:
The rejected or waste parts of any process, especially the inedible parts of a butchered animal, such as the viscera.
To present, as an act of worship; to immolate; to sacrifice; to present in prayer or devotion; -- often with up .
Often; frequently; not rarely; many times.
Frequently; many times; not seldom.
Compar. of Oft .
Same as Ogham .
A particular kind of writing practiced by the ancient Irish, and found in inscriptions on stones, metals, etc.
The arch or rib which crosses a Gothic vault diagonally.
To view or look at with side glances, as in fondness, or with a design to attract notice.
One who ogles.
An imaginary monster, or hideous giant of fairy tales, who lived on human beings; hence, any frightful giant; a cruel monster.
An exclamation expressing various emotions, according to the tone and manner, especially surprise, pain, sorrow, anxiety, or a wish. See the Note under O .

The standard unit in the measure of electrical resistance, being the resistance of a circuit in which a potential difference of one volt produces a current of one ampére. As defined by the International Electrical Congress in 1893, and by United States Statute, it is a resistance substantially equal to 10 9 units of resistance of the C. G. S. system of electro-magnetic units, and is represented by the resistance offered to an unvarying electric current by a column of mercury at the temperature of melting ice 14.4521 grams in mass, of a constant cross-sectional area, and of the length of 106.3 centimeters. As thus defined it is called the international ohm .
An exclamation of surprise, etc.

Any one of a great variety of unctuous combustible substances, more viscous than and not miscible with water; as, olive oil , whale oil , rock oil , etc. They are of animal, vegetable, or mineral origin and of varied composition, and they are variously used for food, for solvents, for anointing, lubrication, illumination, etc. By extension, any substance of an oily consistency; as, oil of vitriol .
Covered or treated with oil; dressed with, or soaked in, oil.
One who deals in oils.
Consisting of oil; containing oil; having the nature or qualities of oil; unctuous; oleaginous; as, oily matter or substance .
A spring, surrounded by rushes or rank grass; an oasis.

A peculiar mammal ( Okapia johnstoni ) closely related to the giraffe, discovered in the deep forests of Belgian Congo in 1900. It is smaller than an ox, and somewhat like a giraffe, except that the neck is much shorter. Like the giraffe, it has no dewclaws. There is a small prominence on each frontal bone of the male. The color of the body is chiefly reddish chestnut, the cheeks are yellowish white, and the fore and hind legs above the knees and the haunches are striped with purplish black and cream color.
Satifactory; agreeable; pleasant; as, things are okay ; he's an okay guy .
A Turkish and Egyptian weight, equal to about 2 3/4 pounds.
Variant spellings of okay .
See Ocher .
An annual plant ( Abelmoschus esculentus syn. Hibiscus esculentus ), whose green pods, abounding in nutritious mucilage, are much used for soups, stews, or pickles; gumbo.
Palm leaves, prepared for being written upon with a style pointed with steel.
Open country.
Old; ancient; as, the olden time .
A genus of trees including the olive.

Pertaining to, derived from, or contained in, oil; as, oleic acid, an acid of the acrylic acid series found combined with glyceryl in the form of olein in certain animal and vegetable fats and oils, such as sperm oil, olive oil, etc. At low temperatures the acid is crystalline, but melts to an oily liquid above 14° C.

A fat, liquid at ordinary temperatures, but solidifying at temperatures below 0° C., found abundantly in both the animal and vegetable kingdoms (see Palmitin ). It dissolves solid fats, especially at 30-40° C. Chemically, olein is a glyceride of oleic acid; and, as three molecules of the acid are united to one molecule of glycerol to form the fat, it is technically known as triolein . It is also called elain .
The European bullfinch.
Having a strong, disagreeable smell; fetid.
A dish of stewed meat of different kinds.
A genus of polished marine gastropod shells, chiefly tropical, and often beautifully colored.

A tree ( Olea Europaea ) with small oblong or elliptical leaves, axillary clusters of flowers, and oval, one-seeded drupes. The tree has been cultivated for its fruit for thousands of years, and its branches are the emblems of peace. The wood is yellowish brown and beautifully variegated.
A pot or jar having a wide mouth; a cinerary urn, especially one of baked clay.
A European cave-dwelling aquatic salamander ( Proteus anguinus ) with permanent external gills.
A colloquial or humorous name for any science or branch of knowledge.
Originally, a leather flask or vessel for oils or liquids; afterward, an earthenware vase or pitcher without a spout.

A mystic syllable or ejaculation used by Hindus and Buddhists in religious rites, -- orig. among the Hindus an exclamation of assent, like Amen , then an invocation, and later a symbol of the trinity formed by Vishnu , Siva , and Brahma .
Of or relating to Oman or its people; as, Omani oil producers; Omani ports .
A game at cards, borrowed from the Spaniards, and usually played by three persons.
A large Mediterranean food fish ( Umbrina cirrhosa ): -- called also umbra , and umbrine .
The last letter of the Greek alphabet. See Alpha .
An occurrence supposed to portend, or show the character of, some future event; any indication or action regarded as a foreshowing; a foreboding; a presage; an augury.
A Hebrew measure, the tenth of an ephah. See Ephah .
To let go; to leave unmentioned; not to insert or name; to drop.
Mellow, as land.
The general signification of on is situation, motion, or condition with respect to contact or support beneath
For one time; by limitation to the number one; not twice nor any number of times more than one.
Hatred; fury; envy.
They say, or it is said.
Being a single unit, or entire being or thing, and no more; not multifold; single; individual.

A liliaceous plant of the genus Allium ( Allium cepa ), having a strong-flavored bulb and long hollow leaves; also, its bulbous root, much used as an article of food. The name is often extended to other species of the genus.
One alone; single; as, the only man present; his only occupation.
A rushing or setting upon; an attack; an assault; a storming; especially, the assault of an army.
On the top of; upon; on. See On to , under On , prep.
A burden; an obligation.
Chalcedony in parallel layers of different shades of color. It is used for making cameos, the figure being cut in one layer with the next as a ground.

Any of several beautiful birds of the genus Moho , including the extinct Moho nobilis . They are honey-eaters native to the Hawaiian Islands. It yields the brilliant yellow feathers formerly used in making the royal robes. Called also yellow-tufted honeysucker .
To bind with a thread or cord; to join; to unite.
Soft mud or slime; earth so wet as to flow gently, or easily yield to pressure.
Miry; containing soft mud; resembling ooze; as, the oozy bed of a river .

A large oceanic fish ( Lampris guttatus ), inhabiting the Atlantic Ocean. It is remarkable for its brilliant colors, which are red, green, and blue, with tints of purple and gold, covered with round silvery spots. Called also king of the herrings .
See Opaque .
A mineral consisting, like quartz, of silica, but inferior to quartz in hardness and specific gravity.

Free of access; not shut up; not closed; affording unobstructed ingress or egress; not impeding or preventing passage; not locked up or covered over; -- applied to passageways; as, an open door, window, road, etc. ; also, to inclosed structures or objects; as, open houses, boxes, baskets, bottles, etc. ; also, to means of communication or approach by water or land; as, an open harbor or roadstead .
A large African forest tree ( Nauclea diderrichii ) yielding a strong hard yellow to golden brown lumber; sometimes placed in genus Sarcocephalus , and then called Sarcocephalus diderrichii .

A drama, either tragic or comic, of which music forms an essential part; a drama wholly or mostly sung, consisting of recitative, arias, choruses, duets, trios, etc., with orchestral accompaniment, preludes, and interludes, together with appropriate costumes, scenery, and action; a lyric drama.
To have an opinion; to judge; to think; to suppose.
The inspissated juice of the Papaver somniferum , or white poppy.
The organ of sight; an eye.

A particle that marks an alternative; as, you may read or may write, -- that is, you may do one of the things at your pleasure, but not both . It corresponds to either . You may ride either to London or to Windsor. It often connects a series of words or propositions, presenting a choice of either; as, he may study law, or medicine, or divinity, or he may enter into trade .
A money of account among the Anglo-Saxons, valued, in the Domesday Book, at twenty pence sterling.
A genus ( Atriplex ) of herbs or low shrubs of the Goosefoot family, most of them with a mealy surface.
Uttered by the mouth, or in words; spoken, not written; verbal; as, oral traditions; oral testimony; oral law.
See Orang-outang .
A blank window or panel.
Having the form of an orb; round.
Spherical; orbicular; orblike; circular.
The path described by a heavenly body in its periodical revolution around another body; as, the orbit of Jupiter, of the earth, of the moon .
Orblike; having the course of an orb; revolving.
Any of several cetaceans, especialy the grampus ( Grampus griseus ) of the dolphin family.
The killer whale ( Orcinus orca ).

A colorless crystalline substance, C6H3.CH3.(OH)2 , which is obtained from certain lichens ( Roccella , Lecanora , etc.), also from extract of aloes, and artificially from certain derivatives of toluene. It changes readily into orcein.
The god of the underworld; counterpart of Greek Pluto.
An edge or point; also, a beginning.
To put in order; to reduce to a methodical arrangement; to arrange in a series, or with reference to an end. Hence, to regulate; to dispose; to direct; to rule.
Honor; grace; favor; mercy; clemency; happy augury.
One of the nymphs of mountains and grottoes.
A confection consisting of a white cream filling sandwiched between two chocolate cookies.
A bright-colored domesticated variety of the id. See Id .
See Argol .
An instrument or medium by which some important action is performed, or an important end accomplished; as, legislatures, courts, armies, taxgatherers, etc., are organs of government .
Any one of a number of long, thick pieces of timber, pointed and shod with iron, and suspended, each by a separate rope, over a gateway, to be let down in case of attack.
A frantic revel; drunken revelry. See Orgies
See Oriel .
A large and bright constellation on the equator, between the stars Aldebaran and Sirius. It contains a remarkable nebula visible to the naked eye.
A wind instrument of music in use among the Spaniards.
The lowest deck of a vessel, esp. of a ship of war, consisting of a platform laid over the beams in the hold, on which the cables are coiled.
An abalone.
To ornament; to adorn.
A yellow pigment of various degrees of intensity, approaching also to red.
A plant of the genus Iris ( Iris Florentina ); a kind of flower-de-luce. Its rootstock has an odor resembling that of violets.
A morsel left at a meal; a fragment; refuse; -- commonly used in the plural.
A kind of sage ( Salvia Horminum ).
The blindworm.
See Oriel .
A genus of African antelopes which includes the gemsbok, the leucoryx, the bisa antelope ( Oryx beisa ), and the beatrix antelope ( Oryx beatrix ) of Arabia.
A genus of grasses including the rice plant; rice.
Pasta shaped like pearls of barley; frequently prepared with lamb in Greek cuisine.
A mouth; an opening; an entrance.
A tributary of the Missouri River.
See 3d Os .
Of or pertaining to the Osci, a primitive people of Campania, a province of ancient Italy.

A kind of willow ( Salix viminalis ) growing in wet places in Europe and Asia, and introduced into North America. It is considered the best of the willows for basket work. The name is sometimes given to any kind of willow.
Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, osmium; specifically, designating those compounds in which it has a valence higher than in other lower compounds; as, osmic oxide .
To prophesy; to presage.
A prophetic or ominous utterance.
Pertaining to, or applied to, the language of the Tuscaroras, Iroquois, Wyandots, Winnebagoes, and a part of the Sioux Indians.
Any eared seal.
Either; -- used with other or or for its correlative (as either . . . or are now used).
Of, pertaining to, or in the region of, the ear; auricular; auditory.
A genus of birds including certain of the bustards.
See Attar .
A corruption of Annotto .
See Attar .
A socket or bezel holding a precious stone; hence, a jewel or ornament worn on the person.
See Aught .
A unit of mass or weight, the sixteenth part of a pound avoirdupois, and containing 28.35 grams or 437 1/2 grains.
A fairy; a goblin; an elf.
Of or pertaining to us; belonging to us; as, our country; our rights; our troops; our endeavors. See I .
See Note under Our .
One of several species of European thrushes, especially the blackbird ( Merula merula , or Turdus merula ), and the mountain or ring ousel ( Turdus torquatus ).
To take away; to remove.

In its original and strict sense, out means from the interior of something; beyond the limits or boundary of somethings; in a position or relation which is exterior to something; -- opposed to in or into . The something may be expressed after of , from , etc. (see Out of , below); or, if not expressed, it is implied; as, he is out ; or, he is out of the house, office, business, etc.; he came out ; or, he came out from the ship, meeting, sect, party, etc.
To go beyond in performance; to excel; to surpass.

Being on the outside; external; farthest or farther from the interior, from a given station, or from any space or position regarded as a center or starting place; -- opposed to inner ; as, the outer wall; the outer court or gate; the outer stump in cricket; the outer world.
That which goes out, or is paid out; outlay; expenditure; -- the opposite of income ; as, when one's outgo exceeds one's income, distress follows quickly .
Same as Ousel .
Of or pertaining to eggs; done in the egg, or inception; as, oval conceptions .
That part of the pistil which contains the seed, and in most flowering plants develops into the fruit. See Illust. of Flower .

A place arched over with brick or stonework, and used for baking, heating, or drying; hence, any structure, whether fixed or portable, which may be heated for baking, drying, etc.; esp., now, a chamber in a stove, used for baking or roasting.
Above, or higher than, in place or position, with the idea of covering; -- opposed to under ; as, clouds are over our heads; the smoke rises over the city.
See Ovine .
Of or pertaining to sheep; consisting of sheep.

The old theory that the egg contains the whole embryo of the future organism and the germs of all subsequent offsprings and is merely awakened to activity by the spermatozoon; -- opposed to spermism or animalculism .
A believer in ovism. Same as Ovulist .
Resembling an egg in shape; egg-shaped; ovate; as, an ovoidal apple .
A round, convex molding. See Illust. of Column .

The rudiment of a seed. It grows from a placenta, and consists of a soft nucleus within two delicate coatings. The attached base of the ovule is the hilum , the coatings are united with the nucleus at the chalaza , and their minute orifice is the foramen .

A more or less spherical and transparent cell, which by a process of multiplication and growth develops into a mass of cells, constituting a new individual like the parent; an egg, spore, germ, or germ cell. See Illust. of Mycropyle .
To possess; to have, as the rightful owner; to own.
Had or held under obligation of paying; due.
To pry about; to prowl.
One who owls; esp., one who conveys contraband goods. See Owling , n.
A small owl; especially, the European species ( Athene noctua ), and the California flammulated owlet ( Megascops flammeolus ).
To grant; to acknowledge; to admit to be true; to confess; to recognize in a particular character; as, we own that we have forfeited your love .
having an owner; often used in combination; as, state- owned railways . Opposite of unowned .
One who owns; a rightful proprietor; one who has the legal or rightful title, whether he is the possessor or not.
The aurochs.
Tanner's ooze. See Ooze , 3.

The male of bovine quadrupeds, especially the domestic animal when castrated and grown to its full size, or nearly so. The word is also applied, as a general name, to any species of bovine animals, male and female.

A frame of wood, bent into the shape of the letter U , and embracing an ox's neck as a kind of collar, the upper ends passing through the bar of the yoke; also, anything so shaped, as a bend in a river.
The oxeye daisy. See under Daisy .
The gadfly of cattle.
See Oxide .
A binary compound of oxygen with an atom or radical, or a compound which is regarded as binary; as, iron oxide , ethyl oxide , nitrogen oxide , etc.
One of a series of isonitroso derivatives obtained by the action of hydroxylamine on aldehydes or ketones.
The great cowslip ( Primula veris , var. elatior ).
The armpit; also, the arm.
A hearing or an inspection, as of a deed, bond, etc., as when a defendant in court prays oyer of a writing .
Hear; attend; -- a term used by criers of courts to secure silence before making a proclamation. It is repeated three times.
See Eyelet .
A discharge of fetid matter from the nostril, particularly if associated with ulceration of the soft parts and disease of the bones of the nose.

A colorless gaseous substance ( O3 ) obtained (as by the silent discharge of electricity in oxygen) as an allotropic form of oxygen, containing three atoms in the molecule. It is a strong oxidizer, and probably exists in the air, though by the ordinary tests it is liable to be confused with certain other substances, as hydrogen dioxide, or certain oxides of nitrogen. It derives its name from its peculiar odor, which resembles that of weak chlorine.
A shortened form of Papa .
A toll for passage over another person's grounds.
The Easter festival.

A political action committee , a committee formed by an organization or special-interest group to raise money to support candidates for office or to influence legislation. A PAC provides a legal means for corporations in the U. S. to support political candidates even when direct contributions from corporations to candidates is forbidden by law. In theory, the corporation may not itself contribute to a PAC, but may pay the expenses of raising money from individuals. PACs may also be formed by organizations other than commercial corporations, such as trade associations.

A large burrowing South American rodent ( Agouti paca syn. Cuniculus paca , formerly Cœlogenys paca ), having blackish brown fur, with four parallel rows of white spots along its sides; the spotted cavy. It is closely allied to the agouti and the Guinea pig and is highly esteemed as food.
A single movement from one foot to the other in walking; a step.
Having, or trained in, [such] a pace or gait; trained; -- used in composition; as, slow- paced ; a thorough- paced villain.
One who, or that which, paces.
A civil or military authority in Turkey or Egypt; same as Pasha .

To make a pack of; to arrange closely and securely in a pack; hence, to place and arrange compactly as in a pack; to press into close order or narrow compass; as, to pack goods in a box; to pack fish .
Same as Alpaca .
An agreement; a league; a compact; a covenant.
A South American fresh-water fish ( Myletes pacu ), of the family Characinidæ . It is highly esteemed as food.
A footpath; a road.
Groats; coarse flour or meal.
Low; mean; boorish; vagabond.
The barn owl; -- called also pudge , and pudge owl .
A paddock, or toad.

A Christian priest or monk; used as a term of address for priests in some churches (especially Roman or Orthodox Catholic in Italy, Spain, Portugal, and Spanish America); -- also used in the American military.
One who worships false gods; an idolater; a heathen; one who is neither a Christian, a Mohammedan, nor a Jew.

A serving boy; formerly, a youth attending a person of high degree, especially at courts, as a position of honor and education; now commonly, in England, a youth employed for doing errands, waiting on the door, and similar service in households; in the United States, a boy or girl employed to wait upon the members of a legislative body. Prior to 1960 only boys served as pages in the United States Congress

A small electronic communication device which signals when a telephone call has been received at a base station. Each such device receives radio signals from the base station specifically coded for the individual to whom it is registered; the signal given by the device to the registered user may be a beeping sound, indicating that the user should call the base station to receive a message; or it may display a telephone number to which the user may call directly to return the incoming call, or may display a short message. Such devices are small enough to carry in the pocket or pocketbook, or to clip onto a belt or other part of the clothing. Also called beeper .
An exclamation expressing disgust or contempt. See Bah .
A large war canoe of the Society Islands.
Receiving pay; compensated; hired; as, a paid attorney .
A vessel of wood or tin, etc., usually cylindrical and having a bail, -- used esp. for carrying liquids, as water or milk, etc.; a bucket. It may, or may not, have a cover.
Punishment suffered or denounced; suffering or evil inflicted as a punishment for crime, or connected with the commission of a crime; penalty.
Labor; toilsome effort; care or trouble taken; -- plural in form, but used with a singular or plural verb, commonly the former.
To cover with coloring matter; to apply paint to; as, to paint a house, a signboard, etc.
To be joined in pairs; to couple; to mate, as for breeding.
The country; the people of the neighborhood.
See Poise .
A mate; a partner; esp., an accomplice or confederate.
Paleness; pallor.
Same as Palea .
pl. of Palus .
Same as Pawl .
An oblong rectangular piece of cloth, worn by Roman ladies, and fastened with brooches.
Having the relationship of friends or pals; -- used colloquially.
The inner and somewhat concave part of the hand between the bases of the fingers and the wrist.
Bearing palms; abounding in palms; derived from palms; as, a palmy shore .
A pole or timber of any kind; -- in the names of trees.
Same as Palpus .
pl. of Palpus . (Zool.) See Palpus .
Paralysis, complete or partial. See Paralysis .
One of several upright slender calcareous processes which surround the central part of the calicle of certain corals.
Pale; wanting color; dim.
The knave of clubs.
A plain. See pampas .
A part; a portion.
A genus of perennial herbs of eastern North America and Asia having aromatic tuberous roots: ginseng.
See Paunch .
See pansy .

A small Asiatic mammal ( Ailurus fulgens ) having fine soft fur, which inhabits the mountains of Northern India. It was once thought to be related to the bears, but is now believed to be more closely related to raccoons. It has reddish-brown fur on the back and sides, and black fur on the legs and underside. Called also the lesser panda .
The narrow edge of a hammer head. See Peen .
Having panes; provided with panes; also, having openings; as, a paned window; paned window sash.
A sunken compartment with raised margins, molded or otherwise, as in ceilings, wainscotings, etc.
A paroxysm of extreme pain or anguish; a sudden and transitory agony; a throe; as, the pangs of death .
A plant of the genus Panicum ; panic grass; also, the edible grain of some species of panic grass.
See Painim .
A fabric resembling velvet, but having the nap flat and less close.

A plant of the genus Viola ( Viola tricolor ) and its blossom, originally purple and yellow. Cultivated varieties have very large flowers of a great diversity of colors. Called also heart's-ease , love-in-idleness , and many other quaint names.
To breathe quickly or in a labored manner, as after exertion or from eagerness or excitement; to respire with heaving of the breast; to gasp.
A garment extending from the waist to the knee or ankle, covering each leg separately.
See Panim .
An old Italian silver coin, worth about ten cents.
A soft food for infants, made of bread boiled or softened in milk or water.
Same as papaya , senses 1 and 2.
A spiritual father; specifically, the pope.

A substance in the form of thin sheets or leaves intended to be written or printed on, or to be used in wrapping. It is made of rags, straw, bark, wood, or other fibrous material, which is first reduced to pulp, then molded, pressed, and dried.
Like pap; soft; succulent; tender.
A Pacific island north of Australia; governed by Australia and Indonesia.

By; with; -- used frequently in Early English in phrases taken from the French, being sometimes written as a part of the word which it governs; as, par amour, or par amour; par cas, or par case; par fay, or par fay.
A piece of Turkish money, usually copper, the fortieth part of a piaster, or about one ninth of a cent.
A white crystalline nitrogenous substance ( C2H4N4 ); -- called also dicyandiamide .
To burn the surface of; to scorch; to roast over the fire, as dry grain; as, to parch the skin; to parch corn.
A leopard; a panther.
Certainly; surely; truly; verily; -- originally an oath.
A money of account once used in in Goa, India, equivalent to about 2s. 6d. sterling. or 60 cts. (in 1913).
To cut off, or shave off, the superficial substance or extremities of; as, to pare an apple; to pare a horse's hoof.
One who, or that which, pares; an instrument for paring.
A plant common in Europe ( Paris quadrifolia ); herb Paris; truelove. It has been used as a narcotic.
A piece of ground inclosed, and stored with beasts of the chase, which a man may have by prescription, or the king's grant.
An outer garment made of the skins of birds or mammals, worn by Eskimos, etc.
Cold; -- of weather.
To talk; to converse; to parley.
Given or done by word of mouth; oral; also, given by a writing not under seal; as, parol evidence .
A young salmon in the stage when it has dark transverse bands; -- called also samlet , skegger , and fingerling .
To ward off, evade, or turn aside something, as a blow, argument, etc.
To resolve into its elements, as a sentence, pointing out the several parts of speech, and their relation to each other by government or agreement; to analyze and describe grammatically.
Same as Parsee .

One of the portions, equal or unequal, into which anything is divided, or regarded as divided; something less than a whole ; a number, quantity, mass, or the like, regarded as going to make up, with others, a larger number, quantity, mass, etc., whether actually separate or not; a piece; a fragment; a fraction; a division; a member; a constituent.
The local environment; as, he hasn't been seen around these parts in years .
A part or portion.
The type genus of the family Paridae .
A pace; a step, as in a dance.
The gemsbok.
The passover; the feast of Easter.
To strike; to crush; to smash; to dash in pieces.
An honorary title given to officers of high rank in Turkey, as to governers of provinces, military commanders, etc. The earlier form was bashaw .
See Pasch .
A kind of minuet, in triple time, of French origin, popular in the reign of Queen Elizabeth and for some time after; -- called also passing measure , and passymeasure .

To go; to move; to proceed; to be moved or transferred from one point to another; to make a transit; -- usually with a following adverb or adverbal phrase defining the kind or manner of motion; as, to pass on, by, out, in, etc.; to pass swiftly, directly, smoothly, etc.; to pass to the rear, under the yoke, over the bridge, across the field, beyond the border, etc.
Past; gone by; hence, past one's prime; worn; faded; as, a passée belle .
Of or pertaining to a former time or state; neither present nor future; gone by; elapsed; ended; spent; as, past troubles; past offences.

Any of a variety of edible unleavened doughey preparations made from flour, eggs and water, originating in Italy , and shaped into various forms, such as solid strings (as spaghetti), hollow tubes, or layered squares (ravioli). They may be mixed with various sauces, often having a tomato base, or filled with meat or cheese fillings.
A soft composition, as of flour moistened with water or milk, or of earth moistened to the consistence of dough, as in making potter's ware.
Like paste, as in color, softness, stickness.
To strike gently with the fingers or hand; to stroke lightly; to tap; as, to pat a dog .
A West African long-tailed monkey ( Cercopithecus ruber ); the red monkey.
A piece of cloth, or other suitable material, sewed or otherwise fixed upon a garment to repair or strengthen it, esp. upon an old garment to cover a hole.
The head of a person; the top, or crown, of the head.
Having a pate; -- used only in composition; as, long- pated ; shallow- pated .
See Pattee .
A trodden way; a footway.
A plate. See Paten .
A paved yard or floor where ores are cleaned and sorted, or where ore, salt, mercury, etc., are trampled by horses, to effect intermixture and amalgamation.
Fitly; seasonably.
A little pie.
An Italian silver coin. See Paolo .
To palm off by fraud; to cheat at cards.
A kind of bread. See Pone .
A temporary stop or rest; an intermission of action; interruption; suspension; cessation.
A curassow ( Ourax pauxi ), which, in South America, is often domesticated.
A stately and formal Spanish dance for which full state costume is worn; -- so called from the resemblance of its movements to those of the peacock.

To lay or cover with stone, brick, or other material, so as to make a firm, level, or convenient surface for vehicles, horses, carriages, or persons on foot, to travel on; to floor with brick, stone, or other solid material; as, to pave a street; to pave a court.
covered with a firm surface; -- of pathways or roadways.
See Pavan .
One who paves; one who lays a pavement.
Timid; fearful.
See Pavan .
A large heavy oblong shield covering the whole body, carried by a pavisor, who sometimes also screened an archer with it. It was originally carried but sometimes set up in permanent position
A genus of birds, including the peacocks.
A small triangular flag, esp. one attached to a knight's lance; a pennon.
The foot of a quadruped having claws, as the lion, dog, cat, etc.
A small lobster.
Arch; cunning; sly.

A pivoted tongue, or sliding bolt, on one part of a machine, adapted to fall into notches, or interdental spaces, on another part, as a ratchet wheel, in such a manner as to permit motion in one direction and prevent it in the reverse, as in a windlass; a catch, click, or detent. See Illust. of Ratchet Wheel .
See Pan , the masticatory.
The kiss of peace; also, the embrace in the sanctuary now substituted for it at High Mass in Roman Catholic churches.
