To cover, as bottom of a vessel, a seam, a spar, etc., with tar or pitch, or waterproof composition of tallow, resin, etc.; to smear.
the British system of withholding tax.

The person to whom money is to be, or has been, paid; the person named in a bill or note, to whom, or to whose order, the amount is promised or directed to be paid. See Bill of exchange , under Bill .
One who pays; specifically, the person by whom a bill or note has been, or should be, paid.
Bread. Having
See Payer .
Phosphate-buffered saline, a saline solution containing a phosphate buffer.

A personal computer; a computer{2} designed for use by one person at a time; -- contrasted with shared-time computers such as mainframes and minicomputers , which may be accessed by multiple users each operating from a different input device (in the 1990's, usually a terminal). A personal computer typically uses a microprocessor for its CPU.
A drug originally taken in the form of powder ("dust") for its hallucinogenic effects.
Percent; a fractional proportion, multiplied by 100.
The chemical symbol for palladium , an element of the platinum group, of atomic number 46.
The 17th letter of the Hebrew alphabet.
The sliding weight on a steelyard.
A state of quiet or tranquillity; freedom from disturbance or agitation; calm; repose
To accuse of crime; to inform against.
A kind of aboriginal shell money, or wampum, of the Atlantic coast of the United States; -- originally applied only to polished white cylindrical beads. See also wampum .
See Paage .
A point; the sharp end or top of anything that terminates in a point; as, the peak , or front, of a cap .
Having a peak or peaks.
A small salmon; a grilse; a sewin.
One of the furs, the ground being sable , and the spots or tufts or .
The fleshy pome, or fruit, of a rosaceous tree ( Pyrus communis ), cultivated in many varieties in temperate climates; also, the tree which bears this fruit. See Pear family , below.
A fringe or border.
Active; lively; brisk; smart; -- often applied to convalescents; as, she is quite peart to-day .
A small person; a pet; -- sometimes used contemptuously.
Composed of peat; abounding in peat; resembling peat.
An armadillo ( Tatusia novemcincta ) which is found from Texas to Paraguay; -- called also tatouhou .

A species of hickory ( Carya olivæformis ), growing in North America, chiefly in the Mississippi valley and in Texas, where it is one of the largest of forest trees; also, its fruit, a smooth, oblong nut, an inch or an inch and a half long, with a thin shell and well-flavored meat.
See Pekoe .
The fourth part of a bushel; a dry measure of eight quarts; as, a peck of wheat .
The pectoral muscles; -- a contraction used by body-building and health enthusiasts. Used similarly to abs and delts .
See Picul .
A basket; a hammer; a pannier.
Of or pertaining to the foot, or to feet, literally or figuratively; specifically (Zool.) , pertaining to the foot of a mollusk; as, the pedal ganglion .
The five of trumps in certain varieties of auction pitch.
See 1st Pea .
See Piece .
To look surreptitiously, or with the eyes half closed, or through a crevice; to peep.
A small tower, fort, or castle; a keep.

A graceful and swift South African antelope ( Pelea capreola ). The hair is woolly, and ash-gray on the back and sides. The horns are black, long, slender, straight, nearly smooth, and very sharp. Called also rheeboc , rhebuck , rhebok , and rehboc .
A round-edged, or hemispherical, end to the head of a hammer or sledge, used to stretch or bend metal by indentation.
To cry, as a chicken hatching or newly hatched; to chirp; to cheep.
To come in sight; to appear.
Same as Peart .
A small, pointed piece of wood, used in fastening boards together, in attaching the soles of boots or shoes, etc.; as, a shoe peg .
A sort of moving machine employed in the old pageants.
A weight; a poise.
See Fisher , 2.
a Pekingese.
A kind of black tea.
See Wax insect , under Wax .
Money; riches; lucre; gain; -- generally conveying the idea of something ill-gotten or worthless. It has no plural.
To pelt; to knock about.
The under surface of the foot.
The skin of a beast with the hair on; a raw or undressed hide; a skin preserved with the hairy or woolly covering on it. See 4th Fell .
A small shield, especially one of an approximately elliptic form, or crescent-shaped.
To write; to compose and commit to paper; to indite; to compose; as, to pen a sonnet .
Of or pertaining to punishment, to penalties, or to crimes and offenses; pertaining to criminal jurisprudence
pl. of Penny . See Penny .
Oil cake; penock.
The erectile external sexual organ of males, used in copulation, and in mammals, also for urination.
A minnow. See Pink , n. , 4.
A perfect, or normal, feather.
Denoting the weight in pounds for one thousand; -- used in combination, with respect to nails; as, ten penny nails, nails of which one thousand weight ten pounds .
pl. of Penny ; pence.
Penned or shut up; confined; -- often with up .
A foot soldier; a policeman; also, an office attendant; a messenger.
A plant, and its flower, of the ranunculaceous genus Pæonia . Of the four or five species, one is a shrub; the rest are perennial herbs with showy flowers, often double in cultivation.
Any fleshy fruit with a firm rind, as a pumpkin, melon, or gourd. See Gourd .
Full of pep; spirited; bouncy{2}; as, the peppy and interesting talk .
Pepsi Cola; -- a familiar contraction; as, I prefer Pepsi to Coke .

Through; by means of; through the agency of; by; for; for each; as, per annum; per capita, by heads, or according to individuals; per curiam, by the court; per se, by itself, of itself . Per is also sometimes used with English words.
A genus of fishes, including the fresh-water perch.

Any fresh-water fish of the genus Perca and of several other allied genera of the family Percidæ , as the common American or yellow perch ( Perca flavescens syn. Perca Americana ), and the European perch ( Perca fluviatilis ).
One placed on watch, or in ambush.
Truly. See Parde .
An imaginary being, male or female, like an elf or fairy, represented as a descendant of fallen angels, excluded from paradise till penance is accomplished.
Danger; risk; hazard; jeopardy; exposure of person or property to injury, loss, or destruction.
To make trim or smart; to straighten up; to erect; to make a jaunty or saucy display of; as, to perk the ears; to perk up one's head.
Perk; pert; jaunty; trim.
To take profit of; to make profitable.
A fermented liquor made from pears; pear cider.
Light blue; grayish blue; -- a term applied to different shades at different periods.
Open; evident; apert.
A pear tree. See Pirie .
The distal segment of the hind limb of vertebrates, including the tarsus and foot.
Pestering; vexatious; troublesome. Used also as an intensive.
A Spanish dollar; also, an Argentine, Chilian, Colombian, etc., coin, equal to from 75 cents to a dollar; also, a pound weight.
A fatal epidemic disease; a pestilence; specif., the plague.

A sauce used in Italian cuisine, typically made by blending olive oil, basil, garlic, pine nuts, and grated parmesan cheese; it is served hot or cold over pasta, meat, or fish. Where pine nuts are expensive, sunflower seeds are sometimes substituted.
A cade lamb; a lamb brought up by hand.
One of the leaves of the corolla, or the colored leaves of a flower. See Corolla , and Illust. of Flower .
See Petard .
A common baptismal name for a man. The name of one of the twelve apostles of Christ.
Small; little; insignificant; mean; -- Same as Petty .
See Saltpeter .
The breast.
Little; trifling; inconsiderable; unimportant; also, inferior; subordinate; as, a petty fault; petty complaints; a petty prince.

One of the compartments in a church which are separated by low partitions, and have long seats upon which several persons may sit; -- sometimes called slip . Pews were originally made square, but are now usually long and narrow.
A common American tyrant flycatcher ( Sayornis phœbe , or Sayornis fuscus ). Called also pewit , and phœbe .
Same as Pewit .
The lapwing.
A territory in southwestern Germany formerly ruled by the counts palatine.
A beacon tower; a lighthouse.
A pharos; a lighthouse.
That which is exhibited to the eye; the appearance which anything manifests, especially any one among different and varying appearances of the same object.
An apparition; a phantom; an appearance.

A scholastic degree awarded for study beyond college; the Doctorate degree in Philosophy. In America it is usually based on at least 3 years graduate study and a dissertation; the doctorate is the highest degree awarded by a graduate school, and is awarded in other fields, such as Doctor of Arts. The Ph.D. is broadly applicable, as in most fields of science and technology; -- the term philosophy being derived from an earlier label for experimental science as Natural Philosophy .
See Phœbe .
See 1st Fere .
A bearing representing the head of a dart or javelin, with long barbs which are engrailed on the inner edge.
A glass vessel or bottle, especially a small bottle for medicines; a vial.
The face or visage.
A genus of American herbs, having showy red, white, or purple flowers.
A genus of seals. It includes the common harbor seal and allied species. See Seal .
An instrument that converts sound into signals that can be transmitted over distances and then converts received signals back into sounds; a telephone; as, I talked to him on the phone .
A South American butterfly ( Ithonia phono ) having nearly transparent wings.
imitating something superior; intended to deceive; fraudulent; having a misleading appearance; not genuine; counterfeit; fake; as, a phony diamond; a phony hundred-dollar bill .
A contraction of Photograph .
A local division of the people in ancient Athens; a clan; a tribe.
A tubercle on any external part of the body.
A genus of fresh-water Pulmonifera, having reversed spiral shells. See Pond snail , under Pond .
The inorganic orthophoshate ion; -- a symbol used in biochemistry.
Pertaining to the pia mater .
The yaws. See Yaws .
Soft; -- a direction to the performer to execute a certain passage softly, and with diminished volume of tone. (Abbrev. p. )
A Turkish cloth measure, varying from 18 to 28 inches.
The genus that includes the magpies.
A small copper coin of the East Indies, worth less than a cent.

A genus of coniferous trees of the northen hemisphere, including the Norway spruce and the American black and white spruces. These trees have pendent cones, which do not readily fall to pieces, in this and other respects differing from the firs.
A division of birds including the woodpeckers and wrynecks.
To throw; to pitch.
A small piece of land inclosed with a hedge; a close.
One of many small loops, as of thread, forming an ornamental border, as on a ribbon.
The powder of aloes with canella, formerly officinal, employed as a cathartic.
A race of people of uncertain origin, who inhabited Scotland in early times.

A commercial weight varying in different countries and for different commodities. In Borneo it is 135 5/8 lbs.; in China and Sumatra, 133 1/2 lbs.; in Japan, 133 1/3 lbs.; but sometimes 130 lbs., etc. Called also, by the Chinese, tan .
A genus of woodpeckers, including some of the common American and European species.
An article of food consisting of paste baked with something in it or under it; as, chicken pie ; venison pie ; mince pie ; apple pie ; pumpkin pie .
A fragment or part of anything separated from the whole, in any manner, as by cutting, splitting, breaking, or tearing; a part; a portion; as, a piece of sugar; to break in pieces .
imp. & p. p. of Pi , or Pie , v.
Full; having all the instruments.
Any detached mass of masonry, whether insulated or supporting one side of an arch or lintel, as of a bridge; the piece of wall between two openings.
The dipper, or water ouzel.
Veneration or reverence of the Supreme Being, and love of his character; loving obedience to the will of God, and earnest devotion to his service.
The young of swine, male or female; also, any swine; a hog.
A piggin. See 1st Pig .
Pitched; fixed; determined.
See Pygmy .

Any one of several species of tailless rodents of the genus Ochotona (formerly Lagomys ), resembling small rabbits, but with short ears alnd legs. They inhabit the high mountains of Asia and America. Called also calling hare , and crying hare and rock rabbit . See Chief hare .
A foot soldier's weapon, consisting of a long wooden shaft or staff, with a pointed steel head. It is now superseded by the bayonet.
Furnished with a pike; ending in a point; peaked; pointed.
See Pillau .
A gown or case of skin, or one trimmed or lined with fur.
A hair; hence, the fiber of wool, cotton, and the like; also, the nap when thick or heavy, as of carpeting and velvet.
Having a pile or point; pointed.
One who places things in a pile.
The small, troublesome tumors or swellings about the anus and lower part of the rectum which are technically called hemorrhoids . See Hemorrhoids . [The singular pile is sometimes used.]
The peel or skin.
A conical loaf of sugar.
One employed to steer a vessel; a helmsman; a steersman.
Like pile or wool.
One who provides gratification for the lust of others; a procurer; a pander.
To inclose; to confine; to pen; to pound.
A cone of silver amalgam prepared for retorting; also, the residuary cone of spongy silver left after the retorting.
A tablet; a register; hence, a list or scheme inscribed on a tablet.
To press hard or squeeze between the ends of the fingers, between teeth or claws, or between the jaws of an instrument; to squeeze or compress, as between any two hard bodies.
Woe; torment; pain.
A term used in designating an East Indian tree (the Vateria Indica or piney tree, of the order Dipterocarpeæ , which grows in Malabar, etc.) or its products.
The sound made by a bullet in striking a solid object or in passing through the air.
Of or pertaining to the pine; obtained from the pine; formerly, designating an acid which is the chief constituent of common resin, -- now called abietic , or sylvic , acid .
A vessel with a very narrow stern; -- called also pinky .
See 1st Pink .
A leaflet of a pinnate leaf. See Illust. of Bipinnate leaf , under Bipinnate .
A measure of capacity, equal to half a quart, or four gills, -- used in liquid and dry measures. See Quart .
Lit., painted; hence, piebald; mottled; pied.

A large genus of evergreen coniferous trees, mostly found in the northern hemisphere. The genus formerly included the firs, spruces, larches, and hemlocks, but is now limited to those trees which have the primary leaves of the branchlets reduced to mere scales, and the secondary ones ( pine needles ) acicular, and usually in fascicles of two to seven. See Pine .
Abounding with pines.
See Peony .
The magpie.
Of or pertaining to piety; exhibiting piety; reverential; dutiful; religious; devout; godly.

A contagious disease of fowls, characterized by hoarseness, discharge from the nostrils and eyes, and an accumulation of mucus in the mouth, forming a “scale” on the tongue. By some the term pip is restricted to this last symptom, the disease being called roup by them.
The Surinam toad ( Pipa Americana ), noted for its peculiar breeding habits.
A wind instrument of music, consisting of a tube or tubes of straw, reed, wood, or metal; any tube which produces musical sounds; as, a shepherd's pipe ; the pipe of an organ.
Formed with a pipe; having pipe or pipes; tubular.
See Pepper .

Any one of numerous species of small singing birds belonging to Anthus and allied genera, of the family Motacillidæ . They strongly resemble the true larks in habits, colors, and the great length of the hind claw. They are, therefore, often called titlarks , and pipit larks .

Any one of numerous species of small clamatorial birds belonging to Pipra and allied genera, of the family Pipridæ . The male is usually glossy black, varied with scarlet, yellow, or sky blue. They chiefly inhabit South America.
Like a pipe; hollow-stemmed.
The jigger. See Jigger .
Same as Piraya .
See Pirry .
To spin, as a top.
A quill or reed on which thread or yarn is wound; a bobbin; also, the wound yarn on a weaver's shuttle; also, the reel of a fishing rod.
A rough gale of wind.
An exclamation of contempt.
The Canada lynx.
To discharge urine, to urinate; -- usually considered vulgar.
See Piste .
The track or tread a horseman makes upon the ground he goes over.
A large cavity or hole in the ground, either natural or artificial; a cavity in the surface of a body; an indentation
A fiber obtained from the Agave Americana and other related species, -- used for making cordage and paper. Called also pita fiber , and pita thread .
A thick, black, lustrous, and sticky substance obtained by boiling down tar. It is used in calking the seams of ships; also in coating rope, canvas, wood, ironwork, etc., to preserve them.
The soft spongy substance in the center of the stems of many plants and trees, especially those of the dicotyledonous or exogenous classes. It consists of cellular tissue.
Consisting wholly, or in part, of pith; abounding in pith; as, a pithy stem; a pithy fruit.

A metal spike having a sharpened point on one end, and a hole through which a rope can be passed on the other; it is driven into the face of a rock cliff during climbing, and used as an anchor point for a rope.
The worst possible situation, person, or thing; something extremely bad, boring, or depressing; -- always used with the ; as, cleaning the house is the pits .

Any one of a large group of bright-colored clamatorial birds belonging to Pitta , and allied genera of the family Pittidæ . Most of the species are varied with three or more colors, such as blue, green, crimson, yellow, purple, and black. They are called also ground thrushes , and Old World ant thrushes ; but they are not related to the true thrushes.
To feel pity or compassion for; to have sympathy with; to compassionate; to commiserate; to have tender feelings toward (any one), awakened by a knowledge of suffering.
A fixed pin or short axis, on the end of which a wheel or other body turns.
An old English name for a fairy; an elf.
Any portion of space regarded as measured off or distinct from all other space, or appropriated to some definite object or use; position; ground; site; spot; rarely, unbounded space.
A small copper coin formerly current in Scotland, worth less than a cent.
A stripe of color.
A region; country.
A rectangular garment or piece of cloth, usually made of the checkered material called tartan, but sometimes of plain gray, or gray with black stripes. It is worn by both sexes in Scotland.
To lament; to bewail; to complain.
A flat fold; a doubling, as of cloth; a pleat; as, a box plait .

A draught or form; properly, a representation drawn on a plane, as a map or a chart; especially, a top view, as of a machine, or the representation or delineation of a horizontal section of anything, as of a building; a graphic representation; a diagram.
Any tree of the genus Platanus .
A broad piece of sawed timber, differing from a board only in being thicker. See Board .

A vegetable; an organized living being, generally without feeling and voluntary motion, and having, when complete, a root, stem, and leaves, though consisting sometimes only of a single leafy expansion, or a series of cellules, or even a single cellule.
A small pool of standing water; a puddle.
A mold or matrix in which anything is cast or formed to a particular shape.
To form by interlaying interweaving; to braid; to plait.
A flat, or nearly flat, piece of metal, the thickness of which is small in comparison with the other dimensions; a thick sheet of metal; as, a steel plate .
See Lodge , n.
Like a plate; consisting of plates.
To applaud.
To engage in sport or lively recreation; to exercise for the sake of amusement; to frolic; to spot.
A beach; a strand; in the plains and deserts of Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona, a broad, level spot, on which subsequently becomes dry by evaporation.
A public square in a city or town.

That which is alleged by a party in support of his cause; in a stricter sense, an allegation of fact in a cause, as distinguished from a demurrer ; in a still more limited sense, and in modern practice, the defendant's answer to the plaintiff's declaration and demand. That which the plaintiff alleges in his declaration is answered and repelled or justified by the defendant's plea . In chancery practice, a plea is a special answer showing or relying upon one or more things as a cause why the suit should be either dismissed, delayed, or barred. In criminal practice, the plea is the defendant's formal answer to the indictment or information presented against him.

To argue in support of a claim, or in defense against the claim of another; to urge reasons for or against a thing; to attempt to persuade one by argument or supplication; to speak by way of persuasion; as, to plead for the life of a criminal; to plead with a judge or with a father.
See Plait .
The common people; the mob.
The commonalty of ancient Rome who were citizens without the usual political rights; the plebeians; -- distinguished from the patricians .
imp. & p. p. of Plead
To complain. See Plain .
Full; complete; plenary.
A pool; a plash.
Full See Plein .
An old term for a river boat.
A disease of the hair ( Plica polonica ), in which it becomes twisted and matted together. The disease is of Polish origin, and is hence called also Polish plait .
imp. & p. p. of Ply .
To swell, as grain or wood with water.
An instrument of punishment or torture resembling the knout, used in Russia.
A mixture of hair and tar for covering the bottom of a ship.

A figure in which a word is separated or repeated by way of emphasis, so as not only to signify the individual thing denoted by it, but also its peculiar attribute or quality; as, “His wife 's a wife indeed .”
To travel slowly but steadily; to trudge.
To fall, drop, or move in any way, with a sudden splash or slap, as on the surface of water.
A small extent of ground; a plat; as, a garden plot .

A well-known implement, drawn by horses, mules, oxen, or other power, for turning up the soil to prepare it for bearing crops; also used to furrow or break up the soil for other purposes; as, the subsoil plow ; the draining plow .
Sport; frolic.
To pull; to draw.
To throw out, as smoke, dust, etc., in puffs.
Any piece of wood, metal, or other substance used to stop or fill a hole; a stopple.
A little mass or weight of lead, or the like, attached to a line, and used by builders, etc., to indicate a vertical direction; a plummet; a plumb bob. See Plumb line , below.
To pick and adjust the plumes or feathers of; to dress or prink.
Well rounded or filled out; full; fleshy; fat; as, a plump baby; plump cheeks.
Covered or adorned with plumes, or as with plumes; feathery.
To pluck and release quickly (a musical string); to twang.
A textile fabric with a nap or shag on one side, longer and softer than the nap of velvet.
The son of Saturn and Rhea, brother of Jupiter and Neptune; the dark and gloomy god of the Lower World.
To bend; to yield.
One who, or that which, plies
The place at Athens where the meetings of the people were held for making decrees, etc.
A genus of grasses, including a great number of species, as the kinds called meadow grass , Kentucky blue grass , June grass , and spear grass (which see).
To cook, as eggs, by breaking them into boiling water; also, to cook with butter after breaking in a vessel.
Waste matter from the preparation of skins, consisting of hair, lime, oil, etc.
The poke ( Phytolacca decandra ); -- called also pocan bush .
A pustule raised on the surface of the body in variolous and vaccine diseases.
Full of pocks; affected with smallpox or other eruptive disease.
A little; -- used chiefly in phrases indicating the time or movement; as, poco più allegro, a little faster; poco largo, rather slow.
A bag; a pouch.
A puddle; a plash.
Fat and short; pudgy.
Same as Poi .

A metrical composition; a composition in verse written in certain measures, whether in blank verse or in rhyme, and characterized by imagination and poetic diction; -- contradistinguished from prose ; as, the poems of Homer or of Milton .
One skilled in making poetry; one who has a particular genius for metrical composition; the author of a poem; an imaginative thinker or writer.
See Porgy .
The menhaden.
An exclamation expressing contempt or disgust; bah !
A national food of the Hawaiians, made by baking and pounding the kalo (or taro) root, and reducing it to a thin paste, which is allowed to ferment.
To impound, as cattle.
To appoint.
Weight; gravity; that which causes a body to descend; heaviness.
See Poise .
A tall drinking cup.

A large North American herb of the genus Phytolacca ( Phytolacca decandra ), bearing dark purple juicy berries; -- called also garget , pigeon berry , pocan , and pokeweed . The root and berries have emetic and purgative properties, and are used in medicine. The young shoots are sometimes eaten as a substitute for asparagus, and the berries are said to be used in Europe to color wine.
One who pokes.
Confined; cramped.
Of or pertaining to one of the poles of the earth, or of a sphere; situated near, or proceeding from, one of the poles; as, polar regions; polar seas; polar winds.
A native or inhabitant of Poland; a Polander.
One who poles.
Without horns; polled.
A dance of Polish origin, but now common everywhere. It is performed by two persons in common time.
A parrot; -- familiarly so called.
A woman's name; also, a popular name for a parrot.
A game of ball of Eastern origin, resembling hockey, with the players on horseback.
A blow or thump.

A whitish woolly plant ( Teucrium Polium ) of the order Labiatæ , found throughout the Mediterranean region. The name, with sundry prefixes, is sometimes given to other related species of the same genus.
One of the feeding or nutritive zooids of a hydroid or coral.
A fruit composed of several cartilaginous or bony carpels inclosed in an adherent fleshy mass, which is partly receptacle and partly calyx, as an apple, quince, or pear.
A figure supposed to resemble an apple; a roundel, -- always of a green color.
A procession distinguished by ostentation and splendor; a pageant.
A body of water, naturally or artificially confined, and usually of less extent than a lake.
A kind of johnnycake.
Any large ape; especially, the chimpanzee and the orang-outang.

A bridge; -- applied to several parts which connect others, but especially to the pons Varolii , a prominent band of nervous tissue situated on the ventral side of the medulla oblongata and connected at each side with the hemispheres of the cerebellum; the mesocephalon. See Brain .
See Pontee .
A small horse.
Excrement; feces; -- informal baby talk sometimes used as a euphemism.
To round one's lips as if intending to kiss.
A Russian weight, equal to forty Russian pounds or about thirty-six English pounds avoirdupois.
Pshaw! pish! nonsense! -- an expression of scorn, dislike, or contempt.
A small and rather deep collection of (usually) fresh water, as one supplied by a spring, or occurring in the course of a stream; a reservoir for water; as, the pools of Solomon .
A name for several East Indian, or their wood, used for the masts and spars of vessels, as Calophyllum angustifolium , Calophyllum inophullum , and Sterculia fœtida ; -- called also peon .
See 2d Poppy .
Destitute of property; wanting in material riches or goods; needy; indigent.
A small, sharp, quick explosive sound or report; as, to go off with a pop .
Any ecclesiastic, esp. a bishop.

Any plant or species of the genus Papaver , herbs with showy polypetalous flowers and a milky juice. From one species ( Papaver somniferum ) opium is obtained, though all the species contain it to some extent; also, a flower of the plant. See Illust. of Capsule .

A covered and inclosed entrance to a building, whether taken from the interior, and forming a sort of vestibule within the main wall, or projecting without and with a separate roof. Sometimes the porch is large enough to serve as a covered walk. See also Carriage porch , under Carriage , and Loggia .
One of the minute orifices in an animal or vegetable membrane, for transpiration, absorption, etc.
One who pores.
The flesh of swine, fresh or salted, used for food.
A dark red or purple astringent wine made in Portugal. It contains a large percentage of alcohol.
The part of the liver or other organ where its vessels and nerves enter; the hilus.
The Ottoman court; the government of the Turkish empire, officially called the Sublime Porte , from the gate ( port ) of the sultan's palace at which justice was administered.
Porous; as, pory stone . [R.] Dryden.
A cold in the head; catarrh.
Firm; determined; fixed.
One who, or that which, puzzles; a difficult or inexplicable question or fact.
To dispose or set firmly or fixedly; to place or dispose in relation to other objects.
To push; to dash; to throw.
See Posse comitatus .
Hired to do what is wrong; suborned.
A brief poetical sentiment; hence, any brief sentiment, motto, or legend; especially, one inscribed on a ring.
A metallic or earthen vessel, appropriated to any of a great variety of uses, as for boiling meat or vegetables, for holding liquids, for plants, etc.; as, a quart pot ; a flower pot ; a bean pot .
To thrust; to push.
A large South American goatsucker ( Nyctibius grandis ).
A size of paper. See under Paper .
A nocturnal mammal ( Perodictius potto ) of the Lemur family, found in West Africa. It has rudimentary forefingers. Called also aposoro , and bush dog .
A small bag; usually, a leathern bag; as, a pouch for money; a shot pouch ; a mail pouch , etc.
Lit., a puff;
Same as Octopus .
A young chicken, partridge, grouse, or the like.
To strike repeatedly with some heavy instrument; to beat.

To cause to flow in a stream, as a liquid or anything flowing like a liquid, either out of a vessel or into it; as, to pour water from a pail; to pour wine into a decanter; to pour oil upon the waters; to pour out sand or dust.
The young of some birds, as grouse; a young fowl.
A small British lake whitefish ( Coregonus clupeoides , or Coregonus ferus ); -- called also gwyniad and lake herring .
Same as Poor , the fish.
See Poop , v. i.
Strictly, a disease by pustules or eruptions of any kind, but chiefly or wholly restricted to three or four diseases, -- the smallpox, the chicken pox, and the vaccine and the venereal diseases.
A support; -- used in composition; as, tea poy .
See Poind , Poinder .
A South American armadillo ( Dasypus sexcinctus ). Called also sixbanded armadillo .
See 5th Pose .
A flat-bottomed boat or lighter, -- used in Holland and the Baltic, and sometimes armed in case of war.
See Praam .
To adorn in a showy manner; to dress or equip ostentatiously; -- often followed by up ; as, to prank up the body . See Prink .
A variety of cryptocrystalline of a leek-green color.
To talk much and to little purpose; to be loquacious; to speak foolishly; to babble.

Any one of numerous species of large shrimplike Crustacea having slender legs and long antennæ. They mostly belong to the genera Pandalus , Palæmon , Palæmonetes , and Peneus , and are much used as food. The common English prawn is Palæmon serratus .

To make request with earnestness or zeal, as for something desired; to make entreaty or supplication; to offer prayer to a deity or divine being as a religious act; specifically, to address the Supreme Being with adoration, confession, supplication, and thanksgiving.
To prey; to plunder.
Cleared and ready for engagement, as a ship.
A forked tool used by clothiers in dressing cloth.
Press; throng.
An East Indian insectivore ( Tupaia ferruginea ). It is arboreal in its habits, and has a bushy tail. The fur is soft, and varies from rusty red to maroon and to brownish black.
imp. & p. p. of Press .
Anything, as goods, etc., taken or got by violence; anything taken by force from an enemy in war; spoil; booty; plunder.
A corruption of pair royal . See under Pair , n.
A fine, white, somewhat friable clay; also, the ore contained in a mixture of clay and pebbles.

The sum or amount of money at which a thing is valued, or the value which a seller sets on his goods in market; that for which something is bought or sold, or offered for sale; equivalent in money or other means of exchange; current value or rate paid or demanded in market or in barter; cost.
That which pricks, penetrates, or punctures; a sharp and slender thing; a pointed instrument; a goad; a spur, etc.; a point; a skewer.
A small European lamprey ( Petromyzon branchialis ); -- called also prid , and sandpiper .
The plant privet.
imp. & p. p. of Pry .
One who pries; one who inquires narrowly and searches, or is inquisitive.
To haggle about the price of a commodity; to bargain hard.
A nugget of virgin metal.
The privet.
First in order of time; original; primeval; primitive; primary.
First; chief.
To be formal or affected in dress or manners; -- often with up .
Being in its prime.
To dress or adjust one's self for show; to prank.
To fix or impress, as a stamp, mark, character, idea, etc., into or upon something.

any of several types of protein particle lacking nucleic acid, believed to be the cause of certain slow-developing infectious diseases such as scapie in sheep, and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and Kuru in humans.

Preceding in the order of time; former; antecedent; anterior; previous; as, a prior discovery; prior obligation; -- used elliptically in cases like the following: he lived alone [in the time] prior to his marriage.
See Price , and 1st Prize .
An enterprise.
A solid whose bases or ends are any similar, equal, and parallel plane figures, and whose sides are parallelograms.

A partaker; a person having an interest in any action or thing; one who has an interest in an estate created by another; a person having an interest derived from a contract or conveyance to which he is not himself a party. The term, in its proper sense, is distinguished from party .
To move with a lever; to force up or open; to pry.
A Latin preposition signifying for , before , forth .

A sailing canoe of the Ladrone Islands and Malay Archipelago, having its lee side flat and its weather side like that of an ordinary boat. The ends are alike. The canoe is long and narrow, and is kept from overturning by a cigar-shaped log attached to a frame extending several feet to windward. It has been called the flying proa , and is the swiftest sailing craft known.
An instrument for examining the depth or other circumstances of a wound, ulcer, or cavity, or the direction of a sinus, of for exploring for bullets, for stones in the bladder, etc.
To thrust some pointed instrument into; to prick with something sharp; as, to prod a soldier with a bayonet; to prod oxen ; hence, to goad, to incite, to worry; as, to prod a student .
A crossbow. See Prod , 3.
Preface; introduction; preliminary observations; prelude.
To wander about and beg; to seek food or other supplies by low arts; to seek for advantage by mean shift or tricks.
To lop; to trim; to prune; to adorn.
To poke; to thrust.
To search or prowl after; to rob; to plunder.
To jump straight up or almost straight up; -- used of kangaroos and gazelles.
A shell, used as a die. See Props .
A game of chance, in which four sea shells, each called a prop , are used instead of dice.
The prow or fore part of a ship.
The ordinary language of men in speaking or writing; language not cast in poetical measure or rhythm; -- contradistinguished from verse , or metrical composition .
a contracted form of prosit .
Feeling or manifesting pride, in a good or bad sense
To try or to ascertain by an experiment, or by a test or standard; to test; as, to prove the strength of gunpowder or of ordnance; to prove the contents of a vessel by a standard measure.
The fore part of a vessel; the bow; the stem; hence, the vessel itself.
To rove over, through, or about in a stealthy manner; esp., to search in, as for prey or booty.
“The ticket or list of candidates at elections, presented to the people for their votes.”
The agency for another who acts through the agent; authority to act for another, esp. to vote in a legislative or corporate capacity.
Prussian leather.
A woman of affected modesty, reserve, or coyness; one who is overscrupulous or sensitive; one who affects extraordinary prudence in conduct and speech.
To lop or cut off the superfluous parts, branches, or shoots of; to clear of useless material; to shape or smooth by trimming; to trim: as, to prune trees; to prune an essay.
A lever; also, leverage.
See Prian .
A sacred song; a poetical composition for use in the praise or worship of God.
Pish! pooch! -- an exclamation used as an expression of contempt, disdain, dislike, etc.
An internal muscle arising from the lumbar vertebræ and inserted into the femur. In man there are usually two on each side, and the larger one, or great psoas, forms a part of the iliopsoas.
A cutaneous disease; especially, the itch.
A retail business where alcoholic beverages are sold by the drink; a bar; a tavern.
The hair which appears upon the lower part of the hypogastric region at the age of puberty.
Of or pertaining to the pubes; in the region of the pubes; as, the pubic bone; the pubic region, or the lower part of the hypogastric region . See Pubes .
The ventral and anterior of the three principal bones composing either half of the pelvis; sharebone; pubic bone.
Of a dark brown or brownish purple color.
See Pucelle .
A celebrated fairy, “the merry wanderer of the night;” -- called also Robin Goodfellow , Friar Rush , Pug , etc.
Good of its kind; -- variously used as implying substantial, real, fixed, sure, etc., and specif., of buildings, made of brick and mortar.
Same as Pood .
Short and fat or sturdy; dumpy; podgy; as, a short, pudgy little man; a pudgy little hand.
Of or pertaining to the external organs of generation.
A very small deer ( Pudua humilis ), native of the Chilian Andes. It has simple spikelike antlers, only two or three inches long.
To make a low whistling sound; to chirp, as birds.
The dung of dogs, used as an alkaline steep in tanning.
A sudden and single emission of breath from the mouth; hence, any sudden or short blast of wind; a slight gust; a whiff.
Swelled with air, or any soft matter; tumid with a soft substance; bloated; fleshy; as, a puffy tumor .
Tempered clay; clay moistened and worked so as to be plastic.
Pshaw! pish! -- a word used in contempt or disdain.
As much as is taken up between the thumb and two first fingers.
The same as Pugh .
A well; a small stream; a fountain; a spring.
To eject the contests of the stomach; to vomit; to spew.
One who pukes, vomits.
Same as Pucka .
The East Indian leguminous tree Butea frondosa . See Gum Butea , under Gum .
To cry like a chicken.
One who pules; one who whines or complains; a weak person.
A genus of parasitic insects including the fleas. See Flea .
To draw, or attempt to draw, toward one; to draw forcibly.
A moist, slightly cohering mass, consisting of soft, undissolved animal or vegetable matter.
Like pulp; consisting of pulp; soft; fleshy; succulent; as, the pulpy covering of a nut; the pulpy substance of a peach or a cherry.
Leguminous plants, or their seeds, as beans, pease, etc.

A vegetable substance consisting of soft, elastic, yellowish brown chaff, gathered in the Hawaiian Islands from the young fronds of free ferns of the genus Cibotium , chiefly Cibotium Menziesii ; -- used for stuffing mattresses, cushions, etc., and as an absorbent.

A large American carnivore ( Felis concolor ), found from Canada to Patagonia, especially among the mountains. Its color is tawny, or brownish yellow, without spots or stripes. Called also catamount , cougar , American lion , mountain lion , and panther or painter .
A low shoe with a thin sole.
Large and rounded.
A play on words which have the same sound but different meanings; an expression in which two different applications of a word present an odd or ludicrous idea; a kind of quibble or equivocation.
A cold arid table-land, as in the Andes of Peru.

A beverage composed of wine or distilled liquor, water (or milk), sugar, and the juice of lemon, with spice or mint; -- specifically named from the kind of spirit used; as rum punch , claret punch , champagne punch , etc.
A kind of plain sleigh drawn by one horse; originally, a rude oblong box on runners.
A small sloop or shallop, or a large boat with sails.
Wood so decayed as to be dry, crumbly, and useful for tinder; touchwood.
A machine for fanning a room, usually a movable fanlike frame covered with canvas, and suspended from the ceiling. It is kept in motion by pulling a cord.
To play at basset, baccara, faro. or omber; to gamble.
A point or hit.
See Pontee .
Imperfectly developed in size or vigor; small and feeble; inferior; petty.
Same as Poy , n. , 3.
A young dog; a puppy.
Any insect in that stage of its metamorphosis which usually immediately precedes the adult, or imago, stage.
Of or pertaining to a pupa, or the condition of a pupa.
The aperture in the iris; the sight, apple, or black of the eye. See the Note under Eye , and Iris .
The young of a canine animal, esp. of the common dog; a whelp.
To utter a low, murmuring, continued sound, as a cat does when pleased.
Separate from all heterogeneous or extraneous matter; free from mixture or combination; clean; mere; simple; unmixed; as, pure water; pure clay; pure air; pure compassion.
Purified; refined.
To cleanse, clear, or purify by separating and carrying off whatever is impure, heterogeneous, foreign, or superfluous.
See Euxanthin .
A Jewish festival, called also the Feast of Lots, instituted to commemorate the deliverance of the Jews from the machinations of Haman.
To decorate with fringe or embroidery.
To murmur as a cat. See Pur .
The dunlin.

A small bag or pouch, the opening of which is made to draw together closely, used to carry money in; by extension, any receptacle for money carried on the person; a wallet; a pocketbook; a portemonnaie.
Fat and short-breathed; fat, short, and thick; swelled with pampering; as, pursy insolence .
The yellowish white opaque creamy matter produced by the process of suppuration. It consists of innumerable white nucleated cells floating in a clear liquid.
A pustule; a pimple.
Very small; little; petty.
A cat; -- a fondling appellation.
A pet name for a cat; also, an endearing name for a girl.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Put , contracted from putteth .
Rotten; fetid; stinking; base; worthless. Jer . Taylor .
A stroke made on the putting green to play the ball into a hole.

A kind of thick paste or cement compounded of whiting, or soft carbonate of lime, and linseed oil, when applied beaten or kneaded to the consistence of dough, -- used in fastening glass in sashes, stopping crevices, and for similar purposes.

to connect a device to a telephone line surreptitiously, so as to listen to or record the conversations of persons on the telephone without their knowledge; -- of telephones, persons, or locations. Used as police jargon.
A fool; a jerk.
See 2d Pie (b) .
A magpie; a piet.
Situated in the region of the rump, or posterior end of the backbone; -- applied especially to the posterior median plates in the carapace of chelonians.
Of or pertaining to a pygmy; resembling a pygmy or dwarf; dwarfish; very small.
An albuminoid constituent of pus, related to mucin, possibly a mixture of substances rather than a single body.
An ancient English fishing boat.
The passage between the iter and optocœle in the brain.
A low tower, having a truncated pyramidal form, and flanking an ancient Egyptian gateway.
Of or pertaining to pus; of the nature of, or like, pus.
The magpie. See Piet .
Of or pertaining to a pyre.
A funeral pile; a combustible heap on which the dead are burned; hence, any pile to be burnt.
Abbreviation of pyrogallic acid .
A genus of rosaceous trees and shrubs having pomes for fruit. It includes the apple, crab apple, pear, chokeberry, sorb, and mountain ash.
The box, case, vase, or tabernacle, in which the host is reserved.
Same as Pixy .
A box; a pyx.
Quality control.
Quantum chromodynamics.
Quantum electrodynamics.
In so far as; in the capacity or character of; as.
An unfledged bird; hence, something immature or unfinished.
The cry of the duck, or a sound in imitation of it; a hoarse, quacking noise.
Evil; bad; baffling; as, a quade wind .
To drink with relish; to drink copiously of; to swallow in large draughts.
A quagmire.
To die; to perish; hence, to wither; to fade.
A quire; a book.
To be agitated with quick, short motions continually repeated; to shake with fear, cold, etc.; to shudder; to tremble.
Shaky, or tremulous; quaking.
Sickness; disease; pestilence; death.
A punting pole with a broad flange near the end to prevent it from sinking into the mud; a setting pole.
A medusa, or jellyfish.
The fourth part; a quarter; hence, a region of the earth.
A kind of beer. Same as Quass .
Same as Squash .

As if; as though; as it were; in a manner sense or degree; having some resemblance to; qualified; -- used as an adjective, or a prefix with a noun or an adjective; as, a quasi contract, an implied contract, an obligation which has arisen from some act, as if from a contract; a quasi corporation, a body that has some, but not all, of the peculiar attributes of a corporation; a quasi argument, that which resembles, or is used as, an argument; quasi historical, apparently historical, seeming to be historical .
A thin, sour beer, made by pouring warm water on rye or barley meal and letting it ferment, -- much used by the Russians. Called also kvass .
To satiate; to satisfy.
The coaita.
See Quaver .
A mole, bank, or wharf, formed toward the sea, or at the side of a harbor, river, or other navigable water, for convenience in loading and unloading vessels.
p. p. of Quail .

A measure of information, being the information that can be stored in one object that can take a quantum state of 0 or 1. It differs from the classical bit of information theory in that quantum states may assume many intermediate states that are superpositions of the individual discrete states; the quantum states of multiple quantum systems may also be correlated by a phenomenon called entanglement , increasing the complexity of the information storage and retrieval process. See 4th bit , n.
A half farthing.
A woman; a young or unmarried woman; a girl.
A word occurring in a corrupt passage of Bacon's Essays, and probably meaning, to stir, to move.
The wife of a king.
At variance with what is usual or normal; differing in some odd way from what is ordinary; odd; singular; strange; whimsical; as, a queer story or act .
A drinking vessel. See Quaich .
To take the life of; to kill.
To twirl; to turn or wind round; to coil; as, to querl a cord, thread, or rope .
A mill for grinding grain, the upper stone of which was turned by hand; -- used before the invention of windmills and watermills.
A question; an inquiry to be answered or solved.
The act of seeking, or looking after anything; attempt to find or obtain; search; pursuit; as, to rove in quest of game, of a lost child, of property, etc.
The common guillemot.
A tail-like appendage of hair; a pigtail.
A quip; a gibe.
A small South American opossum ( Didelphys quica ), native of Guiana and Brazil. It feeds upon insects, small birds, and fruit.
See Queest .
Alive; living; animate; -- opposed to dead or inanimate .
A portion suitable to be chewed; a cud; as, a quid of tobacco .
In a state of rest or calm; without stir, motion, or agitation; still; as, a quiet sea; quiet air.
One of the large feathers of a bird's wing, or one of the rectrices of the tail; also, the stock of such a feather.

Anything that is quilted; esp., a quilted bed cover, or a skirt worn by women; any cover or garment made by putting wool, cotton, etc., between two cloths and stitching them together; also, any outer bed cover.
A European scallop ( Pecten opercularis ), used as food.
A set or sequence of five, as in piquet.
A smart, sarcastic turn or jest; a taunt; a severe retort; a gibe.
Same as Quipu .

A contrivance employed by the ancient Peruvians, Mexicans, etc., as a substitute for writing and figures, consisting of a main cord, from which hung at certain distances smaller cords of various colors, each having a special meaning, as silver, gold, corn, soldiers. etc. Single, double, and triple knots were tied in the smaller cords, representing definite numbers. It was chiefly used for arithmetical purposes, and to register important facts and events.
See Choir .
A sudden turn; a starting from the point or line; hence, an artful evasion or subterfuge; a shift; a quibble; as, the quirks of a pettifogger .
See Querl .
A rawhide whip plaited with two thongs of buffalo hide.
See Cuish .
Any one of numerous species of small passerine birds native of tropical America. See Banana quit , under Banana , and Guitguit .
See the Note under Quit , a.
A riddle or obscure question; an enigma; a ridiculous hoax.
To throb; to quiver.
A quadrangle or court, as of a prison; hence, a prison.
Originally, a solid exterior angle, as of a building; now, commonly, one of the selected pieces of material by which the corner is marked.
A flattened ring-shaped piece of iron, to be pitched at a fixed object in play; hence, any heavy flat missile used for the same purpose, as a stone, piece of iron, etc.
imp. of Quake .
A marsupial of Australia ( Dasyurus macrurus ), about the size of a cat.
imp. of Quake .
A proportional part or share; the share or proportion assigned to each in a division.
To cite, as a passage from some author; to name, repeat, or adduce, as a passage from an author or speaker, by way of authority or illustration; as, to quote a passage from Homer .
Said; spoke; uttered; -- used only in the first and third persons in the past tenses, and always followed by its nominative, the word or words said being the object; as, quoth I , quoth he .
See Koran .
A roe; a deer.
The electric catfish.
A rod or stick used by masons in mixing hair with mortar.
A polishing material made of potter's clay that has failed in baking.
Master; lord; teacher; -- a Jewish title of respect or honor for a teacher or doctor of the law.
Furious; raging; extremely violent.
A rubber of hard wood used in smoothing marble to be polished.
A term of reproach used by the Jews of our Savior's time, meaning “worthless.”
A progress; a course; a movement or progression.
One who, or that which, races, or contends in a race; esp., a race horse.
A dog that pursued his prey by scent, as distinguished from the greyhound.
Same as Arrack .
See Rakel .
Having a strong flavor indicating origin; of distinct characteristic taste; tasting of the soil; hence, fresh; rich.
A unit of measurement of the amount of ionizing radiation absorbed by an object, equal to an energy of 100 ergs per gram of irradiated material (equal to 0.01 gray).

An electronic device designed to detect objects at a distance, and determine their distance from the device, by transmitting a pulse of radio waves and measuring the time required for the echo of the pulse to return to the emitting device; as, the radar showed a plane approaching rapidly . For more information of radar, see the article What is Radar? .
imp. of Read , Rede .
pl. of Radius .
A primitive word, from which spring other words; a radical; a root; an etymon.

An intensely radioactive gaseous element produced by the radioactive decay of radium-226, which is the main isotope of radium found in pitchblende. Chemically it is an inert noble gas. Its atomic symbol is Rn . It has an atomic number of 86. The radon isotope produced by decay of radium has an atomic weight of 222.017, and this isotope decays by alpha emission with a half-life of 3.82 days. Numerous other isotopes have been observed, all radioactive and all having half-lives shorter than that of radon-222. Radon was discovered by M. and Mme. Curie, of Paris, in their studies of the radioactive substances in pitchblende. Radon was originally called radium emanation or exradio .
To sweep, snatch, draw, or huddle together; to take by a promiscuous sweep.
imp. & p. p. of Reave .
imp. of Reave .
Damp; musty.
To scold or rail at; to rate; to tease; to torment; to banter.
Violent excitement; eager passion; extreme vehemence of desire, emotion, or suffering, mastering the will.
A genus of rays which includes the skates. See Skate .
The order of elasmobranch fishes which includes the sawfishes, skates, and rays; -- called also Rajae , and Rajii .
A hostile or predatory incursion; an inroad or incursion of mounted men; a sudden and rapid invasion by a cavalry force; a foray.
An outer cloak or covering; a neckerchief for women.
Water falling in drops from the clouds; the descent of water from the clouds in drops.
Abounding with rain; wet; showery; as, rainy weather; a rainy day or season .
A rope; also, a measure equal to a rod.
Same as 2d Reis .
Reign; rule.
Same as Rajah .
A native prince or king; also, a landholder or person of importance in the agricultural districts.

An implement consisting of a headpiece having teeth, and a long handle at right angles to it, -- used for collecting hay, or other light things which are spread over a large surface, or for breaking and smoothing the earth.
Hasty; reckless; rash.
One who, or that which, rakes
A kind of ardent spirits used in southern Europe and the East, distilled from grape juice, grain, etc.
To collect, and reduce to order, as troops dispersed or thrown into confusion; to gather again; to reunite.
A name sometimes given to the raven.
The male of the sheep and allied animals. In some parts of England a ram is called a tup .
Of or pertaining to a ramus, or branch; rameal.
Having the frames, stem, and sternpost adjusted; -- said of a ship on the stocks.
See Ramie .
The grasscloth plant ( Bœhmeria nivea ); also, its fiber, which is very fine and exceedingly strong; -- called also China grass , and rhea . See Grass-cloth plant , under Grass .
Like a ram; rammish.
A leap; a spring; a hostile advance.
The cuckoopint.
A branch; a projecting part or prominent process; a ramification.
imp. of Run .
A genus of anurous batrachians, including the common frogs.
Having a general affinity to ranunculaceous plants.
A prop or shore.
To wrench; to tear; to sprain; to injure by violent straining or contortion.
A border; edge; margin.
research and development; -- used mostly to refer to the division of a corporation responsible for performing research and developing new products; -- a commonly used abbreviation.
Same as Rani .
imp. of Ring , v. t. & i.
To set in a row, or in rows; to place in a regular line or lines, or in ranks; to dispose in the proper order; to rank; as, to range soldiers in line .
Inclined or able to range, or rove about, for considerable distances; apt or suited for much roving, -- chiefly used of cattle.
A queen or princess; the wife of a rajah.
Luxuriant in growth; of vigorous growth; exuberant; grown to immoderate height; as, rank grass; rank weeds.
The erd shrew.
To rave in violent, high-sounding, or extravagant language, without dignity of thought; to be noisy, boisterous, and bombastic in talk or declamation; as, a ranting preacher .
Wild; noisy; boisterous.
A lay or skein containing 120 yards of yarn.
Fruit, as grapes, plucked from the cluster.
A line, ridge, furrow, or band of fibers, especially in the median line; as, the raphe of the tongue .

The part of a river where the current moves with great swiftness, but without actual waterfall or cascade; sometimes called whitewater ; -- usually used in the plural; as, the Lachine rapids in the St. Lawrence . For boaters on the river, it is a place that can be hazardous, with danger of capsizing or crashing into large rocks.
imp. & p. p. of Rap , to snatch away.
Nearly raw; partially cooked; not thoroughly cooked; underdone; as, rare beef or mutton .
See 2d Reis .
To rub along the surface of; to graze.
To pull off or pluck violently.
Like a rasp, or the sound made by a rasp; grating.

A carnivore ( Viverricula Mallaccensis ) allied to the civet but smaller, native of China and the East Indies. It furnishes a perfume resembling that of the civet, which is highly prized by the Javanese. Called also Malacca weasel , and lesser civet .

One of several species of small rodents of the genus Rattus (formerly included in Mus ) and allied genera, of the family Muridae , distinguished from mice primarily by being larger. They infest houses, stores, and ships, especially the Norway rat , also called brown rat , ( Rattus norvegicus formerly Mus decumanus ), the black rat ( Rattus rattus formerly Mus rattus ), and the roof rat (formerly Mus Alexandrinus , now included in Rattus rattus ). These were introduced into America from the Old World. The white rat used most commonly in laboratories is primarily a strain derived from Rattus rattus .
A New Zealand forest tree ( Metrosideros robusta ), also, its hard dark red wood, used by the Maoris for paddles and war clubs.
See Rattan .
Same as Rotche .
To chide with vehemence; to scold; to censure violently; to berate.
Any carnivore of the genus Mellivora , allied to the weasels and the skunks; -- called also honey badger .
One who rates or estimates.
A hill or mound.

The relation which one quantity or magnitude has to another of the same kind. It is expressed by the quotient of the division of the first by the second; thus, the ratio of 3 to 6 is expressed by 3/6 or 1/2 ; of a to b by a/b ; or (less commonly) the second term is made the dividend; as, a:b = b/a .
A small rat.
imp. of Rive .
To separate or undo the texture of; to unravel; to take apart; to untwist; to unweave or unknit; -- often followed by out ; as, to ravel a twist; to ravel out a stocking.

A large black passerine bird ( Corvus corax ), similar to the crow, but larger, and has a harsh, loud call. It is native of the northern parts of Europe, Asia and America, and is noted for its sagacity.
One who raves.
Food obtained by violence; plunder; prey; raven.
Not altered from its natural state; not prepared by the action of heat; as, raw sienna ;
In a raw manner; unskillfully; without experience.
Array; order; arrangement; dress.
A person not a Mohammedan, who pays the capitation tax.
A synthetic fiber, made of thin filaments of regenerated cellulose, extruded from a solution of viscose . Called also viscose fiber and viscose rayon fiber .
A Shakespearean word (used once) supposed to mean the same as race , a root.
Slashed or striped in patterns.
An armed ship having her upper deck cut away, and thus reduced to the next inferior rate, as a seventy-four cut down to a frigate.
A keen-edged knife of peculiar shape, used in shaving the hair from the face or the head; also called a straight razor .
coming next after the twenty-second in a series
A syllable applied in solmization to the second tone of the diatonic scale of C; in the American system, to the second tone of any diatonic scale.
An effort to vomit.
To act or perform a second time; to do over again; to reenact; as, to react a play; the same scenes were reacted at Rome.
Rennet. See 3d Reed .

Prepared for what one is about to do or experience; equipped or supplied with what is needed for some act or event; prepared for immediate movement or action; as, the troops are ready to march; ready for the journey.
A former small Spanish silver coin; also, a denomination of money of account, formerly the unit of the Spanish monetary system.
A royal jurisdiction or domain; a region which is under the dominion of a king; a kingdom.
Cream; also, the cream or froth on ale.
To cut with a sickle, scythe, or reaping machine, as grain; to gather, as a harvest, by cutting.
Early; soon.
To take away by violence or by stealth; to snatch away; to rob; to despoil; to bereave. [Archaic] .
An instrument formerly used which somewhat resembled the violin, having three strings, and being played with a bow.
Pertaining to rebels or rebellion; acting in revolt; rebellious; as, rebel troops .

A mode of expressing words and phrases by pictures of objects whose names resemble those words, or the syllables of which they are composed; enigmatical representation of words by figures; hence, a peculiar form of riddle made up of such representations.
To retire; to recoil.
To make account of; to care for; to heed; to regard.
A writ of right.
To come back; to return again or repeatedly; to come again to mind.
imp. & p. p. of Read .
A work having two parapets whose faces unite so as to form a salient angle toward the enemy.
obs. imp. of Read , or Rede .
To advise or counsel.

A kind of larva, or nurse, which is prroduced within the sporocyst of certain trematodes by asexual generation. It in turn produces, in the same way, either another generation of rediae, or else cercariae within its own body. Called also proscolex , and nurse . See Illustration in Appendix.
A reserve force in the Turkish army, or a soldier of the reserve. See Army organization , above.
In a red manner; with redness.
To refit; to repair, or make reparation for; hence, to repay or requite.
To riddle; to sift; to separate or throw off.
Same as Rede .
Abounding with reeds; covered with reeds.
A chain or range of rocks lying at or near the surface of the water. See Coral reefs , under Coral .
Full of reefs or rocks.
Vapor; steam; smoke; fume.
Soiled with smoke or steam; smoky; foul.
A lively dance of the Highlanders of Scotland; also, the music to the dance; -- often called Scotch reel .
The Hebrew name of a horned wild animal, probably the Urus.
The female of the ruff.
To go over again; to repeat.
To refute; to disprove; as, to refel the tricks of a sophister .
To carry or send back.
To fit or prepare for use again; to repair; to restore after damage or decay; as, to refit a garment; to refit ships of war.
To fix again or anew; to establish anew.
A chink; a rift. See Rift .
Of or pertaining to a king; kingly; royal; as, regal authority, pomp, or sway .
See Rigel .
To get again.
To rule; to govern.
A kind of dry fruit, consisting of three or more cells, each which at length breaks open at the inner angle.
See Reign .
A portuguese money of account, in value about one tenth of a cent.
Robbery; spoil.
Royal authority; supreme power; sovereignty; rule; dominion.
A strip of oxhide, deprived of hair, and rendered pliable, -- used for twisting into ropes, etc.
The strap of a bridle, fastened to the curb or snaffle on each side, by which the rider or driver governs the horse.
The kidneys; also, the region of the kidneys; the loins.
The word is used as a Portuguese designation of money of account, one hundred reis being about equal in value to eleven cents.
Sedge; seaweed.
To make lax or loose; to make less close, firm, rigid, tense, or the like; to slacken; to loosen; to open; as, to relax a rope or cord; to relax the muscles or sinews.
To lay again; to lay a second time; as, to relay a pavement .
That which remains; that which is left after loss or decay; a remaining portion; a remnant.

To rest with confidence, as when fully satisfied of the veracity, integrity, or ability of persons, or of the certainty of facts or of evidence; to have confidence; to trust; to depend; -- with on , formerly also with in .
To send back; to give up; to surrender; to resign.
To mix again or repeatedly.
See Renne .
Of or pertaining to the kidneys; in the region of the kidneys.
To deny; to disown.
To separate into parts with force or sudden violence; to tear asunder; to split; to burst; as, powder rends a rock in blasting; lightning rends an oak.
To make new again; to restore to freshness, perfection, or vigor; to give new life to; to rejuvenate; to reëstablish; to recreate; to rebuild.
A rank; a row.
To plunder; -- only in the phrase “to rape and renne .” See under Rap , v. t. , to snatch.
imp. & p. p. of Rend .
In France, interest payable by government on indebtedness; the bonds, shares, stocks, etc., which represent government indebtedness.
A fabric made of silk or wool, or of silk and wool, and having a transversely corded or ribbed surface.
To pay back; to refund; as, to repay money borrowed or advanced .
To drive back; to force to return; to check the advance of; to repulse as, to repel an enemy or an assailant.
To make a return in words or writing; to respond; to answer.
To broadcast again, as of a film; as, they reran the episode for the tenth time .
A thing; the particular thing; a matter; a point.
To saw again; specifically, to saw a balk, or a timber, which has already been squared, into dimension lumber, as joists, boards, etc.
To shake; to quake; to tremble.
The act of resetting.

Any one of a class of yellowish brown solid inflammable substances, of vegetable origin, which are nonconductors of electricity, have a vitreous fracture, and are soluble in ether, alcohol, and essential oils, but not in water; specif., pine resin (see Rosin ).
To sow again.
A state of quiet or repose; a cessation from motion or labor; tranquillity; as, rest from mental exertion; rest of body or mind .
Disposed to rest; indisposed toexercton; sluggish; also, restive.
To prepare for use, as flax, by separating the fibers from the woody part by process of soaking, macerating, and other treatment.
To make an effort to vomit; to strain, as in vomiting.
A net or network; a plexus; particularly, a network of blood vessels or nerves, or a part resembling a network.
To annual, as orders.
To try (esp. judicially) a second time; as, to retry a case; to retry an accused person.
An officer, steward, or governor.
See Reveal .
To face, as an embankment, with masonry, wood, or other material.
To vie with, or rival, in return.
To win again, or win back.
Rain or rein.
To go on a military expedition.
The ramie or grass-cloth plant. See Grass-cloth plant , under Grass .
A suborder of struthious birds including the rheas.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid (commonly called chrysophanic acid) found in rhubarb ( Rheum ).
Chrysophanic acid.
A genus of plants. See Rhubarb .
See Rhyme .
A water course; a ditch.
Gold and silver, or money.
See 1st Rob .

An equilateral parallelogram, or quadrilateral figure whose sides are equal and the opposite sides parallel. The angles may be unequal, two being obtuse and two acute, as in the cut, or the angles may be equal, in which case it is usually called a square .
A line which crosses successive meridians at a constant angle; -- called also rhumb line , and loxodromic curve . See Loxodromic .
A genus of shrubs and small treets. See Sumac .
An expression of thought in numbers, measure, or verse; a composition in verse; a rhymed tale; poetry; harmony of language.
A Spanish coin. See Real .
Laughing; laughable; exciting gayety; gay; merry; delightful to the view, as a landscape.
One of the curved bones attached to the vertebral column and supporting the lateral walls of the thorax.
See Ribbon .
A genus of shrubs including gooseberries and currants of many kinds.

A well-known cereal grass ( Oryza sativa ) and its seed. This plant is extensively cultivated in warm climates, and the grain forms a large portion of the food of the inhabitants. In America it grows chiefly on low, moist land, which can be overflowed.
Having an abundance of material possessions; possessed of a large amount of property; well supplied with land, goods, or money; wealthy; opulent; affluent; -- opposed to poor .
A stack or pile, as of grain, straw, or hay, in the open air, usually protected from wet with thatching.
imp. & p. p. of Ride , v. i.
To be carried on the back of an animal, as a horse.
imp. pl. & p. p. of Ride .
One who, or that which, rides.
The back, or top of the back; a crest.
Having a ridge or ridges; rising in a ridge.
Prevailing; prevalent; abounding.
To seize and bear away by force; to snatch away; to carry off.
p. p. of Rive .
To furnish with apparatus or gear; to fit with tackling.
A fixed star of the first magnitude in the left foot of the constellation Orion.
Straight; direct; not crooked; as, a right line .
Firm; stiff; unyielding; not pliant; not flexible.
A circle; hence, a diadem.
Rigidity; stiffness.
To render turbid or muddy; to stir up; to roil.
A very small brook; a streamlet.
One of certain narrow, crooked valleys seen, by aid of the telescope, on the surface of the moon.
The border, edge, or margin of a thing, usually of something circular or curving; as, the rim of a kettle or basin .
A narrow and elongated aperture; a cleft; a fissure.
A rent or long aperture; a chink; a fissure; a crack.
A rhymer; a versifier.
To compose in rhyme; to versify.
Abounding with rime; frosty.
The external covering or coat, as of flesh, fruit, trees, etc.; skin; hide; bark; peel; shell.
Having a rind or skin.
Having a rind
To cause to sound, especially by striking, as a metallic body; as, to ring a bell .
The smooth and level extent of ice marked off for the game of curling.
To wash lightly; to cleanse with a second or repeated application of water after washing.
Wanton or unrestrained behavior; uproar; tumult.
A wicker fish basket.
The bank of a river.
To grow ripe; to become mature, as grain, fruit, flowers, and the like; as, grapes ripen in the sun .
A bough or branch; a twig.

To move from a lower position to a higher; to ascend; to mount up. Specifically: -- (a) To go upward by walking, climbing, flying, or any other voluntary motion; as, a bird rises in the air; a fish rises to the bait .
p. p. & a. from Rise .
One who rises; as, an early riser .
A rush (the plant).
Hazard; danger; peril; exposure to loss, injury, or destruction.
Attended with risk or danger; hazardous.
imp. of Rise .
3d pers. sing. pres. of Rise , contracted from riseth .
3d pers. sing. pres. of Ride , contracted from rideth .

The act of performing divine or solemn service, as established by law, precept, or custom; a formal act of religion or other solemn duty; a solemn observance; a ceremony; as, the rites of freemasonry .
A person having a common right or privilege with another; a partner.
To rend asunder by force; to split; to cleave; as, to rive timber for rails or shingles .
To contract into wrinkles; to shrivel; to shrink; as, riveled fruit; riveled flowers .
p. p. & a. from Rive .
One who rives or splits.

A metallic pin with a head, used for uniting two plates or pieces of material together, by passing it through them and then beating or pressing down the point so that it shall spread out and form a second head; a pin or bolt headed or clinched at both ends.
the symbol for the chemical element radon .
A cockroach.
A journey, or stage of a journey.
To go from place to place without any certain purpose or direction; to rove; to wander.
Having a bay, chestnut, brown, or black color, with gray or white thickly interspersed; -- said of a horse.
To cry with a full, loud, continued sound.
To cook by exposure to radiant heat before a fire; as, to roast meat on a spit, or in an oven open toward the fire and having reflecting surfaces within ; also, to cook in a close oven.
The inspissated juice of ripe fruit, obtained by evaporation of the juice over a fire till it acquires the consistence of a sirup. It is sometimes mixed with honey or sugar.
An outer garment; a dress of a rich, flowing, and elegant style or make; hence, a dress of state, rank, office, or the like.
A small European singing bird ( Erythacus rubecula ), having a reddish breast; -- called also robin redbreast , robinet , and ruddock .
The California white oak ( Quercus lobata ).
A monstrous bird of Arabian mythology.
A distaff used in spinning; the staff or frame about which flax is arranged, and from which the thread is drawn in spinning.
Full of, or abounding in, rocks; consisting of rocks; as, a rocky mountain; a rocky shore .
The orange-colored pulp covering the seeds of the tropical plant Bixa Orellana , from which annotto is prepared. See Annoto .
A straight and slender stick; a wand; hence, any slender bar, as of wood or metal (applied to various purposes).
Full of rods or twigs.
Redness; complexion.
A round-up. See Round-up .
The gadwall.
A roebuck. See Roebuck .
Filled with roe.
A black flag with white skull and crossbones, formerly used by pirates; -- called also Jolly Roger and pirate flag .
A vagrant; an idle, sturdy beggar; a vagabond; a tramp.
An inspissated juice. See Rob .
To render turbid by stirring up the dregs or sediment of; as, to roil wine, cider, etc. , in casks or bottles; to roil a spring.
Turbid; as, roily water .
See Royne .
See Aroint .
See Roister .
Mist; smoke; damp
Misty; foggy; cloudy.
A part, or character, performed by an actor in a drama; hence, a part of function taken or assumed by any one; as, he has now taken the role of philanthropist .
To cause to revolve by turning over and over; to move by turning on an axis; to impel forward by causing to turn over and over on a supporting surface; as, to roll a wheel, a ball, or a barrel .
Of or pertaining to Rome, or the Roman people; like or characteristic of Rome, the Roman people, or things done by Romans; as, Roman fortitude; a Roman aqueduct; Roman art .

A method of notation for all spoken sounds, proposed by Mr. Sweet; -- so called because it is based on the common Roman -letter alphabet. It is like the palaeotype of Mr. Ellis in the general plan, but simpler.
To play rudely and boisterously; to leap and frisk about in play.
Broken, as an ordinary; cut off, or broken at the top, as a chevron, a bend, or the like.
See Croaker , n. , 2. (a) .
A kind of script in which the heavy strokes are nearly upright, giving the characters when taken together a round look.
A composition, vocal or instrumental, commonly of a lively, cheerful character, in which the first strain recurs after each of the other strains.
imp. & p. p. of Ring .
In Japan, under the feudal system, a samurai who had renounced his clan or who had been discharged or ostracized and had become a wanderer without a lord; an outcast; an outlaw.
obs. imp. pl.
A representation in sculpture or in painting of the cross with Christ hanging on it.
Rank in growth.

The cover of any building, including the roofing (see Roofing ) and all the materials and construction necessary to carry and maintain the same upon the walls or other uprights. In the case of a building with vaulted ceilings protected by an outer roof, some writers call the vault the roof , and the outer protection the roof mask . It is better, however, to consider the vault as the ceiling only, in cases where it has farther covering.
Having roofs.
Mist; fog. See Roke .
Misty; gloomy.
Unobstructed spase; space which may be occupied by or devoted to any object; compass; extent of place, great or small; as, there is not room for a house; the table takes up too much room .
Having ample room; spacious; large; as, a roomy mansion; a roomy deck.
Vermilion red; red.
See Roust , v. t.
To turn up the earth with the snout, as swine.
Full of roots; as, rooty ground .
A large, stout cord, usually one not less than an inch in circumference, made of strands twisted or braided together. It differs from cord , line , and string , only in its size. See Cordage .
A maker of ropes.
capable of being drawn into a thread, as a glutinous substance; stringy; viscous; tenacious; glutinous; as ropy sirup; ropy lees .

A form of croquet modified for greater accuracy of play. The court has a wood border often faced with rubber, used as a cushion in bank shots. The balls are 3 1/4 in. in diameter, the cage (center arches or wickets) 3 3/8 in. wide, the other arches 3 1/2 in. wide.
Of or pertaining to dew; consisting of dew; dewy.
Of or pertaining to dew; resembling dew; dewy.
Dewy; bedewed.
imp. of Rise .
Consisting of roses; rosy.
A rosier; a rosebush.
A red color used by painters.
The hard, amber-colored resin left after distilling off the volatile oil of turpentine; colophony.
The rough, scaly matter on the surface of the bark of trees.
See Roust .
Resembling a rose in color, form, or qualities; blooming; red; blushing; also, adorned with roses.

To undergo a process common to organic substances by which they lose the cohesion of their parts and pass through certain chemical changes, giving off usually in some stages of the process more or less offensive odors; to become decomposed by a natural process; to putrefy; to decay.
An ecclesiastical court of Rome, called also Rota Romana , that takes cognizance of suits by appeal. It consists of twelve members.
Relating to wheels or to rotary motion; rotary.
A kind of guitar, the notes of which were produced by a small wheel or wheel-like arrangement; an instrument similar to the hurdy-gurdy.
The rotating part of a generator or motor. Contrasted with stator , the stationary part.
To make rotten.
A small wheel formerly fixed to the pan of firelocks for discharging them.
A red amorphous powder consisting of ferric oxide. It is used in polishing glass, metal, or gems, and as a cosmetic, etc. Called also crocus , jeweler's rouge , etc.
Having inequalities, small ridges, or points, on the surface; not smooth or plain; as, a rough board; a rough stone; rough cloth .
See 5th Ruck , and Roke .
To whisper.
To whisper.
To cry or shout; hence, to sell by auction.
To pull or haul strongly and all together, as upon a rope, without the assistance of mechanical appliances.
To rouse; to disturb; as, to roust one out .
To roar; to bellow; to snort; to snore loudly.
The course or way which is traveled or passed, or is to be passed; a passing; a course; a road or path; a march.
A thickening, made of flour, for soups and gravies.
To draw through an eye or aperture.
One who practices robbery on the seas; a pirate.
Rough; stern; angry.
Rowan tree.
One who engages in rows, or noisy quarrels; a ruffianly fellow.
Formed into a row, or rows; having a row, or rows; as, a twelve- rowed ear of corn .
The little wheel of a spur, with sharp points.
A stubble field left unplowed till late in the autumn, that it may be cropped by cattle.
One who rows with an oar.
Kingly; pertaining to the crown or the sovereign; suitable for a king or queen; regal; as, royal power or prerogative; royal domains; the royal family; royal state .
To bite; to gnaw.

To subject (a body) to the action of something moving over its surface with pressure and friction, especially to the action of something moving back and forth; as, to rub the flesh with the hand; to rub wood with sandpaper .

The unit of monetary value in Russia. It is divided into 100 copecks, and in the gold coin of the realm (as in the five and ten ruble pieces) is worth about 77 cents. The silver ruble is a coin worth about 60 cents.
A genus of rosaceous plants, including the raspberry and blackberry.
A precious stone of a carmine red color, sometimes verging to violet, or intermediate between carmine and hyacinth red. It is a red crystallized variety of corundum.
A plaited, quilled, or goffered strip of lace, net, ribbon, or other material, -- used in place of collars or cuffs, and as a trimming for women's dresses and bonnets.
To draw into wrinkles or unsightly folds; to crease; as, to ruck up a carpet .
Redness; blush.

A fresh-water European fish of the Carp family ( Leuciscus erythrophthalmus ). It is about the size and shape of the roach, but it has the dorsal fin farther back, a stouter body, and red irises. Called also redeye , roud , finscale , and shallow . A blue variety is called azurine , or blue roach .
Of a red color; red, or reddish; as, a ruddy sky; a ruddy flame .
Characterized by roughness; umpolished; raw; lacking delicacy or refinement; coarse.
A perennial suffrutescent plant ( Ruta graveolens ), having a strong, heavy odor and a bitter taste; herb of grace. It is used in medicine.
A game similar to whist, and the predecessor of it.
