A phenol derivative of anthracene obtained as a white crystalline substance, which on oxidation produces a red dyestuff related to anthraquinone.
Eructation; belching.
A kind of coarse, heavy frieze, formerly used for garments.
A wrinkle; a fold; as, the rugae of the stomach .
Rugged; rough.
A nappy cloth.
The act of falling or tumbling down; fall.

That which is prescribed or laid down as a guide for conduct or action; a governing direction for a specific purpose; an authoritative enactment; a regulation; a prescription; a precept; as, the rules of various societies; the rules governing a school; a rule of etiquette or propriety; the rules of cricket .
One who rules; one who exercises sway or authority; a governor.
Orderly; easily restrained; -- opposed to unruly .

A kind of intoxicating liquor distilled from cane juice, or from the scummings of the boiled juice, or from treacle or molasses, or from the lees of former distillations. Also, sometimes used colloquially as a generic or a collective name for intoxicating liquor.
The first stomach of ruminants; the paunch; the fardingbag. See Illust. below.
Of or pertaining to rum; characteristic of rum; as a rummy flavor.
A flying or popular report; the common talk; hence, public fame; notoriety.
The end of the backbone of an animal, with the parts adjacent; the buttock or buttocks.

To move, proceed, advance, pass, go, come, etc., swiftly, smoothly, or with quick action; -- said of things animate or inanimate. Hence, to flow, glide, or roll onward, as a stream, a snake, a wagon, etc.; to move by quicker action than in walking, as a person, a horse, a dog.
The wild radish.
A letter, or character, belonging to the written language of the ancient Norsemen, or Scandinavians; in a wider sense, applied to the letters of the ancient nations of Northern Europe in general.
A bard, or learned man, among the ancient Goths.
imp. & p. p. of Ring .
Of or pertaining to a rune, to runes, or to the Norsemen; as, runic verses; runic letters; runic names; runic rhyme .
Any animal which is unusually small, as compared with others of its kind; -- applied particularly to domestic animals.
Like a runt; diminutive; mean.
A silver coin, and money of account, in the East Indies.
An eruption upon the skin, consisting of vesicles with inflamed base and filled with serous, purulent, or bloody fluid, which dries up, forming a blackish crust.
Of or pertaining to the country, as distinguished from a city or town; living in the country; suitable for, or resembling, the country; rustic; as, rural scenes; a rural prospect .
An artifice; trick; stratagem; wile; fraud; deceit.
A name given to many aquatic or marsh-growing endogenous plants with soft, slender stems, as the species of Juncus and Scirpus .
Abounding with rushes.
A kind of light, soft bread made with yeast and eggs, often toasted or crisped in an oven; or, a kind of sweetened biscuit.
A depilatory made of orpiment and quicklime, and used by the Turks. See Rhusma .
A Russian, or the Russians.
The reddish yellow coating formed on iron when exposed to moist air, consisting of ferric oxide or hydroxide; hence, by extension, any metallic film of corrosion.
Covered or affected with rust; as, a rusty knife or sword; rusty wheat .
Sexual desire or oestrus of deer, cattle, and various other mammals; heat; also, the period during which the oestrus exists.
Sorrow for the misery of another; pity; tenderness.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, rue ( Ruta ); as, rutic acid, now commonly called capric acid .

A glucoside resembling, but distinct from, quercitrin. Rutin is found in the leaves of the rue ( Ruta graveolens ) and other plants, and obtained as a bitter yellow crystalline substance which yields quercitin on decomposition.
Ruttish; rutting; lustful.
See Rial , an old English coin.
A clause added to a document; a rider. See Rider .
A grain yielded by a hardy cereal grass ( Secale cereale ), closely allied to wheat; also, the plant itself. Rye constitutes a large portion of the breadstuff used by man.
A piece of iron crossing the hole in the upper millstone by which the stone is supported on the spindle.
A peasant or cultivator of the soil.
Rush, a plant.
Same as Bushmen .
A genus of palm trees including the palmetto of the Southern United States.
A sword with a broad and heavy blade, thick at the back, and usually more or less curved like a scimiter; a cavalry sword.
A carnivorous animal of the Weasel family ( Mustela zibellina ) native of the northern latitudes of Europe, Asia, and America, -- noted for its fine, soft, and valuable fur.
A kind of wooden shoe worn by the peasantry in France, Belgium, Sweden, and some other European countries.
See Saber .
The privilege formerly enjoyed by the lord of a manor, of holding courts, trying causes, and imposing fines.
See Saker .
A name formerly given to various dry Spanish wines.
See Saker .
A tribe of Indians, which, together with the Foxes, formerly occupied the region about Green Bay, Wisconsin.
Sated; satisfied; weary; tired.
A work in the Persian tongue, being a summary of the Zend-Avesta, or sacred books.
A member of a monotheistic sect of Hindoos. Sadhs resemble the Quakers in many respects.
Wearily; heavily; firmly.
A plant of the genus Ziziphus ( Ziziphus lotus ); -- so called by the Arabs of Barbary, who use its berries for food. See Lotus (b) .
Free from harm, injury, or risk; untouched or unthreatened by danger or injury; unharmed; unhurt; secure; whole; as, safe from disease; safe from storms; safe from foes .

To sink, in the middle, by its weight or under applied pressure, below a horizontal line or plane; as, a line or cable supported by its ends sags , though tightly drawn; the floor of a room sags ; hence, to lean, give way, or settle from a vertical position; as, a building may sag one way or another; a door sags on its hinges .
A Scandinavian legend, or heroic or mythic tradition, among the Norsemen and kindred people; a northern European popular historical or religious tale of olden time.

A suffruticose labiate plant ( Salvia officinalis ) with grayish green foliage, much used in flavoring meats, etc. The name is often extended to the whole genus, of which many species are cultivated for ornament, as the scarlet sage, and Mexican red and blue sage.

A dry granulated starch imported from the East Indies, much used for making puddings and as an article of diet for the sick; also, as starch, for stiffening textile fabrics. It is prepared from the stems of several East Indian and Malayan palm trees, but chiefly from the Metroxylon Sagu ; also from several cycadaceous plants ( Cycas revoluta , Zamia integrifolia , etc.).
The military cloak of the Roman soldiers.
A genus of palms from which sago is obtained.
Full of sage; seasoned with sage.
A respectful title or appellation given to Europeans of rank.
A marmoset.
See Capuchin , 3 (a) .
A kind of ketch very common in the Levant, which has neither topgallant sail nor mizzen topsail.
imp. & p. p. of Say .
An antelope ( Saiga Tartarica ) native of the plains of Siberia and Eastern Russia. The male has erect annulated horns, and tufts of long hair beneath the eyes and ears.
An extent of canvas or other fabric by means of which the wind is made serviceable as a power for propelling vessels through the water.
Like a sail.
Lard; grease.
To sanctify; to bless so as to protect from evil influence.
A person sanctified; a holy or godly person; one eminent for piety and virtue; any true Christian, as being redeemed and consecrated to God.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Say .
One of an important religious sect in India which regards Siva with peculiar veneration.
Same as Sapajou .

Final cause; end; purpose of obtaining; cause; motive; reason; interest; concern; account; regard or respect; -- used chiefly in such phrases as, for the sake of , for his sake , for man's sake , for mercy's sake , and the like; as, to commit crime for the sake of gain; to go abroad for the sake of one's health .
A falcon ( Falco sacer ) native of Southern Europe and Asia, closely resembling the lanner.
Any one of several species of South American monkeys of the genus Pithecia . They have large ears, and a long hairy tail which is not prehensile.
The divine energy, personified as the wife of a deity (Brahma, Vishnu, Siva, etc.); the female principle.
An East Indian timber tree ( Shorea robusta ), much used for building purposes. It is of a light brown color, close-grained, heavy, and durable.

A preparation of vegetables, as lettuce, celery, water cress, onions, etc., usually dressed with salt, vinegar, oil, and spice, and eaten for giving a relish to other food; as, lettuce salad ; tomato salad , etc.
A salutation or compliment of ceremony in the east by word or act; an obeisance, performed by bowing very low and placing the right palm on the forehead.
See 1st Sallow .
See Salep .
The dried tubers of various species of Orchis , and Eulophia . It is used to make a nutritious beverage by treating the powdered preparation with hot water.
Of or pertaining to the Salian Franks, or to the Salic law so called.
A genus of trees or shrubs including the willow, osier, and the like, growing usually in wet grounds.
To leap or rush out; to burst forth; to issue suddenly; as a body of troops from a fortified place to attack besiegers; to make a sally.
Same as Salmis .
A white crystalline substance consisting of phenol salicylate.
An apartment for the reception of company; hence, in the plural, fashionable parties; circles of fashionable society.
Any species of Salpa , or of the family Salpidae .
A genus of transparent, tubular, free-swimming oceanic tunicates found abundantly in all the warmer latitudes. See Illustration in Appendix.
A mud volcano, the water of which is often impregnated with salts, whence the name.

The chloride of sodium, a substance used for seasoning food, for the preservation of meat, etc. It is found native in the earth, and is also produced, by evaporation and crystallization, from sea water and other water impregnated with saline particles.
Containing salt; tasting of salt; saltish; as, the salty sea; the potatoes are too salty .
To say “ Salve ” to; to greet; to salute.
An exception; a reservation; an excuse.
a Surface to Air Missile .
A society or congregation; a church or religious body.
A negro; sometimes, the offspring of a black person and a mulatto; -- formerly used colloquially or with humorous intent, but now considered offensive or racist by African-Americans.
Not different or other; not another or others; identical; unchanged.
An article of food consisting of maize broken or bruised, which is cooked by boiling, and usually eaten with milk; coarse hominy.
Fine particles of stone, esp. of siliceous stone, but not reduced to dust; comminuted stone in the form of loose grains, which are not coherent when wet.
Consisting of, abounding with, or resembling, sand; full of sand; covered or sprinkled with sand; as, a sandy desert, road, or soil .
Being in a healthy condition; not deranged; acting rationally; -- said of the mind.
imp. of Sing .
The Abyssinian ox ( Bos Africanus syn. Bibos Africanus ), noted for the great length of its horns. It has a hump on its back.
imp. of Sink .
The sandpiper.
Without; deprived or destitute of. Rarely used as an English word.
Any marine annelid of the genus Hyalinaecia , especially Hyalinaecia tubicola of Europe, which inhabits a transparent movable tube resembling a quill in color and texture.
The juice of plants of any kind, especially the ascending and descending juices or circulating fluid essential to nutrition.
Having the power of affecting the organs of taste; possessing savor, or flavor.
Power of affecting the organs of taste; savor; flavor; taste.
Musty; tainted.
A variety of carnelian, of a rich reddish yellow or brownish red color. See the Note under Chalcedony .

The principal garment of a Hindoo woman. It consists of a long piece of cloth, which is wrapped round the middle of the body, a portion being arranged to hang down in front, and the remainder passed across the bosom over the left shoulder.
Any one of several species of sparoid fishes belonging to Sargus , Pomadasys , and related genera; -- called also sar , and saragu .
Same as Saree .
To cover with sarking, or thin boards.
A pavement or stepping-stone.
A Chaldean astronomical period or cycle, the length of which has been variously estimated from 3,600 years to 3,600 days, or a little short of 10 years.
A large toadfish of the Southern United States and the Gulf of Mexico ( Batrachus tau , var. pardus ).
Sarsaparilla.
A fine sieve; a searce.
An assart, or clearing.

A scarf or band worn about the waist, over the shoulder, or otherwise; a belt; a girdle, -- worn by women and children as an ornament; also worn as a badge of distinction by military officers, members of societies, etc.
The Indian antelope ( Antilope bezoartica syn. Antilope cervicapra ), noted for its beauty and swiftness. It has long, spiral, divergent horns.
A sluice or lock, as in a river, to make it more navigable.
imp. of Sit .
The grand adversary of man; the Devil, or Prince of darkness; the chief of the fallen angels; the archfiend.
To satisfy the desire or appetite of; to satiate; to glut; to surfeit.
A silk cloth, of a thick, close texture, and overshot woof, which has a glossy surface.
A sylvan deity or demigod, represented as part man and part goat, and characterized by riotous merriment and lasciviousness.
A composition of condiments and appetizing ingredients eaten with food as a relish; especially, a dressing for meat or fish or for puddings; as, mint sauce ; sweet sauce , etc.
Showing impertinent boldness or pertness; transgressing the rules of decorum; treating superiors with contempt; impudent; insolent; as, a saucy fellow .
Save; except.
imp. sing. of See .
Same as Sacs .
Same as Sal , the tree.
A rapid in some rivers; as, the Sault Ste. Marie .
Soil; dirt; dirty water; urine from a cowhouse.

A slender marine fish ( Scomberesox saurus ) of Europe and America. It has long, thin, beaklike jaws. Called also billfish , gowdnook , gawnook , skipper , skipjack , skopster , lizard fish , and Egypt herring .
An assault.
p. p. of Sauter .
The herb sage, or salvia.
One who saves.

A coniferous shrub ( Juniperus Sabina ) of Western Asia, occasionally found also in the northern parts of the United States and in British America. It is a compact bush, with dark-colored foliage, and produces small berries having a glaucous bloom. Its bitter, acrid tops are sometimes used in medicine for gout, amenorrhoea, etc.
That property of a thing which affects the organs of taste or smell; taste and odor; flavor; relish; scent; as, the savor of an orange or a rose; an ill savor .
A variety of the common cabbage ( Brassica oleracea major ), having curled leaves, -- much cultivated for winter use.
To understand; to comprehend; know.
imp. of See .
One who saws; a sawyer.
A kind of chopping instrument for trimming the edges of roofing slates.
One of a nation or people who formerly dwelt in the northern part of Germany, and who, with other Teutonic tribes, invaded and conquered England in the fifth and sixth centuries.
Trial by sample; assay; sample; specimen; smack.
One who says; an utterer.
p. p. of Senge , to singe.
An incrustation over a sore, wound, vesicle, or pustule, formed by the drying up of the discharge from the diseased part.
A small carangoid fish ( Trachurus saurus ) abundant on the European coast, and less common on the American. The name is applied also to several allied species.
A machine formerly employed for reducing dislocations of the humerus.
To burn with hot liquid or steam; to pain or injure by contact with, or immersion in, any hot fluid; as, to scald the hand .

The dish of a balance; hence, the balance itself; an instrument or machine for weighing; as, to turn the scale ; -- chiefly used in the plural when applied to the whole instrument or apparatus for weighing. Also used figuratively.
A scurf or scabby disease, especially of the scalp.
A bed of oysters or mussels.
Covered or abounding with scales; as, a scaly fish .
A rascal; a swindler; a rogue.
To mount by steps; to go through with step by step.

Not full, large, or plentiful; scarcely sufficient; less than is wanted for the purpose; scanty; meager; not enough; as, a scant allowance of provisions or water; a scant pattern of cloth for a garment .
A peduncle rising from the ground or from a subterranean stem, as in the stemless violets, the bloodroot, and the like.
A mark in the skin or flesh of an animal, made by a wound or ulcer, and remaining after the wound or ulcer is healed; a cicatrix; a mark left by a previous injury; a blemish; a disfigurement.
A shard or fragment.
To frighten; to strike with sudden fear; to alarm.
A cormorant.
A band in the same position as the bend sinister, but only half as broad as the latter.
Barren land having only a thin coat of grass.
Go away; begone; away; -- chiefly used in driving off a cat.
See Skate , for the foot.
Harm; damage; injury; hurt; waste; misfortune.
A bed or stratum of shellfish; scalp.
A precipitous bank or rock; a scar.
A scene in an opera.
The structure on which a spectacle or play is exhibited; the part of a theater in which the acting is done, with its adjuncts and decorations; the stage.
To perceive by the olfactory organs; to smell; as, to scent game, as a hound does .
To discern; to perceive.
A slunk calf.
A shoot or sprout of a plant; a sucker.
Of or pertaining to the island Scio (Chio or Chios).
To cut; to penetrate.
Same as Slav .
To prop; to scotch.
Raspings of ivory, hartshorn, metals, or other hard substance.
Derision; ridicule; mockery; derisive or mocking expression of scorn, contempt, or reproach.
Poke ( Phytolacca decandra ).
To find fault or rail with rude clamor; to brawl; to utter harsh, rude, boisterous rebuke; to chide sharply or coarsely; -- often with at ; as, to scold at a servant .
A cake, thinner than a bannock, made of wheat or barley or oat meal.
A large ladle; a vessel with a long handle, used for dipping liquids; a utensil for bailing boats.
To walk fast; to go quickly; to run hastily away.
That at which one aims; the thing or end to which the mind directs its view; that which is purposed to be reached or accomplished; hence, ultimate design, aim, or purpose; intention; drift; object.
A notch or incision; especially, one that is made as a tally mark; hence, a mark, or line, made for the purpose of account.
Extreme and lofty contempt; haughty disregard; that disdain which springs from the opinion of the utter meanness and unworthiness of an object.
A name for a horse.
To clothe or cover up.
Of or pertaining to the Scotch; Scotch; Scottish; as, Scots law; a pound Scots (1s. 8d.) .

To rub hard with something rough, as sand or Bristol brick, especially for the purpose of cleaning; to clean by friction; to make clean or bright; to cleanse from grease, dirt, etc., as articles of dress.
A swift sailing boat.
A large flat-bottomed boat, having broad, square ends.
To wrinkle the brows, as in frowning or displeasure; to put on a frowning look; to look sour, sullen, severe, or angry.
Something thin, lean, or rough; a bony piece; especially, a bony neckpiece of meat; hence, humorously or in contempt, the neck.
to leave; to go away; used mostly as an impolite command to a person to go away from a specific location.
Something scraped off; hence, a small piece; a bit; a fragment; a detached, incomplete portion.
To scratch.
A tern; the sea swallow.
A pebble; a stone; also, a heap of stones or rocky débris.

A cylinder, or a cylindrical perforation, having a continuous rib, called the thread , winding round it spirally at a constant inclination, so as to leave a continuous spiral groove between one turn and the next, -- used chiefly for producing, when revolved, motion or pressure in the direction of its axis, by the sliding of the threads of the cylinder in the grooves between the threads of the perforation adapted to it, the former being distinguished as the external , or male screw , or, more usually the screw ; the latter as the internal , or female screw , or, more usually, the nut .
A screed; a shred; a fragment.
A kind of light cotton or linen fabric, often woven in openwork patterns, -- used for curtains, etc,; -- called also India scrim .
A small bag; a wallet; a satchel.
Writing; document; scroll.
A young codfish, especially when cut open on the back and dressed.
A stunted shrub, bush, or branch.
To rub hard; to wash with rubbing; usually, to rub with a wet brush, or with something coarse or rough, for the purpose of cleaning or brightening; as, to scrub a floor, a doorplate .
A flock of wild fowl.
To move swiftly; especially, to move as if driven forward by something.
A silver coin, and money of account, used in Italy and Sicily, varying in value, in different parts, but worth about 4 shillings sterling, or about 96 cents; also, a gold coin worth about the same.
The back part of the neck; the scruff.
A place of shelter; the declivity of a hill.
See Skulk , Skulker .
A shoal of fish.
To sculpture; to carve; to engrave.
To take the scum from; to clear off the impure matter from the surface of; to skim.

A marine sparoid food fish ( Stenotomus chrysops , or Stenotomus argyrops ), common on the Atlantic coast of the United States. It appears bright silvery when swimming in the daytime, but shows broad blackish transverse bands at night and when dead. Called also porgee , paugy , porgy , scuppaug .
To move hastily; to scour.
Thin dry scales or scabs upon the body; especially, thin scales exfoliated from the cuticle, particularly of the scalp; dandruff.
The tail of a hare, or of a deer, or other animal whose tail is short, esp. when carried erect; hence, sometimes, the animal itself.
See Scutum .
A small shield.
Arm scye, a cutter's term for the armhole or part of the armhole of the waist of a garment.
To hide; to secrete; to conceal.

One of the larger bodies of salt water, less than an ocean, found on the earth's surface; a body of salt water of second rank, generally forming part of, or connecting with, an ocean or a larger sea; as, the Mediterranean Sea ; the Sea of Marmora; the North Sea ; the Carribean Sea .
A Jewish dry measure containing one third of an ephah.
Soap prepared for use in milling cloth.
Any aquatic carnivorous mammal of the families Phocidae and Otariidae .
Grease; tallow; lard.
Having a seam; containing seams, or showing them.
A seine. See Seine .
Dry; withered; no longer green; -- applied to leaves.
The place or thing upon which one sits; hence; anything made to be sat in or upon, as a chair, bench, stool, saddle, or the like.
Overgrown with rushes.
The eleventh month of the ancient Hebrew year, approximately corresponding with February.
See Sebacic .
Barren; unprofitable. See Rent seck , under Rent .
Secret; secretive; faithful to a secret.
A cutting; a scion.
A portable chair or covered vehicle for carrying a single person, -- usually borne on poles by two men. Called also sedan chair .

Any plant of the genus Carex , perennial, endogenous, innutritious herbs, often growing in dense tufts in marshy places. They have triangular jointless stems, a spiked inflorescence, and long grasslike leaves which are usually rough on the margins and midrib. There are several hundred species.
Overgrown with sedge.
A genus of plants, mostly perennial, having succulent leaves and cymose flowers; orpine; stonecrop.
A seat; a site; a place where sovereign power is exercised.
A ripened ovule, consisting of an embryo with one or more integuments, or coverings; as, an apple seed ; a currant seed . By germination it produces a new plant.
Abounding with seeds; bearing seeds; having run to seeds.
To go in search of; to look for; to search for; to try to find.
To close the eyes of (a hawk or other bird) by drawing through the lids threads which were fastened over the head.
See Silly .
To appear, or to appear to be; to have a show or semblance; to present an appearance; to look; to strike one's apprehension or fancy as being; to be taken as.
p. p. of See .
To run or soak through fine pores and interstices; to ooze.
Oozy; -- applied to land under cultivation that is not well drained.
Sore; painful.
imp. of Seethe .
A castrated bull.
See Cigar .
The hedge sparrow.
A sign. See Al segno , and Dal segno .
A liliaceous plant ( Calochortus Nuttallii ) of Western North America, and its edible bulb; -- so called by the Ute Indians and the Mormons.
A descendant of Mohammed through his daughter Fatima and nephew Ali.
A large net, one edge of which is provided with sinkers, and the other with floats. It hangs vertically in the water, and when its ends are brought together or drawn ashore incloses the fish.
See Seize .
Something peculiar to one's self.
To fall or rush upon suddenly and lay hold of; to gripe or grasp suddenly; to reach and grasp.
A place in a pagan temple in which the images of the deities were inclosed.
A word of doubtful meaning, occuring frequently in the Psalms; by some, supposed to signify silence or a pause in the musical performance of the song.
Rare; uncommon; unusual.
Same; particular; very; identical.
A cell; a house.
Self; same.
A linguistic sign.
The seed of plants.
A Japanese coin, worth about one half of a cent.
To cause to go in any manner; to dispatch; to commission or direct to go; as, to send a messenger .
The leaves of several leguminous plants of the genus Cassia . ( Cassia acutifolia , Cassia angustifolia , etc.). They constitute a valuable but nauseous cathartic medicine.

A faculty, possessed by animals, of perceiving external objects by means of impressions made upon certain organs (sensory or sense organs) of the body, or of perceiving changes in the condition of the body; as, the senses of sight, smell, hearing, taste, and touch . See Muscular sense , under Muscular , and Temperature sense , under Temperature .
See Scent , v. & n.
Without; as, senza stromenti, without instruments .
A leaf or division of the calyx.
The common European cuttlefish.
Of or pertaining to sepia; done in sepia; as, a sepic drawing .
See Supawn .
A native of India employed as a soldier in the service of a European power, esp. of Great Britain; an Oriental soldier disciplined in the European manner.
A clan, tribe, or family, proceeding from a common progenitor; -- used especially of the ancient clans in Ireland.
A palace; a seraglio; also, in the East, a place for the accommodation of travelers; a caravansary, or rest house.
Dry; withered. Same as Sear .
A servant or slave employed in husbandry, and in some countries attached to the soil and transferred with it, as formerly in Russia.
A woolen twilled stuff, much used as material for clothing for both sexes.
A European finch ( Serinus hortulanus ) closely related to the canary.
Same as Ceroon .
To crowd, press, or drive together.
To crowd; to press together.
The watery portion of certain animal fluids, as blood, milk, etc.

To work for; to labor in behalf of; to exert one's self continuously or statedly for the benefit of; to do service for; to be in the employment of, as an inferior, domestic, serf, slave, hired assistant, official helper, etc.; specifically, in a religious sense, to obey and worship.
To lay a tax upon; to assess.
Hurry; run.

To cause to sit; to make to assume a specified position or attitude; to give site or place to; to place; to put; to fix; as, to set a house on a stone foundation; to set a book on a shelf; to set a dish on a table; to set a chest or trunk on its bottom or on end .

Any slender, more or less rigid, bristlelike organ or part; as the hairs of a caterpillar, the slender spines of a crustacean, the hairlike processes of a protozoan, the bristles or stiff hairs on the leaves of some plants, or the pedicel of the capsule of a moss.
See 2d Settee .
An evil beast-headed god with high square ears and a long snout; his was the brother and murderer of Osiris. Called also Set
See Shittim .
A few silk threads or horsehairs, or a strip of linen or the like, introduced beneath the skin by a knife or needle, so as to form an issue; also, the issue so formed.
See Set , n. , 2 (e) and 3.
One more than six; six and one added; as, seven days make one week .
To separate, as one from another; to cut off from something; to divide; to part in any way, especially by violence, as by cutting, rending, etc.; as, to sever the head from the body .
Juice; gravy; a seasoned dish; a delicacy.
To perform the duties of a sewer. See 3d Sewer .
A scarecrow, generally made of feathers tied to a string, hung up to prevent deer from breaking into a place.
A British trout usually regarded as a variety (var. Cambricus ) of the salmon trout.
One who sews, or stitches.
Same as Sewen .

The distinguishing peculiarity of male or female in both animals and plants; the physical difference between male and female; the assemblage of properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female.
Belonging to sex; having sex; distinctively male of female; as, the sexed condition .
Pertaining to sex.
The office for the sixth canonical hour, being a part of the Breviary.
A book consisting of sheets each of which is folded into six leaves.
imp. sing. & 2d pers. pl. of See .
imp. pl. & p. p. of See .
p. p. of Senge , to singe.
A gridle. See 1st Seint .
The itch in animals; also, a scab.
To shed or fall, as corn or grain at harvest.

Any one of several species of food fishes of the Herring family. The American species ( Alosa sapidissima formerly Clupea sapidissima ), which is abundant on the Atlantic coast and ascends the larger rivers in spring to spawn, is an important market fish. The European allice shad, or alose ( Alosa alosa formerly Clupea alosa ), and the twaite shad ( Alosa finta formerly Clupea finta ), are less important species.
Rounded stones containing tin ore, lying at the surface of the ground, and indicating a vein.
Comparative obscurity owing to interception or interruption of the rays of light; partial darkness caused by the intervention of something between the space contemplated and the source of light.
Abounding in shade or shades; overspread with shade; causing shade.
The slender, smooth stem of an arrow; hence, an arrow.
Coarse hair or nap; rough, woolly hair.
A former title of the supreme ruler in certain Eastern countries, especially Persia and Iran.
See Sheik .
To walk sidewise.
obs. p. p. of Shake .
A kind of military cap or headdress.
Shaking or trembling; as, a shaky spot in a marsh; a shaky hand .
A shell or husk; a cod or pod.
To owe; to be under obligation for.
See Shawm .
2d per. sing. of Shall .
Resembling shale in structure.
That which deceives expectation; any trick, fraud, or device that deludes and disappoints; a make-believe; delusion; imposture; humbug.

A saxicoline singing bird ( Kittacincla macroura ) of India, noted for the sweetness and power of its song. In confinement it imitates the notes of other birds and various animals with accuracy. Its head, neck, back, breast, and tail are glossy black, the rump white, the under parts chestnut.
A painful sensation excited by a consciousness of guilt or impropriety, or of having done something which injures reputation, or of the exposure of that which nature or modesty prompts us to conceal.
See Chank .
To form or create; especially, to mold or make into a particular form; to give proper form or figure to.
Chaparajos.
A plant; chard.
The part (usually an iron or steel plate) of a plow which cuts the ground at the bottom of a furrow; a plowshare.
Any one of numerous species of elasmobranch fishes of the order Plagiostomi , found in all seas.
Having a very thin edge or fine point; of a nature to cut or pierce easily; not blunt or dull; keen.
The scarf of a turban.
obs. p. p. of Shave .
A thicket; a small wood or grove.
A square or oblong cloth of wool, cotton, silk, or other textile or netted fabric, used, especially by women, as a loose covering for the neck and shoulders.
A wind instrument of music, formerly in use, supposed to have resembled either the clarinet or the hautboy in form.
This or that female; the woman understood or referred to; the animal of the female sex, or object personified as feminine, which was spoken of.
A quantity of the stalks and ears of wheat, rye, or other grain, bound together; a bundle of grain or straw.
Same as Sheeling .
To cut, clip, or sever anything from with shears or a like instrument; as, to shear sheep; to shear cloth .
A slight or temporary structure built to shade or shelter something; a structure often open in front; an outbuilding; a hut; as, a wagon shed ; a wood shed .
Bright; glittering; radiant; fair; showy; sheeny.
Any one of several species of ruminants of the genus Ovis , native of the higher mountains of both hemispheres, but most numerous in Asia.
Bright; clear; pure; unmixed.
In general, a large, broad piece of anything thin, as paper, cloth, etc.; a broad, thin portion of any substance; an expanded superficies.
The head of an Arab family, or of a clan or a tribe; also, the chief magistrate of an Arab village. The name is also applied to Mohammedan ecclesiastics of a high grade.
See Sheeling .
Variegated; spotted; speckled; piebald.
A flat tablet or ledge of any material set horizontally at a distance from the floor, to hold objects of use or ornament.
A hard outside covering, as of a fruit or an animal.
To injure, mar, spoil, or harm.
obs. 3d pers. sing. pres. of Shend , for shendeth .
The place of departed spirits; Hades; also, the grave.
A fragment; -- now used only in composition, as in pot sherd . See Shard .
See Shearn .
The part of a plow which projects downward beneath the beam, for holding the share and other working parts; -- also called standard , or post .
p. p. of Shew .
Same as Shiite ; when used with a plural verb, the Shiites, collectively.
A thin board; a billet of wood; a splinter.
See Shy , to throw.
imp. & p. p. of Shy .
A sheeling.
To divide; to distribute; to apportion.
To put under cover; to sheal.
See Shyly .
A kind of shallow plow used in tillage to break the ground, and clear it of weeds.
The front part of the leg below the knee; the front edge of the shin bone; the lower part of the leg; the shank.
To emit rays of light; to give light; to beam with steady radiance; to exhibit brightness or splendor; as, the sun shines by day; the moon shines by night.
Bright; luminous; clear; unclouded.
Pay; reward.

A portion of Great Britain originally under the supervision of an earl; a territorial division, usually identical with a county, but sometimes limited to a smaller district; as, Wilt shire , York shire , Richmond shire , Hallam shire .
To procure by petty fraud and trickery; to obtain by mean solicitation.
See Schorl .
A series of close parallel runnings which are drawn up so as to make the material between them set full by gatherings; -- called also shirring , and gauging .

A loose under-garment for the upper part of the body, made of cotton, linen, or other material; -- formerly used of the under-garment of either sex, now commonly restricted to that worn by men and boys.
See Shist , Schistose .
A slice; as, a shive of bread .
A train of vein material mixed with rubbish; fragments of ore which have become separated by the action of water or the weather, and serve to direct in the discovery of mines.
A great multitude assembled; a crowd; a throng; -- said especially of fish; as, a shoal of bass .
A prop. See 3d Shore .
A young hog. Same as Shote .
A pile or assemblage of sheaves of grain, as wheat, rye, or the like, set up in a field, the sheaves varying in number from twelve to sixteen; a stook.
The parting of the hair on the head.
A covering for the human foot, usually made of leather, having a thick and somewhat stiff sole and a lighter top. It differs from a boot on not extending so far up the leg.
One who fits shoes to the feet; one who furnishes or puts on shoes; as, a shoer of horses .
A shock; a jog; a violent concussion or impulse.
A plank fixed beneath an object, as beneath the rudder of a vessel, to protect it from injury; a plank on the ground under the end of a shore or the like.
imp. & p. p. of Shine .
Begone; away; -- an expression used in frightening away animals, especially fowls.
The Richardson's skua ( Stercorarius parasiticus );- so called from its cry.
imp. & obs. or poet. p. p. of Shake .
pl. of Shoe .
imp. of Shape . Shaped.

An inclined plane, either artificial or natural, down which timber, coal, etc., are caused to slide; also, a narrow passage, either natural or artificial, in a stream, where the water rushes rapidly; esp., a channel, having a swift current, connecting the ends of a bend in the stream, so as to shorten the course.
imp. of Shape . Shaped.
imp. of Shear .
See Schorl , Schorlaceous .
p. p. of Shear .
Not long; having brief length or linear extension; as, a short distance; a short piece of timber; a short flight.
Lying near the shore.
imp. & p. p. of Shoot .
A fish resembling the trout.
The refuse of cattle taken from a drove.
To utter a sudden and loud outcry, as in joy, triumph, or exultation, or to attract attention, to animate soldiers, etc.

To drive along by the direct and continuous application of strength; to push; especially, to push (a body) so as to make it move along the surface of another body; as, to shove a boat on the water; to shove a table across the floor.

To exhibit or present to view; to place in sight; to display; -- the thing exhibited being the object, and often with an indirect object denoting the person or thing seeing or beholding; as, to show a house; show your colors; shopkeepers show customers goods (show goods to customers).
p. p. of Show .
Making a show; attracting attention; presenting a marked appearance; ostentatious; gay; gaudy.
A twig of a tree cut off.
To cause to shrink or shrivel with cold; to benumb.
A place baited with chaff to entice birds.
A long, narrow piece cut or torn off; a strip.
Wicked; malicious.
A liquor composed of vegetable acid, especially lemon juice, and sugar, with spirit to preserve it.
To draw up or contract (the shoulders), especially by way of expressing doubt, indifference, dislike, dread, or the like.
A shock of grain.
The husks and other refuse of rice mills, used to adulterate oil cake, or linseed cake.
To writhe the body so as to produce friction against one's clothes, as do those who have the itch.
To avoid; to keep clear of; to get out of the way of; to escape from; to eschew; as, to shun rocks, shoals, vice .
To shun; to move from.
To close so as to hinder ingress or egress; as, to shut a door or a gate; to shut one's eyes or mouth.
Same as Chute , or Shoot .
Easily frightened; timid; as, a shy bird .
In a shy or timid manner; not familiarly; with reserve.
A syllable applied, in solmization, to the note B; more recently, to the seventh tone of any major diatonic scale. It was added to Guido's scale by Le Maire about the end of the 17th century.
The ahu, or jairou.
A blood relation.
A woman supposed to be endowed with a spirit of prophecy.
A seal; a coining die; -- used adjectively to designate the silver currency of the Mogul emperors, or the Indian rupee of 192 grains.
The number six at dice.
A strong drink; cider.
Affected with disease of any kind; ill; indisposed; not in health. See the Synonym under Illness .
A genus of malvaceous plants common in the tropics. All the species are mucilaginous, and some have tough ligneous fibers which are used as a substitute for hemp and flax.

The margin, edge, verge, or border of a surface; especially (when the thing spoken of is somewhat oblong in shape), one of the longer edges as distinguished from the shorter edges, called ends ; a bounding line of a geometrical figure; as, the side of a field, of a square or triangle, of a river, of a road, etc.
Having (such or so many) sides; -- used in composition; as, one- sided ; many- sided .
One who takes a side.
To go or move with one side foremost; to move sidewise; as, to sidle through a crowd or narrow opening .
A seat; especially, a royal seat; a throne.
Sir; -- a title of respect used by the French.
A small variety of the Lima bean ( Phaseolus lunatus ).

A utensil for separating the finer and coarser parts of a pulverized or granulated substance from each other. It consist of a vessel, usually shallow, with the bottom perforated, or made of hair, wire, or the like, woven in meshes.
The white indris of Madagascar. It is regarded by the natives as sacred.
To separate with a sieve, as the fine part of a substance from the coarse; as, to sift meal or flour; to sift powder; to sift sand or lime.

To inhale a larger quantity of air than usual, and immediately expel it; to make a deep single audible respiration, especially as the result or involuntary expression of fatigue, exhaustion, grief, sorrow, or the like.
The act of seeing; perception of objects by the eye; view; as, to gain sight of land .
A seal; a signature.
The signs, abbreviations, letters, or characters standing for words, shorthand, etc., in ancient manuscripts, or on coins, medals, etc.
The Greek letter Σ, σ, or ς (English S , or s ). It originally had the form of the English C.
That by which anything is made known or represented; that which furnishes evidence; a mark; a token; an indication; a proof.
Such. See Such .
A gutter; a stream, such as is usually dry in summer.
See 2d Sicker , Sickerly , etc.
A religious sect noted for warlike traits, founded in the Punjab at the end of the 15th century.
To strain, as fresh milk.
Silica, SiO2 as found in nature, constituting quarz, and most sands and sandstones. See Silica , and Silicic .

The fine, soft thread produced by various species of caterpillars in forming the cocoons within which the worm is inclosed during the pupa state, especially that produced by the larvae of Bombyx mori .
Of or pertaining to silk; made of, or resembling, silk; silken; silklike; as, a silky luster .

The basis or foundation of a thing; especially, a horizontal piece, as a timber, which forms the lower member of a frame, or supports a structure; as, the sills of a house, of a bridge, of a loom, and the like .
Happy; fortunate; blessed.
A pit or vat for packing away green fodder for winter use so as to exclude air and outside moisture. See Ensilage .
Mud or fine earth deposited from running or standing water.
Full of silt; resembling silt.
The forest trees of a region or country, considered collectively.
A woman's long dress or robe; also light covering; a scarf.
A Linnaean genus of Quadrumana which included the types of numerous modern genera. By modern writers it is usually restricted to the genus which includes the orang-outang.
Old form of Since .
From a definite past time until now; as, he went a month ago, and I have not seen him since .
A saddle girth made of leather, canvas, woven horsehair, or woven grass.
A native of Sind, India, esp. one of the native Hindoo stock.
The length of a perpendicular drawn from one extremity of an arc of a circle to the diameter drawn through the other extremity.
To knit together, or make strong with, or as with, sinews.

To utter sounds with musical inflections or melodious modulations of voice, as fancy may dictate, or according to the notes of a song or tune, or of a given part (as alto, tenor, etc.) in a chorus or concerted piece.
To burn slightly or superficially; to burn the surface of; to burn the ends or outside of; as, to singe the hair or the skin .
Of or pertaining to the Chinese and allied races; Chinese.
To fall by, or as by, the force of gravity; to descend lower and lower; to decline gradually; to subside; as, a stone sinks in water; waves rise and sink ; the sun sinks in the west .
See Shinto , etc.
An opening; a hollow; a bending.
A nation of American Indians; see Dakotas .
To drink or imbibe in small quantities; especially, to take in with the lips in small quantities, as a liquid; as, to sip tea .
Having a taste or flavorl savory; sapid.
A man of social authority and dignity; a lord; a master; a gentleman; -- in this sense usually spelled sire .
A lord, master, or other person in authority. See Sir .
One of three sea nymphs, -- or, according to some writers, of two, -- said to frequent an island near the coast of Italy, and to sing with such sweetness that they lured mariners to destruction.
See Sirocco .
A quicksand.
A thick and viscid liquid made from the juice of fruits, herbs, etc., boiled with sugar.
A colloquial abbreviation of Sister .
Six; the highest number on a die; the cast of six in throwing dice.
The suslik.
Cider. See Sicer .
To make a hissing sound; as, a flatiron hot enough to siss when touched with a wet finger .
To stay, as judicial proceedings; to delay or suspend; to stop.
obs. 3d pers. sing. pres. of Sit , for sitteth .
The place where anything is fixed; situation; local position; as, the site of a city or of a house .
Having a site; situated.
Since; afterwards; seeing that.
To cut with a scythe; to scythe.
The method in which the parts of a plant are arranged; also, the position of the parts.
One of the triad of Hindoo gods. He is the avenger or destroyer, and in modern worship symbolizes the reproductive power of nature.
The third month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year; -- supposed to correspond nearly with our month of June.
Same as Sewen .
One more than five; twice three; as, six yards .
First after the fifth; next in order after the fifth.
Six times ten; fifty-nine and one more; threescore.

One of a body of students in the universities of Cambridge (Eng.) and Dublin, who, having passed a certain examination, are exempted from paying college fees and charges. A sizar corresponded to a servitor at Oxford.
A thin, weak glue used in various trades, as in painting, bookbinding, paper making, etc.
Adjusted according to size.
Same as Scissel , 2.
See Sizar .
Sizelike; viscous; glutinous; as, sizy blood .
An additional piece fastened to the keel of a boat to prevent lateral motion. See Skeg .
See Skein .
See 5th Scald .
To scale; to mount.
Wild; timid; shy.

A three-handed card game played with 32 cards, of which two constitute the skat (sense 2), or widow. The players bid for the privilege of attempting any of several games or tasks, in most of which the player undertaking the game must take tricks counting in aggregate at least 61 (the counting cards being ace 11, ten 10, king 4, queen 3, jack 2). The four jacks are the best trumps, ranking club, spade, heart, diamond, and ten outranks king or queen (but when the player undertakes to lose all the tricks, the cards rank as in whist). The value of hands depends upon the game played, trump suit, points taken, and number of matadores.
A metallic runner with a frame shaped to fit the sole of a shoe, -- made to be fastened under the foot, and used for moving rapidly on ice.
A knife or short dagger, esp. that in use among the Highlanders of Scotland. [Variously spelt.]
A long strip of wood, curved upwards in front, used on the foot for sliding; now usually spelled ski .
A shallow wooden vessel for holding milk or cream.
A scoop with a long handle, used to wash the sides of a vessel, and formerly to wet the sails or deck.
A sort of wild plum.
A quantity of yarn, thread, or the like, put up together, after it is taken from the reel, -- usually tied in a sort of knot.
A blow; a smart stroke.
See Skean .
A coarse round farm basket.
Awry; obliquely; askew.

A long, flat, narrow runner made of wood, plastic or metal, curved upwards in front, having a fitting allowing it to be attached to the foot, and used for gliding or sliding over snow. Commonly used in the plural, to designate the pair.

A shoe or clog, as of iron, attached to a chain, and placed under the wheel of a wagon to prevent its turning when descending a steep hill; a drag; a skidpan; also, by extension, a hook attached to a chain, and used for the same purpose.
imp. & p. p. of Sky , v. t.
See Skyey .
A small, light boat.
Discrimination; judgment; propriety; reason; cause.
To clear (a liquid) from scum or substance floating or lying thereon, by means of a utensil that passes just beneath the surface; as, to skim milk; to skim broth.
To slight; to do carelessly; to scamp.
The external membranous integument of an animal.
Any one of numerous species of regularly scaled harmless lizards of the family Scincidae , common in the warmer parts of all the continents.
A basket. See Skep .
To utter in a shrill tone; to scream.
To ramble over in order to clear; to scour.
The lower and loose part of a coat, dress, or other like garment; the part below the waist; as, the skirt of a coat, a dress, or a mantle .
To cast reflections on; to asperse.
The iron lap used by diamond polishers in finishing the facets of the gem.
A guillemot.
Any jager gull; especially, the Megalestris skua ; -- called also boatswain .
To hide, or get out of the way, in a sneaking manner; to lie close, or to move in a furtive way; to lurk.
A school, company, or shoal.

Any one of several species of American musteline carnivores of the genus Mephitis and allied genera. They have two glands near the anus, secreting an extremely fetid liquid, which the animal ejects at pleasure as a means of defense.
A boat; a small vessel.
To hang (a picture on exhibition) near the top of a wall, where it can not be well seen.
Surrounded by sky.
Like the sky; ethereal; being in the sky.
A thin piece of anything, especially of marble or other stone, having plane surfaces.
Small coal; also, coal dust; culm.
A little dell or valley; a flat piece of low, moist ground.
The dross, or recrement, of a metal; also, vitrified cinders.
A weaver's reed; a sley.
To allay; to quench; to extinguish; as, to slake thirst .
To shut with force and a loud noise; to bang; as, he slammed the door .
imp. of Sling . Slung.
imp. & p. p. of Slink .
To be turned or inclined from a right line or level; to lie obliquely; to slope.
A blow, esp. one given with the open hand, or with something broad.
Slippery; smooth; crafty; hypocritical.
To cut by striking violently and at random; to cut in long slits.
A thin, narrow strip or bar of wood or metal; as, the slats of a window blind .
An argillaceous rock which readily splits into thin plates; argillite; argillaceous schist.
A slab of stone used as a veneer for coarse masonry.
Resembling slate; having the nature, appearance, or properties, of slate; composed of thin parallel plates, capable of being separated by splitting; as, a slaty color or texture .
One of a race of people occupying a large part of Eastern and Northern Europe, including the Russians, Bulgarians, Roumanians, Servo-Croats, Slovenes, Poles, Czechs, Wends or Sorbs, Slovaks, etc.

A person who is held in bondage to another; one who is wholly subject to the will of another; one who is held as a chattel; one who has no freedom of action, but whose person and services are wholly under the control of another.
Sliced cabbage served as a salad, cooked or uncooked.
To put to death with a weapon, or by violence; hence, to kill; to put an end to; to destroy.
See Sleazy .
A vehicle on runners, used for conveying loads over the snow or ice; -- in England called sledge .
Having an even, smooth surface; smooth; hence, glossy; as, sleek hair .
imp. of Sleep. Slept.
The part of a mortar extending from the chamber to the trunnions.
To sley, or prepare for use in the weaver's sley, or slaie.
See Slant .
imp. of Sleep . Slept.
imp. & p. p. of Sleep .
imp. of Slay .
A weaver's reed.
A thin, broad piece cut off; as, a slice of bacon; a slice of cheese; a slice of bread.
See Schlich .
Sleek; smooth.
imp. & p. p. of Slide .
To move along the surface of any body by slipping, or without walking or rolling; to slip; to glide; as, snow slides down the mountain's side .
See Slyly .
Worthless; bad.
Soft, moist earth or clay, having an adhesive quality; viscous mud.
Of or pertaining to slime; resembling slime; of the nature of slime; viscous; glutinous; also, covered or daubed with slime; yielding, or abounding in, slime.

An instrument for throwing stones or other missiles, consisting of a short strap with two strings fastened to its ends, or with a string fastened to one end and a light stick to the other. The missile being lodged in a hole in the strap, the ends of the string are taken in the hand, and the whole whirled rapidly round until, by loosing one end, the missile is let fly with centrifugal force.
To creep away meanly; to steal away; to sneak.
To move along the surface of a thing without bounding, rolling, or stepping; to slide; to glide.
A cut; as, slish and slash .
3d. pers. sing. pres. of Slide .
To cut; to split; to separate.
A layer of earth between coal seams.
A narrow piece of timber which holds together large pieces; a slat; as, the sloats of a cart .
To quench; to allay; to slake. See Slake .
A small, bitter, wild European plum, the fruit of the blackthorn ( Prunus spinosa ); also, the tree itself.
To hit hard, esp. with little attention to aim or the like, as in cricket or boxing; to slug.
See sloakan .
A slough; a run or wet place. See 2d Slough , 2.

A vessel having one mast and fore-and-aft rig, consisting of a boom-and-gaff mainsail, jibs, staysail, and gaff topsail. The typical sloop has a fixed bowsprit, topmast, and standing rigging, while those of a cutter are capable of being readily shifted. The sloop usually carries a centerboard, and depends for stability upon breadth of beam rather than depth of keel. The two types have rapidly approximated since 1880. One radical distinction is that a sloop may carry a centerboard. See Cutter , and Illustration in Appendix.
Water or other liquid carelessly spilled or thrown aboyt, as upon a table or a floor; a puddle; a soiled spot.
An oblique direction; a line or direction including from a horizontal line or direction; also, sometimes, an inclination, as of one line or surface to another.
Sloping; inclined.
See Slush , Slushy .
A broad, flat, wooden bar; a slat or sloat.
Slowness; tardiness.
Moving a short space in a relatively long time; not swift; not quick in motion; not rapid; moderate; deliberate; as, a slow stream; a slow motion .
imp. of Slee ,to slay.
Milk sickness.

Lit., skilled mechanical work, such as that required in wood carving; trade work; hence, a system (usually called the sloyd system ) of manual training in the practical use of the tools and materials used in the trades, and of instruction in the making and use of the plans and specifications connected with trade work. The sloyd system derives its name from the fact that it was adopted or largely developed from a similar Swedish system, in which wood carving was a chief feature. Its purpose is not only to afford practical skill in some trade, but also to develop the pupils mentally and physically.
A roll of wool slightly twisted; a rove; -- called also slubbing .
Miry; slushy.
To turn about a fixed point, usually the center or axis, as a spar or piece of timber; to turn; -- used also of any heavy body.
A drone; a slow, lazy fellow; a sluggard.
Half-roasted ore.

A foul back street of a city, especially one filled with a poor, dirty, degraded, and often vicious population; any low neighborhood or dark retreat; -- usually in the plural; as, Westminster slums are haunts for theives .
The gross amount; the mass; the lump.
imp. & p. p. of Sling .
imp. & p. p. of Slink .
To soil; to sully; to contaminate; to disgrace.
To smear with slush or grease; as, to slush a mast .
An untidy woman; a slattern.
Dexterous in performing an action, so as to escape notice; nimble; skillful; cautious; shrewd; knowing; -- in a good sense.
In a sly manner; shrewdly; craftily.
A narrow passage between two buildings, as between the transept and chapter house of a monastery.
A small sailing vessel, commonly rigged as a sloop, used chiefly in the coasting and fishing trade.

Having little size, compared with other things of the same kind; little in quantity or degree; diminutive; not large or extended in dimension; not great; not much; inconsiderable; as, a small man; a small river .
A deep blue pigment or coloring material used in various arts. It is a vitreous substance made of cobalt, potash, and calcined quartz fused, and reduced to a powder.
To feel a lively, pungent local pain; -- said of some part of the body as the seat of irritation; as, my finger smarts ; these wounds smart .
To break in pieces by violence; to dash to pieces; to crush.
To overspread with anything unctuous, viscous, or adhesive; to daub; as, to smear anything with oil .
The pintail duck.
A salt glaze on pottery, made by adding common salt to an earthenware glaze.

To perceive by the olfactory nerves, or organs of smell; to have a sensation of, excited through the nasal organs when affected by the appropriate materials or qualities; to obtain the scent of; as, to smell a rose; to smell perfumes .
imp. & p. p. of Smell .
See Smirk .
small European merganser ( Mergus albellus ) which has a white crest; -- called also smee , smee duck , white merganser , and white nun .
A match for firing a charge of powder, as in blasting; a fuse.
To express amusement, pleasure, moderate joy, or love and kindness, by the features of the face; to laugh silently.
To smile in an affected or conceited manner; to smile with affected complaisance; to simper.
imp. & p. p. of Smite .
To strike; to inflict a blow upon with the hand, or with any instrument held in the hand, or with a missile thrown by the hand; as, to smite with the fist, with a rod, sword, spear, or stone .
One who forges with the hammer; one who works in metals; as, a black smith , gold smith , silver smith , and the like .
Fine clay or ocher made up into balls, used for marking sheep.
A woman's under-garment; a shift; a chemise.
The visible exhalation, vapor, or substance that escapes, or expelled, from a burning body, especially from burning vegetable matter, as wood, coal, peat, or the like.
Emitting smoke, esp. in large quantities or in an offensive manner; fumid; as, smoky fires .
A young salmon two or three years old, when it has acquired its silvery color.
To suffocate or smother.
To smother. See Smoor .
imp. ( and rare p. p.) of Smite .
Studiously neat or nice, especially in dress; spruce; affectedly precise; smooth and prim.
Foul matter, like soot or coal dust; also, a spot or soil made by such matter.
A share; a part or portion; -- obsolete, except in the colloquial phrase, to go snacks , i. e., to share.
A stump or base of a branch that has been lopped off; a short branch, or a sharp or rough branch; a knot; a protuberance.

Any one of numerous species of terrestrial air-breathing gastropods belonging to the genus Helix and many allied genera of the family Helicidae . They are abundant in nearly all parts of the world except the arctic regions, and feed almost entirely on vegetation; a land snail.
Any species of the order Ophidia; an ophidian; a serpent, whether harmless or venomous. See Ophidia , and Serpent .
Of or pertaining to a snake or snakes; resembling a snake; serpentine; winding.
To break at once; to break short, as substances that are brittle.
To bevel the end of a timber to fit against an inclined surface.
A contrivance, often consisting of a noose of cord, or the like, by which a bird or other animal may be entangled and caught; a trap; a gin.
To form raised work upon the outer surface of (thin metal ware) by the repercussion of a snarling iron upon the inner surface.
Resembling, or consisting of, snares; entangling; insidious.
The snuff, or burnt wick, of a candle.
The handle of a scythe; a snead.
To creep or steal (away or about) privately; to come or go meanly, as a person afraid or ashamed to be seen; as, to sneak away from company .
To check; to reprimand; to rebuke; to chide.
To reprimand; to sneap.
To fasten by a hatch; to latch, as a door.
To lop; to snathe.
To show contempt by turning up the nose, or by a particular facial expression.
Active; brisk; nimble; quick; sharp.
The fat of a deer.
To snow; to abound.
To check; to sneap; to sneb.
A small cut or mark.
Tricky; deceptive; contemptible; as, a snide lawyer; snide goods.
To draw air audibly up the nose; to snuff; -- sometimes done as a gesture of suspicion, offense, or contempt.
To chop off; to cut.
To cut off the nip or neb of, or to cut off at once with shears or scissors; to clip off suddenly; to nip; hence, to break off; to snatch away.
Any one of numerous species of limicoline game birds of the family Scolopacidae , having a long, slender, nearly straight beak.
Like a snipe.
To blow, as the nose; to snuff, as a candle.
A vulgar person who affects to be better, richer, or more fashionable, than he really is; a vulgar upstart; one who apes his superiors.
A fillet; a headband; a snood.
A short candle end used for igniting a fuse.
The fillet which binds the hair of a young unmarried woman, and is emblematic of her maiden character.
To lurk; to lie in ambush.
To breathe with a rough, hoarse, nasal voice in sleep.
To force the air with violence through the nose, so as to make a noise, as do high-spirited horsed in prancing and play.
Mucus secreted in, or discharged from, the nose.
The long, projecting nose of a beast, as of swine.
A square-rigged vessel, differing from a brig only in that she has a trysail mast close abaft the mainmast, on which a large trysail is hoisted.
The hooded merganser.
White like snow.
To sob with convulsions.
The part of a candle wick charred by the flame, whether burning or not.
Close and warm; as, an infant lies snug .
An upward bend in a piece of timber; the sheer of a vessel.
In that manner or degree; as, indicated (in any way), or as implied, or as supposed to be known .

To cause or suffer to lie in a fluid till the substance has imbibed what it can contain; to macerate in water or other liquid; to steep, as for the purpose of softening or freshening; as, to soak cloth; to soak bread; to soak salt meat, salt fish, or the like.
Full of moisture; wet; soppy.
The sole of a shoe.
A chain by which a leading horse draws a plow.

A substance which dissolves in water, thus forming a lather, and is used as a cleansing agent. Soap is produced by combining fats or oils with alkalies or alkaline earths, usually by boiling, and consists of salts of sodium, potassium, etc., with the fatty acids (oleic, stearic, palmitic, etc.). See the Note below, and cf. Saponification . By extension, any compound of similar composition or properties, whether used as a cleaning agent or not.
Resembling soap; having the qualities of, or feeling like, soap; soft and smooth.
To fly aloft, as a bird; to mount upward on wings, or as on wings.
To sigh with a sudden heaving of the breast, or with a kind of convulsive motion; to sigh with tears, and with a convulsive drawing in of the breath.
Temperate in the use of spirituous liquors; habitually temperate; as, a sober man .
The lord's power or privilege of holding a court in a district, as in manor or lordship; jurisdiction of causes, and the limits of that jurisdiction.
A plowshare.
Wet; soaky.
A plain block or plinth forming a low pedestal; any base; especially, the base of a statue, column, or the like. See Plinth .
The rock dove.
Sodium oxide or hydroxide.
Consisting of sod; covered with sod; turfy.
See Solder .
Of or pertaining to sodium; containing sodium.
A large wooden vessel for holding water; a cowl.
A long seat, usually with a cushioned bottom, back, and ends; -- much used as a comfortable piece of furniture.
Same as Sufi .

Easily yielding to pressure; easily impressed, molded, or cut; not firm in resisting; impressible; yielding; also, malleable; -- opposed to hard ; as, a soft bed; a soft peach; soft earth; soft wood or metal.
Any one attached to a Mohammedan mosque, esp. a student of the higher branches of theology in a mosque school.
Var. of Soldier .
Filled with water; soft with moisture; sodden; soaked; wet; as, soggy land or timber .
Ho; -- a word used in calling from a distant place; a sportsman's halloo.

To feed, as cattle or horses, in the barn or an inclosure, with fresh grass or green food cut for them, instead of sending them out to pasture; hence (such food having the effect of purging them), to purge by feeding on green food; as, to soil a horse .
Dirty; soiled.
An Asiatic leguminous herb ( Glycine max , formerly Glycine Soja ) the seeds of which (called soy beans ) are used in preparing the sauce called soy . Called also soya .
Var. of Soldier .
A toll. See Soc , n. , 2.
An African anthropoid ape, supposed to be a variety of the chimpanzee.
A syllable applied in solmization to the note G, or to the fifth tone of any diatonic scale.
See Solus .
A loft or upper chamber; a garret room.
imp. & p. p. of Sell .
A small Italian coin worth a sou or a cent; the twentieth part of a lira.
Any one of several species of flatfishes of the genus Solea and allied genera of the family Soleidae , especially the common European species ( Solea vulgaris ), which is a valuable food fish.
A cradle, as for a broken limb. See Cradle , 6.
A loft or garret. See Solar , n.
pl. of Solo .

Having the constituent parts so compact, or so firmly adhering, as to resist the impression or penetration of other bodies; having a fixed form; hard; firm; compact; -- opposed to fluid and liquid or to plastic , like clay, or to incompact , like sand.
A tune, air, strain, or a whole piece, played by a single person on an instrument, or sung by a single voice.
A celebrated Athenian lawmaker, born about 638 b. c. ; hence, a legislator; a publicist; -- often used ironically.
Alone; -- chiefly used in stage directions, and the like.

To explain; to resolve; to unfold; to clear up (what is obscure or difficult to be understood); to work out to a result or conclusion; as, to solve a doubt; to solve difficulties; to solve a problem .
The whole axial portion of an animal, including the head, neck, trunk, and tail.
A society; a congregation, a worshiping assembly, or church, esp. of the Brahmo-somaj.

Consisting of a greater or less portion or sum; composed of a quantity or number which is not stated; -- used to express an indefinite quantity or number; as, some wine; some water; some persons . Used also pronominally; as, I have some .
A male child; the male issue, or offspring, of a parent, father or mother.
Lucky; fortunate; thriving; plump.
That which is sent; a message or messenger; hence, also, a visitation of providence; an affliction or trial.
That which is sung or uttered with musical modulations of the voice, whether of a human being or of a bird, insect, etc.
See Soncy .
In a short time; shortly after any time specified or supposed; as, soon after sunrise .
Skin of bacon.

A black substance formed by combustion, or disengaged from fuel in the process of combustion, which rises in fine particles, and adheres to the sides of the chimney or pipe conveying the smoke; strictly, the fine powder, consisting chiefly of carbon, which colors smoke, and which is the result of imperfect combustion. See Smoke .
True; faithful; trustworthy.
Of or pertaining to soot; producing soot; soiled by soot.
Anything steeped, or dipped and softened, in any liquid; especially, something dipped in broth or liquid food, and intended to be eaten.
A contraction of Soph ister .
Profound sleep from which a person can be roused only with difficulty.
Soaked or saturated with liquid or moisture; very wet or sloppy.
Above; before; over; upon.

A North American rail ( Porzana Carolina ) common in the Eastern United States. Its back is golden brown, varied with black and white, the front of the head and throat black, the breast and sides of the head and neck slate-colored. Called also American rail , Carolina rail , Carolina crake , common rail , sora rail , soree , meadow chicken , and orto .
The wild service tree ( Pyrus torminalis ) of Europe; also, the rowan tree.
See Sward .
Reddish brown; sorrel.
Same as Sora .
A young buck in the third year. See the Note under Buck .
A genus of small Insectivora, including the common shrews.
Indian millet and its varieties. See Sorghum .
pl. of Sorus .
To obtrude one's self on another for bed and board.
Grieved for the loss of some good; pained for some evil; feeling regret; -- now generally used to express light grief or affliction, but formerly often used to express deeper feeling.
A lot; also, a kind of divination by means of lots.
Chance; lot; destiny.
One of the fruit dots, or small clusters of sporangia, on the back of the fronds of ferns.
Green vitriol, or some earth imregnated with it.
The letters signified by the signal ( . . . --- . . . ) prescribed by the International Radiotelegraphic Convention of 1912 for use by ships in distress.
To fall at once into a chair or seat; to sit lazily.
A stupid person; a blockhead; a dull fellow; a dolt.
An old French copper coin, equivalent in value to, and now displaced by, the five-centime piece ( 1/20 of a franc), which is popularly called a sou .
See 1st Souse .
A small drain; an adit.
To afford suitable sustenance.
The air bladder of a fish; as, cod sounds are an esteemed article of food .
A liquid food of many kinds, usually made by boiling meat and vegetables, or either of them, in water, -- commonly seasoned or flavored; strong broth.
Resembling soup; souplike.
Having an acid or sharp, biting taste, like vinegar, and the juices of most unripe fruits; acid; tart.
Source. See Source .
A corrupt form of Sou.
Pickle made with salt.
That one of the four cardinal points directly opposite to the north; the region or direction to the right or direction to the right of a person who faces the east.
To sew. See Sew .
In India, a mounted soldier.
See Souse .
One who, or that which, sows.
To pull by the ears; to drag about.
p. p. of Sow .
See Souse .
A Chinese and Japanese liquid sauce for fish, etc., made by subjecting boiled beans (esp. soybeans), or beans and meal, to long fermentation and then long digestion in salt and water.
To solve, to clear up; as, to soyl all other texts .
A spring or mineral water; -- so called from a place of this name in Belgium.
A kind of spar; earth flax, or amianthus.
Extension, considered independently of anything which it may contain; that which makes extended objects conceivable and possible.
A nail one or two inches long, of iron, brass, tin, or tinner iron, with a hole through the flattened head, used to mark stations in underground surveying.
A hart or stag three years old.
Same as Spade , 2.
To foretell; to divine.
Formerly, one of the Turkish cavalry.
See 1st Spade .
imp. of Speak .
A lath; a shaving or chip, as of wood or stone.
The shoulder.
Liable to break or split; brittle; as, spalt timber .
imp. & p. p. of Spin .
To spangle.
To strike, as the breech, with the open hand; to slap.

An old name for a nonmetallic mineral, usually cleavable and somewhat lustrous; as, calc spar , or calcite, fluor spar , etc. It was especially used in the case of the gangue minerals of a metalliferous vein.
To use frugally or stintingly, as that which is scarce or valuable; to retain or keep unused; to save.
A small particle of fire or ignited substance which is emitted by a body in combustion.
Sparing; parsimonious.
An involuntary and unnatural contraction of one or more muscles or muscular fibers.
imp. of Spit .
A river flood; an overflow or inundation.
A splinter or fragment, as of wood or stone. See Spall .
To produce or deposit (eggs), as fishes or frogs do.
To remove or extirpate the ovaries of, as a sow or a bitch; to castrate (a female animal).
To utter words or articulate sounds, as human beings; to express thoughts by words; as, the organs may be so obstructed that a man may not be able to speak .
A long, pointed weapon, used in war and hunting, by thrusting or throwing; a weapon with a long shaft and a sharp head or blade; a lance.
Species; kind.
The blubber of whales or other marine mammals; also, the fat of the hippopotamus.
imp. & p. p. of Speed .
Prosperity in an undertaking; favorable issue; success.
To ask. See Spere .
A small stick or rod used as a spike in thatching; a splinter.
A spelk, or splinter.
imp. & p. p. of Spell . Spelled.
To weigh or lay out; to dispose of; to part with; as, to spend money for clothing .
Exhausted; worn out; having lost energy or motive force.
To shut in; to support; to inclose; to fasten.
To search; to pry; to ask; to inquire.
The male fecundating fluid; semen. See Semen .
To spit; to throw out.
To eject from the stomach; to vomit.
Wet; soggy; inclined to spew.
Any one of numerous species of sand wasps of the genus Sphex and allied genera. These wasps have the abdomen attached to the thorax by a slender pedicel. See Illust. of Sand wasp , under Sand .
A spy; a scout.
A kind of bandage passing, by successive turns and crosses, from an extremity to the trunk; -- so called from its resemblance to a spike of a barley.
Species; kind.
A spike or nail.
Flavored with, or containing, spice or spices; fragrant; aromatic; as, spicy breezes .
imp. & p. p. of Spy .
A sort of very large nail; also, a piece of pointed iron set with points upward or outward.
Like a spike; spikelike.
A small plug or wooden pin, used to stop a vent, as in a cask.
A bit of wood split off; a splinter.
imp. & p. p. of Spill . Spilled.
To draw out, and twist into threads, either by the hand or machinery; as, to spin wool, cotton, or flax; to spin goat's hair ; to produce by drawing out and twisting a fibrous material.
A sharp appendage to any of a plant; a thorn.
The chaffinch.
Full of spines; thorny; as, a spiny tree .
To breathe.
Same as Spurt .
Of a spiral form; wreathed; curled; serpentine.
Thick; crowded; compact; dense.
A long, slender, pointed rod, usually of iron, for holding meat while roasting.
Ill-will or hatred toward another, accompanied with the disposition to irritate, annoy, or thwart; petty malice; grudge; rancor; despite.
To display; to spread.

To divide lengthwise; to separate from end to end, esp. by force; to divide in the direction of the grain or layers; to rive; to cleave; as, to split a piece of timber or a board; to split a gem; to split a sheepskin .
To plunder; to strip by violence; to pillage; to rob; -- with of before the name of the thing taken; as, to spoil one of his goods or possessions .
imp. of Speak .
An irregular, narrow, projecting part of a field.
See Spunk .
A spirit; a ghost; an apparition; a hobgoblin.
A piece of cane or reed with a knot at each end, or a hollow cylinder of wood with a ridge at each end, used to wind thread or yarn upon.
To be driven steadily and swiftly, as before a strong wind; to be driven before the wind without any sail, or with only a part of the sails spread; to scud under bare poles.
See Spoom .
The track or trail of any wild animal; as, the spoor of an elephant; -- used originally by travelers in South Africa .
One of the minute grains in flowerless plants, which are analogous to seeds, as serving to reproduce the species.
That which diverts, and makes mirth; pastime; amusement.
A mark on a substance or body made by foreign matter; a blot; a place discolored.
To throw out forcibly and abundantly, as liquids through an orifice or a pipe; to eject in a jet; as, an elephant spouts water from his trunk .
p. p. of Spread .
A young salmon.
A small European herring ( Clupea sprattus ) closely allied to the common herring and the pilchard; -- called also garvie . The name is also applied to small herring of different kinds.
A small shoot or branch; a twig.
A merry frolic; especially, a drinking frolic; a carousal.
A small shoot or twig of a tree or other plant; a spray; as, a sprig of laurel or of parsley .
To throw out with force from a narrow orifice; to eject; to spurt out.
A salmon in its second year.
Strictly, the hole through which melted metal is poured into the gate, and thence into the mold.
To make smart.
Having great power of leaping or running; nimble; active.
A sharp, narrow spade, usually with a long handle, used by farmers for digging up large-rooted weeds; a similarly shaped implement used for various purposes.
See Spook .
Frothy matter raised on liquids by boiling, effervescence, or agitation; froth; foam; scum.
imp. & p. p. of Spin .
Wood that readily takes fire; touchwood; also, a kind of tinder made from a species of fungus; punk; amadou.

An implement secured to the heel, or above the heel, of a horseman, to urge the horse by its pressure. Modern spurs have a small wheel, or rowel, with short points. Spurs were the badge of knighthood.
To drive back or away, as with the foot; to kick.
To gush or issue suddenly or violently out in a stream, as liquor from a cask; to rush from a confined place in a small stream or jet; to spirt.
An annular reenforce, to strengthen a place where a hole is made.
To dispute; to discuss.
To gain sight of; to discover at a distance, or in a state of concealment; to espy; to see.
Fat; thick; plump; bulky.
A small party of men assembled for drill, inspection, or other purposes.
An oilskin hat or southwester; -- a fisherman's name.
The angel fish ( Squatina angelus ).
A female; a woman, especially a married woman; a wife; -- in the language of Indian tribes of the Algonquin family, correlative of sannup .
A little pipe, or hollow cylinder of paper, filled with powder or combustible matter, to be thrown into the air while burning, so as to burst there with a crack.

Any one of numerous species of ten-armed cephalopods having a long, tapered body, and a caudal fin on each side; especially, any species of Loligo , Ommastrephes , and related genera. See Calamary , Decacerata , Dibranchiata .
To throw with a jerk; to throw edge foremost.
Scum; refuse.
preceding all other objects or events in order, time, or importance; occurring before all other members of a series.
To pierce with a pointed weapon; to wound or kill by the thrust of a pointed instrument; as, to stab a man with a dagger ; also, to thrust; as, to stab a dagger into a person .

A large and to some degree orderly pile of hay, grain, straw, or the like, usually of a nearly conical form, but sometimes rectangular or oblong, contracted at the top to a point or ridge, and sometimes covered with thatch.
A landing place or wharf.
A long piece of wood; a stick; the long handle of an instrument or weapon; a pole or stick, used for many purposes; as, a surveyor's staff ; the staff of a spear or pike.
The adult male of the red deer ( Cervus elaphus ), a large European species closely related to the American elk, or wapiti.
A floor or story of a house.
Having an air or manner characteristic of the stage; theatrical; artificial; as, a stagy tone or bearing ; -- chiefly used depreciatively.
imp. & p. p. of Stay .
A handle, as of a mop; a stale.
To discolor by the application of foreign matter; to make foul; to spot; as, to stain the hand with dye; armor stained with blood .
One step of a series for ascending or descending to a different level; -- commonly applied to those within a building.
A piece of wood, usually long and slender, pointed at one end so as to be easily driven into the ground as a support or stay; as, a stake to support vines, fences, hedges, etc.
The stock or handle of anything; as, the stale of a rake .
The stem or main axis of a plant; as, a stalk of wheat, rye, or oats; the stalks of maize or hemp.
A stand; a station; a fixed spot; hence, the stand or place where a horse or an ox is kept and fed; the division of a stable, or the compartment, for one horse, ox, or other animal.
To strike beat, or press forcibly with the bottom of the foot, or by thrusting the foot downward.
To be at rest in an erect position; to be fixed in an upright or firm position
imp. of Sting .
Weak; worn out.
One of the innumerable luminous bodies seen in the heavens; any heavenly body other than the sun, moon, comets, and nebulae.
The starling.
Stiff; rigid.
