The European starling.
To leap; to jump.
The circumstances or condition of a being or thing at any given time.
Shortened form of statistics {2} (b) .

One of a number of narrow strips of wood, or narrow iron plates, placed edge to edge to form the sides, covering, or lining of a vessel or structure; esp., one of the strips which form the sides of a cask, a pail, etc.
To be fixed or set; to stay.

A large, strong rope, employed to support a mast, by being extended from the head of one mast down to some other, or to some part of the vessel. Those which lead forward are called fore-and-aft stays ; those which lead to the vessel's side are called backstays . See Illust. of Ship .
Place, or spot, in general.
A slice of beef, broiled, or cut for broiling; -- also extended to the meat of other large animals; as, venison steak ; bear steak ; pork steak ; turtle steak .
A handle; a stale, or stele.
The elastic, aeriform fluid into which water is converted when heated to the boiling point; water in the state of vapor; gaseous water.
See Steen .
See Stead , Steadfast , etc.
A horse, especially a spirited horse for state or war; -- used chiefly in poetry or stately prose.
To pierce with a sharp instrument; hence, to stitch; to sew; also, to fix; to fasten.

A variety of iron intermediate in composition and properties between wrought iron and cast iron (containing between one half of one per cent and one and a half per cent of carbon), and consisting of an alloy of iron with an iron carbide. Steel, unlike wrought iron, can be tempered, and retains magnetism. Its malleability decreases, and fusibility increases, with an increase in carbon.
See Esteem .
A vessel of clay or stone.
Bright; glittering; fiery.
A young male of the ox kind; especially, a common ox; a castrated taurine male from two to four years old. See the Note under Ox .
See Steek .
See Steen .
A small column or pillar, used as a monument, milestone, etc.
Same as Stela .
To place or fix firmly or permanently.
A gleam of light; flame.
To keep within limits; to restrain; to cause to stop, or cease; to stint.
To move the foot in walking; to advance or recede by raising and moving one of the feet to another resting place, or by moving both feet in succession.
A unit of cubic measure in the metric system, being a cubic meter, or kiloliter, and equal to 35.3 cubic feet, or nearly 1 1/3 cubic yards.
The black tern.
Let it stand; -- a word used by proof readers to signify that something once erased, or marked for omission, is to remain.
To pack or stow, as cargo in a ship's hold. See Steeve .
A small pond or pool where fish are kept for the table; a vivarium.
A sty on the eye. See Styan .
A verse, of whatever measure or number of feet.
A small shoot, or branch, separated, as by a cutting, from a tree or shrub; also, any stem or branch of a tree, of any size, cut for fuel or timber.
Not easily bent; not flexible or pliant; not limber or flaccid; rigid; firm; as, stiff wood, paper, joints .
A pin set on the face of a dial, to cast a shadow; a style. See Style .
Motionless; at rest; quiet; as, to stand still ; to lie or sit still .

A pole, or piece of wood, constructed with a step or loop to raise the foot above the ground in walking. It is sometimes lashed to the leg, and sometimes prolonged upward so as to be steadied by the hand or arm.
A slight gleam or glimmer; a glimpse.

Any sharp organ of offense and defense, especially when connected with a poison gland, and adapted to inflict a wound by piercing; as the caudal sting of a scorpion. The sting of a bee or wasp is a modified ovipositor. The caudal sting, or spine, of a sting ray is a modified dorsal fin ray. The term is sometimes applied to the fang of a serpent. See Illust. of Scorpion .
To emit a strong, offensive smell; to send out a disgusting odor.
Any one of several species of small sandpipers, as the sanderling of Europe and America, the dunlin, the little stint of India ( Tringa minuta ), etc. Called also pume .
The stalk or petiole of a frond, as of a fern.
To change the place of in any manner; to move.
A young bullock or heifer.
Stock; race; family.
Started; leaped.
Strong; stiff; rigid.
To stuff; to crowd; to fill full; hence, to make hot and close; to render stifling.
To stop; to choke.
The ermine in its summer pelage, when it is reddish brown, but with a black tip to the tail. The name is sometimes applied also to other brown weasels.
The stem, or main body, of a tree or plant; the fixed, strong, firm part; the trunk.
heavy; coarse; clumsy.

A disciple of the philosopher Zeno; one of a Greek sect which held that men should be free from passion, unmoved by joy or grief, and should submit without complaint to unavoidable necessity, by which all things are governed.
To stick; to thrust; to stab.
A long garment, descending to the ankles, worn by Roman women.
imp. of Steal .
One of the minute apertures between the cells in many serous membranes.
To stamp with the foot.
Stop; halt; hindrance.
Concreted earthy or mineral matter; also, any particular mass of such matter; as, a house built of stone ; the boy threw a stone ; pebbles are rounded stones .
3d pers. sing. present of Stand .
Of or pertaining to stone, consisting of, or abounding in, stone or stones; resembling stone; hard; as, a stony tower; a stony cave; stony ground; a stony crust .
imp. & p. p. of Stand .
A small collection of sheaves set up in the field; a shock; in England, twelve sheaves.
A plant from which layers are propagated by bending its branches into the soil.

Originally, a covered porch with seats, at a house door; the Dutch stoep as introduced by the Dutch into New York. Afterward, an out-of-door flight of stairs of from seven to fourteen steps, with platform and parapets, leading to an entrance door some distance above the street; the French perron . Hence, any porch, platform, entrance stairway, or small veranda, at a house door.
To rise in clouds, as dust.
To close, as an aperture, by filling or by obstructing; as, to stop the ears ; hence, to stanch, as a wound.
A horizontal working forming one of a series, the working faces of which present the appearance of a flight of steps.
See Stoor .
That which is accumulated, or massed together; a source from which supplies may be drawn; hence, an abundance; a great quantity, or a great number.

Any one of several species of large wading birds of the family Ciconidae , having long legs and a long, pointed bill. They are found both in the Old World and in America, and belong to Ciconia and several allied genera. The European white stork ( Ciconia alba ) is the best known. It commonly makes its nests on the top of a building, a chimney, a church spire, or a pillar. The black stork ( Ciconia nigra ) is native of Asia, Africa, and Europe.
A violent disturbance of the atmosphere, attended by wind, rain, snow, hail, or thunder and lightning; hence, often, a heavy fall of rain, snow, or hail, whether accompanied with wind or not.

A set of rooms on the same floor or level; a floor, or the space between two floors. Also, a horizontal division of a building's exterior considered architecturally, which need not correspond exactly with the stories within.
See Stoat .
A flagon; a vessel or measure for liquids.
A battle or tumult; encounter; combat; disturbance; passion.
Strong; lusty; vigorous; robust; sinewy; muscular; hence, firm; resolute; dauntless.
imp. of Stave .
To place or arrange in a compact mass; to put in its proper place, or in a suitable place; to pack; as, to stow bags, bales, or casks in a ship's hold; to stow hay in a mow; to stow sheaves .
To spring or recoil with violence.
A long, narrow, pliable strip of leather, cloth, or the like; specifically, a strip of thick leather used in flogging.
To spread or scatter. See Strew , and Strow .
To wander, as from a direct course; to deviate, or go out of the way.

To scatter; to spread by scattering; to cast or to throw loosely apart; -- used of solids, separated or separable into parts or particles; as, to strew seed in beds; to strew sand on or over a floor; to strew flowers over a grave.

A minute groove, or channel; a threadlike line, as of color; a narrow structural band or line; a striation; as, the striae , or groovings, produced on a rock by a glacier passing over it; the striae on the surface of a shell; a stria of nervous matter in the brain .
A narrow passage between precipitous rocks or banks, which looks as if it might be crossed at a stride.

To deprive; to bereave; to make destitute; to plunder; especially, to deprive of a covering; to skin; to peel; as, to strip a man of his possession, his rights, his privileges, his reputation; to strip one of his clothes; to strip a beast of his skin; to strip a tree of its bark.
One of the flutings of a column.
A strap; specifically, same as Strap , 3.
Same as Strew .
To destroy.
To play on an instrument of music, or as on an instrument, in an unskillful or noisy way; to thrum; as, to strum a piano .
To swell; to bulge out.
The stump of a tree; that part of a tree or plant which remains fixed in the earth when the stem is cut down; -- applied especially to the stump of a small tree, or shrub.
imp. & p. p. of Stick .
A collection of breeding horses and mares, or the place where they are kept; also, a number of horses kept for a racing, riding, etc.
A setting of the mind or thoughts upon a subject; hence, application of mind to books, arts, or science, or to any subject, for the purpose of acquiring knowledge.
A jet of steam issuing from a fissure in the earth.
Material which is to be worked up in any process of manufacture.
A framework of timber covered with boards to support rubbish; also, a framework of boards to protect miners from falling stones.
A shaft or gallery to drain a mine.
A short, stout post used for any purpose, a to mark a boundary.
Unfermented grape juice or wine, often used to raise fermentation in dead or vapid wines; must.
The part of a tree or plant remaining in the earth after the stem or trunk is cut off; the stub.
To make senseless or dizzy by violence; to render senseless by a blow, as on the head.
imp. & p. p. of Sting .
imp. & p. p. of Stink .
To hinder from growing to the natural size; to prevent the growth of; to stint, to dwarf; as, to stunt a child; to stunt a plant .
A mound or monument commemorative of Buddha.
Cloth or flax dipped in warm water or medicaments and applied to a hurt or sore.
To disturb.
See Stirk .
To vex; to annoy; to startle.
To stutter.
A pen or inclosure for swine.
See Sty , a boil.
An anglo-Saxon copper coin of the lowest value, being worth half a farthing.
See Sty , a boil.

An instrument used by the ancients in writing on tablets covered with wax, having one of its ends sharp, and the other blunt, and somewhat expanded, for the purpose of making erasures by smoothing the wax.
The principal river of the lower world, which had to be crossed in passing to the regions of the dead.
To persuade.
To assuage.
Spread equally over the surface; uniform; even.
Sweet; pleasant; delightful; gracious or agreeable in manner; bland.
A subordinate; a subaltern.
A province; a government, as of a viceroy; also, a subahdar.

Of that kind; of the like kind; like; resembling; similar; as, we never saw such a day ; -- followed by that or as introducing the word or proposition which defines the similarity, or the standard of comparison; as, the books are not such that I can recommend them, or, not such as I can recommend; these apples are not such as those we saw yesterday; give your children such precepts as tend to make them better .

To draw, as a liquid, by the action of the mouth and tongue, which tends to produce a vacuum, and causes the liquid to rush in by atmospheric pressure; to draw, or apply force to, by exhausting the air.
A silver coin of Ecuador, worth 68 cents (ca. 1900).
A tangled mass of floating vegetal matter obstructing navigation.
The lowest of the four great castes among the Hindoos. See Caste .
Water impregnated with soap, esp. when worked up into bubbles and froth.
To follow up; to chase; to seek after; to endeavor to win; to woo.
Swedish glove leather, -- usually made from lambskins tanned with willow bark. Also used adjectively; as, suede gloves; blue suede shoes .
Uniformly or evenly distributed or spread; even; smooth. See Suant .
One who sues; a suitor.
The fat and fatty tissues of an animal, especially the harder fat about the kidneys and loins in beef and mutton, which, when melted and freed from the membranes, forms tallow.
Consisting of, or resembling, suet; as, a suety substance .
A title or surname of the king of Persia.
A kind of worm or larva.

A sweet white (or brownish yellow) crystalline substance, of a sandy or granular consistency, obtained by crystallizing the evaporated juice of certain plants, as the sugar cane, sorghum, beet root, sugar maple, etc. It is used for seasoning and preserving many kinds of food and drink. Ordinary sugar is essentially sucrose. See the Note below.
A mixture of oleomargarine with lard or other fatty ingredients. It is used as a substitute for butter. See Butterine .
The process of soaking through anything.
A peculiar substance obtained from the wool of sheep, consisting largely of potash mixed with fatty and earthy matters. It is used as a source of potash and also for the manufacture of gas.
One who seeks for things which gratify merely himself; a selfish person; a selfist.
The act of following or pursuing, as game; pursuit.
A retinue or company of attendants, as of a distinguished personage; as, the suite of an ambassador . See Suit , n. , 5.
Indian wheat, granulated but not pulverized; a kind of semolina.
A genus of sea birds including the booby and the common gannet.
To be silently sullen; to be morose or obstinate.
The condition of being sulky; a sulky mood or humor; as, to be in the sulks .
Moodly silent; sullen; sour; obstinate; morose; splenetic.
To soil; to dirty; to spot; to tarnish; to stain; to darken; -- used literally and figuratively; as, to sully a sword; to sully a person's reputation .
A member of the most prominent tribe of the Moro tribes, occupying the Sulu Archipelago; also, their language.
The aggregate of two or more numbers, magnitudes, quantities, or particulars; the amount or whole of any number of individuals or particulars added together; as, the sum of 5 and 7 is 12 .

Any plant of the genus Rhus , shrubs or small trees with usually compound leaves and clusters of small flowers. Some of the species are used in tanning, some in dyeing, and some in medicine. One, the Japanese Rhus vernicifera , yields the celebrated Japan varnish, or lacquer.
A round pit of stone, lined with clay, for receiving the metal on its first fusion.
A dunce; a blockhead.

The luminous orb, the light of which constitutes day, and its absence night; the central body round which the earth and planets revolve, by which they are held in their orbits, and from which they receive light and heat. Its mean distance from the earth is about 92,500,000 miles, and its diameter about 860,000.
imp. & p. p. of Sing .
imp. & p. p. of Sink .
An East Indian leguminous plant ( Crotalaria juncea ) and its fiber, which is also called sunn hemp .
A collection of traditions received by the orthodox Mohammedans as of equal authority with the Koran.
Of or pertaining to the sun; proceeding from, or resembling the sun; hence, shining; bright; brilliant; radiant.
To take into the mouth with the lips, as a liquid; to take or drink by a little at a time; to sip.
A contraction of Supernumerary , in sense 2.
Over; above; before; also, beyond; besides; -- much used as a prefix.
One of the sections or chapters of the Koran, which are one hundred and fourteen in number.
A soft twilled silk fabric much used for women's dresses; -- called also surah silk .
Of or pertaining to the calf of the leg; as, the sural arteries .
Net having the sense of hearing; deaf.
Certainly knowing and believing; confident beyond doubt; implicity trusting; unquestioning; positive.
The swell of the sea which breaks upon the shore, esp. upon a sloping beach.
Consisting of, abounding in, or resembling, surf; as, a surfy shore .
A spring; a fountain.
Rising in surges or billows; full of surges; resembling surges in motion or appearance; swelling.
Arrogant; haughty.
See Soosoo .
A kind of sirup made by the Indians of Arizona from the fruit of some cactaceous plant (probably the Cereus giganteus ).
A precept; an aphorism; a brief rule.
To clean with a mop or swab; to wipe when very wet, as after washing; as, to swab the desk of a ship .
A cod, or pod, as of beans or pease.
To hang or move, as something loose and heavy; to sway; to swing.
See Assuage .
To walk proudly; to sweep along.
A valley or low place; a tract of low, and usually wet, land; a moor; a fen.
imp. of Swim .
Wet, spongy land; soft, low ground saturated with water, but not usually covered with it; marshy ground away from the seashore.

Any one of numerous species of large aquatic birds belonging to Cygnus , Olor , and allied genera of the subfamily Cygninae . They have a large and strong beak and a long neck, and are noted for their graceful movements when swimming. Most of the northern species are white. In literature the swan was fabled to sing a melodious song, especially at the time of its death.
imp. of Swing .
To strike; -- with off .
See Sweep , n. , 12.
Skin; covering.
imp. of Swear .
To grow languid; to faint.
To climb a tree, pole, or the like, by embracing it with the arms and legs alternately. See Shin .
Of a dark hue; moderately black; swarthy; tawny.
An oval figure, whose moldings are oblique to the axis of the work.
imp. of Sweat .
imp. of Sweat .
A line of grass or grain cut and thrown together by the scythe in mowing or cradling.
To move or wield with the hand; to swing; to wield; as, to sway the scepter .
To melt and run down, as the tallow of a candle; to waste away without feeding the flame.

To affirm or utter a solemn declaration, with an appeal to God for the truth of what is affirmed; to make a promise, threat, or resolve on oath; also, to affirm solemnly by some sacred object, or one regarded as sacred, as the Bible, the Koran, etc.
To excrete sensible moisture from the pores of the skin; to perspire.
A native or inhabitant of Sweden.

To pass a broom across (a surface) so as to remove loose dirt, dust, etc.; to brush, or rub over, with a broom for the purpose of cleaning; as, to sweep a floor, the street, or a chimney . Used also figuratively.
Having an agreeable taste or flavor such as that of sugar; saccharine; -- opposed to sour and bitter ; as, a sweet beverage; sweet fruits; sweet oranges.

To grow larger; to dilate or extend the exterior surface or dimensions, by matter added within, or by expansion of the inclosed substance; as, the legs swell in dropsy; a bruised part swells ; a bladder swells by inflation.
imp. of Swell .
imp. & p. p. of Sweep .
See Sward , n. & v.
Moving a great distance in a short time; moving with celerity or velocity; fleet; rapid; quick; speedy; prompt.
To drink in long draughts; to gulp; as, to swig cider .
To wash; to drench.
To be supported by water or other fluid; not to sink; to float; as, any substance will swim , whose specific gravity is less than that of the fluid in which it is immersed .

Any animal of the hog kind, especially one of the domestical species. Swine secrete a large amount of subcutaneous fat, which, when extracted, is known as lard . The male is specifically called boar , the female, sow , and the young, pig . See Hog .
To move to and fro, as a body suspended in the air; to wave; to vibrate; to oscillate.
To labor; to toil; to salve.
A swape or sweep. See Sweep .
To whirl, or cause to whirl, as in an eddy.
To flourish, so as to make the sound swish .
A native or inhabitant of Switzerland; a Switzer; the people of Switzerland.
To copulate with (a woman).
Contraction of Swollen , p. p.
imp. of Swim .
To sink into a fainting fit, in which there is an apparent suspension of the vital functions and mental powers; to faint; -- often with away .
To fall on at once and seize; to catch while on the wing; as, a hawk swoops a chicken .
Same as Swap .
An offensive weapon, having a long and usually sharp-pointed blade with a cutting edge or edges. It is the general term, including the small sword, rapier, saber, scimiter, and many other varieties.
imp. of Swear .
p. p. of Swear .
imp. & p. p. of Swim .
imp. & p. p. of Swing .
Silver, pounded into ingots of the shape of a shoe, and used as currency. The most common weight is about one pound troy.
See Sicker .
A young herring ( Clupea harengus ).
An imaginary being inhabiting the air; a fairy.
Same as Silva .
See Simar .
Afterwards; since; ago.
An ecclesiastic council or meeting to consult on church matters.
See Siren .
A long dress, trailing on the floor, worn by tragic actors in Greek and Roman theaters.
A quicksand; a bog.
Same as Sirup , Sirupy .
See Sith , Sithe .
A heap. See Tas .
The flap or latchet of a shoe fastened with a string or a buckle.
A kind of waved silk, usually called watered silk , manufactured like taffeta, but thicker and stronger. The watering is given to it by calendering.
Same as Tabor .
Progressive emaciation of the body, accompanied with hectic fever, with no well-marked local symptoms.
Affected by tabes; tabetic.
A smooth, flat surface, like the side of a board; a thin, flat, smooth piece of anything; a slab.

A total prohibition of intercourse with, use of, or approach to, a given person or thing under pain of death, -- an interdict of religious origin and authority, formerly common in the islands of Polynesia; interdiction.
A small drum used as an accompaniment to a pipe or fife, both being played by the same person.
See Taboo .
A kind of customary payment by a tenant; -- a word used in old records.
The cross, or church, of St. Antony. See Illust. (6), under Cross , n.
It is silent; -- a direction for a vocal or instrumental part to be silent during a whole movement.
Something used for taking hold or holding; a catch; a loop; a button.
Done or made in silence; implied, but not expressed; silent; as, tacit consent is consent by silence, or by not interposing an objection .
A stain; a tache.
Sticky; somewhat adhesive;; -- said of paint, varnish, etc., when not well dried.
The sense of touch; feeling.
A denomination of money, in China, worth nearly six shillings sterling, or about a dollar and forty cents; also, a weight of one ounce and a third.
p. p. of Ta , to take, or a contraction of Taken .
A kind of candy made of molasses or brown sugar boiled down and poured out in shallow pans.
A variety of rum.
Any slight appendage, as to an article of dress; something slight hanging loosely; specifically, a direction card, or label.
One of a Malayan race, mainly of central Luzon, next to the Visayans the most numerous of the native peoples of the Philippines. Nearly all are Christians and many are highly educated.
The African rufous-necked weaver bird ( Hyphantornis texor ).
Same as Thar .
Designating, or pertaining to, the chief linguistic stock of Indo-China, including the peoples of Siamese and Shan speech. It includes the Thai language.
Limitation; abridgment.
Thin tin plate; also, tin foil for mirrors.
A thrust with a lance, which fails of its intended effect.
Same as Tayra .

A small nocturnal and arboreal Australian marsupial ( Tarsipes rostratus ) about the size of a mouse. It has a long muzzle, a long tongue, and very few teeth, and feeds upon honey and insects. Called also noolbenger .
In an active sense; To lay hold of; to seize with the hands, or otherwise; to grasp; to get into one's hold or possession; to procure; to seize and carry away; to convey.
p. p. of Take .
One who takes or receives; one who catches or apprehends.

A soft mineral of a soapy feel and a greenish, whitish, or grayish color, usually occurring in foliated masses. It is hydrous silicate of magnesia. Steatite , or soapstone , is a compact granular variety.
That which is told; an oral relation or recital; any rehearsal of what has occured; narrative; discourse; statement; history; story.
A kind of quadrangular piece of cloth put on by the Jews when repeating prayers in the synagogues.
Persons added to a jury, commonly from those in or about the courthouse, to make up any deficiency in the number of jurors regularly summoned, being like, or such as, the latter.
To utter words; esp., to converse familiarly; to speak, as in familiar discourse, when two or more persons interchange thoughts.

High in stature; having a considerable, or an unusual, extension upward; long and comparatively slender; having the diameter or lateral extent small in proportion to the height; as, a tall person, tree, or mast .
Originally, a piece of wood on which notches or scores were cut, as the marks of number; later, one of two books, sheets of paper, etc., on which corresponding accounts were kept.
A kind of large cape, or short, full cloak, forming part of the dress of ladies.
The claw of a predaceous bird or animal, especially the claw of a bird of prey.
A genus of small insectivores including the common European mole.
The astragalus.
To broach or enter upon; to taste, as a liquor; to divide; to distribute; to deal out.
One who tames or subdues.
Of or pertaining to the Tamils, or to their language.
A sieve, or strainer, made of a kind of woolen cloth.
A kind of woolen, or woolen and cotton, cloth, often highly glazed, -- used for curtains, sieves, strainers, etc.
In blasting, to plug up with clay, earth, dry sand, sod, or other material, as a hole bored in a rock, in order to prevent the force of the explosion from being misdirected.
See Picul .
Same as Banxring .
A term used among Jews for the Hebrew Bible; the Old Testament.
A coarse blackish seaweed ( Fucus nodosus ).

A difficult dance in two-four time characterized by graceful posturing, frequent pointing positions, and a great variety of steps, including the cross step and turning steps. The dance is of Spanish origin, and is believed to have been in its original form a part of the fandango.
A small Indian dry measure, averaging 240 grains in weight; also, a Bombay weight of 72 grains, for pearls.
A kind of boat used in Canton. It is about 25 feet long and is often rowed by women. Called also tankia .

Any plant of the composite genus Tanacetum . The common tansy ( Tanacetum vulgare ) has finely divided leaves, a strong aromatic odor, and a very bitter taste. It is used for medicinal and culinary purposes.
A small scarlet arachnid.
To strike with a slight or gentle blow; to touch gently; to rap lightly; to pat; as, to tap one with the hand or a cane .
A kind of cloth prepared by the Polynesians from the inner bark of the paper mulberry; -- sometimes called also kapa .
A narrow fillet or band of cotton or linen; a narrow woven fabric used for strings and the like; as, curtains tied with tape .
A small wax candle; a small lighted wax candle; hence, a small light.
Worked or figured stuff; tapestry.

Any one of several species of large odd-toed ungulates belonging to Tapirus , Elasmognathus , and allied genera. They have a long prehensile upper lip, short ears, short and stout legs, a short, thick tail, and short, close hair. They have three toes on the hind feet, and four toes on the fore feet, but the outermost toe is of little use.
Tapestry; formerly, the cover of a council table.
A sailor; a seaman.
Slow; -- a direction to perform a passage slowly.
Moving with a slow pace or motion; slow; not swift.
A weed that grows among wheat and other grain; -- alleged by modern naturalists to be the Lolium temulentum , or darnel.
Weighed; determined; reduced to equal or standard weight; as, tared filter papers, used in weighing precipitates .
A shield or target.
The siskin.
A mountain lake or pool.

A name for several aroid plants ( Colocasia antiquorum , var. esculenta , Colocasia macrorhiza , etc.), and their rootstocks. They have large ovate-sagittate leaves and large fleshy tuberous rootstocks, which are cooked and used for food in tropical countries.
A game of cards; -- called also taroc .
To set on, as a dog; to incite.
Consisting of, or covered with, tar; like tar.
The male falcon.
pl. of Tarsus .
Sharp to the taste; acid; sour; as, a tart apple .
A kind of clay for making melting pots.
Labor or study imposed by another, often in a definite quantity or amount.
A piece of armor for the thighs, forming an appendage to the ancient corselet.
To try by the touch; to handle; as, to taste a bow .
A key or thing touched to produce a tone.
Having a good taste; -- applied to persons; as, a tasty woman . See Taste , n. , 5.
Gunny cloth made from the fiber of the Corchorus olitorius , or jute.
A spot or stain; also, a trick.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Ta , to take.

The giant armadillo ( Priodontes gigas ) of tropical South America. It becomes nearly five feet long including the tail. It is noted for its burrowing powers, feeds largely upon dead animals, and sometimes invades human graves.
To make (anything) by tatting; to work at tatting; as, tatted edging .
A bamboo frame or trellis hung at a door or window of a house, over which water is suffered to trickle, in order to moisten and cool the air as it enters.
A mat or screen of fibers, as of the kuskus grass, hung at a door or window and kept wet to moisten and cool the air as it enters.
Same as Tatou .
The nineteenth letter (Τ, τ) of the Greek alphabet, equivalent to English t .
Very high or tall; as, a ship with taunt masts .
The constellation Taurus.
Tight; stretched; not slack; -- said esp. of a rope that is tightly strained.
To push; to tug; to tow.
One who taws; a dresser of white leather.
Of a dull yellowish brown color, like things tanned, or persons who are sunburnt; as, tawny Moor or Spaniard; the tawny lion .
A leather lash, or other instrument of punishment, used by a schoolmaster.
A charge, especially a pecuniary burden which is imposed by authority.
The American badger.
One who taxes.
same as taxicab .
Manipulation applied to a hernial tumor, or to an intestinal obstruction, for the purpose of reducing it.
a taxonomic group, or the name of a taxonomic grouping.
Same as Taxer , n. , 2.
A South American carnivore ( Galera barbara ) allied to the grison. The tail is long and thick. The length, including the tail, is about three feet.
The teasel.
An ornamental cup or vase with a large, flat, shallow bowl, resting on a pedestal and often having handles.
See under T .

A type of white blood cell that circulates in the blood and lymph, and provides cell-mediated immunity for the organism, protecting against infecting cells or the body's own malignant cells; also called T lymphocyte . There are several types of T cells. They develop, as do B cells, from progenitor cells in the bone marrow, but are distinguished from B-cells (B-lymphocytes) by their site of differentiation; T-cells mature in the thymus and B-cells in the bone marrow (in birds in the Bursa of Fabricius). They also have different antigen receptors from those of B-cells. T-cells differentiate into cells that can directly kill infecting cells (cell-mediated immunity, cytotoxity) or activate other cells of the immune system (helper T cells), whereas B-cells differentiate on activation into antibody-secreting plasma cells. Helper T cells interact with B-cells by secreting lymphokines that stimulate the B cell which have detected a foreign antigen to enter the cell cycle and develop, by repeated mitosis, into a clone of cells with identical receptors, and then to secrete antibodies to that specific antigen.
The prepared leaves of a shrub, or small tree ( Thea Chinensis or Camellia Chinensis ). The shrub is a native of China, but has been introduced to some extent into some other countries.

To impart the knowledge of; to give intelligence concerning; to impart, as knowledge before unknown, or rules for practice; to inculcate as true or important; to exhibit impressively; as, to teach arithmetic, dancing, music, or the like; to teach morals.
A tree of East Indies ( Tectona grandis ) which furnishes an extremely strong and durable timber highly valued for shipbuilding and other purposes; also, the timber of the tree.

Any one of several species of small fresh-water ducks of the genus Anas and the subgenera Querquedula and Nettion . The male is handsomely colored, and has a bright green or blue speculum on the wings.
A group of young animals, especially of young ducks; a brood; a litter.

A drop of the limpid, saline fluid secreted, normally in small amount, by the lachrymal gland, and diffused between the eye and the eyelids to moisten the parts and facilitate their motion. Ordinarily the secretion passes through the lachrymal duct into the nose, but when it is increased by emotion or other causes, it overflows the lids.
Wet with tears; tearful.
To comb or card, as wool or flax.
The protuberance through which milk is drawn from the udder or breast of a mammal; a nipple; a pap; a mammilla; a dug; a tit.
Peevish; fretful; irritable.
See Tucum .
To spread, or turn from the swath, and scatter for drying, as new-mowed grass; -- chiefly used in the past participle.
The gate of a mold, through which the melted metal is poured; runner, geat.
The mark aimed at in curling and in quoits.
To pour; -- commonly followed by out ; as, to teem out ale .
Grief; sorrow; affiction; pain.
To kindle; to burn.
The years of one's age having the termination -teen , beginning with thirteen and ending with nineteen; as, a girl in her teens .
Very small; tiny.
A tinsmith's stake, or small anvil.
pl. of Tooth .
A sheep in its second year; also, a doe in its second year.
The lime tree, or linden; -- called also teil tree .
See Teyne .
Tint; color; tinge, See Tint .
A Siberian ibex.
Denoting the final end or purpose, as distinguished from ecbatic . See Ecbatic .
To mention one by one, or piece by piece; to recount; to enumerate; to reckon; to number; to count; as, to tell money .
The rate or degree of movement in time.
To put to trial; to prove; to test; to try.
One more than nine; twice five.
A European fresh-water fish ( Tinca tinca , or Tinca vulgaris ) allied to the carp. It is noted for its tenacity of life.
To make a tender of; to offer or tender.
See 1st and 2d Teen .
Any opinion, principle, dogma, belief, or doctrine, which a person holds or maintains as true; as, the tenets of Plato or of Cicero .
See Taenia .
Lit., King of Heaven; -- a title of the emperor of Japan as the head of the Shinto religion.

A projecting member left by cutting away the wood around it, and made to insert into a mortise, and in this way secure together the parts of a frame; especially, such a member when it passes entirely through the thickness of the piece in which the mortise is cut, and shows on the other side. Cf. Tooth , Tusk .
A state of holding on in a continuous course; manner of continuity; constant mode; general tendency; course; career.

One of the forms which a verb takes by inflection or by adding auxiliary words, so as to indicate the time of the action or event signified; the modification which verbs undergo for the indication of time.
A kind of wine of a deep red color, chiefly from Galicia or Malaga in Spain; -- called also tent wine , and tinta .
Next in order after the ninth; coming after nine others.
A division of a perianth.
An Indian wigwam or tent.
Moderately warm; lukewarm; as, a tepid bath; tepid rays; tepid vapors.
Gentle heat; moderate warmth; tepidness.
See Tierce .
A sandpiper ( Terekia cinerea ) of the Old World, breeding in the far north of eastern Europe and Asia and migrating to South Africa and Australia. It frequents rivers.
Round; terete.
A small yellow singing bird, with an ash-colored head; the European siskin. Called also tarin .
That which limits the extent of anything; limit; extremity; bound; boundary.
The terminal lamina, or thin ventral part, of the anterior wall of the third ventricle of the brain.
Any one of numerous species of long-winged aquatic birds, allied to the gulls, and belonging to Sterna and various allied genera.
The earth; earth.
A kind of heavy colored fabric, either all silk, or silk and worsted, or silk and cotton, often called terry velvet , used for upholstery and trimmings.
Appearing as if rubbed or wiped off; rubbed; smooth; polished.
A cupel or cupelling hearth in which precious metals are melted for trial and refinement.
Fretful; peevish; petulant; easily irritated.
A large African antelope ( Alcelaphus tora ). It has widely divergent, strongly ringed horns.
Testy; irritable.
The redshank.
To prepare by beating or working, as leather or hemp; to taw.
A tribe of American Indians including many of the Pueblos of New Mexico and adjacent regions.
Fatigued; worn with labor or hardship.
A pipe, funnel, or chimney, as for smoke.
A structure on the hurricane deck of a steamer, containing the pilot house, officers' cabins, etc.
A discourse or composition on which a note or commentary is written; the original words of an author, in distinction from a paraphrase, annotation, or commentary.
A thin plate of metal.
coming next after the nine hundred ninety-ninth in a series
See Thatch , Thatcher .
The language of Thailand (Siam); it is a member of the Tai group of languages.

A particle expressing comparison, used after certain adjectives and adverbs which express comparison or diversity, as more , better , other , otherwise , and the like. It is usually followed by the object compared in the nominative case. Sometimes, however, the object compared is placed in the objective case, and than is then considered by some grammarians as a preposition. Sometimes the object is expressed in a sentence, usually introduced by that ; as, I would rather suffer than that you should want .
A police station.

A dignitary under the Anglo-Saxons and Danes in England. Of these there were two orders, the king's thanes, who attended the kings in their courts and held lands immediately of them, and the ordinary thanes, who were lords of manors and who had particular jurisdiction within their limits. After the Conquest, this title was disused, and baron took its place.
A expression of gratitude; an acknowledgment expressive of a sense of favor or kindness received; obligation, claim, or desert, or gratitude; -- now generally used in the plural.

A goatlike animal ( Capra Jemlaica ) native of the Himalayas. It has small, flattened horns, curved directly backward. The hair of the neck, shoulders, and chest of the male is very long, reaching to the knees. Called also serow , and imo .

As a demonstrative pronoun ( pl. Those ), that usually points out, or refers to, a person or thing previously mentioned, or supposed to be understood. That , as a demonstrative, may precede the noun to which it refers; as, that which he has said is true; those in the basket are good apples.
Same as theave .
To melt, dissolve, or become fluid; to soften; -- said of that which is frozen; as, the ice thaws .
Liquefying by heat after having been frozen; thawing; melting.
A word placed before nouns to limit or individualize their meaning.
A genus of plants found in China and Japan; the tea plant.
A sheath; a case; as, the theca , or cell, of an anther; the theca , or spore case, of a fungus; the theca of the spinal cord.
To thrive; to prosper.
The act of stealing; specifically, the felonious taking and removing of personal property, with an intent to deprive the rightful owner of the same; larceny.
Thane. See Thane .
The possessive case of the personal pronoun they ; as, their houses; their country .
The objective case of they. See They .
A subject or topic on which a person writes or speaks; a proposition for discussion or argument; a text.
At that time (referring to a time specified, either past or future).
In or at that place.
Not fermented; unleavened; -- said of bread, loaves, etc.
one of several units of heat, especially one equivalent to 1000 large calories, or 100,000 British thermal units.
The plural of this . See This .

A letter of the Greek alphabet corresponding to th in English; -- sometimes called the unlucky letter, from being used by the judges on their ballots in passing condemnation on a prisoner, it being the first letter of the Greek qa`natos , death.
Manner; custom; habit; form of behavior; qualities of mind; disposition; specifically, good qualities; virtues.
Having strong or large thews or muscles; muscular; sinewy; strong.
The plural of he , she , or it . They is never used adjectively, but always as a pronoun proper, and sometimes refers to persons without an antecedent expressed.
Measuring in the third dimension other than length and breadth, or in general dimension other than length; -- said of a solid body; as, a timber seven inches thick .
One who steals; one who commits theft or larceny. See Theft .
The proximal segment of the hind limb between the knee and the trunk. See Femur .
That same; this; that.
One of the two long pieces of wood, extending before a vehicle, between which a horse is hitched; a shaft.
Having little thickness or extent from one surface to its opposite; as, a thin plate of metal; thin paper; a thin board; a thin covering.

A form of the possessive case of the pronoun thou , now superseded in common discourse by your , the possessive of you , but maintaining a place in solemn discourse, in poetry, and in the usual language of the Friends, or Quakers.
Whatever exists, or is conceived to exist, as a separate entity, whether animate or inanimate; any separable or distinguishable object of thought.
To seem or appear; -- used chiefly in the expressions methinketh or methinks , and methought .
Next after the second; coming after two others; -- the ordinal of three; as, the third hour in the day .
To bore; to drill or thrill. See Thrill .
As a demonstrative pronoun, this denotes something that is present or near in place or time, or something just mentioned, or that is just about to be mentioned.
A wooden or metal pin, set in the gunwale of a boat, to serve as a fulcrum for the oar in rowing.
A strap of leather; especially, one used for fastening anything.
The god of thunder, and son of Odin.
A hard and sharp-pointed projection from a woody stem; usually, a branch so transformed; a spine.
A group of houses in the country; a small village; a hamlet; a dorp; -- now chiefly occurring in names of places and persons; as, Al thorp , Mable thorpe .
The plural of that . See That .

The god of eloquence and letters among the ancient Egyptians, and supposed to be the inventor of writing and philosophy. He corresponded to the Mercury of the Romans, and was usually represented as a human figure with the head of an ibis or a lamb.
The second personal pronoun, in the singular number, denoting the person addressed; thyself; the pronoun which is used in addressing persons in the solemn or poetical style.
See Throse .
One more than two; two and one.
imp. of Throw .
To pass through in the manner of a thread or a needle; to make or find a course through; to thread.
To beat, or pulsate, with more than usual force or rapidity; to beat in consequence of agitation; to palpitate; -- said of the heart, pulse, etc.
Extreme pain; violent pang; anguish; agony; especially, one of the pangs of travail in childbirth, or purturition.
Pain; especially, pain of travail; throe.
One of the ends of weaver's threads; hence, any soft, short threads or tufts resembling these.

A dull sound without resonance, like that produced by striking with, or striking against, some comparatively soft substance; also, the stroke or blow producing such sound; as, the thrud of a cannon ball striking the earth .
One of an association of robbers and murderers in India who practiced murder by stealthy approaches, and from religious motives. They have been nearly exterminated by the British government.
A genus of evergreen trees, thickly branched, remarkable for the distichous arrangement of their branches, and having scalelike, closely imbricated, or compressed leaves.

The name given by ancient geographers to the northernmost part of the habitable world. According to some, this land was Norway, according to others, Iceland, or more probably Mainland, the largest of the Shetland islands; hence, the Latin phrase ultima Thule , farthest Thule.
The short, thick first digit of the human hand, differing from the other fingers in having but two phalanges; the pollex. See Pollex .
The sound made by the sudden fall or blow of a heavy body, as of a hammer, or the like.
A hole; an aperture.
The commoner kind of frankincense, or that obtained from the Norway spruce, the long-leaved pine, and other conifers.
Same as Thuja .

Of thee, or belonging to thee; the more common form of thine , possessive case of thou ; -- used always attributively, and chiefly in the solemn or grave style, and in poetry. Thine is used in the predicate; as, the knife is thine . See Thine .
Any plant of the labiate genus Thymus . The garden thyme ( Thymus vulgaris ) is a warm, pungent aromatic, much used to give a relish to seasoning and soups.
Abounding with thyme; fragrant; as, a thymy vale .

A form of headdress worn by the ancient Persians. According to Xenophon, the royal tiara was encircled with a diadem, and was high and erect, while those of the people were flexible, or had rims turned over.
The inner, or preaxial, and usually the larger, of the two bones of the leg or hind limb below the knee.
A local and habitual convulsive motion of certain muscles; especially, such a motion of some of the muscles of the face; twitching; velication; -- called also spasmodic tic .
A bean-shaped coin of Siam, worth about sixty cents; also, a weight equal to 236 grains troy.
A ball bowled to strike the ground about a bat's length in front of the wicket.
Credit; trust; as, to buy on, or upon, tick .
Tender; soft; nice; -- now only used in tid bit.
Of or pertaining to tides; caused by tides; having tides; periodically rising and falling, or following and ebbing; as, tidal waters .
imp. of Tide , v. i.
Time; period; season.
Affected by the tide; having a tide.
The wren; -- called also tiddy .
A knot; a fastening.
One who, or that which, ties.
Liquor; especially, a small draught of liquor.
A fit of pettishness, or slight anger; a tiff.
A game among children. See Tag .

A very large and powerful carnivore ( Felis tigris ) native of Southern Asia and the East Indies. Its back and sides are tawny or rufous yellow, transversely striped with black, the tail is ringed with black, the throat and belly are nearly white. When full grown, it equals or exceeds the lion in size and strength. Called also royal tiger , and Bengal tiger .
A close, or inclosure; a croft.
p. p. of Tie .
A tick. See 2d Tick .
A starch or arrow-root made from the tubes of an East Indian zinziberaceous plant ( Curcuma angustifolia ); also, the plant itself.
An East Indian tree ( Garcinia pedunculata ) having a large yellow fleshy fruit with a pleasant acid flavor.

The accentual mark placed over n , and sometimes over l , in Spanish words [thus, ñ , &ltilde_; ], indicating that, in pronunciation, the sound of the following vowel is to be preceded by that of the initial, or consonantal, y .
To protect from the intrusion of the uninitiated; as, to tile a Masonic lodge .
A man whose occupation is to cover buildings with tiles.

A genus of trees, the lindens, the type of the family Tiliaceae , distinguished by the winglike bract coalescent with the peduncle, and by the indehiscent fruit having one or two seeds. There are about twenty species, natives of temperate regions. Many species are planted as ornamental shade trees, and the tough fibrous inner bark is a valuable article of commerce. Also, a plant of this genus.
A vetch; a tare.
A covering overhead; especially, a tent.
The state of being tilled, or prepared for a crop; culture; as, land is good tilth .
The blue titmouse.
Duration, considered independently of any system of measurement or any employment of terms which designate limited portions thereof.
A timekeeper; especially, a watch by which small intervals of time can be measured; a kind of stop watch. It is used for timing the speed of horses, machinery, etc.
Wanting courage to meet danger; easily frightened; timorous; not bold; fearful; shy.
See Tamerlane .

An elementary substance found as an oxide in the mineral cassiterite, and reduced as a soft silvery-white crystalline metal, with a tinge of yellowish-blue, and a high luster. It is malleable at ordinary temperatures, but brittle when heated. It is softer than gold and can be beaten out into very thin strips called tinfoil. It is ductile at 2120, when it can be drawn out into wire which is not very tenacious; it melts at 4420, and at a higher temperature burns with a brilliant white light. Air and moisture act on tin very slightly. The peculiar properties of tin, especially its malleability, its brilliancy and the slowness with which it rusts make it very serviceable. With other metals it forms valuable alloys, as bronze, gun metal, bell metal, pewter and solder. It is not easily oxidized in the air, and is used chiefly to coat iron to protect it from rusting, in the form of tin foil with mercury to form the reflective surface of mirrors, and in solder, bronze, speculum metal, and other alloys. Its compounds are designated as stannous , or stannic . Symbol Sn ( Stannum ). Atomic weight 117.4.
Tined; tinged.
Trouble; distress; teen.
A name applied to various skin diseases, but especially to ringworm. See Ringworm , and Sycosis .
Furnished with tines; as, a three- tined fork .
Brushwood and thorns for making and repairing hedges.
A sharp sound, as of a bell; a tinkling.

To imbue or impregnate with something different or foreign; as, to tinge a decoction with a bitter taste ; to affect in some degree with the qualities of another substance, either by mixture, or by application to the surface; especially, to color slightly; to stain; as, to tinge a blue color with red; an infusion tinged with a yellow color by saffron.
To make a sharp, shrill noise; to tinkle.
Pertaining to, abounding with, or resembling, tin.
A slight coloring.
A red Madeira wine, wanting the high aroma of the white sorts, and, when old, resembling tawny port.
Very small; little; puny.
The point or extremity of anything; a pointed or somewhat sharply rounded end; the end; as, the tip of the finger; the tip of a spear .
Being under the influence of strong drink; rendered weak or foolish by liquor, but not absolutely or completely drunk; fuddled; intoxicated.
A tier, row, or rank. See Tier .
Weary; fatigued; exhausted.
To quiver; to vibrate; to veer about.
The oyster catcher.
Same as Tyro .
See under T .
The fireplace at the side of an annealing oven.
Consumptive, phthisical.
The seventh month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year, answering to a part of September with a part of October.
A small horse.
Tight; nimble.

A tenth; the tenth part of anything; specifically, the tenthpart of the increase arising from the profits of land and stock, allotted to the clergy for their support, as in England, or devoted to religious or charitable uses. Almost all the tithes of England and Wales are commuted by law into rent charges.
Same as Teetee .
An inscription put over or upon anything as a name by which it is known.
A little teat; a nipple.
A kind of ocher which is used in some parts of England in marking sheep.
With great speed; -- a huntsman's word or sound.
See Ulexite .
Thin Layer Chromatography. An initialism.
the size of a book whose pages are made by folding a sheet of paper twice to form four leaves.

Any one of numerous species of batrachians belonging to the genus Bufo and allied genera, especially those of the family Bufonidae . Toads are generally terrestrial in their habits except during the breeding season, when they seek the water. Most of the species burrow beneath the earth in the daytime and come forth to feed on insects at night. Most toads have a rough, warty skin in which are glands that secrete an acrid fluid.
A mean flatterer; a toadeater; a sycophant.
To dry and brown by the heat of a fire; as, to toast bread .
The handle of a joiner's plane.
A kind of inferior cigar of a long slender shape, tapered at one end.
A book of the Apocrypha.
A small jug, pitcher, or mug, generally used for ale, shaped somewhat like a stout man, with a cocked hat forming the brim.
A toucan ( Ramphastos toco ) having a very large beak. See Illust. under Toucan .
A bush; a thick shrub; a bushy clump.
A juice drawn from various kinds of palms in the East Indies; or, a spirituous liquor procured from it by fermentation.
Any one of several species of small insectivorous West Indian birds of the genus Todus . They are allied to the kingfishers.
One of the terminal members, or digits, of the foot of a man or an animal.
Having (such or so many) toes; -- chiefly used in composition; as, narrow- toed , four- toed .
A fop; a beau; a swell.
A knoll or hill.
To put toggery, or togs, on; to dress; -- usually with out , implying care, elaborateness, or the like.

The loose outer garment worn by the ancient Romans, consisting of a single broad piece of woolen cloth of a shape approaching a semicircle. It was of undyed wool, except the border of the toga praetexta.
Clothes; garments; toggery.
The namaycush.
To hew in pieces.
A net or snare; any thread, web, or string spread for taking prey; -- usually in the plural.
An old measure of length in France, containing six French feet, or about 6.3946 French feet.
A grape of an oval shape and whitish color.
Something intended or supposed to represent or indicate another thing or an event; a sign; a symbol; as, the rainbow is a token of God's covenant established with Noah .
To take away. See Toll .
A weight of British India. The standard tola is equal to 180 grains.
imp. & p. p. of Tell .
To draw, or cause to follow, by displaying something pleasing or desirable; to allure by some bait.
To take away; to vacate; to annul.
A writ by which a cause pending in a court baron was removed into a country court.
A fragrant balsam said to have been first brought from Santiago de Tolu, in New Granada. See Balsam of Tolu , under Balsam .
The hydrocarbon radical, CH3.C6H4 , regarded as characteristic of certain compounds of the aromatic series related to toluene; as, tolyl carbinol .
The knave of trumps at gleek.
A money of account in Persia, whose value varies greatly at different times and places. Its average value may be reckoned at about two and a half dollars.
A pit in which the dead body of a human being is deposited; a grave; a sepulcher.
As many writings as are bound in a volume, forming part of a larger work; a book; -- usually applied to a ponderous volume.
Bread, -- generally a penny roll; the supply of food carried by workmen as their daily allowance.
pl. of Toe .
Sound, or the character of a sound, or a sound considered as of this or that character; as, a low, high, loud, grave, acute, sweet, or harsh tone .
Having (such) a tone; -- chiefly used in composition; as, high- toned ; sweet- toned .

In China, an association, secret society, or organization of any kind; in the United States, usually, a secret association of Chinese such as that of the highbinders; in the U. S. the tongs have been frequently associated with criminal activity and gang warfare.
A drug useful in neuralgia, derived from a Fijian plant supposed to be of the aroid genus Epipremnum .
The mangrove; -- so called in the Pacific Islands.

An instrument, usually of metal, consisting of two parts, or long shafts, jointed together at or near one end, or united by an elastic bow, used for handling things, especially hot coals or metals; -- often called a pair of tongs .

Of or relating to tones or sounds; specifically (Phon.) , applied to, or distingshing, a speech sound made with tone unmixed and undimmed by obstruction, such sounds, namely, the vowels and diphthongs, being so called by Dr. James Rush (1833) “ from their forming the purest and most plastic material of intonation.”
A metric ton.
Tonicity, or tone; as, muscular tonus .
A simpleton.
imp. of Take .

An instrument such as a hammer, saw, plane, file, and the like, used in the manual arts, to facilitate mechanical operations; any instrument used by a craftsman or laborer at his work; an implement; as, the tools of a joiner, smith, shoe-maker, etc. ; also, a cutter, chisel, or other part of an instrument or machine that dresses work.
pl. of Toe .
To stand out, or be prominent.

One of the hard, bony appendages which are borne on the jaws, or on other bones in the walls of the mouth or pharynx of most vertebrates, and which usually aid in the prehension and mastication of food.

A child's toy, commonly in the form of a conoid or pear, made to spin on its point, usually by drawing off a string wound round its surface or stem, the motion being sometimes continued by means of a whip.
The rhinocerous bird (a) .

A mineral occurring in rhombic prisms, generally yellowish and pellucid, also colorless, and of greenesh, bluish, or brownish shades. It sometimes occurs massive and opaque. It is a fluosilicate of alumina, and is used as a gem.
A moundlike Buddhist sepulcher, or memorial monument, often erected over a Buddhist relic.

An Eskimo house made of material other than snow, esp. one having walls of turf, driftwood, rock, or skin, and a roof of skins of the walrus or seal. In Alaska it is often partially underground and covered with timber and turf. Topeks are also used by Indians of the lower Yukon region.
One who topes, or drinks frequently or to excess; a drunkard; a sot.
The European crested titmouse.
kind of sandstone.

An antelope ( Damaliscus corrigum jimela ) having a glossy purplish brown coat. It is related to the blesbok and is native of East Africa. Also, any of various related varieties of other districts south of the Sahara.

One of the various general forms of argument employed in probable as distinguished from demonstrative reasoning, -- denominated by Aristotle to`poi (literally, places), as being the places or sources from which arguments may be derived, or to which they may be referred; also, a prepared form of argument, applicable to a great variety of cases, with a supply of which the ancient rhetoricians and orators provided themselves; a commonplace of argument or oratory.
A kind of cap worn in the 16th century, and copied in modern fashions; -- called also toquet .
A law; a precept.

A gateway, commonly of wood, but sometimes of stone, consisting of two upright pillars carrying one to three transverse lintels. It is often minutely carved with symbolic sculpture, and serves as a monumental approach to a Buddhist temple.
Same as Torque , 1.
A light or luminary formed of some combustible substance, as of resinous wood; a large candle or flambeau, or a lamp giving a large, flaring flame.
imp. of Tear .
A ring for fastening a hawk's leash to the jesses; also, a ring affixed to the collar of a dog, etc.
p. p. of Tear .
The cusk. See Cusk .
The human body, as distinguished from the head and limbs; in sculpture, the trunk of a statue, mutilated of head and limbs; as, the torso of Hercules .
Mischief; injury; calamity.
a flat heap of moist, crushed silver ore, prepared for the patio process.

A member of the conservative party, as opposed to the progressive party which was formerly called the Whig, and is now called the Liberal, party; an earnest supporter of existing royal and ecclesiastical authority.
To tease, or comb, as wool.
Neat; trim.
To throw with the hand; especially, to throw with the palm of the hand upward, or to throw upward; as, to toss a ball .
Tossing the head, as in scorn or pride; hence, proud; contemptuous; scornful; affectedly indifferent; as, a tossy commonplace .
imp. & p. p. of Toss.
Quick; rapid.
Anything small; -- frequently applied as a term of endearment to a little child.
The grivet.
Whole; not divided; entire; full; complete; absolute; as, a total departure from the evidence; a total loss.

To carry or bear; as, to tote a child over a stream; to tote a gun on one's hip ; -- a colloquial word originating in the Southern States, and used there esp. by negroes, now common throughout the U. S.

A rude picture, as of a bird, beast, or the like, used by the North American Indians as a symbolic designation, as of a family or a clan; also, the object or animal itself, considered as an symbol of the family.
The stone roller. See Stone roller (a) , under Stone .
Unsteady; dizzy; tottery.
A sailor or fisherman; -- so called in some parts of the Pacific.
To come in contact with; to hit or strike lightly against; to extend the hand, foot, or the like, so as to reach or rest on.
Having the quality of flexibility without brittleness; yielding to force without breaking; capable of resisting great strain; as, the ligaments of animals are remarkably tough .
A going round; a circuit; hence, a journey in a circuit; a prolonged circuitous journey; a comprehensive excursion; as, the tour of Europe; the tour of France or England .
A spinning wheel.
To pull; to haul; to tear; to worry.
Tousled; tangled; rough; shaggy.
To act as a tout. See 2d Tout .
See Touse .
The coarse and broken part of flax or hemp, separated from the finer part by the hatchel or swingle.
A cloth used for wiping, especially one used for drying anything wet, as the person after a bath.
A mass of building standing alone and insulated, usually higher than its diameter, but when of great size not always of that proportion.

Formerly: (a) An inclosure which surrounded the mere homestead or dwelling of the lord of the manor. [Obs.] (b) The whole of the land which constituted the domain. [Obs.] (c) A collection of houses inclosed by fences or walls.
Composed of, or like, tow.
Of or pertaining to poison; poisonous; as, toxic medicines .

A poisonous product formed by an organism, such as a pathogenic bacterium, a plant or an animal, usually having a high molecular weight, often a protein or a polysaccharide, but occasionally a low-molecular weight agent such as tetrodotoxin .
To dally amorously; to trifle; to play.
One who toys; one who is full of trifling tricks; a trifler.
To pull violently; to touse.
Soft, like wool that has been teased.
Same as Trubu .
One of two straps, chains, or ropes of a harness, extending from the collar or breastplate to a whiffletree attached to a vehicle or thing to be drawn; a tug.
A mark left by something that has passed along; as, the track , or wake, of a ship; the track of a meteor; the track of a sled or a wheel.
A written discourse or dissertation, generally of short extent; a short treatise, especially on practical religion.
imp. of Tread .
A track; a trail; a way; a path; also, passage; travel; resort.
See under T.
To be drilled in military exercises; to do duty in a military company.
A four-wheeled truck running on rails, and used in a mine, as for carrying coal or ore.
The loosely woven substance which lines the chambers within the gleba in certain Gasteromycetes .
To tread upon forcibly and repeatedly; to trample.
To traffic in an itinerary manner; to peddle.
To dress with ornaments; to adorn; -- said especially of horses.
To walk or run about in an idle or slatternly manner; to traipse.
Small or portable articles for dress, furniture, or use; goods; luggage; things.
That which is worthless or useless; rubbish; refuse.

A white to gray volcanic tufa, formed of decomposed trachytic cinders; -- sometimes used as a cement. Hence, a coarse sort of plaster or mortar, durable in water, and used to line cisterns and other reservoirs of water.
A crossbeam; a lay of joists.
To take fish, or other marine animals, with a trawl.
To betray; to deceive.
See Trais .
To set the foot; to step.
To handle; to manage; to use; to bear one's self toward; as, to treat prisoners cruelly; to treat children kindly.
To drive to a tree; to cause to ascend a tree; as, a dog trees a squirrel .
Made of wood; wooden.
Ceremonially unclean, according to the Jewish law; -- opposed to kosher .
To draw or haul a load, as oxen.
A fish spear.
To have a particular direction; to run; to stretch; to tend; as, the shore of the sea trends to the southwest .
A braid, knot, or curl, of hair; a ringlet.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Tread , for treadeth .
Trowsers; especially, those of the Scotch Highlanders.
Three, at cards, dice, or dominoes; a card, die, or domino of three spots or pips.
A union of three; three objects treated as one; a ternary; a trinity; as, a triad of deities .
The act of trying or testing in any manner.

The formation situated between the Permian and Lias, and so named by the Germans, because consisting of three series of strata, which are called in German the Bunter sandstein , Muschelkalk , and Keuper .
To distribute into tribes or classes.
An apothecium in certain lichens, having a spherical surface marked with spiral or concentric ridges and furrows.
To pull; to haul; to drag; to pull away.
An artifice or stratagem; a cunning contrivance; a sly procedure, usually with a dishonest intent; as, a trick in trade .
Short and ready; fleet; as, a tride pace ; -- a term used by sportsmen.
imp. & p. p. of Try.
One who tries; one who makes experiments; one who examines anything by a test or standard.
To fill; to stuff; to cram.
To flow in a small stream, or in drops rapidly succeeding each other; to trickle.
To make trim; to put in due order for any purpose; to make right, neat, or pleasing; to adjust.
Threefold; triple; as, trine dimensions, or length, breadth, and thickness .
A kind of fishing net.
Three, considered collectively; three in company or acting together; a set of three; three united.
Same as Trier , 2 and 3.

To cause to stumble, or take a false step; to cause to lose the footing, by striking the feet from under; to cause to fall; to throw off the balance; to supplant; -- often followed by up ; as, to trip up a man in wrestling .
The large stomach of ruminating animals, when prepared for food.
Sad; sorrowful; gloomy.
Worn out; common; used until so common as to have lost novelty and interest; hackneyed; stale; as, a trite remark; a trite subject.
See Trode .
To cry, as a buck in rutting time.
An old English game; -- called also lawn billiards .
imp. & p. p. of Tread .
imp. of Tread .
Pertaining to Troy; Trojan.
A supernatural being, often represented as of diminutive size, but sometimes as a giant, and fabled to inhabit caves, hills, and like places; a witch.

A blowing apparatus, in which air, drawn into the upper part of a vertical tube through side holes by a stream of water within, is carried down with the water into a box or chamber below which it is led to a furnace.
See 3d Trone , 2.

A native double salt, consisting of a combination of neutral and acid sodium carbonate, Na2CO3.2HNaCO3.2H2O , occurring as a white crystalline fibrous deposit from certain soda brine springs and lakes; -- called also urao , and by the ancients nitrum .
A small drain.
A collection of people; a company; a number; a multitude.

The use of a word or expression in a different sense from that which properly belongs to it; the use of a word or expression as changed from the original signification to another, for the sake of giving life or emphasis to an idea; a figure of speech.
To proceed by a certain gait peculiar to quadrupeds; to ride or drive at a trot. See Trot , n.
Belief; faith; fidelity.
See Troll .

Any one of numerous species of fishes belonging to Salmo , Salvelinus , and allied genera of the family Salmonidae . They are highly esteemed as game fishes and for the quality of their flesh. All the species breed in fresh water, but after spawning many of them descend to the sea if they have an opportunity.
A boat with an open well amidships. It is used in spearing fish.
See Troll .
Troy weight.
An East India herring ( Clupea toli ) which is extensively caught for the sake of its roe and for its flesh.
A suspension of arms by agreement of the commanders of opposing forces; a temporary cessation of hostilities, for negotiation or other purpose; an armistice.
A small wheel, as of a vehicle; specifically (Ord.) , a small strong wheel, as of wood or iron, for a gun carriage.
In accordance with truth; truly.
A trough, or tray.
A drab; a strumpet; a harlot; a trollop.
In a true manner; according to truth; in agreement with fact; as, to state things truly ; the facts are truly represented .
A wind instrument of music; a trumpet, or sound of a trumpet; -- used chiefly in Scripture and poetry.
The stem, or body, of a tree, apart from its limbs and roots; the main stem, without the branches; stock; stalk.
A bundle; a package; as, a truss of grass .
Assured resting of the mind on the integrity, veracity, justice, friendship, or other sound principle, of another person; confidence; reliance; reliance.
The quality or being true; as: -- (a) Conformity to fact or reality; exact accordance with that which is, or has been; or shall be.
To divide or separate, as one sort from another; to winnow; to sift; to pick out; -- frequently followed by out ; as, to try out the wild corn from the good .
To mutually agree to meet at a certain place.
The title of the emperor of Russia. See Czar .
The springbok.
An open wooden vessel formed with staves, bottom, and hoops; a kind of short cask, half barrel, or firkin, usually with but one head, -- used for various purposes.
An ancient trumpet.
Of or pertaining to a tube; specifically, of or pertaining to one of the Fallopian tubes; as, tubal pregnancy .
Resembling a tub; specifically sounding dull and without resonance, like a tub; wanting elasticity or freedom of sound; as, a tubby violin .
A hollow cylinder, of any material, used for the conveyance of fluids, and for various other purposes; a pipe.
A fleshy, rounded stem or root, usually containing starchy matter, as the potato or arrowroot; a thickened root-stock. See Illust. of Tuberous .
The Mexican pocket gopher ( Geomys Mexicanus ). It resembles the common pocket gopher of the Western United States, but is larger. Called also tugan , and tuza .
See Tucket , a steak.
A dark-colored kind of marble; touchstone.
A long, narrow sword; a rapier.

A fine, strong fiber obtained from the young leaves of a Brazilian palm ( Astrocaryum vulgare ), used for cordage, bowstrings, etc.; also, the plant yielding this fiber. Called also tecum , and tecum fiber .
Of or pertaining to a royal line of England, descended from Owen Tudor of Wales, who married the widowed queen of Henry V. The first reigning Tudor was Henry VII.; the last, Elizabeth.
The parson bird.
The lapwing.
A soft or porous stone formed by depositions from water, usually calcareous; -- called also calcareous tufa .
Same as Tufa .
A collection of small, flexible, or soft things in a knot or bunch; a waving or bending and spreading cluster; as, a tuft of flowers or feathers .
Abounding with tufts.
To pull or draw with great effort; to draw along with continued exertion; to haul along; to tow; as, to tug a loaded cart; to tug a ship into port.
Same as Tucan .
A large bulrush ( Scirpus lacustris , and Scirpus Tatora ) growing abundantly on overflowed land in California and elsewhere.
Any plant of the liliaceous genus Tulipa . Many varieties are cultivated for their beautiful, often variegated flowers.
To allure; to tole.
A kind of silk lace or light netting, used for veils, etc.
Swelled, enlarged, or distended; as, a tumid leg; tumid flesh.
A morbid swelling, prominence, or growth, on any part of the body; especially, a growth produced by deposition of new tissue; a neoplasm.
A little hillock; a knoll.
A large cask; an oblong vessel bulging in the middle, like a pipe or puncheon, and girt with hoops; a wine cask.
The Opuntia Tuna . See Prickly pear , under Prickly .
A sound; a note; a tone.
One who tunes; especially, one whose occupation is to tune musical instruments.
A sharp blow; a thump.

The chiefly British equivalent of tuna ; any one of several species of large oceanic fishes belonging to the Mackerel family, especially the common or great tunny ( Thunnus thynnus syn. Albacora thynnus , formerly Orcynus thynnus ) native of the Mediterranean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean . It sometimes weighs a thousand pounds or more, and is extensively caught in the Mediterranean. On the American coast it is called horse mackerel . See Illust. of Horse mackerel , under Horse .
To butt, as a ram does.
Any one of the tupaiids.

An Indian of the tribe from which the Tupian stock takes its name, dwelling, at the advent of the Portuguese, about the mouth of the Amazon. Also, their language, which is the basis of the Indian trade language of the Amazon.
A kind of warm cap winter wear, made from a knit bag with closed tapered ends by pushing one end within the other, thus making a conical cap of double thickness.
Any one of numerous marine gastropods of the genus Turbo or family Turbinidae , usually having a turbinate shell, pearly on the inside, and a calcareous operculum.
That upper stratum of earth and vegetable mold which is filled with the roots of grass and other small plants, so as to adhere and form a kind of mat; sward; sod.
Abounding with turf; made of, or covered with, turf.
A shoot or sprout from the ground.
A member of any of numerous Tartar tribes of Central Asia, etc.; esp., one of the dominant race in Turkey.
One of a body of native Algerian tirailleurs in the French army, dressed as a Turk.
A troop; a company.

To cause to move upon a center, or as if upon a center; to give circular motion to; to cause to revolve; to cause to move round, either partially, wholly, or repeatedly; to make to change position so as to present other sides in given directions; to make to face otherwise; as, to turn a wheel or a spindle; to turn the body or the head .
An exclamation indicating check, rebuke, or contempt; as, tush , tush ! do not speak of it .
Same as Torsk .
Having tusks.
Be still; hush; -- an exclamation used for checking or rebuking.
One who guards, protects, watches over, or has the care of, some person or thing.
All; -- a direction for all the singers or players to perform together.
A yellow or brown amorphous substance obtained as a sublimation product in the flues of smelting furnaces of zinc, and consisting of a crude zinc oxide.
Lit., thine; that which is thine; -- used in meum and tuum . See 2d Meum .
Shortened form of tuxedo .
A lock or tuft of hair.
Two; -- nearly obsolete in common discourse, but used in poetry and burlesque.
A tang. See Tang a state.
To cause to make a sharp twanging sound; to twang, or twangle.
Two; twain.
A pinching condition; perplexity; trouble; distress.
To pinch and pull with a sudden jerk and twist; to twitch; as, to tweak the nose .
A soft and flexible fabric for men's wear, made wholly of wool except in some inferior kinds, the wool being dyed, usually in two colors, before weaving.
See Twill .
Same as Tuyère .
To twitch; to pull; to tweak.
To weave, as cloth, so as to produce the appearance of diagonal lines or ribs on the surface.
Being one of two born at a birth; as, a twin brother or sister .
A twist; a convolution.
To twinkle.
A twisted filament; a thread.
To move or turn round rapidly; to whirl round; to move and turn rapidly with the fingers.
To contort; to writhe; to complicate; to crook spirally; to convolve.
To vex by bringing to notice, or reminding of, a fault, defect, misfortune, or the like; to revile; to reproach; to upbraid; to taunt; as, he twitted his friend of falsehood .
The European tree sparrow.
One and one; twice one.
Same as Tidy .
A knot; a tie.
One who ties, or unites.
p. pr. of Tie .
See 2d Tike .
See 2d Tiler .
A hollow water-cooled iron casting in the upper part of the archway in which the dam stands.
To shut; to close.
To become lost; to perish.
Small; tiny.
Relating to a type or types; belonging to types; serving as a type; typical.
The mark or impression of something; stamp; impressed sign; emblem.
A compositor.
Curdled milk.
A beginner in learning; one who is in the rudiments of any branch of study; a person imperfectly acquainted with a subject; a novice.
See Tithe .
The emperor of Russia. See Czar .

Vars. of Odal , etc.; property held by udal, or allodial, right -- Obs. exc. in Shetland and the Orkney Islands, where udal designates a freehold, land held in fee simple without any charter and free of any feudal character.
The glandular organ in which milk is secreted and stored; -- popularly called the bag in cows and other quadrupeds. See Mamma .
An exclamation expressive of disgust, horror, or recoil. Its utterance is usually accompanied by a shudder.
Offensive to the sight; contrary to beauty; being of disagreeable or loathsome aspect; unsightly; repulsive; deformed.
One of a certain description of militia among the Tartars.
In Russia, a published proclamation or imperial order, having the force of law.
See Uhlan .

A solution of continuity in any of the soft parts of the body, discharging purulent matter, found on a surface, especially one of the natural surfaces of the body, and originating generally in a constitutional disorder; a sore discharging pus. It is distinguished from an abscess , which has its beginning, at least, in the depth of the tissues.
A Mexican and Central American tree ( Castilloa elastica and Castilloa Markhamiana ) related to the breadfruit tree. Its milky juice contains caoutchouc . Called also ule tree .

A college or body composed of the hierarchy (the imams, or ministers of religion, the muftis, or doctors of law, and the cadis, or administrators of justice). That of Turkey alone now has political power; its head is the sheik ul Islam.
A European owl ( Syrnium aluco ) of a tawny color; -- called also uluia .
Pertaining to ulmin; designating an acid obtained from ulmin.
A brown amorphous substance found in decaying vegetation. Cf. Humin .
A genus of trees including the elm.
The postaxial bone of the forearm, or brachium, corresponding to the fibula of the hind limb. See Radius .
Of or pertaining to the ulna, or the elbow; as, the ulnar nerve .
Resembling a scar; scarlike.
Going beyond others, or beyond due limit; extreme; fanatical; uncompromising; as, an ultra reformer ; ultra measures.
A genus of owls including the great gray owl ( Ulula cinerea ) of Arctic America, and other similar species. See Illust. of Owl .
A genus of thin papery bright green seaweeds including the kinds called sea lettuce .

A kind of flower cluster in which the flower stalks radiate from a common point, as in the carrot and milkweed. It is simple or compound; in the latter case, each peduncle bears another little umbel, called umbellet , or umbellule .

A brown or reddish pigment used in both oil and water colors, obtained from certain natural clays variously colored by the oxides of iron and manganese. It is commonly heated or burned before being used, and is then called burnt umber ; when not heated, it is called raw umber . See Burnt umber , below.
The boss of a shield, at or near the middle, and usually projecting, sometimes in a sharp spike.

The conical shadow projected from a planet or satellite, on the side opposite to the sun, within which a spectator could see no portion of the sun's disk; -- used in contradistinction from penumbra . See Penumbra .
See Umber .
Inapt; slow; dull.
To put off, or lay down, one's arms or armor.
The two-toed sloth ( Cholopus didactylus ), native of South America. It is about two feet long. Its color is a uniform grayish brown, sometimes with a reddish tint.
To pour, or take, or let go, out of a bag or bags.
To remove a bar or bars from; to unbolt; to open; as, to unbar a gate .
To free from the restraint of anything that surrounds or incloses; to let loose; to open.
To cause not to be; to cause to be another.
To raise or rouse from bed.
