Not bidden; not commanded.
To remove the turns of (a rope or cable) from the bits; as, to unbit a cable .
To remove from a box or boxes.
To divest of the traits of a boy.
To remove a cap or cover from.
An ounce; a small portion.
A twelfth part, as of the Roman as; an ounce.
The brother of one's father or mother; also applied to an aunt's husband; -- the correlative of aunt in sex, and of nephew and niece in relationship.
Unknown; strange, or foreign; unusual, or surprising; distant in manner; reserved.
A hook or claw.
Not cut; not separated or divided by cutting or otherwise; -- said especially of books, periodicals, and the like, when the leaves have not been separated by trimming in binding.
To free from a dam, mound, or other obstruction.

Below or lower, in place or position, with the idea of being covered; lower than; beneath; -- opposed to over ; as, he stood under a tree; the carriage is under cover; a cellar extends under the whole house.
imp. of Undo .
To reverse, as what has been done; to annul; to bring to naught.
Not due; not yet owing; as, an undue debt, note, or bond .
With difficulty; scarcely. See Uneath .

To make unsuitable or incompetent; to deprive of the strength, skill, or proper qualities for anything; to disable; to incapacitate; to disqualify; as, sickness unfits a man for labor; sin unfits us for the society of holy beings.
To loosen from a fastening; to detach from anything that holds; to unsettle; as, to unfix a bayonet; to unfix the mind or affections.
To cause to be unbegotten or unborn, or as if unbegotten or unborn.
The siamang; -- called also ungka ape .
To deprive of divinity; to undeify.
Not gotten; not acquired.
Ill luck; misfortune.
To take off the hat of; to remove one's hat, especially as a mark of respect.
A member of the Greek Church, who nevertheless acknowledges the supremacy of the Pope of Rome; one of the United Greeks. Also used adjectively.
To cause to be one; to make into a unit; to unite; to view as one.
Any one of numerous species of fresh-water mussels belonging to Unio and many allied genera.
The act of uniting or joining two or more things into one, or the state of being united or joined; junction; coalition; combination.
A single thing or person.

To put together so as to make one; to join, as two or more constituents, to form a whole; to combine; to connect; to join; to cause to adhere; as, to unite bricks by mortar; to unite iron bars by welding; to unite two armies.
The state of being one; oneness.
A European aquatic toad ( Bombinator igneus ). Its back is dark; its belly is marked with crimson. Called also feuerkröte .
Odd; strange; ugly; old; uncouth.
See Uncle .
To deprive of the authority or character of law.
To untwist; as, to unlay a rope .
To release from confinement or restraint.
To remove from condition of being a nun.
To remove the oil from.
To undo, take back, or annul, as a payment.
To remove a peg or pegs from; to unfasten; to open.
To release from a pen or from confinement.
To loose from pins; to remove the pins from; to unfasten; as, to unpin a frock; to unpin a frame .
To strip of rigging; as, to unrig a ship .
To rip; to cut open.
Unsteady; fickle.
To recant or recall, as what has been said; to refract; to take back again; to make as if not said.
Not set; not fixed or appointed.
To undo, as something sewn, or something inclosed by sewing; to rip apart; to take out the stitches of.
To deprive of sex, or of qualities becoming to one's sex; esp., to make unfeminine in character, manners, duties, or the like; as, to unsex a woman .
To deprive of sinfulness, as a sin; to make sinless.
To become untied or loosed.
As far as; to the place or degree that; especially, up to the time that; till. See Till , conj.
Until; till.
To deprive of wit.
From a lower to a higher place on, upon, or along; at a higher situation upon; at the top of.
To fasten with a bar.
To end up; to set on end, as a cask.
imp. of Upheave .
A fir pole of from four to seven inches diameter, and twenty to forty feet long, sometimes roughly hewn, used for scaffoldings, and sometimes for slight and common roofs, for which use it is split.
On; -- used in all the senses of that word, with which it is interchangeable.
Being further up, literally or figuratively; higher in place, position, rank, dignity, or the like; superior; as, the upper lip; the upper side of a thing; the upper house of a legislature .
To run up; to ascend.
To set up; to put upright.
The time during which the sun is up, or above the horizon; the time between sunrise and sunset.
A genus of birds which includes the common hoopoe.
imp. of Upgive .
Pertaining to, or designating, the Urals, a mountain range between Europe and Asia.
See Curare .
See Trona .
See Curare .
A salt of uric acid; as, sodium urate ; ammonium urate .
The language more generally called Hindustanee .
Use; practice; exercise.
A very soluble crystalline body which is the chief constituent of the urine in mammals and some other animals. It is also present in small quantity in blood, serous fluids, lymph, the liver, etc.
Of or pertaining to urea; containing, or consisting of, urea; as, ureal deposits .
To press onward or forward.
One who urges.
Of or pertaining to urine; obtained from urine; as, uric acid .
A part or decoration of the breastplate of the high priest among the ancient Jews, by which Jehovah revealed his will on certain occasions. Its nature has been the subject of conflicting conjectures.
In mammals, a fluid excretion from the kidneys; in birds and reptiles, a solid or semisolid excretion.
One of the segments of the abdomen or post-abdomen of arthropods.
The bindings of a hedge.
To inclose in, or as in, an urn; to inurn.
Of or pertaining to an urn; effected by an urn or urns.
The aurochs.
A sort of blue or black clay lying near a vein of coal.
Either one of the Bears. See the Phrases below.
The ursine seal. See the Note under 1st Seal .
The Canada porcupine. See Porcupine .
The bearded seal.
A genus of Carnivora including the common bears.
The black vulture ( Catharista atrata ). It ranges from the Southern United States to South America. See Vulture .

A very large, powerful, and savage extinct bovine animal ( Bos urus or Bos primigenius ) anciently abundant in Europe. It appears to have still existed in the time of Julius Caesar. It had very large horns, and was hardly capable of domestication. Called also, ur , ure , and tur .
The crab-eating ichneumon ( Herpestes urva ), native of India. The fur is black, annulated with white at the tip of each hair, and a white streak extends from the mouth to the shoulder.
The persons speaking, regarded as an object; ourselves; -- the objective case of we . See We .
Using; accustomed.

To be wont or accustomed; to be in the habit or practice; as, he used to ride daily ; -- now disused in the present tense, perhaps because of the similarity in sound, between “ use to,” and “ used to.”
One who uses.

To introduce or escort, as an usher, forerunner, or harbinger; to forerun; -- sometimes followed by in or forth ; as, to usher in a stranger; to usher forth the guests; to usher a visitor into the room .

A genus of lichens, most of the species of which have long, gray, pendulous, and finely branched fronds. Usnea barbata is the common bearded lichen which grows on branches of trees in northern forests.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex acid obtained, as a yellow crystalline substance, from certain genera of lichens ( Usnea , Parmelia , etc.).
Such as is in common use; such as occurs in ordinary practice, or in the ordinary course of events; customary; ordinary; habitual; common.
To practice usury; to charge unlawful interest.

To seize, and hold in possession, by force, or without right; as, to usurp a throne; to usurp the prerogatives of the crown; to usurp power; to usurp the right of a patron is to oust or dispossess him.
The first note in Guido's musical scale, now usually superseded by do . See Solmization .

An extensive tribe of North American Indians of the Shoshone stock, inhabiting Colorado, Utah, New Mexico, Arizona, and adjacent regions. They are subdivided into several subordinate tribes, some of which are among the most degraded of North American Indians.
Any species of large West Indian rodents of the genus Capromys , or Utia . In general appearance and habits they resemble rats, but they are as large as rabbits.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a subdivision of the Trenton Period of the Lower Silurian, characterized in the State of New York by beds of shale.
Profitable; useful.
A small pulpy or juicy fruit containing several seeds and having a thin skin, as a grape.
A conserve made of grapes.
The posterior pigmented layer of the iris; -- sometimes applied to the whole iris together with the choroid coat.

Pertaining to, or obtained from, grapes; specifically, designating an organic acid, C7H8O3 (also called pyrotritartaric acid ), obtained as a white crystalline substance by the decomposition of tartaric and pyrotartaric acids.
See Euphroe .
The pendent fleshy lobe in the middle of the posterior border of the soft palate.
A Burman measure of twelve miles.
To fade; hence, to vanish.
Of or pertaining to the vagus, or pneumogastric nerves; pneumogastric.
An indefinite expanse.
Wandering; -- applied especially to the pneumogastric nerve.
Same as Veil .
Having no real substance, value, or importance; empty; void; worthless; unsatisfying.

The skin of the squirrel, much used in the fourteenth century as fur for garments, and frequently mentioned by writers of that period in describing the costly dresses of kings, nobles, and prelates. It is represented in heraldry by a series of small shields placed close together, and alternately white and blue.
Charged with vair; variegated with shield-shaped figures. See Vair .
A tract of low ground, or of land between hills; a valley.
A male waiting servant; a servant who attends on a gentleman's person; a body servant.
The property or aggregate properties of a thing by which it is rendered useful or desirable, or the degree of such property or sum of properties; worth; excellence; utility; importance.
To advance; to travel.
The front of an army; the first line or leading column; also, the front line or foremost division of a fleet, either in sailing or in battle.
A rope to steady the peak of a gaff.
See Vaunt .
That which is vapid, insipid, or lifeless; especially, the lifeless part of liquor or wine.
Having lost its life and spirit; dead; spiritless; insipid; flat; dull; unanimated; as, vapid beer; a vapid speech; a vapid state of the blood .
To send off in vapor, or as if in vapor; as, to vapor away a heated fluid .
A Spanish measure of length equal to about one yard. The vara now in use equals 33.385 inches.
The monitor. See Monitor , 3.
A wand or staff of authority or justice.
The calcined ashes of any coarse seaweed used for the manufacture of soda and iodine; also, the seaweed itself; fucus; wrack.
The ringtailed lemur ( Lemur catta ) of Madagascar. Its long tail is annulated with black and white.
The bush hog, or boshvark.
A deformity in which the foot is turned inward. See Talipes .
To alter, or be altered, in any manner; to suffer a partial change; to become different; to be modified; as, colors vary in different lights .
A vessel; a duct.

A vessel adapted for various domestic purposes, and anciently for sacrificial uses; especially, a vessel of antique or elegant pattern used for ornament; as, a porcelain vase ; a gold vase ; a Grecian vase . See Illust. of Portland vase , under Portland .
A waste region; boundless space; immensity.
Vast; immense.
A genus including several species of large marine gastropods having massive pyriform shells, with conspicuous folds on the columella.
To put or transfer into a vat.
To boast; to make a vain display of one's own worth, attainments, decorations, or the like; to talk ostentatiously; to brag.
To vault; to leap.
a videocasette recorder .
The flesh of a calf when killed and used for food.

The ancient sacred literature of the Hindus; also, one of the four collections, called Rig-Veda , Yajur-Veda , Sama-Veda , and Atharva-Veda , constituting the most ancient portions of that literature.
Of or pertaining to the Vedas or one of the Vedas.
A Russian liquid measure, equal to 3.249 gallons of U. S. standard measure, or 2.706 imperial gallons.
To change direction; to turn; to shift; as, wind veers to the west or north .

An American thrush ( Turdus fuscescens ) common in the Northern United States and Canada. It is light tawny brown above. The breast is pale buff, thickly spotted with brown. Called also Wilson's thrush .
A brilliant star of the first magnitude, the brightest of those constituting the constellation Lyra.
A vegetarian who does not eat any animal products, not even fish, eggs, or milk.
A vehmic court.
One of the vessels which carry blood, either venous or arterial, to the heart. See Artery , 2.
Full of veins; veinous; veined; as, veiny marble .
A region or tract of land; esp., the open field, thinly forested or with bushes and shrubs; grass country.
The salted stomach of a calf, used in making cheese; a rennet bag.
Of or pertaining to veins; venous; as, venal blood .
To transfer to another person for a pecuniary equivalent; to make an object of trade; to dispose of by sale; to sell; as, to vend goods; to vend vegetables .
See Wends .
A bout, or turn, as at fencing; a thrust; a hit; a veney.
A bout; a thrust; a venew.
To avenge; to punish; to revenge.
A toxic substance contained in the venom of poisonous snakes; also, a (supposedly identical) toxic substance obtained by the cleavage of an albumose.

Matter fatal or injurious to life; poison; particularly, the poisonous matter which certain animals, such as serpents, scorpions, bees, etc., secrete in a state of health, and communicate by biting or stinging.
Sale; opportunity to sell; market.
A neighborhood or near place; the place or county in which anything is alleged to have happened; also, the place where an action is laid.
The goddess of beauty and love, that is, beauty or love deified.
A word; a vocable.
The privilege of cutting green wood within a forest for fuel.
A rod or staff, carried as an emblem of authority; as, the verge , carried before a dean .
A verse or verses. See Verse , n.
A line consisting of a certain number of metrical feet (see Foot , n. , 9) disposed according to metrical rules.
The reverse, or left-hand, page of a book or a folded sheet of paper; -- opposed to recto .
A Russian measure of length containing 3,500 English feet.
Everything that grows, and bears a green leaf, within the forest; as, to preserve vert and venison is the duty of the verderer .
Virtue; power. See Virtue .
Excitement of imagination such as animates a poet, artist, or musician, in composing or performing; rapture; enthusiasm; spirit; energy.
True; real; actual; veritable.
Onset; rush; violent draught or wind.
A genus of Hymenoptera including the common wasps and hornets.
To clothe with, or as with, a vestment, or garment; to dress; to robe; to cover, surround, or encompass closely.
One of the great divinities of the ancient Romans, identical with the Greek Hestia . She was a virgin, and the goddess of the hearth; hence, also, of the fire on it, and the family round it.
Any leguminous plant of the genus Vicia , some species of which are valuable for fodder. The common species is Vicia sativa .
To prohibit; to negative; also, to refuse assent to, as a legislative bill, and thus prevent its enactment; as, to veto an appropriation bill .
To toss back and forth; to agitate; to disquiet.
Annoyed; harassed; troubled.
One who vexes or troubles.
A vexillum.
A gab at the end of an eccentric rod, with long jaws, shaped like the letter V.
A road or way.
A voyage; a journey.
A small bottle, usually of glass; a little glass vessel with a narrow aperture intended to be closed with a stopper; as, a vial of medicine .
An article of food; provisions; food; victuals; -- used chiefly in the plural.
Of or pertaining to roads; happening on roads.
One deputed or authorized to perform the functions of another; a substitute in office; a deputy.
A defect; a fault; an error; a blemish; an imperfection; as, the vices of a political constitution; the vices of a horse .
Vicious; corrupt.
imperative sing. of L. videre , to see; -- used to direct attention to something; as, vide supra , see above .
To stake a sum upon a hand of cards, as in the old game of gleek. See Revie .
The act of seeing or beholding; sight; look; survey; examination by the eye; inspection.
Having peculiar views; fanciful; visionary; unpractical; as, a viewy person .
In the Orkney and Shetland Islands, beef and mutton hung and dried, but not salted.
Abstinence from sleep, whether at a time when sleep is customary or not; the act of keeping awake, or the state of being awake; sleeplessness; wakefulness; watch.
Active strength or force of body or mind; capacity for exertion, physically, intellectually, or morally; force; energy.
Abusive; scurrilous; defamatory; vile.
A small collection of houses; a village.
A country seat; a country or suburban residence of some pretensions to elegance.
pl. of Villus .
Power; force; energy; spirit; activity; vigor.
A long, slender, flexible shoot or branch.
Any woody climbing plant which bears grapes.
Having leaves like those of the vine; ornamented with vine leaves.
A vinedresser.
Of or pertaining to wine; as, vinic alcohol .
Wine, -- chiefly used in Pharmacy in the name of solutions of some medicinal substance in wine; as: vina medicata , medicated wines; vinum opii , wine of opium.
Of or pertaining to vines; producing, or abounding in, vines.
The hypothetical radical C2H3 , regarded as the characteristic residue of ethylene and that related series of unsaturated hydrocarbons with which the allyl compounds are homologous.
A genus of polypetalous herbaceous plants, including all kinds of violets.
A trade name for rofecoxib .
An arrow, having a rotary motion, formerly used with the crossbow. Cf. Vireton .

Any one of numerous species of American singing birds belonging to Vireo and allied genera of the family Vireonidae . In many of the species the back is greenish, or olive-colored. Called also greenlet .
A wand. See Verge .
A sign of the zodiac which the sun enters about the 21st of August, marked thus [&virgo_;] in almanacs.
A love of the fine arts; a taste for curiosities.
Contagious or poisonous matter, as of specific ulcers, the bite of snakes, etc.; -- applied to organic poisons.
Force; power.

A written stamp or document obtained by a citizen of one country from the proper authorities of another country, denoting that that person's passport has been examined, and that the person who bears the visa is permitted to enter or pass through the second country. It is usually in the form of an endorsement on the passport of the person seeking permission to enter a foreign country; however, in some cases a separate document is issued that does not create a mark in the passport. Same as Visé .
An instrument consisting of two jaws, closing by a screw, lever, cam, or the like, for holding work, as in filing.
To make a visit or visits; to maintain visiting relations; to practice calling on others.
Neighborhood; vicinity; venue. See Venue .
A part of a helmet, arranged so as to lift or open, and so show the face. The openings for seeing and breathing are generally in it.
A view; especially, a view through or between intervening objects, as trees; a view or prospect through an avenue, or the like; hence, the trees or other objects that form the avenue.
A vista; a prospect.
Belonging or relating to life, either animal or vegetable; as, vital energies; vital functions; vital actions.
A genus of plants including all true grapevines.
See Durukuli .
One of the oil tubes in the fruit of umbelliferous plants.
Lit., (long) live; -- an exclamation expressing good will, well wishing, etc.
See Vifda .
Long live, that is, success to; as, vive le roi , long live the king; vive la bagatelle , success to trifles or sport.
A disease of brute animals, especially of horses, seated in the glands under the ear, where a tumor is formed which sometimes ends in suppuration.
True to the life; exhibiting the appearance of life or freshness; animated; spirited; bright; strong; intense; as, vivid colors .
A female fox.
To wit; that is; namely.
See Vizier .
See Visor .
A common gray European moth ( Halia vauaria ) having a V -shaped spot of dark brown on each of the fore wings.
the size of a book whose pages are made by folding a sheet of paper three times to form eight leaves.
Of or pertaining to the voice or speech; having voice; endowed with utterance; full of voice, or voices.
A Russian drink distilled from rye.
An inlet, bay, or creek; -- so called in the Orkney and Shetland Islands.
Same as Vugg .
The way or fashion of people at any particular time; temporary mode, custom, or practice; popular reception for the time; -- used now generally in the phrase in vogue .

Sound uttered by the mouth, especially that uttered by human beings in speech or song; sound thus uttered considered as possessing some special quality or character; as, the human voice ; a pleasant voice ; a low voice .
Containing nothing; empty; vacant; not occupied; not filled.
Of or pertaining to the palm of the hand or the sole of the foot.
A deal at cards that draws all the tricks.
The common sort of people; the crowd; the mob.
To baptize; -- used in contempt by the Reformers.

The unit of electro-motive force; -- defined by the International Electrical Congress in 1893 and by United States Statute as, that electro-motive force which steadily applied to a conductor whose resistance is one ohm will produce a current of one ampère. It is practically equivalent to 1000/1434 the electro-motive force of a standard Clark's cell at a temperature of 15° C.

A turning; a time; -- chiefly used in phrases signifying that the part is to be repeated one, two, or more times; as, una volta , once. Seconda volta , second time, points to certain modifications in the close of a repeated strain.
Turn, that is, turn over the leaf.
A saclike envelope of certain fungi, which bursts open as the plant develops.
A bone, or one of a pair of bones, beneath the ethmoid region of the skull, forming a part a part of the partition between the nostrils in man and other mammals.
To eject the contents of the stomach by the mouth; to puke; to spew.

To express or signify the mind, will, or preference, either viva voce , or by ballot, or by other authorized means, as in electing persons to office, in passing laws, regulations, etc., or in deciding on any proposition in which one has an interest with others.
One who votes; one who has a legal right to vote, or give his suffrage; an elector; a suffragist; as, an independent voter .
To bear witness; to give testimony or full attestation.
To make a vow, or solemn promise.

A vocal, or sometimes a whispered, sound modified by resonance in the oral passage, the peculiar resonance in each case giving to each several vowel its distinctive character or quality as a sound of speech; -- distinguished from a consonant in that the latter, whether made with or without vocality, derives its character in every case from some kind of obstructive action by the mouth organs. Also, a letter or character which represents such a sound. See Guide to Pronunciation , §§ 5, 146-149.
One who makes a vow.
See Viol , 2.
A cavity in a lode; -- called also vogle .
A kind of clamp with gimlet points for holding a barrel head while the staves are being closed around it.
a. & n. from Vie .
The grivet.
A soft, earthy, dark-colored rock or clay derived from the alteration of basalt.
An earthy oxide of manganese, or mixture of different oxides and water, with some oxide of iron, and often silica, alumina, lime, or baryta; black ocher. There are several varieties.
An aboriginal war club.
To pass or cross by wading; as, he waded &unr_;he rivers and swamps .
One who, or that which, wades.
A ravine through which a brook flows; the channel of a water course, which is dry except in the rainy season.
The kittiwake.
To seal or close with a wafer.
To give notice to by waving something; to wave the hand to; to beckon.
To move one way and the other with quick turns; to shake to and fro; to move vibratingly; to cause to vibrate, as a part of the body; as, to wag the head .
To bind one's self; to engage.
See Waggel .
To hazard on the issue of a contest, or on some question that is to be decided, or on some eventuality; to lay; to stake; to bet.
A compensation given to a hired person for services; price paid for labor; recompense; hire. See Wage , n. , 2.
To transport in a wagon or wagons; as, goods are wagoned from city to city .
Any of various American trees or shrubs;
Oppressed with weight; crushed; weighed down.
To choose; to select.
A piece of plank two yard&unr_; long and a foot broad.
To stay for; to rest or remain stationary in expectation of; to await; as, to wait orders .
A waif; a castaway.
The track left by a vessel in the water; by extension, any track; as, the wake of an army .
To wake; to cease to sleep; to be awakened.
One who wakes.

The granting or dedication of property in trust for a pious purpose, that is, to some object that tends to the good of mankind, as to support a mosque or caravansary, to provide for support of one's family, kin, or neighbors, to benefit some particular person or persons and afterward the poor, etc.; also, the trust so created, or the property in trust.
The person creating a wakf.
A forest; -- used as a termination of names. See Weald .
To mark with wales, or stripes.
A horse imported from New South Wales; also, any Australian horse.
To pass through, over, or upon; to traverse; to perambulate; as, to walk the streets .
A kind of knot often used at the end of a rope; a wall knot; a wale.
To roll; to spout; to boil up.
Liable to roll over; crank; as, a walty ship .
A dance performed by two persons in circular figures with a whirling motion; also, a piece of music composed in triple measure for this kind of dance.
An exclamation of grief.
The common American eider.
Having a pale or sickly hue; languid of look; pale; pallid.
A small stick; a rod; a verge.
Long and flexible, like a wand.
To cause to decrease.
A sharp or uneven edge on a board that is cut from a log not perfectly squared, or that is made in the process of squaring. See Wany , a.
See Whang .
A boomerang.
In a wan, or pale, manner.
Want to; as, I wanna go home .
A surcingle, or strap of leather, used for binding a load upon the back of a beast; also, a leather tie; a short wagon rope.
Waning or diminished in some parts; not of uniform size throughout; -- said especially of sawed boards or timber when tapering or uneven, from being cut too near the outside of the log.
To wane; to wither.
To beat; to whap.
Cast down; crushed by misery; dejected.
A fair-leader.
Ware; aware.
The act of guarding; watch; guard; guardianship; specifically, a guarding during the day. See the Note under Watch , n. , 1.
To wear, or veer. See Wear .
See 4th Ware .
Work; a building.
The act of warming, or the state of being warmed; a warming; a heating.
To turn, twist, or be twisted out of shape; esp., to be twisted or bent out of a flat plane; as, a board warps in seasoning or shrinking .
See Warye .
Having warts; full of warts; overgrow with warts; as, a warty leaf .
To curse; to curse; to execrate; to condemn; also, to vex.
The first and third persons singular of the verb be , in the indicative mood, preterit (imperfect) tense; as, I was ; he was .
A bundle of straw, or other material, to relieve the pressure of burdens carried upon the head.

To cleanse by ablution, or dipping or rubbing in water; to apply water or other liquid to for the purpose of cleansing; to scrub with water, etc., or as with water; as, to wash the hands or body; to wash garments; to wash sheep or wool; to wash the pavement or floor; to wash the bark of trees.
Watery; damp; soft.

Any one of numerous species of stinging hymenopterous insects, esp. any of the numerous species of the genus Vespa , which includes the true, or social, wasps, some of which are called yellow jackets .
The second person singular of the verb be , in the indicative mood, imperfect tense; -- now used only in solemn or poetical style. See Was .
To be diminished; to lose bulk, substance, strength, value, or the like, gradually; to be consumed; to dwindle; to grow less; -- commonly used with away .
The fluid which descends from the clouds in rain, and which forms rivers, lakes, seas, etc.
A unit of power or activity equal to 10 7 C.G.S. units of power, or to work done at the rate of one joule a second. An English horse power is approximately equal to 746 watts.
To cry as a cat; to squall; to wail.
See Waive .
Exhibiting a wavelike form or outline; undulating; intended; wavy; as, waved edge .
A sapling left standing in a fallen wood.
The snow goose.
Rising or swelling in waves; full of waves.
To smear or rub with wax; to treat with wax; as, to wax a thread or a table .
Made of wax.
Resembling wax in appearance or consistency; viscid; adhesive; soft; hence, yielding; pliable; impressible.
To go or travel to; to go in, as a way or path.
Used to the way; broken.

The plural nominative case of the pronoun of the first person; the word with which a person in speaking or writing denotes a number or company of which he is one, as the subject of an action expressed by a verb.
To make or become weak; to weaken.
The mark of a stripe. See Wale .
A wood or forest; a wooded land or region; also, an open country; -- often used in place names.
A weanling; a young child.
Same as Weir .
To grow tired; to become exhausted or impatient; as, to weary of an undertaking .
Given to sensual indulgence; gluttonous.
To practice weaving; to work with a loom.
The world-wide web ; -- usually referred to as the web .
Of or pertaining to a web or webs; like a web; filled or covered with webs.
The standard unit of electrical quantity, and also of current. See Coulomb , and Amp&unr_;re .
A pledge; a pawn.
Like a wedge; wedge-shaped.
A little; a bit, as of space, time, or distance.
A sudden illness or relapse, often attended with fever, which attacks women in childbed.
Dressed in weeds, or mourning garments.
A period of seven days, usually that reckoned from one Sabbath or Sunday to the next.
A whirlpool.
To think; to imagine; to fancy.
The lapwing; the wipe; -- so called from its cry.
To know; to wit.
imp. & p. p. of Wave .
A corruption of Way , used only in the phrase under weigh .
A dam in a river to stop and raise the water, for the purpose of conducting it to a mill, forming a fish pond, or the like.
To foretell the fate of; to predict; to destine to.
Same as Wegotism .
See Waive .
A New Zealand rail ( Ocydromus australis ) which has wings so short as to be incapable of flight.
A small New Zealand owl ( Sceloglaux albifacies ). It has short wings and long legs, and lives chiefly on the ground.
See Welsh .
The state of being welded; the joint made by welding.
Prosperity; happiness; well-being; weal.
To welk, or wither.
To wither; to fade; also, to decay; to decline; to wane.
To issue forth, as water from the earth; to flow; to spring.
The sheatfish; -- called also waller .
Of or pertaining to Wales, or its inhabitants.
To furnish with a welt; to sew or fasten a welt on; as, to welt a boot or a shoe; to welt a sleeve .
imp. of Weld , to wield.
The abdomen; the uterus; the womb.
An indolent, encysted tumor of the skin; especially, a sebaceous cyst.
To frequent the company of wenches, or women of ill fame.
p. p. of Wene .
imp. of Wene .
A Slavic tribe which once occupied the northern and eastern parts of Germany, of which a small remnant exists.
imp. & p. p. of Wend ; -- now obsolete except as the imperfect of go , with which it has no etymological connection. See Go .
imp. of Weep .
imp. & p. p. of Weep .
To wear. See 3d Wear .
See Verst .

The second person singular, indicative and subjunctive moods, imperfect tense, of the verb be . It is formed from were , with the ending -t , after the analogy of wast . Now used only in solemn or poetic style.
See Weasand .

Lying toward the west; situated at the west, or in a western direction from the point of observation or reckoning; proceeding toward the west, or coming from the west; as, a west course is one toward the west; an east and west line; a west wind blows from the west .
Dizzy; giddy.

To fill or moisten with water or other liquid; to sprinkle; to cause to have water or other fluid adherent to the surface; to dip or soak in a liquid; as, to wet a sponge; to wet the hands; to wet cloth.
See Weevil .
To grow; to wax.
Way; road; path.
The European curlew; -- called also awp , whaup , great whaup , and stock whaup .
To strike; to beat; to give a heavy or resounding blow to; to thrash; to make with whacks.
To lash with stripes; to wale; to thrash; to drub.
Any aquatic mammal of the order Cetacea , especially any one of the large species, some of which become nearly one hundred feet long. Whales are hunted chiefly for their oil and baleen, or whalebone.
A light color of the iris in horses; wall-eye.
A breeze fly.
A leather thong.
To throw one's self quickly, or by an abrupt motion; to turn suddenly; as, she whapped down on the floor; the fish whapped over.
A guttural pronunciation of the letter r ; a burr. See Burr , n. , 6.
A kind of fine sand from the banks of the Trent, used as a polishing powder.
Something; thing; stuff.
Same as Whall .
See Whaap .
A pustule; a whelk.
A cereal grass ( Triticum vulgare ) and its grain, which furnishes a white flour for bread, and, next to rice, is the grain most largely used by the human race.
A quantity; a goodly number.
See Waft , n. , 4.

Any one numerous species of large marine gastropods belonging to Buccinum and allied genera; especially, Buccinum undatum , common on the coasts both of Europe and North America, and much used as food in Europe.
To bring forth young; -- said of the female of the dog and some beasts of prey.
Place; situation.
A sound like a half-formed whistle, expressing astonishment, scorn, or dislike.
The serum, or watery part, of milk, separated from the more thick or coagulable part, esp. in the process of making cheese.
To emit whiffs, as of smoke; to puff.
Acidulated whey, sometimes mixed with buttermilk and sweet herbs, used as a cooling beverage.
Space of time, or continued duration, esp. when short; a time; as, one while we thought him innocent .
The European widgeon.

To utter a plaintive cry, as some animals; to moan with a childish noise; to complain, or to tell of sorrow, distress, or the like, in a plaintive, nasal tone; hence, to complain or to beg in a mean, unmanly way; to moan basely.
To move nimbly; to start or turn suddenly and do something; to whisk; as, he whipped around the corner .
To whirl round, or revolve, with a whizzing noise; to fly or more quickly with a buzzing or whizzing sound; to whiz.
A game at cards; whist.
A flock of snipe.
Be silent; be still; hush; silence.
The smallest part or particle imaginable; a bit; a jot; an iota; -- generally used in an adverbial phrase in a negative sentence.
To make white; to whiten; to whitewash; to bleach.
To make a humming or hissing sound, like an arrow or ball flying through the air; to fly or move swiftly with a sharp hissing or whistling sound.
Stop; stand; hold. See Ho , 2.
The entire thing; the entire assemblage of parts; totality; all of a thing, without defect or exception; a thing complete in itself.
The objective case of who . See Who .
The hoopoe.
Same as Whap .
A woman who practices unlawful sexual commerce with men, especially one who prostitutes her body for hire; a prostitute; a harlot.
The whortleberry, or bilberry. See Whortleberry (a) .
The possessive case of who or which . See Who , and Which .
A humming or whirring sound, like that of a body moving through the air with velocity; a whir.
See Whort .
A young heifer.

A religion derived from pre-Christian times, also called Witchcraft {4}, which practices a benevolent reverence for nature, and recognizes two deities, variously viewed as Mother & Father, Goddess & God, Female & Male, etc.; its practitioners are called Wiccans, Wiccas, or witches. Since there is no central authority to propagate dogma, the beliefs and practices of Wiccans vary significantly.
A variant of 1st wick .

A bundle of fibers, or a loosely twisted or braided cord, tape, or tube, usually made of soft spun cotton threads, which by capillary attraction draws up a steady supply of the oil in lamps, the melted tallow or wax in candles, or other material used for illumination, in small successive portions, to be burned.
A rope or halter made of flexible twigs, or withes, as of birch.

Having considerable distance or extent between the sides; spacious across; much extended in a direction at right angles to that of length; not narrow; broad; as, wide cloth; a wide table; a wide highway; a wide bed; a wide hall or entry.
To make wide or wider; to extend in breadth; to increase the width of; as, to widen a field; to widen a breach; to widen a stocking.
A woman who has lost her husband by death, and has not married again; one living bereaved of a husband.
The quality of being wide; extent from side to side; breadth; wideness; as, the width of cloth; the width of a door .
Same as Weir .
Wet; moist; marshy.
To censure or rebuke; to hold up to reprobation; to scold.

A kind of canvaslike cotton fabric, used to stiffen and protect the lower part of trousers and of the skirts of women's dresses, etc.; -- so called from Wigan , the name of a town in Lancashire, England.
A kind of raised seedcake.
Swift; nimble; agile; strong and active.
A temporary mark or boundary, as a bough of a tree set up in marking out or dividing anything, as tithes, swaths to be mowed in common ground, etc.; -- called also wicker .
An uninhabited and uncultivated tract or region; a forest or desert; a wilderness; a waste; as, the wilds of America; the wilds of Africa .
A trick or stratagem practiced for insnaring or deception; a sly, insidious; artifice; a beguilement; an allurement.
See Whelk .
To be willing; to be inclined or disposed; to be pleased; to wish; to desire.
To wish; to desire.
2d pers. sing. of Will .
Full of wiles, tricks, or stratagems; using craft or stratagem to accomplish a purpose; mischievously artful; subtle.
To gain the victory; to be successful; to triumph; to prevail.
The act of one who winces.
To wince; to shrink; to kick with impatience or uneasiness.
To turn completely or repeatedly; to become coiled about anything; to assume a convolved or spiral form; as, vines wind round a pole .
To furnish with wings; to enable to fly, or to move with celerity.
Having wings; rapid.
To cause (the eyes) to wink.
Having the taste or qualities of wine; vinous; as, grapes of a winy taste .
A small shaft sunk from one level to another, as for the purpose of ventilation.
The lapwing.
One who, or that which, wipes.
To bind with wire; to attach with wires; to apply wire to; as, to wire corks in bottling liquors .
Certainly; really; indeed.
Way of being or acting; manner; mode; fashion.
To desire; to long for; to hanker after; to have a mind or disposition toward.
To show; to teach; to inform; to guide; to direct.
To know; to learn.
Lit., wise men;
A cone of paper which is placed in a vessel of lard or other fat, and used as a taper.
To reproach; to blame; to censure; also, to impute as blame.
pl. pres. of Wit .
See Withe .
To bind or fasten with withes.
Made of withes; like a withe; flexible and tough; also, abounding in withes.
Tin ore freed from earthy matter by stamping.
To marry, as a man; to take a wife.
pl. of Wife .
To wither; to dry.
Mad. See Wood , a.
A deity corresponding to Odin, the supreme deity of the Scandinavians. Wednesday is named for him. See Odin .
Woeful; sorrowful.
See 2d Will .
imp. of Will . See Would .
See 2d Will .
To act the part of a woman in; -- with indefinite it .
The belly; the abdomen.
pl. of Woman .
imp. & p. p. of Win .
To dwell; to abide.
Using or doing customarily; accustomed; habituated; used.
To court; to make love.
Mad; insane; possessed; rabid; furious; frantic.
Abounding with wood or woods; as, woody land .
One who wooes; one who courts or solicits in love; a suitor.
Having a close texture; dense; as, a woofy cloud .
To wind, or wrap; especially, to wind a rope round, as a mast or yard made of two or more pieces, at the place where it has been fished or scarfed, in order to strengthen it.
Dwelling. See Wone .
A species of steel imported from the East Indies, valued for making edge tools; Indian steel. It has in combination a minute portion of alumina and silica.
To use words, as in discussion; to argue; to dispute.
imp. of Wear .
To labor or operate upon; to give exertion and effort to; to prepare for use, or to utilize, by labor.
To work slowly, gradually, and secretly.
p. p. of Wear .
To feel or express undue care and anxiety; to manifest disquietude or pain; to be fretful; to chafe; as, the child worries ; the horse worries .
Bad, ill, evil, or corrupt, in a greater degree; more bad or evil; less good; specifically, in poorer health; more sick; -- used both in a physical and moral sense.
Bad, evil, or pernicious, in the highest degree, whether in a physical or moral sense. See Worse .
An infusion of malt which is unfermented, or is in the act of fermentation; the sweet infusion of malt, which ferments and forms beer; hence, any similar liquid in a state of incipient fermentation.

To be; to become; to betide; -- now used only in the phrases, woe worth the day, woe worth the man, etc., in which the verb is in the imperative, and the nouns day , man , etc., are in the dative. Woe be to the day, woe be to the man, etc., are equivalent phrases.
2d pers. sing. pres. of Wit , to know.
1st & 3d pers. sing. pres. of Wit , to know. See the Note under Wit , v.
Commonly used as an auxiliary verb, either in the past tense or in the conditional or optative present. See 2d & 3d Will .
imp. & p. p. of Wind to twist, and Wind to sound by blowing.
p. pr. & rare vb. n. of Weave .
p. p. of Weave .
Disordered or unsettled in intellect; deranged.
imp. of Wax .
p. p. of Wax .
A thin, flying cloud; a rack.
To snatch up; transport; -- chiefly used in the p. p. wrapt .
See Wroth .
Angry; vexed; wrathful.
To cry, as a cat; to waul.
To reveal; to disclose.
To reck; to care.
See 2d & 3d Wreak .
See 2d Wreak .
The act of wresting; a wrench; a violent twist; hence, distortion; perversion.
To wriggle.
To writhe; to twist, as with anguish.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Write , for writeth .
To form characters, letters, or figures, as representative of sounds or ideas; to express words and sentences by written signs.
imp. of Wring . Wrung.
imp. of Write . Wrote.
To root with the snout. See 1st Root .
Full of wrath; angry; incensed; much exasperated; wrathful.
imp. & p. p. of Wring .
To twist; to writhe; to bend or wind.
See 2d Will .
imp. of Wit .
A helmeted Australian cockatoo ( Calyptorhynchus funereus ); -- called also funeral cockatoo .
One of the runes (&unr_;) adopted into the Anglo-Saxon, or Old English, alphabet. It had the value of modern English w , and was replaced from about a. d. 1280 at first by uu , later by w.
A narrow lane or alley.
A kind of timber truck, or carriage.
The wipe, or lapwing.
pl. pres. of Wit .
Same as Withe , n. , 4.
The chemical symbol for the chemical element xenon , having atomic number 54; it is one of the six noble gases.

A small three-masted vessel, with projecting bow and stern and convex decks, used in the Mediterranean for transporting merchandise, etc. It carries large square sails, or lateen sails, or both. Xebecs were formerly armed and used by corsairs.
An Arctic fork-tailed gull ( Xema Sabinii ).

A very heavy, inert gaseous element of the noble gas group, occurring in the atmosphere in the proportion of one volume is about 20 millions. It was discovered by Ramsay and Travers in 1898. It can be condensed to a liquid boiling at -107° C., and to a solid which melts at -111.9° C. Symbol Xe (formerly also X ); atomic number 54; atomic weight 131.3.
The radical characteristic of xenylic compounds.
Sherry. See Sherry .
A copying machine which copies graphic matter by the action of light on an electrically charged photoconductive insulating surface in which the latent image is developed with a resinous powder.
The Roman number symbolizing the value eleven. Used after a noun it may symbolize the ordinal number; as, Superbowl XI .
The capital of the ancient Chinese empire.
The Roman number symbolizing the value twelve; denoting a quantity consisting of 12 items or units. Used after a noun it may symbolize the ordinal number; as, Superbowl XII .
the Roman number symbolizing the value thirteen. Used after a noun it may symbolize the ordinal number; as, Superbowl XIII .
the Roman number symbolizing the value forty .
Christmas; -- an abbreviation for the Christian holiday celebrating the birth of Christ; a quarter day in England, Wales, and Ireland.

The first two letters of the Greek word CHRISTOS , Christ; -- an abbreviation used with the letters separate or, oftener, in a monogram, often inclosed in a circle, as a symbol or emblem of Christ. It use as an emblem was introduced by Constantine the Great, whence it is known as the Constantinian symbol , or monogram . See Labarum .

Originally, any of the rays produced when cathode rays strike upon surface of a solid (as a copper target or the wall of the vacuum tube); now defined as electromagnetic radiation with a wavelength of 0.1 to 10 nanometers. X-rays are noted for their penetration of many opaque substances, as wood and flesh, their action on photographic plates, and their fluorescent effects. They were called X rays by their discoverer, W. K. Röntgen , but were also referred to for some time as Roentgen rays . The term X-ray has become the most common designation. They also ionize gases, but cannot be reflected, or polarized, or deflected by a magnetic field. They are used in examining objects opaque to visible light, as for imaging bones or other structures inside the human body, and for detecting flaws in metal objects, such as in welds.
An abbreviation for crosstalk , the presence of an unwanted signal via an accidental coupling.
The Roman number symbolizing the value fifteen.
The Roman number symbolizing the value sixteen.
The Roman number symbolizing the value seventeen.
The Roman number symbolizing the value eighteen.
The Roman number representing twenty ; denoting a quantity consisting of 20 items or units.
The Roman number representing twenty-one .
The Roman number representing twenty-two .
The Roman number representing twenty-three .
The Roman number representing twenty-four .
The Roman number representing twenty-nine .
The Roman number representing twenty-five .
The Roman number representing twenty-six .
The Roman number representing twenty-seven .
The Roman number representing thirty ; -- in the postposition, designating the thirtieth in a series.
A gummy substance of the pentosan class, present in woody tissue, and yielding xylose on hydrolysis; wood gum.
That portion of a fibrovascular bundle which has developed, or will develop, into wood cells; -- distinguished from phloem .
Pertaining to, derived from, or related to, xylene; specifically, designating any one of several metameric acids produced by the partial oxidation of mesitylene and pseudo-cumene.
Same as Xylene .
Any one of three metameric radicals which are characteristic respectively of the three xylenes.
A genus of endogenous herbs with grassy leaves and small yellow flowers in short, scaly-bracted spikes; yellow-eyed grass. There are about seventeen species in the Atlantic United States.
A long and open portico, for athletic exercises, as wrestling, running, etc., for use in winter or in stormy weather.
A West Indian name for two large timber trees ( Podocarpus coriaceus , and Podocarpus Purdicanus ) of the Yew family. The wood, which is much used, is pale brownish with darker streaks.

A light and elegantly furnished vessel, used either for private parties of pleasure, or as a vessel of state to convey distinguished persons from one place to another; a seagoing vessel used only for pleasure trips, racing, etc.
Gave. See Give .
In the German army, one belonging to a body of light infantry armed with rifles, resembling the chasseur of the French army.
One of a race of filthy brutes resembling men but subject to the Houyhnhnms in Swift's “Gulliver's Travels.” See in the Dictionary of Noted Names in Fiction.

A bovine mammal ( Poephagus grunnies ) native of the high plains of Central Asia. Its neck, the outer side of its legs, and its flanks, are covered with long, flowing, fine hair. Its tail is long and bushy, often white, and is valued as an ornament and for other purposes in India and China. There are several domesticated varieties, some of which lack the mane and the long hair on the flanks. Called also chauri gua , grunting cow , grunting ox , sarlac , sarlik , and sarluc .

A large Asiatic antelope ( Budorcas taxicolor ) native of the higher parts of the Himalayas and other lofty mountains. Its head and neck resemble those of the ox, and its tail is like that of the goat. Called also budorcas .
The Turkish language of the Yakuts, a Mongolian people of northeastern Siberia, which is lingua franca over much of eastern Siberia.
The oil of the mahwa tree.
A river in eastern Asia, which rises in North Korea and flows southwest to Korea Bay (forming part of the border between North Korea and China).

A large, esculent, farinaceous tuber of various climbing plants of the genus Dioscorea ; also, the plants themselves. Mostly natives of warm climates. The plants have netted-veined, petioled leaves, and pods with three broad wings. The commonest species is Dioscorea sativa , but several others are cultivated.

The king of the infernal regions, corresponding to the Greek Pluto, and also the judge of departed souls. In later times he is more exclusively considered the dire judge of all, and the tormentor of the wicked. He is represented as of a green color, with red garments, having a crown on his head, his eyes inflamed, and sitting on a buffalo, with a club and noose in his hands.
In China, the official headquarters or residence of a mandarin, including court rooms, offices, gardens, prisons, etc.; the place where the business of any public department is transcated.
An umbelliferous plant ( Carum Gairdneri ); also, its small fleshy roots, which are eaten by the Indians from Idaho to California.
The cry of the wild goose; a honk.
A jerk or twitch.
To bark; to yelp.
Same as Yaupon .
A rod; a stick; a staff.
Ready; dexterous; eager; lively; quick to move.
Same as Saki .
To growl or snarl as a dog.
A gate. See 1st Gate .
To cry out like a child; to yelp.
To rise in blisters, breaking in white froth, as cane juice in the clarifiers in sugar works.
A jade; an old horse or mare.
A small ship's boat, usually rowed by four or six oars.
An involuntary act, excited by drowsiness, etc., consisting of a deep and long inspiration following several successive attempts at inspiration, the mouth, fauces, etc., being wide open.

A disease, occurring in the Antilles and in Africa, characterized by yellowish or reddish tumors, of a contagious character, which, in shape and appearance, often resemble currants, strawberries, or raspberries. There are several varieties of this disease, variously known as framboesia , pian , verrugas , and crab-yaws .
an old method of printing the article the (AS. þe ), the “y” being used in place of the Anglo-Saxon thorn (þ). It is sometimes incorrectly pronounced yē . See The , and Thorn , n. , 4.
An affirmative vote; one who votes in the affirmative; as, a vote by yeas and nays .
Properly, a variant of the defective imperfect yode , but sometimes mistaken for a present. See the Note under Yede .
To bring forth young, as a goat or a sheep; to ean.
The California poison oak ( Rhus diversiloba ). See under Poison , a.
To pain; to grieve; to vex.
Went. See Yode .
Same as Yolk .
To cry out, or shriek, with a hideous noise; to cry or scream as with agony or horror.
A sharp, quick cry; a bark.

The unit of value and account in Japan. The yen is equal to 100 sen . From Japan's adoption of the gold standard, in 1897, to about 1913 the value of the yen was about 50 cents. In 1997 and 1998 the value of the yen varied from 80 per U. S. dollar to 120 per dollar.
To throw; to cast.
Ere; before.
An herb; a plant.
See 1st & 2d Yard .
To throw out the heels; to kick; to jerk.
See 3d Yearn .
Eagerly; briskly; quickly.
Ay; yea; -- a word which expresses affirmation or consent; -- opposed to no .
See Yeast .
See Yeasty .
Any one of several species of large marine gastropods belonging to the genus Yetus , or Cymba ; a boat shell.
Of or pertaining to yew trees; made of the wood of a yew tree; as, a yew whipstock .
Made of yew; as, yewen bows .
To hiccough.
Same as Izedi .
Together. See Ifere .
A Jew; -- now (1998) usually considered offensive or contemptuous.
To give up the contest; to submit; to surrender; to succumb.
A Chinese weight of 2 2/3 pounds.
The European yellow-hammer.
Went; walked; proceeded.
To sing in a manner common among the Swiss and Tyrolese mountaineers, by suddenly changing from the head voice, or falsetto, to the chest voice, and the contrary; to warble.

A species of asceticism among the Hindoos, which consists in a complete abstraction from all worldly objects, by which the votary expects to obtain union with the universal spirit, and to acquire superhuman faculties.
An obsolete letter (&yogh_;) of the Old English alphabet, having a pronunciation similar to the modern “y”.
A follower of the yoga philosophy; an ascetic.
The European yellow-hammer.
A measure of distance, varying from four to ten miles, but usually about five.
To be joined or associated; to be intimately connected; to consort closely; to mate.
A country bumpkin.
Day; -- a Hebrew word used in the names of various Jewish feast days; as, Yom Kippur , the Day of Atonement; Yom Teruah (lit., day of shouting), the Feast of Trumpets .
At a distance, but within view; yonder.
Furious; mad; angry; fierce.
The symbol under which Sakti, or the personification of the female power in nature, is worshiped. Cf. Lingam .
In time long past; in old time; long since.
To unite closely.
To pour water on; to soak in, or mix with, water.
The pronoun of the second person, in the nominative, dative, and objective case, indicating the person or persons addressed. See the Note under Ye .
To yell; to yowl.
The offspring of animals, either a single animal or offspring collectively.
The form of the possessive case of the personal pronoun you .
See the Note under Your .
The cheetah.
To utter a loud, long, and mournful cry, as a dog; to howl; to yell.
An old method of printing that (AS. þæt , ðæt ) the “y” taking the place of the old letter “thorn” (þ). Cf. Ye , the.
See Flicker , n. , 2.
To scratch.
Repugnant or distasteful.

The crowned gibbon ( Hylobates pileatus ), native of Siam, Southern China, and the Island of Hainan. It is entirely arboreal in its habits, and has very long arms. the males are dark brown or blackish, with a caplike mass of long dark hair, and usually with a white band around the face. The females are yellowish white, with a dark spot on the breast and another on the crown. Called also wooyen , and wooyen ape .
Russia leather.
Any one of the four ages, Krita , or Satya , Treta , Dwapara , and Kali , into which the Hindoos divide the duration or existence of the world.
Same as Yuck .
A species of Magnolia ( Magnolia conspicua ) with large white blossoms that open before the leaves. See the Note under Magnolia .
Christmas or Christmastide; the feast of the Nativity of our Savior.

Designating, or pertaining to, an important linguistic stock of North American Indians of the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico, nearly all agriculturists and adept potters and basket makers. Their usual dwelling is the brush wikiup, and in their native state they wear little clothing. The Yuma, Maricopa, Mohave, Walapi, and Yavapai are among the chief tribes, all of fine physique.
A tribe of Indians native of Arizona and the adjacent parts of Mexico and California. They are agricultural, and cultivate corn, wheat, barley, melons, etc.
Very pleasing or attractive; especially, pleasing to the taste; delicious; scrumptious.

An Indian of a linguistic stock of tribes of the Peruvian coast who had a developed agricultural civilization at the advent of the Spaniards, before which they had been conquered by the Incas. They constructed irrigation canals which are still in use, adorned their buildings with bas-reliefs and frescoes, and were skilled goldsmiths and silversmiths.
A genus of birds comprising the wrynecks.
Same as Yaupon .
See Yex , n.
Aware; wary.
Certainly; most likely; truly; probably.

An old solfeggio name for B flat; the seventh harmonic, as heard in the or aeolian string; -- so called by Tartini. It was long considered a false, but is the true note of the chord of the flat seventh.
See Zocco .
A Turkish chief who supports a mounted militia bearing the same name.
A horse of a dark color, neither gray nor white, and having no spots.
the battle in 202 BC in which Scipio decisively defeated Hannibal at the end of the second Punic War.
A large ornamental tropical American tree ( Albizia saman ) with bipinnate leaves and globose clusters of flowers with crimson stamens and sweet-pulp seed pods eaten by cattle.
The child of a mulatto and a negro; also, the child of an Indian and a negro; colloquially or humorously, a negro; a sambo.
A genus of cycadaceous plants, having the appearance of low palms, but with exogenous wood. See Coontie , and Illust. of Strobile .
See Zantewood .
Comical in a clownish or buffoonish manner; whimsically comical.
to shoot, destroy, or inactivate; my TV set was zapped by lightning .
See Army organization , above.
A metallic cuplike stand used for holding a finjan.
A species of macaque ( Macacus pileatus ) native of India and Ceylon. It has a crown of long erect hair, and tuft of radiating hairs on the back of the head. Called also capped macaque .
A tool for trimming and puncturing roofing slates.
A public shed, or portico, for travelers, worshipers, etc.
A genus of large grasses of which the Indian corn ( Zea Mays ) is the only species known. Its origin is not yet ascertained. See Maize .
To be zealous.
See Xebec .
Any member of three species of African wild horses remarkable for having the body white or yellowish white, and conspicuously marked with dark brown or brackish bands.

A bovine mammal ( Ros Indicus ) extensively domesticated in India, China, the East Indies, and East Africa. It usually has short horns, large pendulous ears, slender legs, a large dewlap, and a large, prominent hump over the shoulders; but these characters vary in different domestic breeds, which range in size from that of the common ox to that of a large mastiff.
A large noxious fly of Abyssinia, which like the tsetse fly, is destructive to cattle.
The letter Z ; -- called also zee , and formerly izzard .
A nitrogenous substance of the nature of gluten, obtained from the seeds of Indian corn ( Zea ) as a soft, yellowish, amorphous substance.

The blind mole rat ( Spalax typhlus ), native of Eastern Europe and Asia. Its eyes and ears are rudimentary, and its fur is soft and brownish, more or less tinged with gray. It constructs extensive burrows.

Properly, the translation and exposition in the Huzvâresh, or literary Pehlevi, language, of the Avesta, the Zoroastrian sacred writings; as commonly used, the language (an ancient Persian dialect) in which the Avesta is written.
See Zenick .
The fennec.
To cut into thin slips, as the peel of an orange, lemon, etc.; to squeeze, as peel, over the surface of anything.
Having a pleasantly stimulating flavor. Opposite of bland .
A Greek letter [ζ] corresponding to our z.
The chief deity of the Greeks, and ruler of the upper world (cf. Hades ). He was identified with Jupiter .

A carnivorous mammal ( Viverra zibetha ) closely allied to the civet, from which it differs in having the spots on the body less distinct, the throat whiter, and the black rings on the tail more numerous.
Curd produced from milk by adding acetic acid, after rennet has ceased to cause coagulation.
The second month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year, corresponding to our May.
A low, thorny, suffrutescent, crucifeous plant ( Zilla myagroides ) found in the deserts of Egypt. Its leaves are boiled in water, and eaten, by the Arabs.
A large, venomous, two-winged fly, native of Abyssinia. It is allied to the tsetse fly, and, like the latter, is destructive to cattle.

An abundant element of the magnesium-cadmium group, extracted principally from the minerals zinc blende, smithsonite, calamine, and franklinite, as an easily fusible bluish white metal, which is malleable, especially when heated. It is not easily oxidized in moist air, and hence is used for sheeting, coating galvanized iron, etc. It is used in making brass, britannia, and other alloys, and is also largely consumed in electric batteries. Symbol Zn. Atomic number 30. Atomic weight 65.38.

A publication similar to a magazine{4} but in electronic rather than printed form, maintained as data files on a computer and accessible via the world wide web ; sometimes called e-zine (“e” standing for electronic , as in e-mail.
See Zincky .
A hissing or sibilant sound such as that made by a flying bullet.
quick and energetic.
A tubular pasta in short pieces.
The suslik.
A kind of domestic cattle reared in Asia for its flesh and milk. It is supposed to be a hybrid between the zebu and the yak.
Same as Socle .
Same as Socle .
a trade name for simvastatin .
A Jewish cabalistic book attributed by tradition to Rabbi Simon ben Yochi, who lived about the end of the 1st century, a. d. Modern critics believe it to be a compilation of the 13th century.
Of or pertaining to animals, or animal life.
See Meride .
Reverence for animal life or belief in animal powers and influences, as among savages.
An Asiatic burrowing rodent ( Siphneus aspalax ) resembling the mole rat. It is native of the Altai Mountains.
A zone or band; a layer.
Of or pertaining to a zone; having the form of a zone or zones.
A belt or girdle which the Christians and Jews of the Levant were obliged to wear to distinguish them from Mohammedans.
A girdle; a cincture.
Wearing a zone, or girdle.
Pertaining to, or resembling, an animal.
An animal which is the sole product of a single egg; -- opposed to zooid .
A European fresh-water bream ( Abramis ballerus ).
Same as Zorilla .
The aurochs.
A stump of a tree.
Any member of the tribe of Zulus; a Zulu-Kaffir. See Zulus .

The most important tribe belonging to the Kaffir race. They inhabit a region on the southeast coast of Africa, but formerly occupied a much more extensive country. They are noted for their warlike disposition, courage, and military skill.
See Zymic , Zymological , etc.
Pertaining to, or produced by, fermentation; -- formerly, by confusion, used to designate lactic acid.
